This book is near the top on her list of favorite books.A page-turner, this riveting story combines Ancient Egypt, dead creatures coming alive, the exciting city of New York, a protagonist with a puzzling illness and a best friend who isn't portrayed like a lame sidekick. The story is told wonderfully, but if the reader doesn't like scary, mystical stuff, this might not be the right book; however, know that that reader would be missing out on a great book and a series!I smell a movie deal, if there isn't one already.

These are very much like the current production of the "original" Seventh Generation (SG) wipes, except slightly thicker. Not embossed with designs on the wipes, these are now my favorite wipes because of that extra thickness.As for these being fragrance-free, I don't see any addition of artificial fragrance, but there is a a slight scent to these, probably from the natural scents from the ingredients themselves. Therefore, while the company can claim that the product is fragrance-free, these wipes are not odorless.As for being compostable, I'm not sure if these will be accepted by your composter or municipal compost bin, but if they go in the trash, at least they will disintegrate faster.Because these are slightly thicker, they are more moist than SGs, but not so moist that the wipes are excessively wet. They are slightly more expensive, but by much at all. If you wanted SGs to be more generous with the thickness or wetness, these wipes are the perfect upgrade.

I have an inexpensive "el cheapo" (i.e. $49 Brinkmann) smoker that I spent over $100 and more hours than I can count turning it into the most fantastic and predictable smoker ever - I'd put it up against the Weber any day. I wanted a good cover for it and after going through a number of cheap vinyl covers from Home Depot etc. that sag and don't fit well - or the "higher grade" ones that look great for a few months and then fall apart from the sun, etc., sprang for this one. It's super! A little taller than the smoker so I used a plastic bucket under the top of the smoker to raise it a few inches, but otherwise a great fit. AND, it has held up extremely well to the elements - I'm in central Florida. Well worth spending the few extra bucks for the Ravenna sunblock fabric.

The rubber part of the band looks good and is easy to trim to length, but it is easy to cut it too short if you're not careful. However, the problem is with the clasp and the way it fits the band. To start with, the band I got was not like the picture. The picture shows a "nubby" thicker texture near the ends where it fastens to the watch and a smoother thinner texture where it meets the clasp. Mine was nubby and thicker almost all the way to the clasp. I have small wrists so when I cut it to length I cut off any of the smoother part leaving only the nubby part. I could get it into the two ends of the clasp but the nubby part of the band was too thick to allow the clasp to close easily if at all. In fact I had to push very hard to close it and once I got it closed I couldn't open it with my fingers and had to use pliers to push the two protruding metal pieces together to release the mechanism. (I guess this might be good in that it shows the clasp holds really tightly!) So to fix this I first cut small slices off the textured top of the band to try to allow the clasp to close but I wasn't able to remove enough silicon material to allow the clasp to close easily. I ended up making a fixture for an arbor press to bow the top of the clasp up away from the band...and this worked, but it seems like a lot of trouble to go through. And one other issue. I have a number of mid to high end watches that have bands with this type of closure, and they all work fine. However, the hinge on this clasp has a pin that is too small allowing the two pieces to move side to side. So when closing the clasp, it will land in one of three places: 1) with the left ear overlapping the left metal piece and not latching, 2) the right ear overlapping the right metal piece and not latching, or 3) both ears inside the two metal pieces and the clasp latching. So you have 1 out of 3 chances of it latching when you close it. I'm going to try closing the hinge gap next...

I haven't finished this yet (which I guess says something...) but Tony Robbins recently discovered that a person should save for retirement so they don't end up broke at end of life and wrote this book about it.

We recently moved across the country. We and the dogs went by air and our cars, tools, and stuff came by truck. I knew that in the time between when we got there and our stuff would arrive, I'd be rebuilding the closets - taking down, repositioning, and adding shelves, etc. I also knew I'd be assembling some furniture. Since we flew we were weight restricted so I had to choose carefully what tools I brought. I decided that this would be my power screwdriver, nut driver, and drill for all the projects (before my "real" tools arrived). GREAT choice! I can't believe how this little guy performed - excellent battery life and quick charge time - and since it came with two batteries, I had virtually no down time. And it did some pretty heavy duty work. Very pleased despite my misgivings on the relatively high price - it was worth it!

We recently moved from Reno NV where 25% humidity was VERY humid to Florida where they never see humidity as low as 25% . I've been using this on my tools and fastener collection and so far it works as advertised.
We used two of these to take our two pooches across the country by air and they worked great. Build quality is excellent and they're quite functional.
This is really a simple item, but after going through a couple of smaller and less efficient ones, we got this one and couldn't be happier with it.

Works as advertised. I use it with my Bluetooth headset at the gym where they have TV, etc. as part of the treadmills. Paired with the headset the first time but i haven't had it long enough to comment on battery life.

I got this for use in rental cars when traveling  and it works pretty well. Some have said the ball joint is too loose and can't be tightened enough to hold the phone up and I found that to be somewhat true. However, I turned the head 180 degrees so the phone actually rests on the pad and that works for me. It also stays in place quite well and hasn't fallen off the dash or moved around when driving.
An essential item for when we make shabu-shabu!
We made our own minions from Twinkys and cupcakes for a birthday party. We outlined these with an AmericColor Gourmet Food Writer Set pen and they turned out GREAT!
Really great lens hood that collapses in stages so I can avoid dark corners on any zoom setting on my Sony RX 100 II.

Maybe I missed something, but I don't know what all the hype is about. Little or no story line and to believe that every piece of abandoned space junk still has breathable oxygen in it is a bit far fetched.

I got this to replace my Victorinox toiletry kit that was about 3 times this size. Everything fits fine since you can no longer carry liquids & gels in your toilet kit. So with my liquids & gels in my ridiculous quart baggie, all my other stuff (what's left of it) like a shaver, hair brush, etc. fits fine in here and saves a lot of space.

We just got this to replace our top of the line multi-bowl Cuisinart that has destroyed itself a few times to tune of $40-$60 per part replacement. Suffice it to say from a couple of weeks of use this runs circles around the Cuisinart!

This thing works flawlessly. Many other reviewers have written long reviews on all the positive aspects and how to use it, etc., so I won't go into all that except to say we love it and it works great - and we use extra large eggs...
This clipper is super. It does clip well, but is also very slim and can be carried easily without bulk and so far no problems with TSA.
We're seniors and thought this was really one of the best movies we've seen in a long time...but we did like Despicable Me 2 a little bit better...

We really liked this and we're seniors! The double entendres are great, e.g., Mr. GRU who is obviously a transplant from somewhere in or near Russia and whose last name is the same as the name for the Russian Military Intelligence agency (GRU).

I travel a lot and most hotels I stay in have the little Hamilton Beach one cup coffee maker in the room. We use "half-caf" at home - French roast coffee: half caffeinated and half decaffeinated and the coffee pods furnished by the hotel are no comparison...and are 100% caffeine. We keep our coffee beans in a Breville grinder and when traveling I set the grinder for one cup, grind the half-caf bean mixture into a funnel and use that to fill one of these - works perfectly and is exactly the right amount. I fill as many of these as I think I'll need for the trip, put them in a baggie and I'm set for a really good cup (or two) of FRESH coffee every morning!It is a little time consuming to use but I don't use enough pods in a short time to warrant buying 30 or 40 pre-filled since they'd go stale before I could use all of them. As to sealing time discussed by others, it takes about 5-10 seconds to seal and the sealer does get hot during use. I use a kitchen mitt or towel to hold it together during the sealing process.

I recently bought an Olympus Stylus 1 and then a Sony RX 100 II (due to the shortcomings of the Olympus but that's another story). Unfortunately neither camera has provisions for using filters and I use a polarizing filter relatively often and an ND filter not as often (but will be now considering Sony's 1.8 lens that I want to take advantage of).This is really an elegant solution for the Sony (but doesn't fit on the Olympus). I had serious concerns about fit and aesthetics initially but finally bit the bullet and ordered it. Wow, once the magnetic ring is glued on, you can hardly tell it's there without looking closely - looks great!Functionally, it also works great. The ring itself is only about 0.030" thick and about 3/16" wide but is magnetically strong and holds the threaded ring very securely. When mounted, the magnetic ring holds the threaded ring in place very firmly allowing the polarizing filter to turn on its own - just like in a "real" mount.Having said all that, the first one I got had damaged threads and wouldn't accept a filter, so I returned it and ordered another which works just fine.

This charger is about the size of the battery in girth and about 1" longer than the battery in length. The case slides open and the battery goes inside. Shut the case, plug the USB cable (that came with the camera) into the USB adapter (that also came with the camera) into the end of the charger and the battery starts charging with an indicator light showing it's charging. When the battery is charged, the light goes out. Super compact design and it works. Charged a partially discharged battery in about an hour.Other pluses: Since the charger works from a USB power source, you can charge the battery while traveling; either from a car charger or from an external USB "PowerPack" marketed by a number of companies - no need for a separate "car charger".So now a word about the gripes that the RX 100 cameras came with no external charger. So What? People say you can't use the camera while the battery is charging inside the camera. Well, my Olympus Stylus 1 came with an external charger and guess what? I can't use the camera when the battery is charging in the external charger! So what's the solution? A spare battery AND an external charger. The ACCTRDCX Travel DC Charger Kit fills the bill quite well in a very compact package...and it comes with a spare battery.

I got to try this out by accident since I ordered a Sony ACCTRDCX Travel DC Charger Kit ($53 on Amazon) and got the Travel Kit box but with a used one of these inside. This charger works fine and does charge the battery relatively quickly and also can be used as a USB power supply since when the switch is in the USB position it will output the requisite 5 volts to the USB connector which can be used to charge the battery in the camera (but then what's the point?). I didn't have alignment problems mentioned by some.However, what is also the point of having a charger for a super compact camera that's about half the size of the camera?I returned this charger and got the one I ordered which is really neat (Travel DC Charger Kit - do a search on Amazon for it) AND it comes with a spare battery. It's about the size of the battery in girth and about 1" longer than the battery in length. The case slides open and the battery goes inside. Shut the case, plug the USB cable (that came with the camera) into the USB adapter (that also came with the camera) into the end of the charger and the battery starts charging with an indicator light showing it's charging. When the battery is charged, the light goes out. Super compact design and it works.So now a word about the gripes that the camera came with no external charger. So What? People say you can't use the camera while the battery is charging inside the camera. Well, my Olympus Stylus 1 came with an external charger and guess what? I can't use the camera when the battery is charging in the external charger! So what's the solution? A spare battery AND an external charger. The ACCTRDCX Travel DC Charger Kit fills the bill quite well in a very compact package...and it comes with a spare battery.

I wanted a coffee maker I could take to hotels (when close enough to drive to) and make enough coffee for a morning cup or two and fill my two 16 oz insulated travel mugs for the day ahead when I'm teaching with no coffee nearby. Since I wanted a relatively small coffee maker I went back and forth between this one and the Bonavita (at 6 times the price - $150 with glass carafe!) because the Bonavita was apparently smaller according to the dimensions listed (but I didn't like the glass carafe due to the possibility of breakage).First, the dimensions listed for this Brew Station are 13.5" high x 11" deep x 7.5" wide. Well, those are the dimensions of the carton! The dimensions of the device itself are 12" high x 9" deep x 6" wide!! Perfect - looks like it's going to work just fine...and it's smaller than the Bonavita!Second, using it. This makes good coffee although the temperature of a cup of coffee just taken from the maker after brewing is about 165 degrees; after 45 minutes of so after brewing it's about 175 degrees in the "holding tank". Both temps aren't has high as I'd like but usable. The coffee itself is very good. I've had no problems with loose fit, leaking, etc. as others have stated. It should be noted however that if a 10-12 cup paper filter is used, the "swing arm" that dispenses the water onto the coffee grounds will catch on the paper filter and not move far enough to dispense water into the grounds. Then the "swing arm" will dispense the hot water (meant for the grounds) onto the top of the housing under the lid and the water will run down onto the counter top. So the Melita Junior 4-6 cup paper filters (or similar size) must be used to prevent this.For my purposes stated above, this works great.

I just ordered a 6 cup coffee maker and thought I'd need these to go with it. And, I figured "what a deal, they're an 'add-on' product, meaning (or implying) I couldn't get such a deal without buying a $35 item". Imagine my surprise in going into Target a day after ordering (from Amazon) and seeing the same item for 1/3 the price - and I didn't have to buy a $35 item to get that price! As to how they work, I'm assuming they will work fine but the price...?

I was really excited to get this mug - it could be used with its included cup or used as a direct drink mug. Unfortunately the coffee gets cool really fast. On a recent project, I measured the heat loss on various size stainless steel insulated containers (Thermos bottles, coffee cups, etc.). I started by filling each container to its capacity with 200 degree water. Below are the temperatures for containers in the 16-24 oz. range after a 3 hour & 10 hour period - numbers shown after the item are: temp. after 3 hrs and temp. after 10 hrs. The list includes this item as well as the others listed. I also included a pretty much standard (larger size) 32 oz. Thermos bottle and a "no-name" 16 oz. insulated container with sealing cap & cup/lid that I got free for subscribing to a magazine for comparison. Items are listed in order of the content temperature after 10 hours.32 oz Thermos 193,17824 oz Thermos Direct Drink 180, 15216 oz Thermos Backpack bottle 177, 14316 oz No-Name publication give-away bottle 178, 14221 oz Hydro Flask 177, 13916 oz Thermos Cup rotating seal 169, 13020 oz Kleen Kanteen 167, 12524 oz Oxo Good Grips LiquiSeal 150, 10416 oz Kleen Kanteen 151, 10316 oz Starbucks Cup 144, 100Over time, heat loss occurs through the double stainless walls with a vacuum between them. However, most heat escapes due to poor design, location, and sealing of the lid and/or stopper. Specifically the lid or stopper should seal at or below the upper end of the double wall vacuum section of the stainless portion of the container and the lid/stopper should have some kind of insulation itself, if only an internal air space.For instance the stainless steel Starbucks cup itself has pretty good insulation qualities on its own and the lid seals just at the upper end of the double wall vacuum section. But the cap is a single piece of plastic that just bleeds heat off the surface of the liquid inside. The Oxo is even worse in that it has the same lid configuration the Starbucks cup has but in addition has a band of about an inch between where the lid seals and where the vacuum insulation starts - BIG heat loss here.A note on the measurements: some have commented that they would never have coffee at 200 degrees, a certain temperature is hot enough, etc. The point of the measurements is not to infer that we need 200 degree coffee, but to show relative heat loss over time from the various insulated bottles. The starting temperature could have just as easily been 190, 180, 165, etc.

Yes, you can take it apart to clean, but who wants to do that every day...On another note and on a recent project, I measured the heat loss on various size stainless steel insulated containers (Thermos bottles, coffee cups, etc.). I started by filling each container to its capacity with 200 degree water. Below are the temperatures for containers in the 16-24 oz. range after a 3 hour & 10 hour period - numbers shown after the item are: temp. after 3 hrs and temp. after 10 hrs. The list includes this item (listed as Thermos cup rotating seal) as well as the others listed. I also included a pretty much standard (larger size) 32 oz. Thermos bottle and a "no-name" 16 oz. insulated container with sealing cap & cup/lid that I got free for subscribing to a magazine for comparison. Items are listed in order of the content temperature after 10 hours.32 oz Thermos 193,17824 oz Thermos Direct Drink 180, 15216 oz Thermos Backpack bottle 177, 14316 oz No-Name publication give-away bottle 178, 14221 oz Hydro Flask 177, 13916 oz Thermos Cup rotating seal 169, 13020 oz Kleen Kanteen 167, 12524 oz Oxo Good Grips LiquiSeal 150, 10416 oz Kleen Kanteen 151, 10316 oz Starbucks Cup 144, 100Over time, heat loss occurs through the double stainless walls with a vacuum between them. However, most heat escapes due to poor design, location, and sealing of the lid and/or stopper. Specifically the lid or stopper should seal at or below the upper end of the double wall vacuum section of the stainless portion of the container and the lid/stopper should have some kind of insulation itself, if only an internal air space.For instance the stainless steel Starbucks cup itself has pretty good insulation qualities on its own and the lid seals just at the upper end of the double wall vacuum section. But the cap is a single piece of plastic that just bleeds heat off the surface of the liquid inside. The Oxo is even worse in that it has the same lid configuration the Starbucks cup has but in addition has a band of about an inch between where the lid seals and where the vacuum insulation starts - BIG heat loss here.A note on the measurements: some have commented that they would never have coffee at 200 degrees, a certain temperature is hot enough, etc. The point of the measurements is not to infer that we need 200 degree coffee, but to show relative heat loss over time from the various insulated bottles. The starting temperature could have just as easily been 190, 180, 165, etc.

But doesn't fit my cup holder in the car!!Having said that, on a recent project, I measured the heat loss on various size stainless steel insulated containers (Thermos bottles, coffee cups, etc.). I started by filling each container to its capacity with 200 degree water. Below are the temperatures for containers in the 16-24 oz. range after a 3 hour & 10 hour period - numbers shown after the item are: temp. after 3 hrs and temp. after 10 hrs. The list includes this item as well as the others listed. I also included a pretty much standard (larger size) 32 oz. Thermos bottle and a "no-name" 16 oz. insulated container with sealing cap & cup/lid that I got free for subscribing to a magazine for comparison. Items are listed in order of the content temperature after 10 hours.32 oz Thermos 193,17824 oz Thermos Direct Drink 180, 15216 oz Thermos Backpack bottle 177, 14316 oz No-Name publication give-away bottle 178, 14221 oz Hydro Flask 177, 13916 oz Thermos Cup rotating seal 169, 13020 oz Kleen Kanteen 167, 12524 oz Oxo Good Grips LiquiSeal 150, 10416 oz Kleen Kanteen 151, 10316 oz Starbucks Cup 144, 100Over time, heat loss occurs through the double stainless walls with a vacuum between them. However, most heat escapes due to poor design, location, and sealing of the lid and/or stopper. Specifically the lid or stopper should seal at or below the upper end of the double wall vacuum section of the stainless portion of the container and the lid/stopper should have some kind of insulation itself, if only an internal air space.For instance the stainless steel Starbucks cup itself has pretty good insulation qualities on its own and the lid seals just at the upper end of the double wall vacuum section. But the cap is a single piece of plastic that just bleeds heat off the surface of the liquid inside. The Oxo is even worse in that it has the same lid configuration the Starbucks cup has but in addition has a band of about an inch between where the lid seals and where the vacuum insulation starts - BIG heat loss here.A note on the measurements: some have commented that they would never have coffee at 200 degrees, a certain temperature is hot enough, etc. The point of the measurements is not to infer that we need 200 degree coffee, but to show relative heat loss over time from the various insulated bottles. The starting temperature could have just as easily been 190, 180, 165, etc.

Overall impression is of really solid quality & construction. The ball head is really great and the levels, contrary to what I've read elsewhere, are spot on compared to a "real level". One of the problems that may have led to negative reviews on the levels is the fluid used is much more viscous than that used in ordinary levels meaning it takes a long time for the bubble to seek its level, so a reading taken before the bubble stops moving (slowly) can lead to incorrect readings.I just got done doing a fairly extensive review and analysis on the stability of 10 tripods including this one. The aluminum Sirui T-005RX was also included.There were two rankings regarding stability: 1) stability of the tripod itself without considering the center column and 2) stability of the fully extended center column as if in gusting wind. The scale was 1-5, 5 being the highest. This Dolica tripod got a 4/4 and the T-005RX got a 4/2 score. As a point of reference a Manfrotto Neotec aluminum tripod got a 5/3 score and a really old Velbon AEF-3 with U-shaped aluminum legs got the highest score - 5/5.This is now my "go-to" traveling/field tripod when stability of the center column is important, otherwise I'd choose the lighter & smaller Sirui T-005RX.Hope this helps.

I don't own this tripod but just got done doing a fairly extensive review and analysis of 10 tripods. This was not one of them but the T-005RX was. According to the specs, this is essentially the same tripod as the aluminum T-005RX: same leg diameters (small), same height, same folded height, etc., the only difference being the weight. So what it amounts to is you're paying $100 more for this over the aluminum T-005RX to get it in CF with a resultant weight decrease of around a half pound or less. They both have the same C-10X ball head.As added info, two of the rankings I gave were 1) stability of the tripod itself without considering the center column and 2) stability of the fully extended center column as if in gusting wind. The scale was 1-5, 5 being the highest. The T-005RX got a 4/2 score. As a comparison, the Dolica ProLine CF tripod (thicker legs & approx. 1 lb heavier) got a 4/4. As a point of reference my Manfrotto Neotec aluminum tripod got a 5/3 score and a really old Velbon AEF-3 with U-shaped aluminum legs got the highest score - 5/5.Hope this helps.

I got this camera a few days ago so this is a REALLY preliminary look at it with some initial observations which I'll add to as I use it more.First the odd:I use panorama mode fairly often and I was surprised to see the panorama mode in the Stylus 1 is the same as in my old Olympus SP 565 UZ (circa 2008) - antiquated. Many cameras now allow you to select panorama mode, slowly pan the camera and the camera handles all the heavy lifting - it decides when the end of the first scene occurs and the second begins, and stitches them accordingly. The Stylus 1 requires the user to take picture 1, remember where the end point is, pan the camera so there is overlap at this end point, and then take picture 2. Etc. AND it then requires the individual pictures be stitched together off-camera with either the Olympus software or something like Photoshop. Very cumbersome & very old style.With all the interest in HDR, this camera does nothing to address that. I realize Canon has a patent on processing HDR shots in-camera at the pixel level, so I wouldn't immediately expect Olympus to have the equivalent feature. However, for those of us willing to do post processing of images to achieve HDR results, the camera does little if nothing to support this. For good HDR photos, you need at least 3 shots at -2 EV, 0 EV and +2 EV. The Stylus 1 has +/- 3 EV stops which can be manually set but you can only take a max of 3 BRKT shots with +/- 1 EV for each shot. Even my old SP 565 UZ can take 5 BRKT shots albeit at +/- 1 EV. But then you get the 3 shots at +/- 2EV if you discard shots 2 & 4.NO way to use filters! Even the "magnetic" two piece filter device won't fit. Sometimes you just need a polarizing filter to eliminate glare, so I guess I'm forced to hand-hold a filter in front of the lens when I need one - cumbersome at best...Now for the good:I took a few casual shots around the house and was blown away with the accuracy of the auto white balance - much better than a lot of my older cameras. And although I haven't done controlled testing, I took some hand held close-up shots at almost full zoom that were really crisp and clear - no noticeable camera shake. My other older cameras can't match this.The constant f2.8 lens is fantastic - big difference from my other cameras, some of which start at f2.8 but go to 4.5 at full zoom. This is a great light gathering tool.Having said what I did above about panorama, the Stylus 1 has an electronic level that can be enabled in the display that gives a visual indication of whether the camera is level or not in two axis. Nice feature and nicely implemented that eliminates the need for carrying a hot-shoe level or the need for levels on the tripod head although you'll still need one on the tripod base to make sure the panning section is level for panorama shooting.Some have said the camera has a cheap plastic feel. I have not found that to be the case and in fact think it has a very solid feel, particularly for a camera this size.Size - for what this camera does, it's really compact and one of the main reasons I bought it. As the saying goes, the best camera is the one you have with you. I won't mind carrying this around but wouldn't think of the RX-10 (often mentioned as a comparable in reviews) as being my "go-to" or "take with me everywhere" camera as nice as it might be. And at half the price, half the size, and much lighter, the Stylus 1 wins hands down as my "go everywhere" camera.So far very pleased.And finally, I can't wait to try out the other features like Wi-Fi, etc.

I read in the reviews that this Ravelli (with mini-tripod) was comparable to the "highly regarded and acclaimed" Opteka tripod.So I ordered this and also ordered a Dolica Premium Traveler 60" Carbon Fiber Tripod from Costco thinking I could use each for a different purpose. I returned the Ravelli because the case and tripod were covered with mold!Having said that, here are the other major differences:The Dolica is over twice the price ($199 plus tax from Costco)Center column on the Ravelli is metal - it's CF on the DolicaOverall height of the Ravelli is a few inches taller than the Dolica, but the folded length of the Ravelli is over 18"; the Dolica is 16.5"Dolica is about a half pound lighter.Dolica has 3 leg spread angles; Ravelli has 2.Both have legs that fold 180 degrees to allow for compact storage/travel.Locking mechanism for the leg spread is very straight-forward on the Dolica: press the actual metal part and move the leg. On the Ravelli you must press a plastic button which then activates an unseen mechanism which allows the legs to be adjusted.Head on the Dolica is, well, sweet - with three levels. There are no levels on the Ravelli. The Ravelli head is "gritty" when panning; the Dolica is nice & smooth.One leg on the Dolica unscrews so it can be used in conjunction with the center post as a mono pod. No such feature on the Ravelli.The Dolica comes with rubber feet AND with spikes that can replace the rubber feet by unscrewing the rubber feet and then screwing in the spikes - a tedious at best practice. And, with only spikes on the ends of the legs, the spikes can sink in as far as China (welcome home). Both of these guys need to solve the spike feet problem.The bag for the Dolica is much nicer.As other reviewers stated, Ravelli should not include the funny miniature tripod and use that cost savings to improve their basic tripod.

Does what it says at about half the price of the (overpriced) Sony charger. Even though I get about 7-8 hours use from the Sony when fully charged, I often travel and use this during trips to recharge the Sony. I also want the brighter screen which appears on AC power (I know I can just brighten the screen under settings but it's much more convenient to do it this way and doesn't drain the battery). I use the original Sony power supply at my home office and keep this one with me for traveling.Another advantage over the Sony OEM charger, especially for traveling, is this one has a two prong polarized plug with a longer AC cord (as opposed to Sony's short three wire cord with 3-prong plug). This eliminates the need for carrying a three prong to two prong adapter and allows me to carry a two wire extension cord which is much lighter and less bulky than a three wire cord.One thing to note is that even though this has a right angle DC plug, it will NOT properly fit in the external sheet battery charging socket and therefore will NOT charge that battery as a stand-alone device. I didn't ding the rating for this because I never use it that way.And finally I ordered this on December 4th and got it on the 6th!! Great service from the seller.
Great products-light weight, small, but does the job...and with two outlets per unit. I like how one supplies more current if you need it.

I bought this for measuring the current drawn when charging my various USB charged devices since USB chargers now come labeled "Samsung", "iPad", "USB", etc. and it seems the charger manufacturers interpret the implementation of these differently. For instance one charger I bought that had two ports labeled USB & iPad. I bought it for charging a Motorola RAZR and for charging an iPad but it would charge the iPad in the iPad port but wouldn't charge the Motorola via the USB port - go figure. Anyway this allows me to measure the current to ensure I'm getting maximum charge for my devices and it does that almost okay. It appears to be time-sensitive as to its measurements. For instance when I plug my phone charger in with phone attached it reads .06A. When I unplug the phone charger and plug in my computer charger it also reads .06A. When I unplug the computer charger AND the P3, then plug in the P3 and then plug the computer charger into it the reading is .23A - more like what it should be. I haven't found a good low current plug-able ammeter other than the more rudimentary Belkin, so I can live with this for the occasional times I use it.I didn't buy it for the other features - timer, auto-off, energy savings, etc. so can't comment on them.As to it being a two piece unit, I thought this would be convenient but for what I'm using it for I use it on a power strip so I could have saved $10 and gotten the one piece unit.

The looks of this watch are easily as nice as shown on the web site or nicer - very sharp in my opinion. It is a larger size watch and I have small wrists but it looks good - not oversized.Furthermore, this model has the Multiband 6 feature - radio controlled (RC) time keeping in Asia, Europe, and the US - beware of other Casio watches (in the $300 price range) that look almost identical but DON'T have this feature. An easy way to tell is with RC timekeeping under the date window "NO" and "YES" are printed (showing whether an RC signal was received or not); in the non RC version "ON & "OFF" are printed indicating whether the alarm is on or off.This is one of a new generation of watches from Casio which uses 5 motors for hand movement. This is significant in that the hands can move from one position to another independently, i.e. the hour hand doesn't have to wait for the minute hand to make many revolutions until it can move to the next hour position, etc. This has been elegantly utilized in this watch.In the stop watch mode, all hands go to the "zero" position very fast (because each hand has its own motor) and when the start button is pushed the second hand makes one revolution every second (for the first 30 seconds), the minute hand makes one revolution in a minute and the hour hand makes one revolution in 60 minutes. There are numerous lap time features and record keeping beyond what I'll use but I'm sure will be useful to many.In the countdown timer mode, the hands go to the "set time position" very fast and then begin counting down to zero backwards - looks really cool.After comparing this watch to other world time watches I have, I must conclude that this is a VERY elegant implementation of the various features (timer & stopwatch), but in particular the world time feature. Pushing the mode button (lower left) changes from regular time, to World Time, Stopwatch, Timer, and Alarm - in that order. When in the World Time mode, pulling out the crown allows you to select any of the pre-programmed world time cities and shows the time AND date in that city - not quite instantaneously, but very fast.I can't comment on the many alarms in the watch since I don't use watch alarms anymore because I'm an older guy and don't hear them very well.In summary, this is a very elegant implementation of the many watch features that have previously been implemented via digital technology & displays but now done totally analog.Bottom line is I really like this watch and in comparing it to one of Citizen's latest high-end offerings, I think it is far superior in operation.As for delivery & service - Incredibly great service! This watch was shipped from Japan & Amazon estimated a delivery date between mid to late November. I ordered it on Thursday October17th around noon (around 4:00 PM Friday in Japan). I got an email within hours (around 10:30 PM Japan time) giving all the order details, saying the watch had been "sent" via EMS Express, and that I could see tracking info by the next day - Friday my time in Nevada. The email also included instructions on how to get an English language manual from Casio. Sure enough the next day it showed the watch had been given to EMS on Friday at 8:44 PM Japan time. It arrived in Los Angeles on October 20th at 3:33 PM PST/US time...AND SPENT THE NEXT TWO DAYS IN US CUSTOMS!!!*@$. It finally cleared customs and left Southern California on October 22nd at 4:05 PM PST and was processed through the Reno NV USPS sort facility on October 23rd at 7:04 AM. I live about 45 miles outside of Reno so I received the watch the next day - October 24th around 1:30 PM. Excellent service by World Z King & EMS...if only we could teach our US Customs Service about, well, Service.

I like this watch. I bought it for its style (and, okay, also a little for its tachymeter function). Having said that, (and it's purely subjective), I don't think it looks as good in real life as the pictures on the web site. And I don't know why. The pictures are accurate, they depict the watch fairly, etc.Operationally, some things are worth noting:There are two sub dials:1) The lower right dial marked from 1-10 and measures elapsed minutes in the chrono mode up to 10 minutes2) The upper left dial which has two shared functions:-2a) In normal timekeeping mode it shows time in a second time zone via the outer ring which is calibrated from 1-24 to show hours in that time zone.-2b) In chrono mode it shows elapsed time up to 4 hours; its inner ring is calibrated from 1-4 with tick marks at 10 minute intervals between the 1-4 hour marks.3) there are two second hands:-3a) one that always moves continuously in one second increments and is linked to the main hour/minute hands display (has a T within a circle), and-3b) another which is the chronograph "second" hand. It is always pointed at 12 o'clock until activated by the chronograph function at which time it moves in 1/5 second increments.4) The chronograph uses three separate dials to show elapsed time (up to 4 hours at which point it automatically stops):-4a) the chrono second hand described in 3b above which shows elapsed time in 1/5 seconds up to one minute-4b) the lower right dial which shows elapsed time up to 10 minutes-4c) the upper left dial (which normally shows time in a second time zone) but in the chrono mode shows elapsed time up to 4 hours.In practice it works like this: When the upper right button is pushed to activate the chrono function, the chrono second hand starts moving in 1/5 second increments. At the end of the first minute, the lower right hand moves from zero to 1; at the end of the second minute, the lower right hand moves from 1 to 2. This continues until the lower right dial reaches 10 at which time the upper left dial (which reset to zero from its second time zone setting when the chrono function was activated) moves to its first tick mark - 10 minutes. This process continues until the elapsed time = 4 hours at which time the chrono function stops. To reset the chrono to zero (and restore the second time zone functionality), press the lower right button. This is all a bit convoluted, but, as I see it, this is a "style" watch so function can be "liberalized" to favor style.To use the fly-back function, start the chrono function as usual with the upper right button. When you want to time a second sequence, you would normally press the upper right button to stop the chrono function, then press the lower right button to reset the chrono, and then press the upper right button to again start the chrono function. But with the fly-back functionality, after pressing the upper right button to start the chrono, simply press the lower right button and upon releasing it, the chrono is stopped, reset to zero, and restarted - all with one press of the lower right (fly-back) button!As to overall operation. The watch seems to work fine. For the few days I've had it, it's within a few seconds of the atomic clock in Boulder. The second time zone (using the upper left dial) works great, the fly-back function works great, the chronograph works great, etc. And the chronograph accumulates time up to 4 hours using the three different dials.I haven't had the band problems with the black edging falling off as mentioned by another reviewer, but the band does scuff easily.Two nits I have:1) One is mentioned by another reviewer: the regular second hand (the one with the T in a circle) doesn't always land on the "second" tick marks - sometime it is a little short, sometime a little long, etc. The second hand does make 60 stops per revolution, so overall it's accurate, but it's just an annoyance that a company in the watch business (for many years) can't get the second hand to stop at exactly 1/60 of a revolution and match that up with the printed tick marks.2) The Indiglo feature, which I've seen to be fantastic on other Timex watches, is very pale in this one and is really hard to tell time with when dark.In summary, I like this watch and am keeping it, even though I made a pact with myself a year or so ago to only buy watches with solar charging and radio controlled time...

I got another version of this watch with the darker leather band, black case with rose gold bezel and white numbers on the tachymeter scale, with red highlights on the two pushers and in some areas of the face, and polished gold highlights on the face. It has most of the features I looked for: solar power, atomic timekeeping, stop watch, and day & date indicator but doesn't have atomic timekeeping in Asia (but I don't go there much anymore) and changing between the time zones in the US and London are a no-brainer - just simply move the dial!. It's a great jeans watch and fits with most of my casual wear. I love that watch for its rich feature set and good casual looks (see my review of AT4006-06X), but it doesn't go well with my more formal attire, so I got this one as well.I love it. It has all the features I wanted as listed above and this one looks really good with certain more subtle color combinations where the other one doesn't look quite as good. This one is more subdued in its styling: no red highlights, no polished gold highlights, it has black lettering on the bezel instead of white, and just a very elegant implementations of the same features.The price is over $100 more, I guess for the "genuine Alligator Band", which doesn't mean that much to me, but the looks of this model are worth the extra money (to me).Easily 5 stars.

PROS:Really nice design. Black case with gold rim and red highlights in a few places and gold highlights in the dial, white lettering for the tachymeter scale, and the brown leather band with black highlights let this watch work with almost any clothing or color scheme. Nice "sporting" look.Radio controlled accuracy (in only two time zones).Eco-Drive solar power - no batteries required!Chronograph - easier to access than previous models due to the "fingernail indent" in the crown.TachymeterCONS:Radio controlled in only two time zones; world time requires manually setting if not in the US or London time zones. On the other hand, in the past 15 years, most of my time has been spent in the US time zones...Chronograph function a little hard to access, BUT not as hard as some of the earlier Citizen watches which require pulling the crown out to position 1 and then adjusting. This is because the crown on this watch can be pulled out to position 1 using the fingernails - something that couldn't be done with earlier versions with smooth crowns.A little too sporty to be a "fine dress watch", but can work as that.SUMMARY: Super looking and super functioning watch - I love it!

INTRO/BACKGROUND:We recently upgraded from AT&T DSL internet service (advertised 5 MBPS MAX download speed and 0.250 MBPS upload speed) to cable service with advertised speeds of 30 MBPS download speed and 5 MBPS upload speed. The cable service came with only a wired router but we also needed wireless for one of our offices, so I bought the Securifi Almond - a single band (2.4 GHz) wireless router - to provide access to that office.SETUP:Setup was a breeze. The "manual" is the first two pages of a 4  x 4 ¼ multi-lingual booklet. The first page is how to set it up as a router, the second page is how to set it up as a range extender. Both were completely adequate in conjunction with the on-screen help.PERFORMANCE;Download speed measured from the wired router furnished by the cable company (not the Almond) hard-wired to a computer was 40-50 MBPS and upload speed was a bit in excess of 5 MBPS - both better than advertised.  Download speed measured from the Securifi Almond wireless router to a computer with a Wi-Fi connection in the same office as the router was around 40 MBPS and upload speed was a bit in excess of 4 MBPS. Pretty close to the wired connection speed.Our other "remote" office is 45 feet away from the Almond router on the same floor and the signal was a bit lower in amplitude coming from the Almond (judging from the "bars" of signal strength shown in the lower right corner of the Windows display) so I considered using another Almond device in the Range Extender mode. But on further testing and although I could still maintain a connection, I found that although the signal showed low but acceptable strength with the Almond, the speed had degraded significantly at the greater distance - approx. 2-4 MBPS download and 1.2 MBPS upload on average. So a range extender would only intensify this low data rate signal.I bought a NetGear 1450 dual band wireless router (at almost twice the price) and tried it. At the same distance of 45 feet, the signal was a bit stronger than the Almond, but the data rate for download was 10-20 MBPS and upload was 3-5 MBPS on average. All this in the same 2.4 GHz band that the Almond works on (and the only band it works on). BIG improvement! Then I connected my newer Sony Ultrabook to the 5 GHz band from the NetGear router and got 30-40 MBPS download and 4-5 MBPS upload speeds on average but consistently!! Huge improvement! And of course the Almond only operates on the 2.4 GHz band in N mode, so a comparison couldn't be made. And although the NetGear didn't have a touch screen (or any screen at all), it was also a no-brainer to setup.And the NetGear also has the AC band for future use, and although I have no devices that currently support that yet, it's a nice plus to have.OTHER:Since I now had the NetGear router in play, I thought I'd use the Almond as a repeater for the HP laptop which only had the 2.4 GHz N band, so I hooked it up that way in the "remote office". The Almond did provide a stronger signal, and contrary to other reviewers' comments, it did not degrade transfer speeds. But it did not improve them either. And now I'm running only the NetGear 1450 using both bands (2.4 GHz for the older HP and 5 GHz for the newer Sony) and the Almond is just sitting there doing nothing since it doesn't contribute to the system.SUMMARY:For an inexpensive wireless router with quick setup and used with devices very near the router, this is a great piece of gear. If you need to "push the envelope" re longer range performance, look elsewhere.ADDENDUM/UPDATE:A week or so after purchase, I got an email "from the founder" of Securifi thanking me for the purchase and offering help if needed - I sent back a copy of this review. A day or so later I got a phone call (on Labor Day) from Securifi Tech Support offering to help me get better performance (changing channels, etc.), but we both concluded that the Securifi router is a most basic device and probably wouldn't perform to the levels of the Netgear router I now use. Great customer service & follow-through.During the phone call, I was informed that Securifi is working on an Almond+ that has dual bands (2.4 & 5.0 MHz), the new AC protocol (in addition to G, N, etc.). Should be an interesting piece of gear when released.

I recently got a Sony Duo Ultrabook primarily for traveling and which I love, however I do a lot of spreadsheet work and am accustomed to using a "10 key" keypad on the right of the full size keyboard I use with my desktop computer. I find typing numbers in from the top row of a keyboard un-intuitive, slow, and  bit clumsy.So I started looking for an external keypad, but in the back of my mind I'm thinking that's not going to work very well since I use the mouse very close to the right side of the Ultrabook. Then I came across this mouse/keypad combo and ordered it on the spot. I just got it and have been using it for the past day and have the following comments in addition to those in other reviews:PROS:Small/slim size - excellent for packing in a briefcase, but not too small/slim for use.Paired flawlessly with the Ultrabook.The mouse pointers/wheel work in the "calc" mode, but the number buttons are disabled from inputting to the computer (unless "send" is pressed) so no false number presses when using as a mouse only.Key response is good - doesn't require a hard click; not as hard as some have said.A mouse, keypad, AND a calculator - all in one!Thousands separator in "calc" mode.Floating or fixed decimal in "calc" mode.Carrying case (to protect the finish/display).Left/Right buttons & Scroll wheel work great.CONS:The rectangular shape doesn't allow it to totally fit the hand like a more sculptured mouse - but it works.Not a big con, but no side buttons (but clicking the wheel puts it in "pan" mode for moving left to right or up and down).Originally I listed under "cons" that it would be nice if a forward slash key would have been included instead of the 00 key, but on further testing, I found that the divide key does enter a forward slash for entering dates as an example.To be fair, this is not quite as comfortable as a traditional full size mouse so I wouldn't want to use it all day in mouse mode if I had a choice, but for occasional use as a mouse and keypad combo, it's really great.From comments from some of the reviewers, it seems they are trying to use this as a keypad in the "calc" mode, but the keypad mode has to be selected before it can be used. Also some mentioned the keys are small, and they are. But it's a mouse - the keys can't be "normal size".So far, I love this thing.

I have small wrists so at 46mm case diameter and over a half inch thick this watch is HUGE on my wrist. However, I really like the looks of this watch - the colors of the face and the color of the band go very well together and offset the large size, so I'm happy with it.I like the date feature and tachymeter - interesting implementation of this feature with separate dials.The first one I got was defective in manufacture - the outer markings didn't line up with the tick marks, i.e., the "60" at the top of the dial was completely off to the right of the 12 o"clock tick mark (in fact if you look at the picture the "60" is a bit to the left of the 12 o'clock mark there as well, but not as bad as the one I got). I returned it and the replacement is where it should be.The only time the main sweep second hand hand hits the tick marks accurately is between the 45 second and 60 second marks; the rest of the time the second hand stops on either side of the marks. But I sort of expect that of what I consider "fashion watches".After a month, the time is within a few seconds of the atomic clock in Boulder.Bottom line is I like the looks and it serves well for its purpose so far.

I just got these a couple of hours ago, so this is a really preliminary report.I've been looking for the "ultimate" earphones for some time now. I wanted earphones, not headphones - I have two sets of Bose noise cancelling headphones: over ear and on ear that work great, but they are really bulky for travel.I've tried the Bose earphones and many others. So far, my favorite earphones, which has become my "gold standard" is, of all things, a pair of wired earphones that came with a really old iPod player (when they still had 30 GB hard drives). They outperformed the Bose earphones and all the others in terms of bass, treble, and tonal balance.Well, those Apple earphones finally met their match - and then some! These Phiatons are so far the best in terms of sound quality. And they have blue tooth AND noise cancelling - that as far as I can tell in a limited noisy environment, works great. PLUS a microphone for using as a hands-free device with my Razr phone. How much better can it get...? Oh, it does get better - if the battery dies, you can still use them as wired earphones with the included cord.As to fit, the large black ear tips work great for me.More to come as I get further into it.

I've been looking for a good looking (not clunky/backpacky) "minimalist" carrying case for a Sony Duo Ultrabook (8" x 12 1/5") I just got that could act as a protective sleeve inside of a regular briefcase and also be used on its own as a carrying case in a business setting.My other criteria:Must be able to fit the computer with the extended life sheet battery pack attachedRoom for a few accessories: USB drive, USB cable, stylus, spare AAAA battery for stylus, business cardsA carrying handle (preferably one that can be hidden)After looking at quite a few and buying a couple to try, I bought this one and I love it.This case does it all with a big plus - a shoulder strap! Okay, so why is that such a big deal? I do a lot of things that require two hands. For instance business lunches in buffets where you have to serve yourself. I don't want to leave my computer at the table while doing this, but I need two hands to serve myself. The small shoulder strap works great. And the rings where the shoulder strap connects are well hidden so they don't detract from the looks of the case when not using the strap. (The shoulder strap can be neatly carried at the bottom of the accessory pouch when not being used).Someone commented on the carrying handle being awkward. The handle is a nylon strap with elastic so that it retracts when not being used - neat feature that adds to the clean looks. It is located on the top back of the case, so when carrying it the case does carry at a slight angle, however I don't find that objectionable - it doesn't hit my leg, etc.CONS:Doesn't hold much more than the computer; you can carry some papers, but if you try to add a couple of file folders, the flap won't "latch" to the magnetic closure.Won't easily hold an AC power supply and still close (but with 8-10 hours of battery life, I don't carry a power supply).And finally, compare this case to the Sony case for the Duo that's priced quite a bit higher. On the Sony:No carrying handlesNo shoulder strapNo room for accessoriesCan't fit additional papers/foldersDoes expand to fit the extended life sheet battery packDoes carry the stylus (on the outside of the case)

I just got this a few days ago after much research and trying to decide between it and the Lenovo Yoga and couldn't be happier with the choice. I got the extra battery and can go for days between charges (although I'm not a serious gamer and only use it a few hours a day mostly for business) - unlike my HP with less than 1 1/2 hour battery life. I set it up to use my Microsoft presenter/mouse, but with the digitizer stylus and optical sensor, I haven't had to use the mouse yet...and may never have to. And I'm using the stylus much more than I thought.It's amazing how little things make a big difference. With this device, you just take it out of its case or whatever, turn it on and start using it. If you need the keyboard (and I use that less than I expected so far), just pop up the screen. With the Lenovo, you have to first open it, turn it all the way around if you want to use it as a tablet, turn it on, and then use it. Those extra steps are just a pain.Windows 8 does take some getting used to, but I haven't found anything I don't like about it once I figure out how to use the various features. And there is a lack of documentation on how to use the apps, e.g., Note Anywhere - looks like a great product, but learning it is trial & error.Another big plus is the connectivity. I do a lot of PowerPoint presentations, often using clients' projectors...which "all" have a VGA connector. With the Duo, I don't have to carry a VGA adapter dongle - just plug it in. Ditto with the full size HDMI port and SD slot.My HP laptop is now my "desktop computer" and one of the issues I've been wresting with is how to sync the two since they both run Windows & Microsoft Office. Files can be handled by putting them in the cloud, but email & calendars in Outlook were a problem. After much research (again), I decided to go with Office 365 on both computers (and on my Windows phone which I'll get whenever a good one comes out) - it's working flawlessly so far.Amazingly, this computer is rated at about 3 stars by professional reviewers and a solid 5 stars by users/owners - go figure.More to follow as I get more into it.

We use French Roast coffee and mix half regular and half decaf to make a haf-caf bean mix since we both like to drink coffee but can't take the full caffeine load. We also like to grind our own beans just before making coffee. When our Capresso Team (grind & brew) coffee pot with the swing-out grounds basked quit some months ago, we bought a Breville coffee bean grinder and borrowed a Braun coffee maker from a friend and have been using that combo until the Braun quit. We really need our coffee every day, so we made an emergency purchase of a Mr. Coffee for under $20 to use while we looked for our next "real" coffee pot. I've always wanted this Hamilton Beach, so I ordered it.Amazingly, it produced coffee that that had a strange chemical taste and was much more bitter than the cheap Mr. Coffee pot (which made really good coffee). I exchanged it and the second one is much better, but not better than the Mr. Coffee.However, I really love the single serve feature because we can make a full 12 cups in the morning in the carafe and before I head off I can use the single serving side to make coffee for me to take in my thermal travel cup without depleting the coffee in the carafe, leaving it for my spouse. This works really well with the Breville grinder because I can set it to grind 2 cups, put the small single serve basket under the spout of the Breville and it dispenses just the right amount of grounds right into the single serve basket. Cleanup of both sides is a breeze.I can't comment on the timed function since we don't use that, but the combo features are great.

1:06 MinsWe watch a lot of cooking shows like Top Chef, so we were excited to try sous vide cooking at home. To test it out, my husband made pork chops. We don't have a food vacuum sealer (yet), so we just used Ziploc bags. They work in a pinch, but vacuum sealed bags would work much better. The flavors would absorb better, plus one of the bags melted a little and leaked.He put butter, thyme, salt, and pepper in the bags with the pork. He let them cook for about 4 hours at 134 degrees, then seared them in a cast iron skillet with a little oil. He served them with a sauce of apples, apple cider vinegar, garlic, hard cider, and Dijon mustard.The pork was cooked evenly through, and not overcooked or tough. Pork chops can be difficult to cook just right without overcooking, so sous vide is a great technique to use with them.Overall, I'm very happy with this sous vide machine. I just have 2 cons: 1) It's kind of hard to clean if anything leaks. Using vacuum sealed bags would probably eliminate this issue, though, so I can't complain too much about this. 2) The instructions are lacking. They're pretty basic, and don't include any kind of recipes or suggestions.I received this product at a discounted price in exchange for an honest and unbiased review. I am not compensated for reviews, and I never guarantee a positive rating.

This case is so convenient.
