You have to preheat the pizza stone in the oven, then remove it and assemble the pizza on it if you don't have a pizza peel.I'm so glad I got this one. It's good quality, and made from very nice wood. It's solid wood throughout. It will last for a long time with proper care (don't use it as a cutting board or submerge it in water). We're now able to make awesome pizza from scratch or with pre-made dough. We just sprinkle the pizza peel with cornmeal before placing the dough on it, and it slides right onto the preheated pizza stone in the oven. I'd definitely recommend it.I received this product at a discounted price in exchange for an honest and unbiased review. I am not compensated for reviews, and I never guarantee a positive rating.

0:05 MinsI'm always afraid to open champagne & sparkling wine bottles. It's a bit of a struggle, and I fear the cork will go flying and break something it hurt someone. I thought I'd give this opener a try. I'm so glad I did. It makes opening the bottle so much easier. It grips the cork and I just need to give it a quick twist, and POP! Easy peasy. I seriously said "that was easy" when I first tried it.The opener is good quality, too. It's well-made and durable stainless steel. It feels solid and has some weight to it. It will last for sure. I'd definitely recommend it.I received this product for free in exchange for an honest and unbiased review. I am not compensated for reviews, and I never guarantee a positive rating.

This is a very nice colander. My husband even commented on how nice it was when it first arrived. It's good quality stainless steel, and it feels very sturdy and durable. It's not some cheap flimsy thing, but rather a quality kitchen tool that will last. It has a base to keep it raised, so I don't have to worry about my food touching the sink. This also helps drain the last of the liquid from the bottom. The small holes mean the ends of pasta won't poke through. It has handles so you can hold it without burning your hands when pouring boiling water through. It's very nice and I'd recommend it.I received this product for free in exchange for an honest and unbiased review. I am not compensated for reviews, and I never guarantee a positive rating.

This is an awesome running belt. It's comfortable and stays put without riding up. I like that the phone pocket is vertical, making it quick and easy to remove my phone from it. It also has a pocket on the side and 2 pockets in the back, plus a key hook inside one of the back pockets. I normally wear a size small/6, but I got a medium so I could wear it more on my hips. It fits perfectly. It's great for running, hiking, cycling, or even just everyday when wearing leggings or skirts that don't have pockets. I'd definitely recommend it.I received this product for free in exchange for an honest and unbiased review. I am not compensated for reviews, and I never guarantee a positive rating.

One of the best movies about mountain-climbing, the film is shot with dizzying technical gusto from a simple but diligent plot. By the end of the journey, the experience almost becomes a horror film as the heroes are defeated one by one by the savage elements. The film tries to blend in some noble and uplifting redemption at the story’s end, but the plot often paints brutal portraits of crushing hopelessness. The film itself is breathtaking in scope, beautifully capturing the expansive atmosphere of the Himalayans in all its magnificent danger, taking full advantage of modern film-making technology.The movie also provides an interesting counterpoint to Krakauer’s acclaimed and popular account of these events, as the film credits the lesser-known memoirs of all the other parties in constructing this narrative. Certainly, it’s interesting to see their perspectives on how everything happened that fateful day.

Inside Out is great, but something ultimately felt lacking. Blame the high bar for a Pixar film, but while Inside Out does many things well, it never really hits the highest highs of the company’s other masterpieces.By far the best element of the film is its overall design – a strange land inside the mind populated by outlandish characters, mechanisms and buildings which all brilliantly represent the dizzying dynamics of human thought and emotion. Yet something that kept troubling me was the odd physics involved. Sure, this is a brightly-colored kids cartoon, but still the movie kept purposing so much of its actions around defined spaces, rules and machines that did not behave consistently. Likewise, the inside characters are purposefully one-dimensional beings, which makes their antics a bit redundant when their shtick grows stale.While this film has adventure, suspense and comedy, nothing every really becomes so exciting, thrilling or hilarious. The only thing “Inside Out” does go all out on is sympathy, constantly bombarding the viewer with fuzzy melancholy. The scenes border on being manipulative, but are ultimately quite charming and heartfelt vignettes about childhood, family and growing up.

This slow, surreal film has some legitimate creepiness to it. There’s some beautiful but simple shots that work wonders with light and geometry. The plot could easily be condensed into half the time, yet its simple execution allows a graceful pace that never really wastes time or drags for much. The last act changes to a more gruesome affair with an excellent surprise. Nothing so distinctly powerful and touching, yet it does most things well enough. Certainly best-suited for a more patient horror aficionado.

A bad movie can be dumb and dull, but only the worst movies take special care to also insult and offend the viewer too. So this movie’s stale and simple plot also had to mix in some ludicrous decisions, miraculous happenstance, and some seriously misguided sermons on gender politics too. To frame this loud stupidity and cruelty as some allegorical commentary on women’s rights is a true disservice to feminists.Not Horror, but just plain horrible, the film is best classified as a thriller. I don’t know if one prolonged sex-scene and several wretched attempts at black humor would qualify it as either erotic or comedic. The meat of the runtime involves indulging the whimsy of a pair of insufferable girls, who either engage in wanton vandalism or spew moronic nonsense about self-righteous justice. This movie is like babysitting the world’s dumbest and most spoiled brats. The other half of the film involves some of the most emotive acting ever from poor Keanu, though perhaps his alternating fury and sorrow are genuine expressions from having been cast in such a stinker.The film’s logic is uproariously awful. Everything from people’s decisions, motives, outlooks, ideologies, reactions… nothing is real or human. This series of odd/bad choices are then married to a nonstop deluge of magical circumstances to manipulate the story. Keanu plays the anti-John Wick here, a brainless sad sack who somehow stumbles and trips through every opportunity given him.This film feels like it was produced over a weekend by a smarmy teenager. But what else could one expect from a movie starring the director’s wife? Considering how Shyamalan recently dug his career out of the grave with “The Visit,” Eli Roth is now easily the worst filmmaker in the game right now.

Disney is making some horrible movies these days. Outside of their Marvel subdivision, every big-budget blockbuster going back to maybe the first Pirates has been rather bad, or at least severely underwhelming. “Tomorrowland” might be amongst their worst, where its atrociousness sinks even its heretofore flawless director.This film just doesn’t know what to do, who it is, or where to go. Sure, there’s the retro-futuristic production design that’s spiffy to look at. But besides the CG in the background, the story is a total mess. Clooney is barely in this thing and should’ve stayed home, but the two girl leads aren’t much better though. Like its muddling marketing campaign, the film itself is too heavily invested in mystifying the viewer about what is actually happening with zero payoff. But instead of being a pleasant adventure and intriguing mystery, the story is an annoying jumble of confusion. By the time the great curtain is finally lifted, this wannabe fairy tale still can’t really figure things out without pulling strange ridiculousness out of thin air to answer its numerous self-inflicted plot holes.Little kids might not mind the stupidity and gush at the robots and flying cars, though those scenes are few and far between. Everyone else should skip this trip.

What a strange mess - a film made about childlike preciousness told with adult cussing and graphic violence. Like a monstrous “Short Circuit” by Tarantino, this film’s wannabe themes of humanity and social injustice want to be deep and inspiring, but ultimately are just stupid and underdeveloped.Now this critique is from someone who actually enjoys Die Antwoord’s songs and antics. But as the centerpiece for this movie, their silly shock ridiculousness does not translate into the proper backbone for a heart-warming tale of a robot learning to love. The entire enterprise is like a parody or bad joke, but its earnest sincerity is woefully misplaced and downright painful to watch.The effects are clean, if not misguided. For while the main robot may move around realistically, its design is not engaging and never asked to do so much. Likewise, the bad robot is a straight rip-off of the ED-209 in from the very similar "Robocop."Hollywood often gets rightfully ripped for its lack of originality, but I am stunned that anybody thought this deranged sci-fi gangsta fairy tale was a good idea. Not to mention this guy keeps making the same damn movie over and over again, with the same recycled notions of a sci-fi messiah revolting with class-warfare. This is two strikes in a row now after the less-dreadful "Elysium."

This game is a masterpiece, one of the best ever made. It’s certainly one of the most fun and thrilling games, with nonstop action/horror throughout its epic story. Its taken everything shooters have ever done and combined them together into one sprawling and beautiful experience. I can see how impatient gamers might abandon the slower introduction. But after the first hour or so, the game just won’t stop in its relentless effort to impress and dazzle the player with the deepest bag of tricks ever used in a single game.Building upon the old games, this latest entry just offers more of everything. There’s 7! different playable protagonists now in the magnum opus campaign, where each have tiny little touches like different weapons, HUD displays, or melee moves. Though they can largely play the same, each has their own weapons and personality to fills out their unique role in the humongous cast, which combine together to stop the latest mutant-zombie outbreak in a globe-trotting adventure. This game surpasses even an “Uncharted” in its amount of vivid scenery and settings – including but not limited to mine carts, graveyards, avalanches,  skyscrapers, motorcycles, jump jets, skyscrapers, tanks, rope bridges, Chinese river boats, East European Castles... and that’s not the half of it. The ingenious design of the multiple heroes permits the story to explore anything and everywhere, covering more ground than any other game I’ve played. I remember people swooning at “Half-Life 2” for the neat little mini-games that would surprisingly appear. So from puzzles to vehicles to weapons, RE6 easily trumps all challengers with the broadest scope of gameplay imaginable, along with its superior graphics and sound.And this game is tense! Others seemed to have knocked this entry for being more action-oriented, and there certainly is a lot of shooting with a high body-count. But the creature design is limitless, where many mutate mid-fight into something bigger and meaner. Again, this game pulls no stops in trying to offer the widest possible pantheon of villains with all sorts of shapes, styles, sizes and tactics. The game is constantly introducing new flavors throughout the journey, always surprising the player with strange new creatures to fight. Several of the best villains are unstoppable nightmares that hound the player into fleeing for their lives.The game offers more replay depth and features than most other games as well. The co-op is second to none with stories built around pairs of characters. Often fighting together, but sometimes apart, with each person different than the rest… This game is thankfully one of the last to still have local split screen, when all other shooters have gleefully abandoned this feature to harass users into playing online only. But the game also happily adds many fun features like horde/survival, the ability to play an enemy creature, infinite powerups, and an epic expanse of player challenges too.RE6 is the ultimate in gaming, something that tries to use everything that’s ever been before, while evolving it to a new level of greatness. No one does sci-fi/horror/action/adventure as well as this game. Or as much.

The ridiculously inept title of this film alone should indicate everything you need to know about this clunker, seeing as how the filmmakers do not understand the meaning of the word “Chapter,” nor the value of the number “3.”As this film was subtitled Chapter 3, one would logically expect it to be a continuation of Chapters 1 and 2. So once the movie gets rolling with no connection to the family in parts 1 and 2, I had to Google the film to discover what was happening and why I was watching this thing. So it turns out that this film is actually a prequel, which is not even explained in the film. And by the end, there is still zero connection to the heroes of the first two parts, though a few supporting characters from those films feature in this one. So this movie is sold on a lie, as it’s more akin to a reboot or spin-off, rather than having any major connection to a broader history.Besides that disingenuous labeling, the film is just not very good. There are some okay moments of tension and creepy shots, but overall the film is largely forgettable. The series has had diminishing returns, and the filmmakers’ deficiencies to concoct a decent premise for a third movie extends through their vanilla storyline, stiff characters and weak scares.This movie also has some of the worst and most obnoxious sound mixing I’ve ever heard. To score the cheapest kicks, the mundane volume in the movie is suddenly cranked up to atom-bomb levels of screeching noise to induce their jump scares. The trick is annoying the first few goes, but grows even more annoying when these audio explosions continue to sound false alarms.An overall frustrating experience, this film is barely worth your time. Though I would be remiss if I didn't say at least the film ends with a terrific scare.

Shyamalan was LONG overdue for a comeback film. After the solid “Signs,” it’s astounding he was still allowed to even make movies. Not only had every one of his films since been quite bad, they were offensively stupid and pandering. The law of averages indicates he’d eventually make a not-horrible film, and this certainly qualifies.The lower-budget certainly helps rein him in here, though there are still a number of issues in the film. The pair of young children can be odd and unsympathetic characters, often sounding too adult or cerebral. The smaller boy is especially grating with his hackneyed rapping, which makes him neither cool nor adorable. The logic of the circumstances doesn’t quite work either, as there are still some strange holes and forced decisions to explain things by film’s end.But the horror is good. Some have called this film a comedy, and they aren’t so far off in that there are some shockingly strange sights and moments in this film. But there are several great parts in this movie that successfully frighten. Some of these are clever jumps, others are goosebump-inducing weirdness. And this film features arguably the best jump scare of the decade. The director’s eye for camerawork, editing, sound, and timing are all top-notch in creating some strong and memorable scares in a definite cut above the other usual horror fare. The film is certainly miles above the director’s recent abominations.

This is cookie-cutter filmmaking, a movie remarkably dull and bland in its execution. There is nothing so outrageously bad or offensive, yet nothing exciting or memorable either. It is a prime example of when Hollywood goes to work to manufacture a very safe blockbuster over creating any sort of art.The viewer can feel every whim of the focus-test masses being serviced in one of the most predictable stories ever made. There is hardly a single beat or surprise in either character or plot throughout the film. Despite its promising intro that alludes to a sort of darkly comedic horror film, the rest is completely paint-by-numbers in the simple story of a man saving his family. Of course in these modern times, the hero must be tortured and grim, so an odd backstory is invented that actually toes the lines of darkness and taste in this otherwise family-friendly fare.While the special effects are solid, they are used sparingly and are unoriginal. The film is caught in a conundrum where it wants to gleefully destroy everything, yet must also refrain from showing any actual human casualties to be a sanitized and kid-friendly film. So the entire spectacle is neutered by its PG-13.The average viewer has seen this type of disaster film repeatedly by now, and this one hews to the lower end of the spectrum via its simplicity, blandness and uninspired destruction.

While this movie boasts a few amazing action scenes, the rest of the film is flat and stale. The previous entry in the franchise was astounding and evolved the genre, so this entry is very dull and uninspired by comparison, content to simply rehash old material instead of inventing something new. All the cliches are here: kooky gizmos, femme fatales, globetrotting locales, sleek cars, meddling politicians, triple-crosses, playboy lifestyle, the fate of the world. The story unfolds in a very pat and predictable manner, but also with a stiff clumsiness. Many moments are bluntly explained or conveniently forced in order to advance the thin plot.This franchise has always been on the more playful end in the spectrum of spy thrillers. But this entry often fumbles the tone, as many conversations and moments come off as cartoonishly corny, and not necessarily the cool fun for which it strives. The actual plot is both childishly stupid and unnecessarily convoluted. Unfortunately, the majority of the movie is characters drolly announcing exposition repeatedly at each other. The villains are a real missed opportunity too, as they are first described as the ultimate foil to the team, "the anti-IMF!" but are ultimately another bland and forgettable batch of creepy white-guys. Characters will vanish from the film for long spells only to be reinserted suddenly, yet another example of the film's generally poor pacing and plotting. A real kicker is the film having what might be the dullest climax to a big-budget action film in recent memory.But, man, are these action scenes good. While the rest of the film is content with the basics, these few sequences are where all the care and resources were spent for some truly great spectacles. There is a true devotion to thrilling the viewer from Cruise as he engages in a variety of top-notch stunts to rival the best of Buster Keaton or Jackie Chan. The motorcycle chase might be the best ever put on film. All this makes the limp encounter at the end more stunningly dull.The film is ultimately a letdown compared to its far superior predecessor, but it still has its share of great daredevil moments. Four-star action in a two-star story.

Even the worst Blumhouse horror movies are savvy enough to hit some level of tolerable watchability despite their low-budget limitations. But this film sets a new low. Featuring a few B-stars, (relatively) large budget and theatrical release, one would assume the end result would be their crowning masterpiece and not the exact opposite. This film is boring, predictable, stupid and not scary. Ultimately it’s just very lazy. It’s as if the filmmakers figured that with this abnormal level of money and talent, they would not need to focus on the heart, logic or story as much as usual.Things unfold in an odd pace. Characters have unusual actions and thoughts. The scares are minimal, bloodless, and happen off-screen. The film is so misguided, several of the rare jolts are unintentionally hilarious. The film is so strangely and poorly constructed that it’s like an inexperienced child’s last-second simulacrum of what a horror movie is supposed to be. It’s a shame that stars Olivia Wilde and Donald Glover are damned to another misfire like this, but maybe they’ll finally learn to read a script for once in their life first. Or have someone with a shred of taste read it for them.This is the front-runner for worst film of the year.

A book this wildly experimental is bound to be polarizing, dividing people into clear camps of love or hate. Personally, as the quality of the book runs the entire spectrum of delight and dismay, it is a 50/50 split on the good and bad, running a full bell curve between the awesome and the awful.No one can fault the book’s ambition with its ground-breaking presentation. Told in a series of nested narratives - a story within a story within a story - the book also relies on a relentless onslaught of typographic abnormalities and oddball formatting. Imagine a series of footnotes upon footnotes to understand the taxing mental gymnastics required to navigate the plot.When it works, the book perfectly blends its dense themes of sanity, family and security into the labyrinthine stories of three people being driven mad by the space-bending physics of a mysterious house. The novel’s strange structure, obsessive notations, and multi-directional text all serve to reinforce both the physical worlds and the heady ideas supporting them, becoming a thoroughly unique experience for readers who enjoy complex philosophy married to a challenging but engaging presentation.But when the book fails, it is an unparalleled disaster. Imagine having to endure a dull textbook that’s been filtered through the drunken ramblings of two different lunatics, each shouting over the other. While it is a story about madness, surviving its slapdash compositions is often arduous and unpleasant, i.e. reading upside-down words in a foreign language. With moments like a 9-page footnote cataloging a list of semi-famous buildings, or an epic index which documents the hundreds of pages the word “again” appears on, there is an oftentimes laughable effort to appear dense and academic, as much of the content becomes dull filler without substance.Its primary plot (and majority of the pages) involve one man describing a movie to the reader. The story proper of the family versus the house is solid, but simple. So while there is an admirable, single-minded pursuit of investigative thoroughness and veracity, the basic premise is somewhat faulty and intrinsically obtuse: The real story is for a viewer not a reader. And while there are deep, branching sections devoted to etymology and symbolism which are the obvious curios of a literary/artistic mind, the corresponding scientific investigations to the phenomenon are lacking, underdeveloped and unrealistic. The book strives to be a rigorous examination of facts and meaning, but the methods of study are not always so intelligent, which undercuts the overall effectiveness of the piece.One’s enjoyment might come down to their feelings on a three-page footnote of an untranslated German poem. This book is more performance-art than prose.

Like its title suggests, this film is more creepy than scary. With an unorthodox style and pace, the filmmakers subtly manipulate the viewer with an unnerving and off-kilter style. From its odd premise, screwy shots, erratic editing, and strange characters, the atmospheric film creates a solid tension and suspense throughout the proceedings.  There are only a few jump scares interspersed amongst this series of very strange moments and encounters. Not all sequences are effective, where several parts are even a little dull and redundant.  But most true horror aficionados will recognize this film as a clear step above the usual straight-to-video fare, and a refreshingly different flavor of terror than the norm.

“Ex Machina” starts with a fine idea for a movie, and slowly slides downhill from there before crashing and burning in a limp finale. While the idea of a man meeting the first AI robot is ripe with potential, the filmmakers are quickly lost in the massive universe of possibilities. The story is a messy soup of half-baked and underplayed themes and notions: individuality, friendship, loyalty, morality, love, sex, wealth, freedom – So many solid ideas are given fleeting or misdirected lip-service in an attempt to thread them all into a cohesive experience. The film often lets emptiness fill its space, where slow, dreamy silences allow the viewer ample time to invent their own meaning. In many ways, this film is spiritually identical to “Under the Skin,” another artsy sci-fi film content to let the abstract and bizarre fill a largely directionless and repetitive plot. While many would hail either film as a hallmark for brilliant and philosophical sci-fi, the more demanding and experienced viewers will not abide the undeveloped simplicity. The depth is minimal, the ideas are stale, and the emperor has no clothes.To its credit, the film still looks great on its sleek production design and minimalist visual effects. The acting is generally okay, though Oscar Isaac’s New York Tony Stark seems woefully out of place. The music is solid, though a rip-off (ode?) of "Blade Runner’s" meditative synth. Indeed, much could be learned from that archetype masterpiece, which beautifully blended spacey visuals and sound with visionary ideas. Now that classic was gutsy enough to ask questions about humanity and then answer them too, instead of aimlessly and lazily floating brain farts off into the ether.

This short story is classic horror, taking a bad situation and making things worse. The writing is colorful with good amounts of personality and style. The premise is clean and simple but different, expertly blending several traditional scares together like claustrophobia with fears of the dark, insects, job security and ghosts. Most importantly, the tension is skillfully ratcheted upwards throughout the entire trip until the big, nerve-wracking finale.

This author has an interesting style, which may be objectively admirable but is certainly not my cup of tea. Barker relies heavily on poetic gore to propel very familiar plots. While I can credit his stories for avoiding the traditional trappings and clichés of horror - often inventing novel premises for monsters and demons that avoid easy categorization – the stories themselves all fall into the tired formula of: blank hero - wonders what’s going on - monster! – ironic doom. The barrels of gore are not enjoyable either. Even when using semi-literary language, the author constantly relies on the grotesque and the gory for his thrills. Instead of being scared of the unknown in the shadows, the reader gets a bright spotlight shined on a revolting mess instead. It’s a cheap trick that grows tiresome. Also, for a book with only a few stories, two of them are comedic entries, which are unsuccessful in their execution by being neither funny or scary.I highly recommend Mike Miller’s innovative 3VIL series instead, which has short horror fiction that is both smart and intense, minus cheap shock and tired plots.

This film is funny. While the jokes are only slightly better than average, the quality of the acting elevates the comedy. Both leads are completely game to ham up their overacting in pursuit of the cheapest laughs, where no level is too low. The film’s not so deep, though the “class warfare” theme was an unexpected and welcome wrinkle. While a very predictable plot ushers along solid scenes of simple joy, the simple silliness will tickle those who enjoy raunchy comedies.

While this new Terminator shares many of the same ideas as the originals – time travel, robot uprising, changing the future, apocalypse, Schwarzenegger – there is one major component that this newest entry completely misses: simplicity. Despite the time-travel premise, the old movies are ridiculously simple and easy to follow. Good guy and bad guy come from future to save/kill a target. That’s it.But this new version completely blows that framework out the window, as the various heroes and villains spend all their time between clashes with long, complicated and stupid explanations of the overblown and nonsensical plot. Now everybody’s not only going back in time but forward too, and triple-crossing each other for no good reason while they’re at it. I’ve read an interview with the writers who openly confess to a variety of obfuscated answers to the story. While they claim to have solutions for some of the logical inconsistencies to be revealed in future installments of this new would-be trilogy, other moments are just vague and not well-constructed.Terminator never needed to be an epic saga of familial loyalties, nor a head-scratching puzzle filled with muddled contradictions and mysteries of time-travel continuity. Once the movie invites the viewer into its tangled web of ideas, then it becomes too easy to invalidate the logic and dismiss the silly story. A slight innovation is connecting the rise of the machines with the modern era of social connectivity. But outside of that, the story tries hard but is ultimately somewhat stupid and lazy. Only the truest fans of the franchise would enjoy even trying to decipher the absurd and cryptic plotting.Certainly the one thing the film does well enough is the action. While never rising above the superior bar of the first films, this movie still delivers amply on a variety of action scenes, while also showcasing a variety of horror-like sequences which recalls the films’ earliest roots. The Terminators are now elevated to levels of superhero power and speed, more akin to the incredible Hulk than the tank-like Robocop.As a fan of the old films, I can round up to 4-stars on its earnest nostalgia from low expectations. But newbies to the series will be less forgiving and find it a forgettable 3-star affair at best.

Like its predecessor, this newest film in the franchise also surpasses my mediocre expectations. Despite another uninspired plot which is wholly predictable, the movie succeeds on the merits of its visuals and performances. While the humans are all solid, the CGI apes are all beautiful to behold, and emote powerfully and gracefully in their various expressions and body language. The film opens with a novel look into the apes’ world, a wordless peak into nascent simian civilization which is far more enjoyable than the boilerplate fistfights and shootouts of the back half of the film.

These directors had previously taken a very simple concept - paranormal researchers investigate haunted asylum in "Grave Encounters" - and injected some innovative excitement into the proceedings to make a great film. This movie takes another basic premise - alien abduction/invasion in the woods - yet fails to do anything special or interesting with that setup.Given so much room to do something different or engaging, the film moves along under a series of very tired cliches, which just aren't executed very well: bland characters, slow beginning, boring exposition, weak mood, lack of tension, soft and ineffective scares, predictable plot, hidden monsters.The creators clearly were saving all their best stuff, and blew their entire load in the big finale. Granted, there are some good parts in the final minutes of the film, but unfortunately the hour+ leading up to that is as stale and boring as can be.

This game is really either a high 4-star or low 5-star, because it is so close to absolute greatness, yet has a few frustrating flaws.Being the premier rebooted iteration of the iconic heroine, it's understandable about how some of the gameplay and mechanics are a bit rough around the edges: Her movements occasionally float or don't obey the controller. Difficulty shifts awkwardly. The story moves unevenly in strange climaxes. The puzzles are all a bit on the easy side.But everything else is simply superb: Cool heroine, lush graphics, exciting and varied action, engaging leveling system, variety of villains and challenges, fun weaponry, suspenseful and mysterious mood. The game even mixes in some surprisingly gruesome kills, a small detail which adds to the fun.Certainly this game is something of an "Uncharted" knockoff, but then again "Uncharted" was actually a "Tomb Raider" ripoff, so now the circle is complete. The sequel to this game may well approach the polished perfection of "Uncharted," but this first "origin" adventure is plenty great already.

This isn't the first iteration of the dopey detective, but it might be the most forgettable. From "The Big Lebowski" to "The Long Goodbye," to I'm sure numerous other literary precedents that I can't instantly recall nor care to, the stoned-out gumshoe has long been a popular subculture of the long-storied hard-boiled detective book. But while those reads are typically lean and mean pulp pieces, this iteration has been funneled through a famously obtuse author to become a bloated 400-page mess of rambling tropes.As is typical of the weaker entries in this kind of genre, all the players have the same smart-alecky quips, cardboard characterizations, one-note roles except for the inevitable double-crosses, while the plot meanders through the tired ruminations intercut with tired conversations. "Think about mystery by myself, maybe go somewhere, then talk to someone about mystery. Repeat." You're lucky with the occasional punch to the face or gunshot.The cliches aren't in and of itself bad, but the execution is. The jokes fall flat, the action is tired, the characters are not engaging, the would-be languid imagery and prose is simply basic. Worst of all is that while these mysteries generally thrive on an interesting and engaging plot, this book is literally clueless. But maybe this is all by design as some heady post-modern deconstruction of the genre.

You know a writer's having problems when he writes a barely 200 page "novel," fills it with dozens of chapters less than a page long, yet gives each section a humongous empty header as well so that these paltry "chapters" stretch onto a second page. If this "book" didn't have a Pulitzer Prize winning author's name on it, it'd be roundly drubbed out of most freshman writing seminars.McCarthy goes to his old familiar wheelhouse of rural despair, minimalist prose, colloquial jargon, absent punctuation and macho ultraviolence to produce what is now a very tired entry in his oeuvre. While his slavering fanbase of pseudo-academics may eat up the newest serving of wannabe Faulkner, any sensible person will tire of the aimless emptiness of this book.Granted, there are tiny bursts of poetry occasionally juxtaposed with gruesome shock that salvage the otherwise lugubrious and meandering episodes of this book. But as is typical of intellectually weak art, the book is so sparse in both detail and depth that only those dying to see any meaning will find any.To readers who only engage in traditional "literary" fiction about anguished suburbanites, then indeed this book will feel like a refreshing blast of darkness as they're titillated by its debased incest, rape and murder. But if you're used to reading anything "dark," this work will surely fall towards the bottom of your list.

This heady sci-fi action flick is a lot of fun. While the science can be silly and simplistic, the film still strives for an ambitious answer to what the limits of human evolution hold for mankind. While this sort of subject matter could've been the dry subject of a stiff documentary, instead it is the premise for this insanely wild and kinetic action movie. It is a wonderful mashup of hi/lo ideas, like 2001 meets Spider-man.Any one familiar with director Luc Besson's work, (The Professional, Fifth Element) knows that his films are quite cool, stylish, fun and exciting, and "Lucy" is no exception.So besides thrilling action scenes and special effects, the film also has an abundance of playful humor with its outlandish ideas. The film's only fault is some occasionally stiff dialog and exposition to help propel the story forward. But indeed, this action film is even funnier than most modern comedies.Another applicable genre for this movie is "superhero." While "Lucy" does not specifically adopt a mask and codename to fight crime, it is still a story of a woman who gains super powers. However, the film smartly divests itself from any one specific skill, and instead allows her an infinite amount of power to bend matter, space and time in anyway she can conceive.A final pair of bonus points for the rare blockbuster that features an original story, and a woman hero. Either characteristic is hard enough to find these days, but to have both in one film is a refreshing joy. If you are a fan of smart but fun action filmmaking, it is your civic obligation to support this movie!

This brilliant, old-fashioned ghost story has the type of dread and tension that's hard to come by these days. Don't let the PG-13 fool you, this thing gets intense. Sure, there are some very classically slow moments of drama and character, typical of traditionally gothic horror and not for short-attention spans. But when things get going, it doesn't get much more frightening. There's one extended sequence in the film that ranks among the classics in terms of pure terror.Most of the best frights are of the "walking slowly towards a spooky thing" variety, but there are still some fantastic jump scares that benefit from having the volume scream from 0 to 100 in a blink. The production design is fantastic too, with lots of great effort put into the house, pictures, landscape toys and ghosts to make everything as creepy as possible.Throw in solid performances, a quality script, good sound and score, nice cinematography, and perhaps the film's only flaw is the sometimes brooding pace. Indeed, this film is a modern masterpiece in the horror genre.

This is the best-looking of all the Transformers films and also the dumbest. I thought the second one was bad where Shia Lebouef dies and visits robot heaven. But while that particular moment is still the most incredibly stupid in this entire franchise, this film strings along enough bad parts to make it the worst of the bunch in terms of character and narrative.The FX have improved. Except for one chase through Chicago where they recycled the backgrounds from the last one, everything looks and moves much better in this one than in the past. Bay must've finally listened to his critics as the various robots are now easier to see, with more emotive expressions and distinct coloring. Whereas previous entries looked like a bunch of clones that would battles as giant rolling balls of scrap metal, this one has action that is much easier and more appealing to follow.But the kinetic action visuals are really the only thing this film has going for it. The story is honestly about as clever as an eight-year-old's improv while smashing his toys together: There's a tyrannosaurus who breaths fire too, so he's like a dragon? The new flying dinosaur toy-- er, character isn't a pterodactyl, but it can have 2 heads because that's totally super cool. The bad guy transforms into guns and sports cars or like just his face can be a gun too.This film reeks of being patched together from perhaps 3 different scripts, as there's far too many subplots, settings, side characters and bad guys for it to handle in its already excessive 3-hour runtime. Major characters vanish without meaning, while others are jarringly introduced in the second half. How about if the robots can suddenly use near magical superpowers they never had before, like they can now fly even though they never flew for 4 movies? Let's use the same exact climax as the previous two films where giant ships slowly fly over major cities while destroying them.Of particularly poor taste is the hero's underage teenage daughter and her romance with an adult man. While her sexuality may be modest in comparison to other Bay's past leading ladies, it is still present and rather revolting.The fatal flaw of all these films is the lack of robots. Yet again, the story and screen are carried by boring people, relegating the Transformers to backups in their own movie. There's an especially bad part in the beginning where the camera focuses entirely on the people driving a car through a cheap abandoned warehouse (for the millionth time in the history of action movies) yet the hero and villain robot have a barely visible fistfight in the background. The two brawling robots barely dance into frame like a bad joke. The director focuses on whether the good guys can drive a car any faster from the bad guys' cars, rather than the conflict from the robots' expensive special effects.The fact that "Mahky-Mahk" Wahlberg gets to wear glasses while talking about science as a robotics inventor (yet can't shed his trademark Boston accent to play a Texan) speaks to the stupidity of this film. Actually, the part where he picks up a giant robot sword that also shoots lasers, that was definitely sillier and written by an imaginative small boy.So indeed a young child might forgive the stupidity and love the pyrotechnics here. But even the cutting-edge visuals can't salvage the godawful story. While I think Bay's "Pain and Gain" is a woefully underrated film, there's no doubt this movie is absolute junk.

This film is very similar to the original, so it'd be stunning for someone to say they like one and not the other. That said, this new movie is another classic.As the first one happily deconstructed cliches involved with buddy-cop, high-school and action-comedy movies, this new version similarly pokes fun at the ideas of college, partying, and sequels. Most sequels fail because the creators simply rehash the same tricks as the first one, particularly comedies. But this movie evolves the first's premise while also lampooning it. The almost cartoonish film (this is from the same directors as The Lego Movie and Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs) has a plethora of silly jokes, kooky montages, screwball cameos, foul-mouthed language, and zany pratfalls. The action scenes pop with good stunts and FX too. But again, the juiciest fun is simply the killer chemistry between the two leads, who are constantly bouncing jokes off one another in their goofy prattle. At its core, this franchise is about two morons trying to be cool. Be it high school or now college, they continue to fail, and their schtick simply does not get old.Another pleasant surprise is the lack of any big, traditional romantic interest to slog down the plot. Instead of wasting time with some mushy nonsense about true love, the movie focuses on the jokes, while substituting a wacky bromance subplot about how the boys aren't getting along as partners. Again, another clever twist on a tired formula.As an added bonus, this film has perhaps the greatest end-credits sequence of all time. While I still think the perfection of the first movie is unparalleled, this film is still one of the best modern R-rated comedies around the greatest comedy sequel ever.

Meandering plot, annoying protagonist, corny dialog, weak special effects... the only thing going for this movie is its whimsical set design, but everything else is really, really bad. The worst is how the movie aims to be something deeply and divine - the meaning of the universe! - but cannot formulate any coherent thoughts while spewing out metaphysical mumbo-jumbo. This thing is a bad first draft turned into finished film, the broken and incomplete thoughts of a rambling lunatic. While there are moments intended to be humorous, smart or touching, those parts just come off as weak, stupid and unsympathetic. There is a darkness to this world that's supposed to be "black comedy" that is simply just ugly and depressing. Christolph Waltz is a surly, mumbling grouch whom you're supposed to somehow sympathize with and root for, yet only does a great job of making you loath his misanthropic presence throughout the film.I even like the director's recent "misfires" like "The Imaginarium of Doctor Parnassus" or "Brothers Grimm." But this abomination makes either of those look like "12 Monkeys" or "Brazil" by comparison. If you want to see why a much-loved director with decades of hits and a two-time Oscar winner couldn't get a theatrical release, check out this deranged, illogical and strangely mean movie.

For torture/gore enthusiasts only. This film has a horribly bad plot, built upon a wealth of dumb decisions, magical coincidences, and head-scratching illogical inconsistencies. All of these poor tricks are amply used to artificially drag out the weak story and mediocre suspense.Do you think someone wandering into a room with hundreds of fishing hooks dangling from the ceiling is either cool or scary? Do you mind if someone hits a person who has tried to repeatedly murder them over the head with a gun instead of shooting them with it? If you answered yes and no respectively, you might enjoy this movie. I'm very good with the suspension of disbelief, but this film had far too many moments where you leap off the couch screaming, "Why would they do that when they could do this?" After all, the magical premise of the film is that a house is invaded by both an insane serial killer AND a cat burglar on the same night.There are a few decent cat-and-mouse scares in the beginning as characters silently pursue each other, but otherwise the film has stupefying turns with a plethora of gore and suffering.
Nothing so special. Not bad but not great. Somewhat cliche.

There's an undeniably epic sprawl to the game - from its large cast of characters to its galaxy-saving plot. And with various side missions and quests, the game was an immense 70-hour experience.But unfortunately despite so many things to do and explore, all the tasks and combat became redundant and repetitive. The gameplay is a bit stiff by modern standards. And while the game aspires to have this layered and involved story where you get to pick different conversational responses or moral choices, everything ultimately dissolves together where none of the decisions feel like they ever have any actual impact on the outcome.But still, the mythology is deep and graphics are strong. Hardcore sci-fi fans will definitely enjoy the rich dearth of places, races and activities in one of the best realized gaming universes ever. While the scope is broad, the game just needs a little more depth now.

These stories were uninspired, retreading familiar genre tropes. The author's summary and explanation for each might also be nifty to a true fan intrigued by his process, but really they kinda spoil the plots and ruin the atmosphere. The stories are very redundant too. Most of them have the same premise of a person alone feels something spooky coming, then blam, gotcha, the end. Hardcore fans of the genre will get their kicks, but otherwise I think most readers will lose interest after the first few.Check out "3vil" instead for quality horror of the short story variety.

These stories were really all over the place (in a great way.) From heavy to light, fantastic sci-fi to quiet naturalism, every entry in here is quite different from the other. There's even slight dashes of artwork and poetry to add to the eclectic fun of the collection.If any one common theme unites the works, it's a shared sense of humor. While maybe a pair of them were completely grim and serious, the rest are all quite light and whimsical. But again, even the humor has a nice spectrum to it. Some moments are big, stupid slapstick, while others have a wry and subtle humor or maybe some dark-black comedy.The standouts were "Randolph Rudolph the Radioactive Boy," a very bittersweet love story with a science-fiction twist, and "Taking Care of Wiggles," a fun romp about a lazy boy tasked with putting a bad dog to sleep. But I enjoyed all the stories here. Several of them were quite short, as these stories are all just long enough to make their point enjoyably without artificially dragging things along to some supposed quota on length.It all reminds me a little of Vonnegut, who blended heartfelt stories and clever plots with altered reality and mischievous jokes.

Almost like a classic 80s horror film, a group of teenagers attend the wrong party. But unlike a cliched setting, this story moves with crazed unpredictability. Certainly things go bad, but no reader can ever guess how.There are a variety of scares in here: from slow-burning dread to bizarre creepiness to big jump frights. The story is not without some other charms too, like some gallows humor, an ear for vapid teenage lingo, or the occasional lush use of imagery. There are some very adult moments too involving sex and violence, which may offend the squeamish.Like other great adventures, the darkness and madness just escalates to an awesome, frenzied finish. The read is a very cinematic experience, with lots of intriguing and dark imagery supporting a madcap narrative. It's hard to classify the type of horror here, as it's a rich blend of demons, ghosts, monsters and/or psychopaths, without ever truly belonging to any one category. This story was a great finale for the "3VIL" volume 1 collection.

The advertisements for this movie really missed the mark, as there is so much greatness going on in this film. "Tom Cruise vs the aliens" or sci-fi "Groundhog Day"? Sure, those claims are true, but rather simplistic. There are several other really wonderful things to love about this film:1) Kickass super-heroine - While many lament the absence of women from the modern superhero boom (and rightfully so,) this movie delivers that rare woman warrior. At the start, Tom Cruise is the puny wimp, while Emily Blunt is the fearless leader of Earth's entire army. She swings this ridiculously giant manga-style sword and crushes aliens like nothing. It's simply great and cool to see anybody doing this, but especially a lady.2) Sci-fi D-Day - This movie showcases a classic "storming of Normandy" sequence where instead of Americans  attacking Germans, it's power-suited humans airdropping onto the beach to make battle with alien enemies. It's big, epic, loud and thrilling.3) Comedy - This movie's hysterical. The dark humor milks the premise of the repeating/neverending day for all the jokes it can, where things change in novel, unpredictable ways.4) New aliens - Tired of the same old aliens that are humanoid with 4 limbs or look like big bugs? Just as this film offers fresh spins on other tired cliches, the bad guys here are the most distinct and unique creations in sci-fi cinema that I can remember for quite some time.5) Big ideas - This film combines a plethora of heady themes: destiny, heroism, politics, morality, war, choice, etc. where the viewer has many deep things to contemplate while riding the roller coaster plot.Beyond the above, sure the movie has great performances (Bill Paxton's sassy and evangelical sergeant is downright poetic), killer action, majestic SFX, and interesting and intriguing plot. I know this movie was based on a Japanese graphic novel, but it still one of the most "original," cool and kooky films to be made in this era of remakes, reboots and sequels.

Nonsensical plot, insulting misogyny, bad and stale jokes, fake outtakes over the credits... this movie does everything wrong (unless you want Efron's abs.) This is honestly one of the more offensively dumb and poorly conceived films I've ever seen, the easy frontrunner for worst film of 2014.The cruel, stupid, dishonest and wholly predictable plot might be overlooked if it were in any way funny, touching, insightful or interesting. The sole audience for this film would be the strange subsect of humanity who is somehow both an alpha-idiot frat douche yet somehow has a sensitive and misunderstood heart of gold, a strange oxymoron who, like these characters, are kind rapists and responsible drunks. This film was clearly the work of someone who thought he's grown up from his "deceiving women to sleep with them" playboy baller days into some sort of cool, romantic playboy baller now. I'll peg the over/under on the writer/director's divorces at 2.5. Oh, this guy also co-produced the vile "Movie 43" too? That piece de cinema is 4% on Rotten Tomatoes. 'Nuff said here.The film wants to have it both ways - with a trio of selfish, insensitive cool dudes who are also charming and selfless. By making the females in this film all slobberingly and repeatedly fall for these manipulative jerks is an insult to all women. The film is so psychotically schizophrenic (or plain dumb) that it wants to be both a raunchy gross-out comedy yet tender and sweet romance at the same time, as if it can somehow win over both teenage male dolts and older sensitive women with both poop and poetry.The plot can't even stay consistent: At first all three principals agree to stay single, but later they call it a bet as if there are stakes on the line? Another way to tell the film was conceived by an immature man-child is that these 20-somethings are all anachronistically obsessed with 90s films, as if all the cool kids these days do not care about modern entertainment, but are down with obscure movies from decades ago when they were toddlers. Again much of this could be forgiven if the film was actually funny. But with atrocious running gags, like the umpteenth OMG! because yet another character forgot to lock a door while doing something naughty! - the filmmakers simply recycle the same bad ideas over and over.Further proof of this film's all-time atrociousness is the fake, forced and still unfunny gag reel. The notion of fabricating outtakes is mind-boggling, but the viewer can tell they are unauthentic by seeing these mediocre goofballs struggling to invent absurd ad-libs while breaking the 4th wall.And this Miles Teller guy... I've seen him in several other films he's starred in (21 & Over, Project X) and his "cool motormouth" routine has got to go. His grating smugness is some of the worst "acting" I've ever seen. He's even unpleasant to look at. Unfortunately, this dork must be pure Hollywood royalty to keep falling up, as I saw that he's now in the new Fantastic Four movie. (sigh, shudder, weeps.) I'm sure there's a word in some foreign language that captures the exact opposite of charisma this loser exudes, the strange and particular emotion of "the complete repulsion and hatred of someone/thing trying to be likable and funny." I bet the Japanese or Germans know how to properly communicate that feeling of watching Miles Teller be in a movie.

This story is a truly amazing and unique read. As this tale is told in a "first-person plural" voice, the reader now becomes part of the group of protagonists driving the story. So "we" are going on a dark and macabre story, one involving "us," a crew of cutthroats, and "our" mysterious quest. This trick really helps to fully immerse the reader in the experience.While the kooky voice could be dismissed as just a gimmick, the other parts are entirely enjoyable too. The story is set in an old-fashioned, Gothic and maritime world, one which offers some very rich dialog and imagery that is fairly distinct and different from most other contemporary tales. The horror ranges from the subtly creepy to the wildest jumps, but is always effective and fun.Overall, the story offers a decidedly different and delightful journey from the usual stuff, and is a must for fans of literary horror. If you enjoy this, I'm sure you'd likewise enjoy the collection from which this story comes, "3vil," and/or the author's similarly trippy 2nd-person thriller, "Kill Thy Neighbor."

While so many modern games feel compelled to complicate their play with more and more (features, endings, customization, etc.) these two games are wonderfully minimal in their design. These games are like no other. Using only a few buttons and with very little dialog and the the simplest, both games are a majestic hybrid of action platformer and puzzle game. And though they were designed long ago, they still look and sound amazing. (But the movement and play can be a little meh at points.)The second game "Colossus" is easily the superior one since it features more refined gameplay and a more polished experience. It is a true, innovative classic in gaming.The first game "Ico" can be quite frustrating at times, requiring players to discover new techniques on the fly through the most curious exploration (or cheating with a walkthrough.)Combined together at this price, however, this is a tremendous value for a pair of games that are refreshingly different from everything else and and sublimely cool to play. Both demonstrate the potential of a rare breed in gaming, ones which are creative and artistic.

Part of the joys of this series is that while it has a rich history and world it keeps building upon, each new entry is easy for beginners too. Every film almost acts like a reboot into a new subgenre of this sci-fi/horror series.For this 4th film, after a stunning shoot-em-up opening replete with Matrix-level effects, carnage and destruction, the meat of the story is a pretty bare-bones tale of survival and escape from a prison during a zombie invasion (pre-Walking Dead,) featuring a smaller cast and scale than some of the other films. But while the setting is more intimate than usual, the effects have not been skimped on, featuring some fantastic creatures and awesome "boss" beasts.Jovovich is simply the best action heroine going today bar none, with great intensity and emotion and killer moves.The grand finale is also fantastic in its adventurous mystery, embracing the rich potential of the premise by having another ultimate sequence filled with sci-fi, action and horror as only these movies can.

The zippers are sewn good and work well and have a pull on them to make opening and closing easier. Overall this is a really nicely constructed backpack and I would recommend. This worked Ok but didn't stick as well as some other types I've tried.The purpose of using kinesiology tape is to improve circulation, support muscles and help heal and prevent muscle injury.Supporting the muscle -- Proper taping improves the muscle's ability to contract even when it's weakened, reduces a feeling of pain and fatigue, and protects the muscle from cramping, over-extension and over-contraction.Removing congestion to the flow of body fluids -- Kinesiology tape improves blood and lymphatic circulation and reduces inflammation and excess chemical buildup in the tissue.Activating the endogenous analgesic system -- "Endogenous" refers to something that is self-originating, and calling something "analgesic" means that it can relieve pain in a conscious person. So, this requirement means that the tape must facilitate the body's own healing mechanisms, a central focus in chiropractic medicine.Correcting joint problems -- The goal is improving range of motion and adjusting misalignments that result from tightened muscles.I received this product in exchange for an honest review.

These are very nice bright solar powered LED Sensor Lights. These are a little bit larger than others I have tried. I placed them at the back of our deck for lighting up the steps to let the dog out at night. It has a little hole that you need to push the pin in so it will work the first time. I think this is there to save the battery. You need to position these so that there is good sunlight on it during the day. Then they will shine about 8-12 hours or until morning. It stays on dim until someone approaches it then it shines brighter. I love the fact that this isn't costing us anymore in our electric bill. Easy to install just one screw (included). Overall a good set of solar lights. I received this product in exchange for an honest review.

The purpose of using kinesiology tape is to improve circulation, support muscles and help heal and prevent muscle injury.Supporting the muscle -- Proper taping improves the muscle's ability to contract even when it's weakened, reduces a feeling of pain and fatigue, and protects the muscle from cramping, over-extension and over-contraction.Removing congestion to the flow of body fluids - Kinesiology tape improves blood and lymphatic circulation and reduces inflammation and excess chemical buildup in the tissue.Activating the endogenous analgesic system -"Endogenous" refers to something that is self-originating, and calling something "analgesic" means that it can relieve pain in a conscious person. So, this requirement means that the tape must facilitate the body's own healing mechanisms, a central focus in chiropractic medicine.Correcting joint problems - The goal is improving range of motion and adjusting misalignments that result from tightened muscles.The tape itself worked good for me. If your crossing it over on itself don't let that be the end part. The ends should stick to your skin for better adhesion. I received this product in exchange for an honest review.

If you are like me then you do not want everyone knowing what you ordered. I am always worried when it comes to ordering adult toys on line. That on top of all the different settings you will be sure to find one that you love.Once I was done, I just used my favorite toy cleaner, made sure it was dry and then stored back in the box that it came in.
