They say you shouldn't judge a book by it's cover, but that's what I did with AMP. I only downloaded it because it was free, and did not read it for months, until I ran out of other books to read. So then I got started into AMP, and I liked it enough to try buying book 2, and after book 2, I simply bought the rest in the series. The series starts with the hero down on his luck focusing on his own little world, as we all do in real life, except his revolves around his small spaceship. From there, it gets bigger and bigger until by the end of the series, he is the leader of the Human race, has travelled across many galaxies, and throws off evil tyrants.Download the book. If you like sci fi, you owe it to yourself to at least try this out.

Got this as part of a package deal buying a second hand Olympus EPL-5. Little bit of a mixed bag.Easier to carry due to slim size, get the benefit of faster shutter speed due to f1.7, haven't noticed much, if any, distortion at f1.7.Focusing in low light with the EPL-5 is slow, and the focusing motor makes a relatively loud noise. Is it screw drive focusing motor? Bokeh, which is subjective, is not as creamy as I had hoped. My Olympus 12-50mm seems to produce sharper images with creamier bokeh. Of course the 12-50mm is about 5 times longer,so that's a trade off.Certainly worth getting if you're after a slimmer easier to carry lens for your m4/3 camera body. Just note it's not perfect.

4.5 stars, but rounded up to 5.Another enjoyable well paced non stop military sci fi novel. Both my favourite and least favourite parts were in the front of the book.My favourite part was when McGill was having R&R at home at his parent's place, and, like most of us when our parents are talking nonstop to us, our attention drifts and he gets caught looking at his tapper. His mum promptly says she'll get tweezers to remove hairs which have grown through the tapper, and McGill moans "Aww Mum! I'm not 7 years old anymore!". She uses this as an excuse to look at his tapper's photos and then learn'sthe existence of her grand daughter.  I just smiled at this family moment. You might be a big soldier who can change the course of galactic events, but when you're home, your mum will always be your mum.Not much further from this, McGill is in Turov's office and pretty much coerced into having 3 times a week sex with her. While it's easy to see it just adds to the trend of him having sex willy nilly, I thought it wasn't in great taste (even though he did say he felt taken advantage of). If Turov was a man and McGill a woman, there would be no doubt at all this scene would be a rape scene and there'd be complaints of sexual abuse in the storyline.Aside from this, I enjoyed the book and look forward to the next one.

Based on the many reviews here I expected it to be nothing short of being perfect in fulfilling my expectations of removing heavy mould and mould smell from a second hand back pack I bought recently. I used 3 caps the first time, it dried in about a day with no wringing, was much better but still had a smidgen of mouldy smell, I washed it by spraying water all over outside and inside, removing the white mould, then did it again with 3 caps of mirazyme, but this time no change.The bag is much much better than before, but it's not perfect or infallible.Considering spraying loads of Fabreeze did absolutely zip before I used Mirazyme, I can hardly Mirazyme is useless. But it's not a miracle worker. It's good, but not the stuff of legend.

This LAD Weather watch's biggest problem is the display. It simply isn't very bright. It's got tons of functions, which I love, especially at this price. For Bang for Buck, this watch wins hands down. But you have to adpat to the display.When I fisrt received it, I was so disappointed how dim the display was. My Casio analogue watch- see the time with a split fraction glance. This one- have to take more time to see it.But I used it on a couple of walks and day hikes, and in the sunny day, it's fine. When it's dark, press the "light on" button and it lights up easy to read too. It's in between, like in a moderately lit room, that it's harder to see, and the watch light doesn't help much. But within 2 weeks, my eyes had adapted and the "naturally" squint a bit harder to focus on the digits.As for the functions, I like the altitude one the best. In my limited use, I find it's about 50m too high, but you can still tell roughly how much you you have ascended or descended, which is the main thing.When you use altitude, barometer, compass, these features will take the middle row of the watch, which is the largest row, and will stay there. The time gets moved to the bottom, which is about half the height of the middle row numbers. Staying at the middle is useful. I'd hate to have to keep pushing the mode button for it to appear and disappear every few seconds. It does, however, go idle though- says "IDLE".Another good thing is the wrist strap loop- after you wear it, the excess length gets tucked into the loop. On my Casio, it will often come undone with the strap sticking out. But the LAD Weather strap end has a raised portion, which acts as a ledge to stop the loop moving backwards and slipping off the strap. Nice touch.Ini hindsight, I might have considered the [Lad Weather] Fishing Outdoor (Climbing/ Hiking/ Running/ Walking/ Camping) Altimeter Barometer Chronograph Alarm Weather Forecast Men's Wrist Sports Watches, which has a normal LCD display, but it's too late now, and I've gotten used to it.Can't beat it for the features at this price. 4 out of 5 stars. If there was no display issue, it would be 5 stars for a watch at this price point.

Brands like Gregory are not nearly as popular or well known as ones like Columbia and Osprey. But like I have discovered many times in the past, less known often means it is better than the better known. And so it is with the Gregory Miwok 24.The city I live in mostly has Ospreys, with a small selection of North Face and Columbia bags. I love the look and build of Osprey, but the bags never quite fit me, for a number of reasons. I also feel they are all overpriced.  Recently, a new shop started selling Gregory and I although I was only going to window shop, I ended up buying the Miwok 24. It was high quality, had features I liked, lightweight and on special. I took it home, loaded it up with 5kg and walked around the neighbourhood and to my amazment, it felt really good! Then I put in a 3 litre bladder with 2L of water, and another 2kg of stuff (total weight about 4.3kg), and cycled for 2 hours (with a break at the Popeyes at the halfway point), and I was amazed by how awesome it felt. I honestly can't think of a single thing I don't like about it, and many things that I do.Pros/Features:========== - professional high end build quality - Comes in at least 3 colours. At the shop I saw bright blue, black and that bright orange which is kind of flouro. - Shoulder straps are wide apart so do not rub side of yor neck. The straps are also wide to distribute weight over more of your shoulder. The padding on shoulder straps and back has holes, for better ventilation, weight reduction and less swaeting. ** Awesome pockets and attachments: - two waist pockets which are spcaious and don't flatten out when you tighten it around your waist. I was able to fit my Samsung S4 in with room to spare. The S4 zoom is like a thickish compact camera. - I suspect it is water resistant. The inside of the material has this rubberised coating/lining. I have the same lining in my Osprey Talon 8 waist pack, and it came through a torrential rain storm with no moisture in the compartments or pockets. However, the Miwok 24 will not stand up to extremely heavy rain- the zippers are not those with firm plastic next to the zipper teeth, just normal cloth, so water will soak through. The Osprey zippers have those firm plastic sidings to help with weather proofing. - the shoulder straps have two very useful attachments- on the right one is a clip for your water bladder hose. On the left side is a narrow cloth sleeve with glasses embroided on it, so you can slide an arm of your sunglasses through. It's almost like they were reading my mind. I have lost 2 pairs of sunnies by just having them fall off while cycling and the glasses were just tucked into the top of my t shirt or on chest strap and I didn't notice when they dropped off as I rode.Not to mention how often they fall on the ground when I bend over during hiking. - The top of the pack has a horizontal zip for a wide pocket there. But unlike most bags, this goes all the way from one side to the other, and dips slightly down the slide. Inside the pocket, is a mesh zipped pocket and a lose clip, so you can keep your keys , wallet, passport in the mesh part. I easily fit my 6 inch kindle Fire into the pocket, as well as my wallet and keys and mobile- It's deep, it's wide, it's very convenient to put things in and take them out. It's not just a pocket for sunglasses, it's a full on useable pocket. I use backpacks as cabin luggage, and this pocket is absolutely right on the money for me- wallet, passport, keys, tablet. - The front pocket is a large flexible thing which is about 80% the height of the bag- which is good!. It can be kept streamlined by zipping up the two zippers on the side, or you can unzip them and let the pocket bulge out, and my bicycle helmet fits in perfectly. I put my bike gloves, lights in the helmet space where my head would be. There is a small elastic strap you can hook onto a plastic hook too. Obviously there's a vast range of things you could put into that big pocket/sleeve. This is the first time I've had such a pocket. There are also further elastic locks on the inside/side to tighten the pocket. - There are two side pockets most would assume are for bottles. They are, but boy, are they deep! When I put a 1.5L soft drink bottle in, the pocket goes about 65-70% up the height of the bottle. 1.5L, not 0.5L ! And the pocket is not being stretched to the limit and about to break, either.Furthermore, the way it is designed, the compression strap is near the top of the pocket and there is a sort of vertical /diagnoal flap which partly covers half the pocket, so you can tighten the top of the side pocket and things won't come out as easily if the backpack takes a tumble- it's not a full on zipper or closing but it's pretty good.All pockets are full material, not mesh, so you can put your mobile phones, tablets etc in and people won't be able to see them....or more importantly, thieves won't. The pockets just swallow the 6 inch kindle- it's that big. - on one side of the front there's a elastic tie at top and loop at bottom, for a pole. - There is one more important pocket- immediately behind the mesh foam backing, is a pocket for the water bottle. It's excellent. and my 3 L bladder fit with no problem, and did not sag or move at all.This pocket keeps it out of the way of the main compartment, and is kept closed by two velcro patches. - at the bottom there's a slot for a bike light.I know I wrote a heck of a lot. To be honest, this really lends itself better to a video review to show you what I mean.Bottom line- A fantastic backpack. It makes me want to go out and hike or cycle, just so I can use it.UPDATE 3rd Oct 2015==================I used the Miwok 24 quite a lot before hand but my constantly evolving activities and keenness to try new packs means I use it quite rarely now. It's not quite big enough to always pack everything I need for a weekend getaway, and now I use a Mammut MTR 201 7L pack meant for runners- it weighs only 215 grams, it fits a 3 L water bladder and I've used it for both day hiking and cycling. The Miwok 24 has had no real issues with wear and tear- the bottom where the plastic/foam piece backing- the corners where it presses the fabric material- the blue is wearing away slightly. Nothing has torn, it remains comfortable. But I've found that perhaps the compression from the x2 straps on the sides might not be enough at times. Also, if you stuff the front pocket with clothing, not helmets/big cowboy hats (I have one I like), then the pocket bulges out and the pack looks bit funny. Still, you can put a heck of a lot in that front pocket!So it remains a pretty good pack. The only way I think it could be better would be to put some pockets on the shoulder straps to put your mobile phone or compact camera, and maybe a bit more compression.

Another enjoyable installment in this series. Each book seems to add something to the plot and character development and I would prefer Mr Larson spend time focusing on this series, rather than stretching out the Star Force series.

I truly enjoyed this and afterwards, wished there had been more in the Star Force series on this guy, than just the main guy (I forgot his name). THis guy seems very skillful and interesting. He shold have a series all on his own.

Although this is a not a long book, there are no wasted words. In my view, this is the best of the Star Force series (9 books in all. Book 10 onwards takes place years afterwards, and,in my opinion, is an attempt to drag more money out of us readers). The book is intense, you nevere know what is going to happen, and you feel for the main character as he goes through hell.Read it. You won't regret it.

Another enjoyable installment in this series. Each book seems to add something to the plot and character development and I would prefer Mr Larson spend time focusing on this series, rather than stretching out the Star Force series. Read all of them. I am!

Another enjoyable installment in this series. Each book seems to add something to the plot and character development and I would prefer Mr Larson spend time focusing on this series, rather than stretching out the Star Force series.

Stephen Baxter's XeeLee series is one of the most amazing series I've read. He takes the entire human race from the beginning, to it's end a few million years in the future, and it's war with the XeeLee, and , in developing the XeeLee race, reveals that the war which consumes all of humanity for tens of thousands of years, is but a side show for the universe spanning conflict between the XeeLee and their dark matter enemies, and the XeeLee are losing. The XeeLee are so powerful, that they are able to move entire galaxies. Humans are but a tiny side show, an annoyance.The XeeLee universe is grand, vast, is spread across billions of years. The author is fluid, has plots which grab you and never let go.And yet, at the end of all of this, I have to say that I didn't like it. I found it sad. Downtrodden several times by Alien races, then after thousands of years of warmongering, it's all for nothing. We do not matter in the large scheme of things, and whatever plots are hatched, fail, in the long run. I'm one of those people who likes to see a little something positive happen for the good guys, for the humans. In XeeLee, everyone loses. And we never actually get to see or meet the ultimate bad guys.So as I said, 99% of you will enjoy this epic series of stories. But I felt depressed after each one.

I have bought and read the first four of Kelby's Digital Photogrpahy books and like many, many people, have enjoyed the way he uses humour and writes his explanations as if he's just having a casual conversation with you, as if you bumped into each other at a barbeque, you discovered he's a photography pro, and you picked his brains for a few tips, and struck gold because this photographer knows how to put things in normal language, refraining from using technical jargon and making you feel illiterate, dumb and a fool.To be honest though, I've found that he is stringing out his books. I found that as you progress from Book to, to 2, then 3, then 4, the things you learn decreases, at least for me. Don't get me wrong, I am hardly a pro. And Kelby covers many situations that I'm sure I'll very rarely be involved in, like waking at 5am to take one of those beautiful landscapes with the still waters of the lake, over which a long shadow of the nearby mountain is casting.Overall, should you buy this series of books? If you even a passing interest in photography, then yes, at the very least buy the first book. As the the next 4, it depends on your interest and knowledge levels.

Surprisingly good novel. Made me want to read the second, and am now eagerly awaiting the final book in the trilogy.Initially I thought the over 1800 reviews were likely to be from paid reviewers, but this author has earned his chops.

At top of the amazon pag it says Octant LR, but when I click buy to go to Cart, it says Ultra LR. So I wasn't sure which vest I would eventually get. But at the price I paid, I was ok with either. Received the Ultra LR today, really excited with the looks, quality and my first time uses.Please note I do no jogging at all. I walk, hike or cycle. But I've wanted front pockets on shoulder straps a long time, and when I saw this vest at this price, I thought I'd give it a try.The design features are pretty good.The water bladder weight is at the hips, not up high, there are 4 pockets at the front- the two obvious big ones on the shoulder straps, which you can put bottles , or, for me, I might put cameras, quik dry towels, mobile phone with connected battery to map my hikes, and above these big ones, is a slot type pocket, the right sholder strap one opens from the top of the pocket  and is quite deep, bit deeper than my shortish stubby fingers. The other one the left (when you wear it), is from the upper/side aspect. It is not deep, and you can slide thin things in, like keys, folded money notes (some countries like Singapore and Australia have changed from making money in paper to plastic - invented in Australia, so you don't have to worry about soggy money) At the back, there's the 2 litre/70 oz water bladder, which you get access to by unzipping the bottom flap on 2 sides. Inside this flap is a hidden zippered pocket- guess you can put something here too. And above this is the stretchy open pocket for something, like change of t shirt, wind breaker, stuff to eat etc. There are no waist side pockets on this model. I wish they did.  Storage is either front or back.Shoulder strap length can be adjusted. About 30cm(?) at the end of the shoulder strap has the cloth end which attaches to the rough sticky velcro side attached a sleeve in the vest. You can detach and adjust as needed. I changed it several times.There are also a number of reflective strips on the front and back, and my pack is white/blue, which makes it easy to see.I found that the weight needs to be distributed evenly. If I put a bottle, camera in the front, but nothing in the back, it pulls forward. I'm quite broad so I notice this. I don't have the pencil thin physique some marathon runners have so it's slightly tight at the upper back for me as well. For about 10-15 mintues, there was this itchy feeling as if the mesh back was irritating one particular place on my back. Don't really notice any weight or pressure from full 2L bladder.I live in a very hot and humis part of the world, so predicatbly I did notice the sweaty back and the sweaty areas from the front pockets which had my camera, mobile phone, phone charger, towel and wallet. Since I walk, not run, I can offset these a bit by unclipping any or all of the 2 chest and one waist buckles, for air to flow behind, for it not to cling tightly to my body.When water, after approx 1L, there was some resistance and I had to suck quite hard to get water. The Camelbak nozzle has a very tight rubber cap, is straight (I prefer bent/right angled) and has a smoothly operating on/off switch you turn. Works well, though the cap seems too tight.Another irritation was the plastic clip for the left front pocket had a particular sharp part, which I kept bumping my left arm on. Nail filed most of the sharp bit away so it's ok now.But otherwise it's a good piece of equipment. Comfortable, flexible, adjustable. Yeah it gets wet from the sweat, but it  is no different from my other thin non frame backpacks in this regards. Just make sure to waterproof your important things, and experiment with the fitting. It is very flexible.I'm also thinking about trying a camelbak waist pack with built in hydration bladder. But we'll see.I'm giving it 4 stars because it's my first vest. I have nothing to compare it to. Maybe later on I might adjust the rating.

I've read the whole Admiral series so far and look forward to each one. In each, there is non stop personal mayhem, political backstabbing, perpetual underdog goes into battle against overwhelming odds and complete lack of gratitude from the the people who the Admiral helps save.Start from the beginning. These books are cheap to buy, but not excellent value on entertainment value.Some reviewers have said this is poorly written drivel. It is true that compared to thoughtfully written in depth sagas, like those written by Iain Banks and Neal Asher, it is on a lower level. But it is not just a lower level, but a different stack. The author is clearly not taking his characters, storyline or himself too seriously. At time, I cringed when I saw references to other things in science fiction. But don't let it deter you. Give the series a chance.

I've used the Samsung S4 Zoom as my number one phone, and 90% of the time when I take photos, and I've taken thousands since I bought it last year. Overall, I love it, but when the K Zoom came out, I had to see what it was like. I spent about 30 minutes playing with it at the shops and this is what I've noticed (ps: I know this isn't the same as owning it, but I feel I'm not approaching it as a total newbie- I have the S4 Zoom and they have similarlities, and I'm comparing the K Zoom to the S4 Zoom) : - Android operating system 4.4 kitkat is very similar to the version used in the S4 Zoom. Coouple of cosmetic changes. Otherwise everything was pretty much same as for the S4 Zoom in terms of app use, phone use. - The body feels like a dimpled curved body, which is what it is. It's fine for a smartphone, but not so much as a camera. - Lens - same zoom range 24-240mm in 35mm format. The rotating ring on the S4 Zoom is gone. Zooming is done by using the volume up and down button, which makes sense. The touchscreen zoom and widen magnifying glasses for zooming onthe screen are gone too. No it's pinch in and out to zoom on screen. Seems inconsistent. Sometimes it will zoom or widen a lot, or not as at all. - Camera software- Big change over the S4 Zoom, making it much more user friendly and very much more customisable. For example:  - In the Gallery, you can now move the album icons around and put them in any order you want.  - When you go to "modes", instead of having the scroll in a circular manner through lots and lots of options, like night, macro, etc, you can see them in two ways- scrool up and down along the left side, where you can see about 5 icons at a time, or, when you press the tab button top right, you can see about ..perhaps 15-18 icon squares across the entire screen. Not only that, but you can manage them, so that you can choose which ones you want to appear. This is very much better than before, where I used to scroll round and round to find macro, then rotate through another 5 or 6 to get, to, say, panoramic, then through several more for continous shot. When I played with the phone, I had as few as three options showing (macro, panoramic, manage), as then changed it to include every option.  - Same thing under manual mode- no more scrolling round and round in a circular time wasting fashion. It's just about 12 ssquare icons all showing at once on the screen, you drag left or right to increas or decrease whatever you waant- iso, f stop, shutter speed. etc - Other things I noticed were: I never use video, but I did, just for the heck of it. I took a 30 second one in the shops, holding the phone horizontally. When I played it back it was fine when horizontal, but when I held it vertically, it did rotate, but did not shrink so you could see the whole width. You could only see the middle 2/3 of the screen. Very strange. Perhaps it happens to others and there is a way to fix it but my lack of video experience meant I couldn't do anything. You can also shrink the video so you get the screen cap of the vid, and the actual clip is playing on the top right corner. - In terms of using the camera, I found it was not nearly as easy to hold. The loss of the camera grip meant you have to hold the thin edges, which is normal for a smartphone, but remember here, you have to zoom a lot. The shutter button is much narrower and very sensitive. Press halfway does produce a focus lock (unlike one or two online "professional" reviewers who have said it does not focus lock, but instead goes straight ahead and takes the photo), but because of the sensitivity you might skip the focus part and go straight to taking the photo. - Obviously the phone is too new for me to even make a guess whether or not there will be slowing down as apps are installed and deleted, and the internal HDD gets filled up. It may or may not. IT has a hex core CPU, so it remains to be seen if that will produce the magic to turn the K zoom into a magnificent mobile/camera hybrid.Overall- as a phone, the Galaxy K Zoom should be familiar to Samsung and android users. The 4.8 inch screen is larger than the 4.3 inch of the S4 Zoom and is something I wouldn't mind having on my S4 Zoom. Much easier ofor viewing, using the internet, as so on. As a camera, it is incredibly more user friendly. I wish I could update the S4 Zoom with the K Zoom camera software. But I really did not like the feel of it in my hands as a camera. If you have never used the S4 Zoom, or not nearly as often as I have, then the K Zoom will probably feel great to you. A nicely styled mobile, coupled with a fantastic lens which is wider than most (great for selfies), and zooms so far that most composition issues are taken care of. For me, I will stay with the S4 Zoom- I am used to it and like the feel in my hands. But for anyone else, I think you will love the K Zoom. It just does so much, and Samsung have obviously been listening to user comments to improve things. Try it. You'll like it.Edit 2014 August 11th====================Disclaimer- I still have not bought the K Zoom and am still using my battered S4 Zoom. However, given the similarities between the two, and I haven't seen anoything online, I thought I'd include this update.On the weekend I was at Hong Kong markets and they now have several types of selfie sticks. In case you don't know, selfie sticks are retractable poles with a handle at one end, which you hold, and a phone holder at the other, which you attach your phone to. By holding the phone further away from you, you can include more in the photo- your friends, the buildings and scenery around you. Because the phone (or small camera) is now beyond your reach, you will need to set the self timer to take the photo. Enterprising souls have introduced a bluetooth remote control- you turn you phone on, activate bluetooth, let the remote control and phone sync, and then you can press the "take the photo" button.Well, things have moved on since this, and at the market there were selfie sticks which have combined the bluetooth remote into the selfie stick handle, so you only need one device, not two. I saw and tried two such sticks. One had just a single button- the shutter button, and the other had four buttons- on/off, one for zoom in, one for zoom out, and one for shutter-take photo.BOTH versions do not work for the S4 Zoom, and I assume may not work for the K Zoom.When I synced the stick to my phone, the following happened. For the single button stick, pressing it made the zoom lens zoom in. That's it.For the multiple button selfie stick, pressing the shutter button made it zoom in, pressing zoom in made it focus.Now the software for the K Zoom is not the same as for the S4 Zoom, so maybe the K zoom will have no problem. But just in case, I've added this here.I've also played with the K Zoom a little more and don't find it too slim any more. Still miss the tripod screw attachment(even though I've only used it twice on the S4 Zoom ;-) )

My overall impression of the 12-50mm lens is that it's pretty good. Many people give it a low rating, but it depends what you compare it to and your expectations.Most kit lenses for m4/3 and DSLR's are 28-80mm (in 35mm format) affairs, usually made of plastic. Images are usually adequate, but not nearly as sharp as more expensive zoom and prime lenses. Aperture is usually 3.5-5.6 - nothing special at all. Pentax adds weather sealing, Canon has USB focus motor. That's about it.In contrast, this 12-50mm has a great deal of ability:- weather sealing. This is important to me as I hike and take a lot of photos. Areas I hike may be very misty, damp and humid, suddenly rain, be rocky or have both sand and mud (ie- normal outdoors away from the city). It's nice to know I can just hang onto this regardless of conditions.- very stylishly designed. It looks high end. Most kit lenses, and many more expensive lenses do not look as sleek and well made- 24-100mm (in 35mm format) is vastly more useful than 28-80mm. It never ceases to amaze me how much more you can fit in at 24mm, than 28mm. At the very least it is easier to take a selfie and larger groups of people. 100mm is a noticeably greater reach than 80mm.- I have only used kit lenses for DSLR's for Pentax and Canon, but I'd say images from this 12-50mm lens are sharper, and there's no obvious distortion at 24mm. I do not magnify images to 1000% to check so maybe I'm missing something. - Related to sharpness, bokeh is very smooth and creamy. Only primes are better, imho.- Fast focusing.- 3 modes- manual zooming, electronis zooming, macro modes. Takes a bit of practice to work out how to switch between modes. Olympus is one of the more user UNfriendly brands I've come across. But having these options is good, and the electronic zooming means you can produce better videos.- aperture...ok, it's not fast. But then, no kit lens is. In fact, you have to pay hundreds and thousands more for f2.8 lenses. They also weigh 3 to 4 times more too.The main disadvantages are:- cost. Less of an issue now that the EM-10 has come out and the EM-5 price has come down.- length. There are several 28-84mm kit lenses for m4/3 which are between 50-70% shorter in length, making them lighter and easier to carry around.Overall, I feel the 12-50mm is a fine lens, and there is no reason for me to spend money for a smaller lens of reduced range, nor hundreds more for a faster lens which is 3-4 times heavierI bring both this lens and my 14-150mm lens when I travel and often when I hike. The 14-150 has far greater reach which is very useful, but I do notice the 28mm being not as wide as the 24mm.Sorry for being wordy. I like this lens.

In recent years, my cameras have been Pentax K-5, Pentax MX-1, X-5, Samsung Galaxy S4 Zoom, and Olympus OM-D EM-5. I've sold all my DSLR gear (too heavy), and for convenience, have used the Samsung Zoom the most in the last 6 months. Recently, however, I used my EM-5 again on a hike and rediscovered how awesome it is, especially with it's weather resistance. I decided to upgrade my EM-5 by buying a bigger eyecup, and getting a 14-150mm lens, when by sheer coincidence, I came upon the Stylus 1, and it seemed to make the EM-5 unnecessary. Same EM-5 style, constant f2.8 28-300mm, but much slimmer than the EM-5, same top of the line Electronic Viewfinder, built in WiFI. The Stylus 1 seemed like the best camera ever!. I played with it at the shops, and used a friend's one for a day or two. Overall, I think the Stylus 1 is an incredible camera, when look at purely as a camera, but when price is taken into consideration, I think it's far overpriced and not good value for money. (of course it's a personal opinion) Pros: ==== - so many built in high end features, like WiFi, EVF, 3 inch swivel screen, EM-5 styling, higher end compact sensor, f2.8 aperture, 28-300mm lens- sure, not as far as Lumix's constant f2.8 camera, but it's a fraction of the size- an excellent performance/weight/size compromise, 7 frame per second with real shutter sound and tactile sensation, better button layout than the EM-5, very smooth bokeh (out of focus background), very customisable, built in flash. Also loved the fact it had a fixed auto lens cover. Nice to not have to fiddle taking lens cover on and off. Olympus lens caps for micro 4/3 lens are ridiculously thin and impractical so the Stylus has a definite edge in user friendliness here. - for it's class of camera, focus is fast, shutter lag is minimal. Image saving to SD card seems quick sometimes, but not other times. I really don't know why there was half to 1 second variation is saving time. Must be how my friend's camera was. Cons: ==== - It feels plastic, as it is made of plastic, not metal like the EM-5, despite the same physical similarity. Thus it doesn't have the same subjective solidness. Sure I'm comparing it to the EM-5, a camera that was released at a much higher price point than the Stylus 1, but even when I compare it to cheaper cameras, it doesn't seem as rugged. - Price. I know Casio has a f2.8 28-300mm camera competitor which is even more expensive, the Stylus 1 is really a long zoom version of the Olympus ZX-1/2 and Pentax MX-1 with a EVF.Both the ZX-1/2 and MX-1 share a 28-112mm (in 35mm format) f1.8-2.5 lens which produced fantastic bokeh. I honestly can't see the price premium.  This is why I say the camera is a 5 star camera, but only 3 star when price is taken into consideration. Of course, if price isn't an issue, then forget all the other so called serious compact cameras like Canon s100/110, Pentax MX-1, Olympus ZX-1/2, and go straight to Stylus 1. The only possible improvements I can predict in the next incarnation of the Stylus 1 is a wider end, 22 to 25mm, instead of 28mm.In the end, I decided to go with the 14-150mm lens to use with my EM-5 because the lens (second hand) was half the price of a new Stylus 1 (this is 70% of the reason I kept the EM-5 over the Stylus 1), I liked using the EM-5, and the EM-5 is a higher end camera with all that entails- faster focus, customisable evrything, fast image saving, larger sensor and sharper more detailed images. I don't think many people will be in the same position I was in, so might not agree with me. I've chosen the EM-5 over Stylus 1, and time will tell if I did the right thing. After all, everyone else here seems to love it!Sorry for the rambling length. I tend to do that.

I have to thank the reviewer's of Mr Campbell's first Hard Luck Hank book for enticing me into buying it. I absolutely loved it. It was fluid, non stop, had multiple overlapping problems that seemed to just escalate, yet the book maintained it's humourous edge and finished with the good guys winning from all sides..which is slightly ironic, given the "good guys" are all corrupt as heck!So when volume 2 came around, I quickly skimmed through the reviews (there were only 7 reviews then- it's 21 now, which goes to show the popularity of Hard Luck Hank, and justly so) and paused.....there were numerous mentions of "It's darker"....I was worried- did that mean it wasn't funny anymore? Was Hank being turned into a deep thinking brooding assassin? Were there going to be pages and pages of self reflection after some murders?Thank goodness it's just more Hard Luck Hank goodness! I think the reviewer before who rated the content divided by violence, sex etc did a pretty accurate job. It's humourous, it's action packed, more and more things happen to Hank, even though it's not his fault, and Mr Campbell ends the book with a twist I certainly did not expect which opens the door to more advanced technology, and uncharted adventures for Hank and the friends.I thoroughly recommend the Hard Luck Hank books and can't wait for volume 3. I want it yesterday!

I've bought and read about a dozen of his books and I can honestly say that I've enjoyed most of them. The storylines are not always original but they are usually well thought out, well paced and have reasonable character development. Guardian Glass is no different and while normally I'd be the first to say I'd like another in the series, Mr Nuttall has so many different series' going on that I'd like him to focus a bit more on some of the others, such as Bookworm.Nuttall is one of my favourite authors and I'm waiting for the next one to pop out.

I have enjoyed this Reawakening series and was lucky enough to only discover it last year, so I got to read sevral volumes one after another, rather than only every few months as you wait for the next one. While I have enjoyed the series, I was disappointed with the last quarter of Master Mage. Without given away soo much in spoilers, it leaves a few unanswered questions, and I felt the epilogue time jumped too far, which again lead to some unanswered questions and unresolved issues. This novel reads like a final book in this series, which is why I have this opinion. If it is not, then some of my disappoiintment isn't justified.If you have been reading the series, I recommend this volume to give yourself some closure. But I have to agree with "Amazon Customer" that it isn't really the author's best work. I think it is 3.5 stars, but because I liked the rest of the series, I'm rounding up to 4 stars

Having read all three of Mr Weinberg's books, it's pretty clear his genre is the anti hero- the self centred immature idiot who happens to have too much power. I was really hoping for the third book in his Psych Investigation series, but this will do as a replacement, for now. I think it takes a special mind to imagine such idiotic thoughts and self image such as Sehn, and Weinberg continues to do it very well.  Read Questing Sucks. You'll laugh. You'll cry, You'll cheer for the heroes. You'll moan at Sehn's antics.As a side note, Mr Weinberg is 24 years old, quite young. I have a feeling he got bored and wanted to take a different tangent and the result is Questing Sucks. I suspect Psych series was getting too serious and he wanted to maintain the idiotic personality apsect longer.

Bought these because of the good reviews. Was looking for underwear which extended down the thigh a bit to help reduce chaffing. Found these and have since bought 6. They are good for travel, as you can wash and dry them in a few hours each night, reducing the number you need to carry, and so far seem durable. There is a slight complaint, but it is personal and to be honest, a little embarrassing, but it is why I give it 4 stars, and not 5

This novella details how Riddick began his path to become the cool badas* that we all love. Anyone who has seen the second Riddick movie might believe that Riddick became the Furyan who Killed the Necromoonger half god because he was the last one left after Furya was wiped out and had to develop survival skills, but this book shows that was only the first in a series of events.Ghosts of Furya begins Fifteen years after Furyan civilisation is destroyed, Earth sends a squad of Marines to Furya to find out what happened to Furya, and if the Necromongers are a threat to Earth. The squad, by accident, stumbles across a Furyan teenage male who is like a solitary Tarzan, except without the family of apes, and then later, a Water Elemental who, via her skills with calculating probabilities, decides to leave the Furyan with the squad and, as they tend to do, says some cryptic words, which, we, with hindsight and some sci fi smarts, know that it means the squad is later going to have a bad day, but they will somehow put Riddick on the path of the Necromonger prophecy.They name the boy Riddick, and get him enrolled to become a US Marine. It seems Earth is still much as it is today- divided into countries, with the US providing the main muscle in space.Three years later, he has nearly finished his Marine training, and it seems everyone hates him- his fellow cadets, his Sergeant, and the General in Charge. Only the original squad who found him treat him decently. I have to admit this hatred seems quite far fetched to me. Riddick really doesn't have a single friend there? Just because he is a better combatant- better coordination, healing, combat skills, ability to anticipate?In any case, he stumbles across two of his fellow cadets raping a 12 year old girl, and kills one and badly injures the other defending the girl. He returns the girl to her home, and is, of course, subsequently framed for the rape of the girl, in order for the General to have him taken into his custody to be dissected and experimented on. The original squad members come to his rescue, and just before he and the squad leader, whom he has always had a romantic crush on, make it to the space ship, they are ambushed, and she, the squad leader, dies. Riddick makes it into space, knowing that he can never return to Earth, upset with the loss of the love of his life.So there you have it. Riddick - origins,  Born on Furya, designed on Earth, subsequent updating of Riddick 2.0 plus in the Milky Way Galaxy ^_^

Usually I give a wordy review on the good and the bad. This timeI'll just say  It's short in length, has a straight forward Star Trek type plot and is resolved reasonably quickly after a minor bit of action.I feel it's 3.5 stars, but I'll round it up to 4 to be nice.Titan is really not doing justice to the type of tactical genius Riker is supposed to be.

Like the previous 23 reviewers, I thoroughly enjoyed this Voyager novel by Beyer. After all the political drama of the Typhon Pact, it's good to see at least one book getting back to the basic premise of Star Trek- to go where no one has gone before. And do they ever. It's not possible to elaborate without giving the plot away, so I won't.But I will confess to being slightly puzzled by the lack of mention of the assassination of the Federation President. Surely this would have affected and stunned the crew.I also have a prediction. Tom and Bellana will win, because when Tom's bad history gets brought up, it will backfire on the "accuser" (who shall remain nameless, so as to not make too big a spoiler).Overall it's a fluidly written and paced book with new lifeforms and new civilisations. It brings back a memory of TNG's very first episode, where after dealing with Farpoint, Picard says- let's see what this Galaxy Class starship can do......except now, they have this mind bogglingly fast Slipstream drive...let's see what this Slipstream drive can do!...Andromeda, here we come? ;-)

I have to agree with most of the reviewers here. The final installment of The Fall has no real bang, even though there is some plot and there is some real character of the Cardassian doctor and "Ishun".  The final nail in the coffin for the aggressive interim Federation President also seems, to me, quite contrived and out of left field. I don't think it was really necessary, given there was the logical and obvious link between him and the True way and setting up the death of previous Federation president (which is itself was a poorly written plot- anyone with a brain could tell "security" as anything but)At least it ends with Starfleet returning "To boldly go where no one has gone before". I've had enough of Federation politics. Let's get back to the adventures of interstellar exploration.

I was surprised to see another book out so soon, and I was even more surprised to see this is the final book of the series! Many authors keep fleshing out their cashcows until people get sick out them,I was happy with this book for many reasons. Some you may agree with, some you may not.- Sandra is gone and Jasmine is in. I found Sandra to be quite annoying and unlikeable after she gained her superpowers.- There is less wholesale slaughter of his troops than usual. (I never liked how tens of thousands of those following him always seemed to perish with little concern. In fact, he seemed more concerned when those dying were non human)- I thought Mr Larson wrote a well rounded, well thought out book which left no real loose ends as far as Kyle and his fight with the Macros are concerned-->, Kyle throws off the yoke of Emporership, gives humanity a chance of becoming unified and peaceful, removes their greatest enemy, reclaims his long lost and sometimes yearned for pre-invasion home life at his old house, albeit with a new wife and child.  There is scope for a new series, but it's not because of some untidy or deliberately open ended finish.- There were some unexpected surprises which spiced up the book. I actually wrote about six lines of them here before deciding to delete them. I know I wrote there are spoilers, but some of the enjoyment comes from discovering some of these for yourself, right? You already know most of the players at this stage of the series, but just go along for the ride.II enjoyed the First book the most, and I regard this one as the second best. Again, this is just my opinion, I'm sure others have their own likes and dislikes. But I'm reasonably sure we all had a good time :)

The poisoned chalice was a book I couldn't put down. All the main characters in titan had a role to play, which was good for their character development,instead of always seeming to be top heavy (in my opinion) and there is considerable political intrigue,mixed with some action. In fact it lays the foundation of a possible intrigue and clandestine storylines in the future.I only had two issues. The first is that it was unnecessary for akaar to keep ruler in the dark.One could argue that it was necessary so riker would take the initiative. But I do not believe that to be true. The second plot weakness was at the end when ruler confronted the main villain and all he did was, as anjar said, was beat his chest. The way ruler left akaar and his wife, I had expected him to pull a rabbit out of his hat, so that was both disappointing and a little out of character.One thing I got out of the poison ed chalice was that it doesn't matter what system of government you have, there's always people who will try to abuse their power, and there always needs to be those who will do what is right and decent. Many people think they are right, but rarely does integrity and decency enter their justifications. The federation is only a few weeks away from possibly electing a militant petty power hungry dictator. Let's see what the next generation crowd can do to set things back on the right path.

I bought this phone after losing several this year forced me to use a 2 year old smartphone which is too slow for today's apps (much like how a decade ago we used to buy a new computer due to increase in speed and software). I've only had it for 5 days but in that time I've found it a perfect fit. As you probably know, there are two sides to this phone- a mobile phone with 4.3 inch touchscreen on one side, and a 24-240mm zoom camera on the other side.Phone: - Works like most android phones and it was easy to get used to it even though my last 3 phones have been Sony's. In fact there are some good differences, such as wrapping the 5 main screens- when you reach the end of one side, you can keep flicking the same direction and it just goes the the other side. On Sony, you had to flick the reverse direction once you reached the end of one side. All apps work well, such as internet, whatsapp, games, searching camera albums, setting alarms (which is not under "alarms", but is a seperate tab under the icon "clock", and S calender.Camera: - When I show people the phone, their first reaction is that it's big and thick. The general public is not knowledgable about the more technical aspects of cameras so don't understand how powerful and useful this lens is. Although thick for a smartphone, this is not just a smartphone. It is a fully integrated highly featured compact camera with a very useful wide angle of 24mm (in 35mm aspect) which can zoom up to 240mm (in 35mm aspect). This is a far cry from the usual 28-105mm you'd normally see on most compact cameras, or even most zoom lenses for expensive DSLR's. Being attached to a smartphone, you get a 4.3 inch LCD screen to view things, which again is vastly larger than the 2.7-3 inch you see on 99% of today's digital camerasI find the added depth useful for a good solid grip so it's stable for photo taking.On the weekend I took about 390 photos and the results have been sharp, colourful and the zoom range has allowed me to capture a range of photos I wouldn't have otherwise with most cameras. For those who are a little more technically in the know, at 24mm there is distortion at the corners which is quite pronounced, and the f stops go from 3.1 at 24mm to 6.3 at 240mm. Because of the small sensor and the f stops, it is obviously not going to give you perfect noise free photos in the dark. But for the day, it is a superb amalgam of camera and phone. There are a large number of options to apply filters, to have manual settings for shutter speed and apeture, white balance, multiple frames per second and so on. You can choose to have the camera remember these options or reset to default each time you turn it on and off.  I usually leave it on auto, as it's the most convenient for me at this stage. With my other more sophisticated cameras, I usually change settings more often, and they are easier to change as the S4 zoom requires some digging into the menus.The camera is reasonably quick to turn on from time out compared to most compact cameras. What you do is turn the camera on, then press the on/off button on the side, which is also the standby button, Then when you swipe the log back in screen, it wil go straight to the camera and turn it back on. There is no button or icon on the unlock screen so this is the only way I've found.Obviously the photos you take can then be sent to Facebook, your online photo albums, shared with friends via social app like whatsapp etc without having to transfer photos from camera to computer to phone.Battery life is surprisingly good for a mobile phone. I was able to take about 200 photos with battery going to 55% charge. 40 of the photos were with flash. Another time I took about 170 photos and the battery went to 60%.I've found this to be a versatile setup for me so far. I'm going to Bangkok very soon and expect it will continue to be my all in one device for a while (until the next best gadget comes along ^_^ )I've become paranoid about losing my phone so I've attached a wrist strap to it. I even have a pouch which I attached to my shoulder strap of my backpack and always loop the wriststrap on first before taking it out- the strap dangles out for this reason. Yeah I know- too much detail! heheThanks for reading my wordy review about this fun and useful camera phone !Edit 30th November 2013=======================I's like to expand on both the phone and camera.**Phone:I've had no problems using the phone. Everything goes from screen to screen quickly. Internet pages upload quickly. There have been no freezing mentioned in other reviews. Calls are clear and loud. My dislikes are minor, like when you pull down from the top of the screen I'd like "mobile data" to be on the first 5 icons at the top rather than flicking to the next 5- be nice to be able to customise this- WiFi and Mobile data are the two buttons on this screen I use most. And for customisation- on main screens, the "apps" icon is always on the bottom left- again be nice to be able to change this.** Camera: The camera continues to perform well. When I said above that it was a fully featured and integrated camera, I didn't say how it was so. In terms of features- you can go to manual mode and you can change exposure, shutter speed and aperture. You can do multi burst, and apply filters, though if you use filters or multi burst, it will take 2-4 seconds to process the photos.Other uses I've found for the zoom lens are: superior ability to compose photos, superior portraits using longer zoom lengths and smoother bokeh (out of focus blurriness), I've been to conferences and used the zoom to get closer in to take photos of slides, and of course, better ability to take occasional candid photos of little kids who are always squirming around.The wider angle 24mm instead of 28-32mm usually seen on most mobile phones, makes it superb for selfies. You can see the whole of your upper half of your body, instead of just your face.One surprise is a very well made and sturdy rotating ring around the zoom lens. If you are using the phone and then turn this ring, a new screen will appear with a heap of options- shooting modes like macro, or viewing the gallery etc. I don't really use it but it's interesting and the quality of the ring is very impressive- not wobbly, smooth yet firm, no gaps.That's it for now. It continues to be an ideal phone for me, at this time.Edit 7th Feb 2014=================I'm still using the S4 Zoom and overall I'm quite happy. I continue to use the Zoom as my primary camera for outings during the day and find the wide angle great for capturing more in the photo, while the zoom is very very useable for composing and getting closer to distant objects. Photos remain very sharp, colour is rich and true, and bokeh (out of focus blur) is unusually good for this type of camera (though a true prime lens of s dslr is still far far superior).An example of the life of the battery- it drops from 100% to 50% after I take 200 photos, use mobile data GPS and track my trail using one of the mapping apps over a 4 hour period.I've found the following not-so-goods.- The phone froze twice while taking a photo.- Viewing the photo albums is getting slower now I've got about 9GB of photos on my memory card and camera- Organising photos from the "camera" album into new albums is quirky. The process is relatively instinctive to anyone used to android- click new album, give it a name, the click the photos you want moved and it will put a tick in the corner of each photo selected, and you press done and can drag the all the selected photos into the new album. This part is fine. The problem is that the new album by default goes to the phone memory, regardless of whether memory card or phone os selected as the main memory of the photos of the camera. Thus while trying to organise my photos, I was stuck after 5 new albums because the phone memory got filled up. I also could not find a way to use the phone to move the new albums from phone memory to SD card. I had to hook it up to the computer and do it via windows explorer.- Wide angle at 24mm has disportion at the sides and corners. This doesn't worry me as I'm more interested in getting things into the photo rather than edge to edge sharpness that "professionals" care about.- There is dust inside the zoom lens.Overall it's still my go to camera phone combo for most of my outings and hikes and I like it.Edit 2014 August 11th====================** Selfie Sticks and Bluetooth:On the weekend I was at Hong Kong markets and they now have several types of selfie sticks. In case you don't know, selfie sticks are retractable poles with a handle at one end, which you hold, and a phone holder at the other, which you attach your phone to. By holding the phone further away from you, you can include more in the photo- your friends, the buildings and scenery around you. Because the phone (or small camera) is now beyond your reach, you will need to set the self timer to take the photo. Enterprising souls have introduced a bluetooth remote control- you turn you phone on, activate bluetooth, let the remote control and phone sync, and then you can press the "take the photo" button.Well, things have moved on since this, and at the market there were selfie sticks which have combined the bluetooth remote into the selfie stick handle, so you only need one device, not two. I saw and tried two such sticks. One had just a single button- the shutter button, and the other had four buttons- on/off, one for zoom in, one for zoom out, and one for shutter-take photo.BOTH versions do not work for the S4 Zoom, and I assume may not work for the K Zoom.When I synced the stick to my phone, the following happened. For the single button stick, pressing it made the zoom lens zoom in. That's it.For the multiple button selfie stick, pressing the shutter button made it zoom in, pressing zoom in made it focus.Looks like it's the basic selfie stick and self timer for S4 Zoom users.** General update:I'm still using the S4. The following issues have happened. The gallery is very slow opening. When you press it from main screen, it may take 3 to 10 seconds to open. Then when you press "camera" for photos taken by the camera, it make take another 3 to 10 seconds. I assume the phone memory is filled up but I can't find where the alleged 3.48GB of photos and videos are.I've dropped the phone multiple times and despite the dents and cracks, it's still going strong.

It's been a while since we've seen Julian Bashir in the main chair of a novel. He's been moping around for a couple of Star Trek years now, and he's been given the chance to finally do what he feels passionate about- to help people. In this case, it's to prevent the extinction of the Andorians.  Long story short- Bashir and Thar are the main characters who work tirelessly to construct a cure for the Andorian's upcoming extinction and battle petty hardline politicians from both the Federation and Andor. Ironically, even the Tholians appear to be nicer people than the Andorian political hardliners.The end is somewhat predictable, but it's a ride getting there, and good to see good triumph over evil.So far, The Fall series is 2 good books for 3, which is not bad for Star Trek.ps: I was worried about the ending for Julian, but I later realised that Section 31 could get him out pretty easily if they wanted to. That means we haven't heard the last of him, I think :)

It had a lot of good reviews so I bought it to try it.I  found it reduced my knee pain better than the Futuro Sport knee strap I bought at the same time. I have no idea why they do or do not work, only how it felt to me. If I were to buy another, it'd be the Mueller oneIn addition to the knee strap, other things I've bought to help with my knee which have helped are Vibram five finger shoes (the ugly looking shoe with 5 toes at the end instead of a nice round end) and crocs (nice and soft soles)

It had a lot of good reviews so I bought it to try it. Unfortuneantely it didnt do much when I used it. I also bought the Mueller Jumper's knee strap and found it reduced my knee pain better. I have no idea why they do or do not work, only how it felt to me. If I were to buy another, it'd be the Mueller one

I've been on the hunt for the best carry all for day hiking for quite a while now. The other day I passed by this and decided to give it a go. How much better would it be if I could keep my back free and airy!The problem with impulse buys is that you don't know what else you could have gotten. Once I got home, I searched amazon for other lumbar packs and it seems the Talon 8 isn't top of the pile. Were they right? Is High Sierra really the best of the best?Let me say that off hand, it seems very well made. Typical brand name quality. Material is top nothc. I really doubt anything will break unless I take a chainsaw to it. However, even though nothing is likely to break, there are two phyicial flaws. One is the often mentioned thin belt strap. The other are the zippers. For this price, I expect zippers which move along the teeth seamlessly. On my one they feel sticky and for me to pull it completely on the track from one end to the other I need to use my other hand to hold the other end.I've used it twice. First time, I loaded it with 2 x 1.5L bottles of Evian water, a t shirt, mini towel, wallet and mobile and went for a half hour walk. Although the bottles are far higher than the top rim of the bottle pockets, the adjustable string kept them firmly in place. Did it feel heavy? Yes. Did they tilt backwards? Yes, but it still felt firm against my back. Did the thin front strap dig into me? Kind of, but I added something extra- a camera pouch, which I clipped over the front lumbar pack strap. This possibly added some thickness to it, thus reducing the cutting into the tummy effect. I was wearing exactly what I'd take on a hike, if I were to hike with this pack. Obviously I can't run with it, since the bottles would bounce like crazy, but it seemed doable.Second time, I went cycling for 2 hours. This time, I used the included Osprey 650ml water bottles, towelette, mobile, wallet, tshirt. The side pockets are quite spaacious- far more spacious than I've seen for dozens of backpakcs with waist ties/belts. In these, I put x2 energy bars, and my mobile as well in the left one. No problem with space, easy access to the bars. There was no sign of any wear or tear.So is this a good lumbar pack? In all honesty, I'm disappointed in it because of it's price. I paid USD$70 for the Talon 8. 2 weeks ago, I went to Home Japan store and bought a bum bag for USD$8 (yes, eight) and it had lots of space, side hip pockets, and zippers were smooth as silk. The only things missing were high density cloth materials used by Osprey, and bottle holding pockets. I definitely did not get $80 of value over the Home Japan bumbag. Still, I can't wait to use it on a longer hike- maybe it'll be worth it in the long run.

Fantastic. Absolutely fantastic. Although the Enterprise is on the cover, don't think this novel is all about the TNG crew. Yes, Picard and Worf are there, but they are merely minor characters in this dramatic novel which stars a cast of Cardassians, foremost of whom is Elim Garak, former Obsidion Order member, tailor, Dominion War hero, and now Ambassador to the Federation.This novel shows us what makes a good book- it's the storytelling and fleshing out characters, be they human or otherwise. IT is clear the author has put some thought into thinking out the layout of a city hitherto unknown to us in much detail, and some components of it's society. I believe that Una has done such a good job that there is potential for a spin off for each of the 3, possibly 4, Cardassian main characters. The author has done such a good job in making each one a solid character who the reader can get into.Should you read this latest installment of Star Trek novels? A resounding yes!ps: I'm going to copy Garak's way of ending personal letters - readers will know what I mean ^_^
This is the same as their other stuff. Its just re-branded. Its all totally FAKE. I used their first product and it was terrible. I don't know what was in it, but it definitely wasn't cassava.

This is a great, natural way to boost your appearance and help your skin maintain its youthfulness. Linguistic scholar John McWhorter rants on the Sapir-Whorf  hypothesis that claims that the world appears different depending on the language one uses to think in.  Whorf, the fire insurance investigator, not the Klingon, noticing back in the 1930's that the Hopi language lacked modifiers and nouns for time and  tense, concluded  that  the Hopi language imbued a different world view from that of English speaking Americans.  Other extensions of this idea  argue that the richness of a language wrt conceptual terms regarding  number,  colour or snow will reflect how how speakers of that language understand/conceptualize the world differently.McWhorter's objection is that the real difference is culture, not language, and that all human beings are capable of seeing the world in the same way.  Grudgingly he admits that  neo-Whorfians have succeeded in illustrating small effects; what he opposes is granting these differences a larger significance.  The first example (pp7-9) involves cognition and categorization.  Stanford  psychologist Lera Boroditsky noted that Russian has  no simple word for pure blue, rather goluboj for a light blue and siniy for a darker navy.  Russian speakers were able to match squares corresponding to their colour words 1/8th of a second faster than squares that did not.  The same experimenter  noted that  in Mandarin time before/after mapped onto up/down, where as in English it was conceptualized as a left/right sequence.  Mandarin speakers tested on a vertical array of buttons  were  170 milliseconds faster than English speakers  whereas English speakers are 300 msec faster when using a horizontal arrangement.  (pp26-27)  (No comment from either that this may not be linguistic rather a reflection of how each group reads text, which seems  more plausible.)While  dismissing these difference as inconsequential  McWhorter doesn't  justify his conclusion, which could make one skeptical of  the arguments that follow.  Most tasks  involve both concentration  and compound judgements.  Episodic memory is only a couple of seconds long, so a difference between 1.1 and 1.224 seconds per assessment could cumulatively be significant.  It would be reasonable to consider  that we prefer  patterns of thought that would allow us to  process information  entirely within that  duration.The book certainly is interesting in its anecdotes.  That the Tuyuca of the Amazon mark sentences using evidential markers based on whether the topic was seen, heard, deduced or heard third hand or that the Nasioi of New Guinea have over 200 different word genders, South American Saramaccans can say one has "more"  of something than another, but there is no word for less.The bte noire of the book is Alfred Bloom who observed  that Chinese is relatively free of tense and gender marker, yet the Chinese appear no less capable of  thinking  about  these matters than any other culture.  However monolingual Chinese speakers appear less willing to consider abstract as opposed to concrete counterfactuals compared to Chinese who spoke more than one language, indicating that multiple languages gave people an enhanced perspective.  Another argument against is that  many different cultures speak English, yet they exhibit differences in interests and values.  If  language determines culture one would expect greater similarity than is observed.McWhorter doesn't do as well when he admits that people who don't have terms for X, don't discuss X, but can still conceptualize about it, but this is not so obviously true.  It is perhaps a major  point of the Whorfian hypothesis that societies create terms and differentiate  them with  meaning  to be used as building blocks for grander ideas.  In a real sense this is what higher education does, initiating students with subject  related jargon and accompanying perspectives in order to provide them tools for thought.  And in the book's concluding chapter he embraces the very Whorfian notion that language can reinforce both sexism and racism, which we need to think about to circumvent.  One comes away feeling that the  real  objection is that Whorfism might lead to politically incorrect conclusions that other cultures are somehow less capable rather than different than our own.  But is that the fault of the hypothesis or its misapplication?It was an  enjoyable read, not too long (or too big) but not as convincing as the author would have liked.  Highly recommended for a book club or discussion group.

A well written survey of archeological findings and deductive techniques used in the region, complemented by useful reference maps (pages 19 and 46) and a timelines  that mark ages from lower Palaeolithic to the late Islamic.  There's an emphasis on dating techniques, especially pottery styles whose difference in composition and manufacture demonstrate linkages to other areas, esp. Egypt and Babylonia, both of which, unlike ancient Palestine,  recorded astronomic events.  Though the Exodus is uncorroborated Rast does mention several affirming reports of events from the era of Kings 1 and 2, including finds of  red burnished Syrian pottery corresponding to the time of King David's expedition to the north.  Another interesting comment is that artifacts found in the less fertile hilltops indicate that very first settlers in the hilltops were Israelites and the conquest of the Canaanites of the valleys were conquered later, which I thought strategically similar to the placement  of Jewish communities  east of the Green Line.About 2/3rds of the book covers prehistory and the split between the Northern and Southern Kingdoms, followed by a short summary of the Greek and Persian eras. A common thread is how the introduction of new technology such as clay containers for storing and transporting food stuffs, coinage for trade, waterproof plaster for cisterns  and the invention of iron implements for agriculture changed diet, longevity and encouraged the growth of larger cities.  Roman roads improved transportation  and aqueducts meant that towns did not need to be located as close to springs.  Coverage of the Byzantine and Islamic periods is  brief, limited to 15 pages,  but  adequately illustrates the relationship between  Christian and Jewish communities by referencing the  relative mix  of synagogues and churches, the former more common  to the west of the Jordan river than the east.If you are planning a trip to the area and are interested in archeological sites, Rast's book would be an excellent source to bring with you  if you looking for suggestions of historical interest.  Having  visited several times I  can recommend Meggido,  Hazor, Ein Gedi, Banias, Ir David  and Beit Guvrin, but there were several such as Taanach, Lachish, Dor, Balata and the tells (archaeological digs)  of Ashkelon and Beersheva that I was unaware of.  The book's organization appears similar to that of the Rockefeller Museum, a personal favourite,  a short walk east  along Rehov Suleiman from  Herod's Gate just outside Jerusalem's old City.  Its  sections are  organized clockwise around a central courtyard from prehistory to the present,  neatly illustrating the progression of regional development.Recommended.

A revealing and wry  insiders account of Israeli diplomacy and foreign policy beginning from  the first days of the State up until the conclusion of  the peace treaty with Egypt.  A protégé of Israel's first foreign minister Moshe Shertock,  he was hired  partly on the basis of being to speak French and the fact that he owned a suit, though it becomes  obvious that analytic intelligence was also a factor.  One of the first tasks of the new Ministry was to send telegrams to various nations sending out requests for recognition.  The first problem - getting the local  post office to recognize the Ministry itself in order buy the postage on credit.Fortuitously Rafael was posted to Brussels during the cold war,  a posting he thought relatively minor until  Shertock  pointed out that this was the political heart of the new Common Market and thus essential for Israeli trade relations, which turned out to be the case.  What fascinates  are the multitude of unexpected insights into intricacies of world politics, ranging from the non-aligned movement to Soviet machinations,  the decline of French and British power in the modern era and of course the strategic considerations of Nasser and Sadat with respect to Israel and the Arab world.  Russia in particular played a triple game in India, Europe and the Middle East,  exhorting against imperialism which extending it's own influence and empire, feigning diplomatic thrusts at Suez while maintaining an iron grip in Hungary being a well known example.  Excellent portraits of Middle East Envoy Joseph  Sisco, Secretary of State William P. Rogers  and British Prime Ministers Bevin, Wilson and Heath, but not a very complete view of Kissinger, Carter or Peres.  Rabin comes off  blandly - whereas Golda was in her element with the  loose coalition of socialist leaders on the left,  Rabin was more influenced by his American diplomatic experience and tended to hold back.  Readers may also be interested in Rafael's discourse on the internal differences between Israeli political figures such as  Ben-Gurion, Golda  Meir, Abba Eban, Moshe Dayan and Prime Minister Levi Eshkol  along with an assessment of each of their styles.Often it's the little touches that both bemuse and enlighten, though perhaps exaggerate.  Who knew that it was a 7 point  Israeli  proposal to the Chinese negotiator in a meeting with UN Secretary General Tryge Lie that resolved the Korean War , or that  it was Israel's abstention on Libya based on a suggestion by Iraq that got it admitted to the UN, or when  Syrian  team  at the UN couldn't find their own town of Quneitra on the map, asking "where is that god forsaken place"  was an Israeli who  laconically pointed it out, the response being a stupefied double take at where the information had come from.A bit plodding on the subject of the 6 Day War but one does get  the reasons for Israel's pre-emptive urgency,  one factor being the unintended consequence French  sudden volte face as Israel's primary arms supplier coupled with the rapid transfer of Russian weaponry and Nasser's ill advised dismissal of UNEF and the blocking of the Straits of Tiran to Israeli shipping.  There are some newish observations regarding the '73 war, in particular that Israeli reassurances to the Arabs that they would not launch a  attack on suspicious Syrian and Egyptian troop movement signaled naivité and weakness rather than good will.  During the war, at least until the end, Rafael served in the Golan in combat, rather than in the diplomatic corps, but we do get a real sense of the underlying need for logistics and supply - had the US not airlifted a massive amount of material it is likely the outcome of that war would have been much grimmer.Overall assessment 4.6/5,  a worthy addition/reference to any library on the history of middle eastern diplomacy, with many considerations that apply in the present.  Just as one should look at Secret Channels: The Inside Story of Arab-Israeli Peace Negotiationsby Mohammed Haykal for an assessment of Egypt's thinking during this period,  Rafael's memoir  is also an invaluable reference on the Israeli range of views.  A downside - it's an  autobiography, there's an index at the back but no corroborating references or bibliography; otherwise a  very engaging read.  Recommended.

It is rare to find a book that so perfectly captures its moment in time.  Bartley Crum was one of 6 Americans appointed by President Harry S Truman to the 12  man 1945 Anglo-American  Commission, charged with forming a resolution the problem of Jewish refugees still held in Europe combined with the then deteriorating situation in Palestine  The Commission set up a series of hearings in Washington,  London,  Cairo, Damascus and  Jerusalem, finally retiring to seclusion in  Lausanne Switzerland to write a final set of recommendations.  Between London and Cairo they manage to break up into smaller ground and review the situation in the DP camps on the continent.Crum  is straightforward in his sympathies as is his assessment of the political realities.  In overwhelming numbers,  he reports, almost without exception, the  remnants of  European Jewry held in displaced persons camps want to go to Palestine.  Europeans have  rejected them, leaving, often wanting,  them to die.  Their communities no longer exist.  They no longer wish to leave their fate  in the hands of others.  To a large extent he comes to  agree with the assessment of Professor Albert Einstein,  who's testimony takes place in Washington. (pp25)  Britain's  main interest is to maintain it's empire, and to do so it has done in Palestine what it has done in India - aligned itself with the ruling landed class who wish to maintain their position of privilege.In addition to Einstein there's quite an assemblage of dramatis personae.  For the  Arabs this includes  historians Philip Hitti and Albert Hourani, a protégé of  the wife of George Antonius,  Hassan al-Banna, the founder of the Muslim Brotherhood,  a representative of King Feisal who claimed that the King did not understand what he was signing vis a vis the Feisal-Weizmann agreement - in spite of an Arabic copy with an addendum written in his own hand; and  Jamal al Husseini (Ch 11), the political right hand of the infamous Grand Mufti of Jerusalem, Hajj Amin al Husseini who demurs that his cousin only consorted with the Nazis to get the best deal for the Arabs in case Germany won the war.Crum knows better.  Previously, while in Nuremberg (Ch 6) he reads through a dossier on the Mufti.  In it is a series of letters to Himmler,  Von Ribbentrop and the heads of State in Nazi Europe  requesting that Jews not be allowed to escape Europe and that Jewish children be sent to Poland for "active supervision" , which Crum recognizes as a euphemism for the gas chambers.Jamal's vision is pan-Arabic, one Arab unbroken nation united in Arab culture and language starting from the Atlas Mountains in the east, encompassing the Levant, Egypt Arabia.  It's also seen as public posturing.  In contrast Dr. Mohammed Fadel Jamali from Iraq sees Palestine as his country's  natural coastline.  However the most compelling Arab testimony is not made in front of the committee but in personal meetings with Crum at the King David.  One is from an unnamed member of the Nashashibi clan who asserts that Hajj Amin had consolidated his power in the 1920s and 1930s by murdering hundreds of his Arab opponents, including the murder of  Fakhri Nashashibi in 1941 Baghdad by agents of the Mufti.  He indicated that a satisfactory resolution would be an Jewish State in the western part of the Mandate, and an extension of Jordanian rule in the eastern section, hopefully rid of the Husseinis, as his clan had always gotten along with King Abdullah and the Hashemites.  He asked to remain nameless indicating that his own life would be forfeit if it were revealed.  Another was Crum's chauffeur, a Christian Arab from Jerusalem who stated that the future of Christians in the Holy Land would be better if it was under the Jews.Contrast this with the position of the US State Department and that of the British.  Early on he's cautioned by Evan Wilson, an attaché working for the State Department, that the primary concern of  both countries is courting Arab opinion to keep them out of Soviet hands.  Crum finds this unnecessarily obsequious as was the Allied response Arab threats to side with the Nazis - one would hardly expect that either regime would tolerate either Islam or the Arab oligarchy for very long.  In reviewing both the formation of Trans-Jordan and the declaration of the 1939 Peel Commission  he finds that both violate the spirit and legality of the original Mandate.  The British are also demanding that the Jewish Haganah turn in their arms and disband,  a recipe for suicide.Much ink and many pixels of layered analysis have flowed under the bridge since, but IMV this is an unparalleled account of how the A-I conflict was argued by a wide range of opinion at the time.  As many of the witnesses reported, the friction was largely generated by British and Arab interests at the top.  Though Crum's report and that of the committee was largely neglected, one senses in it a foreshadowing of Truman's final formulation of US policy.  (And there's a wonderful Truman quote near the beginning that truly reveals his attitude towards his Presidency.)
