It doesn't shy away from talking about the real issues that happened during this time.My favorite character is Mr.Caproni (Stanley Tucci) a historical Italian aircraft designer who is Jiro's mentor in his dreams. I enjoy Stanley's voice acting skills. He's one of those character actors who is fantastic at everything he does. The character himself is fascinating. He looks at aircraft not as a bringer of war, but a creator of dreams.My favorite scene is the last dream sequence, after Jiro goes through a life changing experience. This is one of those bitter sweet endings, where you don't know what to think at first. You just need to take it all in.The message in this film is, "Sometimes the outcome to your dream is not always what you expect." Jiro spends his whole life wanting to make his aircraft, determined to do anything to fulfill his goal. After a few sacrifices, he realizes his potential but it's not what he expects. Mr. Caproni then asks him, "Did you have a good ten years?"I give this 5 out of 5 stars and recommend it to 11 to 18-year-olds. This film shows people smoking and deals with serious issues of the time. This is a must see film!Reviewed by Keefer B, KIDS FIRST Film Critic. For more youth reviews go to kidsfirst.org.

This movie creates a touching new twist on a story that might have come across as corny, but doesn't. Mr. Saajan (Irrfan Khan), a retiring accountant, is grieving over the death of his wife and Lla (Nimrat Kaur), a young mother, desires more attention from her husband. Lla sends her husband a special lunchbox and, by accident, the lunchbox is delivered to Mr. Saajan instead. Realizing the meal was misdirected, Lla writes a letter, places it inside the next day's lunchbox and what unfolds are sincere and beautiful messages that changes their lives.The plot's not unique, but the writers produce an atmosphere in this script that sets it apart. Shot in Mumbai City, India, we roam through the streets and are allowed to observe the people, their traditions, their homes and their work establishments. The dialog is in English much of the time but at times in Hindu with English subtitles which immerses you further into the culture. Irrfan and Nimrat's characters have their own stories that are spectacular to watch and, once these characters start writing to each other, we see a whole new side to both.My favorite character is Mr. Saajan. Khan creates this man who reaches out to someone who he does not even know. His role is heartbreaking to see and you feel the emotions he is experiencing. For anyone who has lost a loved one, you can really identify with his emptiness.My favorite scene is when Mr. Saajan is watching a show that his wife had taped. He remembers watching her and watching the show that made her laugh. You see his face change as he understands the joy she got from the comedy. We see how, a moment that brought joy in the past can still bring joy now, only in a different way.The message in this story is, “Sometimes the wrong train can bring you to the right station.” Lla is unsure what to do when she realizes the lunchbox is going to a perfect stranger. Mr. Saajan is not sure what to do when the notes start to touch his heart. So they both feel they are on the wrong train.I give this 5 out of 5 stars and recommend this to age 11 to 18. There is use of cigarettes and subject matter that is not appropriate for younger audiences. Check it out to see what I'm talking about. Keefer B., KIDS FIRST! Film Critic. . For more reviews, go to kidsfirst dot org.

If you are a family film lover like me, then you'll love "Wide Awake." It's a wonderful family film that deals sensitively, and even with humor, with a fairly unusual situation for the screen: a 9-year-old's struggles with his faith in God.In this movie a young boy learns lessons about life and God during a trying year of discovery in fifth grade at a Catholic boys' school. As the school year opens, Joshua Beal (Joseph Cross) is sad over the recent death of his grandfather (Robert Loggia) . On his first day at school, Joshua is harassed by the class bully. Because his grandfather played football, Joshua tries out for the school team, over the objections of his parents (Dana Delaney and Denis Leary), two physicians who don't like the risk of injury. But Joshua is not very athletic and does not make the team. Joshua continues to seek answers from God about his grandfather, so his teacher, Sister Terry (Rosie O'Donnell) advises him to approach a cardinal who is coming to visit the nearby girls' school. Joshua meets a young girl at the school and falls for her. As the year goes by, Joshua continues his quest for spiritual answers and finds them in unexpected places, such as a winter snowstorm.The main characters are Joshua Beal (Joseph Cross), Mrs.Beal (Dana Delany), Sister Terry  (Rosie O'Donnell), Neena Beal (Julia Stiles), grandfather Beal (Robert Loggia) and Mr.Beal  (Denis Leary).I like this movie because of that way that it is structured, meaning the way that it is put together, the characters seem as if they already knew each other for a very long time.I would recommend this movie to kids age 5 to 12 but, it's really a family movie that parents would enjoy as well. I give this movie 4  out of 5 stars because some of the music doesn't go well with the scenes.Reviewed by Valdi B., KIDS FIRST! Film Critic

This is an animated action thrill ride. Marvel heroes Ironman (Adrian Pasdar) and Hulk (Fred Tatasciore) battle a new villain named Zzzax (Dee Bradley Baker). However these two Characters have a long road ahead of them to become an unstoppable team.What is very unique about this film is the animation. When an action scene happens we see fantastic effects, like the dust when a character falls. They have bright blues and reds in this and it’s electrifying.  The writing is comic book style, we have the hero say a witty remark then, they fight, only to say another witty remark. It brings audiences back to the good old days of comic book lines and it’s perfect for this setting. The characters are well established.  Whenever you get two well known characters together, you get to experience entertaining interactions.My favorite character is Ironman  / Tony Stark (Adrian Pasdar). He’s a crime fighting, egotistical, billionaire. I enjoy Starks personality - a guy who is so full of himself and yet so likable. Plus when he has the Mark VII Iron suit on he’s a powerful ally.My favorite scene is when Hulk and Ironman battle Zzzax for the last time. This is your big ending battle that every super hero fan looks forward to. It’s everything I dreamed it would be and more. Also to top it all up, Hulk wears an Ironman Suit.The message of the story is, “Two heads are better than one.” Hulk and Tony don’t get along at first and they don’t work well together. Half the time Hulk uses Ironman as a club. Soon they learn that they need to work together to conquer villains.I give it 5 out of 5 stars and recommend this to 5-12 year olds, because the kids will enjoy the action and the funny remarks from the characters. You can call some lines corny, but to me it reminds me of the comics I know and love.Keefer B. KIDS FIRST, Film CriticFor more reviews go to kidsfirst dot org

“Ender’s Game” adapted from the worldwide best selling book by Orson Scott Card is a must see event. 50 years after an alien race tried to colonize earth and millions of lives were lost, the International Military continue to strengthen their forces in hopes to prevent and eliminate any possibility of future attacks. Young children are enlisted in a program that trains them to fight and learn strategies through intensive studies and video-game like activities. The best of the best are then sent off to boot camp in space to be trained to lead and fight in the military. Ender Wiggin (Asa Butterfield) is an extremely gifted boy who is recruited by Colonel Gaff (Harrison Ford). Gaff believes that Ender might be the only hope left for the human race and intends to train him to lead the International Military. Will the fate of the entire earth be too much for young Ender to cope with?I am absolutely in love with this film. Not only is it visually breathtaking in Imax, but it has so many emotional layers that touch on an abundance of issues that surface in our society. First off, the cinematography and CGI is absolutely flawless. I love the design of the Space Camp where the recruits are trained. I also thinks it’s cool that although “Ender’s Game” is very futuristic, they didn’t go overboard with the advanced technology which makes it seem as if these could be things we could see in the future. I really like the fact that there is no obvious makeup on the child actors. Since they are only children and are playing children in the film, the makeup artists kept them natural looking and allows their blemishes to be shown which is something you don’t typically see.This film is so emotionally intense. I honestly was speechless once the film was over. “Ender’s Game” is 2 hours long and I could have sat in that theater for several hours more. One thing that really stood out to me is that this film touches on the topic of sending children off to war and the detrimental effect it has on their emotions. This is a serious issue in our society today because, even though we aren’t sending 12-year-olds off to war, so many of our troops are fresh out of high school and are in no way ready for what they are about to face. This film shows how the effects of war and violence weigh on the children and how they are broken down and built back up into people lacking empathy and emotional stability. It was brought up a lot that if these kids even come home alive, there isn’t much left of them. Another issue that is prevalent in our culture that is also addressed in this film is the fact that realistic, violent video games are completely desensitizing our generation to the very real issues of violence in our world today. In the movie, the kids are trained by “playing” several different war games -from contact strategies on teams, to video game-like exercises that test their ability to control a space fleet. They are playing these “games” and not being able to fully understand how what they’re doing will affect others. I also really enjoy the fact that so many different cultures are represented in this movie. A lot of times we just see films that are centered around the U.S. and our own customs but, “Ender’s Game” really shows how all cultures and ethnic backgrounds are affected in these ways.I like so many characters in this film that it’s hard to pick out one favorite. I obviously loved Asa Butterfield's character, Ender, because he does a ridiculously outstanding job of portraying the complexity of his character. Ender is going through extremely rigorous training that pushes him both physically and emotionally and he has to deal with his own issues of being either too empathetic or too quick to violence. I also really love Bonzo, played by Moises Arias, because I think Moses is a fantastic actor and I’ve only ever seen him in more comedic roles. To see him play such an intense role is really powerful. This film also has some other fantastic young actors such as Abigail Breslin, Hailee Steinfeld, Aramis Knight as well as incredible adult actors such as Harrison Ford, Ben Kingsley and Viola Davis. Overall this film has an outstanding cast and characters.I give “Ender’s Game” 5 out of 5 stars because I feel like words can’t describe this film. It made me laugh. It made me cry. It entertained me while also getting me to think about real world issues. I do however recommend this film for ages 13 to 18. This film is very intense emotionally and visually. There is quite a bit of violence and even though it isn’t over-the-top gory, it is very realistic. This film left a big impact on me emotionally and younger children may not be able to handle that type of intensity. But if you are over the age of 13, I strongly recommend it even if you aren’t necessarily into sci-fi or futuristic films. "Ender’s Game” has so many layers that there is something for everyone, So head to your local theater because “Ender’s Game” is showing in Imax and 3D now!Reviewed by Raven D., KIDS FIRST! Film Critic. For more reviews, go to kidsfirst dot org.

There are about 950,000 species of insects on Earth. This was an amazing movie that lets us see just a few of them in their everyday lives - caterpillars, ladybugs, bees, wasp, butterflies, beetles, snails, grass hoppers, spiders and many more.The cinematography is breath taking. I still wonder how they got a camera tiny enough to fit into an ant colony so we could watch them store food. Watching a spider eat a shrimp under water is head tilting.It is an amazing film which lets you watch insects being born. I never thought of bugs as cute before. Well, maybe a lady bug and I do have a pet preying mantis but, this film actually made me want to pet a few of them. You could actually see that bumble buzzes are cute and fluffy, that snails fall in love and ants like to have clean faces. The birth of the insects is fascinating. They all come from eggs and eat them when they are born. Then they dry off and are ready to play in the world.My favorite scene is watching a butterfly come out of its cocoon.  They are stunning and you get to see every detail of their beautiful wings. I also loved watching the lady bugs take off and fly with their hard, bright red spotted shells and hidden wings for flight.The caterpillars are very cute. There is a large variety of them, all with different faces. Viewing the flowers waking up each morning and how they wrap themselves up for a good night sleep was stunning. I never knew how insects got pollen and now I do.The time lapse photography of watching a Venus fly trap capture a bee is another wow moment in this movie. This is a visual film with the audio being that of the surroundings. Insects don’t really talk so it is all about natural sounds. I recommend this film for ages 4 to 18. I think an audience as young as 4 would love this movie.  It might seem a bit long so I would split it up into a few viewings. For bugs lovers, this is a must see. I give this movie 4  Twinkling Stars.Even though this movie gave me a new prospective on insects and I found them to be incredible I think I will still keep my fly swatter handy.Reviewed by KIDS FIRST! Film Critic Morgan B.For more film reviews, visit kidsfirst dot org.

This movie is amazing! It is pretty scary at times and really cool. It also had a lot of action and suspense, but it also is kind of confusing at times because it switches back and forth through different worlds a lot.This movie is all about a girl named Jane (played by Natalie Portman) who is a scientist and is the girlfriend of Thor (who is played by Chris Hemsworth) who found this place that had a red substance under a rock called the Ether. This substance is absorbed into Jane’s body and whenever someone touches her, the Ether zaps them by using her energy and makes Jane pass out every time. There are these evil elves who are trying to get the Ether to destroy the whole universe. The leader of the elves is Malekith. Now the king (Thor’s farther) advises against going against Malekith but he does it anyway.The main characters in the movie are Thor, Jane, Loki, Malekith, Odin, and Darcy. My favorite character in this movie is Darcy because she is really funny and really cool. She is also pretty amazing to help out to save the world.My favorite part in the movie is when, at the very beginning of the movie, Jane found a building that seemed normal but when she went inside they found out that in the building there are secret passage ways that you can’t see and low gravity, which means that you can pick up a gasoline truck with one finger! Why I like this part so much is because Jane found the Ether under a rock which went into her body and could not be taken out! The weirdest part was that when it went in her body, it seemed like it was 1 minute but it turns out that she was gone for 5 hours!I recommend this movie for ages 11 and up because this movie is pretty scary and pretty intense that I don’t think a younger audience would enjoy it. Go out and see this movie in theaters now!Reviewed by Anthony A., KIDS FIRST! Film Critic.For more film reviews, go to kidsfirst dot org.

You should think twice before you eat that Thanksgiving turkey this year!  Especially after you watch the movie, "Free Birds"!  This is a wonderful animated comedy, packed with lots of action and adventure.  Two turkeys team up to travel back in time to try to take turkey off the Thanksgiving menu for good.  If this doesn't sound funny enough, these two turkeys have nothing in common with each other, argue constantly, and run into some hilarious situations when they travel back to pilgrim days.In order to change the course of history, the turkeys, Reggie (Owen Wilson) and Jake (Woody Harrelson), must first learn to get along and put aside their differences.  Reggie is a smart, although a rather lazy and weak turkey, while Jake is a strong and brave turkey, but very dumb.  This duo makes for some great comedy!  Then a female turkey that Reggie has a crush on makes it even funnier!  This role of Jenny is voiced by the very funny Amy Poehler, which could not have been cast any better. The director, Jimmy Hayward, also directed "Horton Hears a Who!"  He is also known for his work on "Finding Nemo," "Toy Story," "Monsters Inc.," and many more great animated hits.  The soundtrack for "Free Birds" is also great. My favorite scene in this movie is when Jake rescues a bunch of baby turkeys, chicks, from a blazing fire.  These adorable, tiny puffballs are clinging to his feathers, and looking up at this massive hero with huge eyes.  It is just too cute!  "Free Birds" is a family movie that is great for all ages.  I give this movie 5 out of 5 stars.  So don't miss out!  Go see this movie when it opens at theaters near you on Nov. 3rd. Reviewed by Molly J., KIDS FIRST! Film Critic

I loved this film. It takes the classic tale by Hans Christian Anderson and updates it with state-of-the-art 3D animation that truly is magnificent. The ice castle created by Elsa, aka The Snow Queen, is an elaborate form of imagery that exudes elegance. The tale takes a creative leap from the original but still centers on the struggle between good and evil and, in the end, we learn how love overcomes the most dire circumstances. There are some scenes which may be too frightening to your younger viewers such as the giant snow monster the Queen creates to guard her castle. But, for the most part, this is a tale to be shared with your younger children and even pre-teens will enjoy it - particularly the imagery.Youth comments: I expected the movie to be kind of like "Tangled" with a main plot and a long, long quest. Well... I was almost right. "Frozen" is a great movie the whole family should see! The movie has so much to love - comedy, romance, adventure, suspense, thrillers, fantasy and so, so much more. It also teaches us a valuable lesson of not being afraid to show who we are and put our "powers" to a good use.The fun starts when two young royal sisters get into an accident. One has a magical power to summon ice. The magical girl hits her little sister, Anna. She lives but, has no memory of the magic and does not see her sister for many years. When Anna finally gets to see her sister, it turns into a tragedy.The animation is so adorable and fitting for the actors. They play the voices very well. The two sisters, Anna (Kristen Bell) and Elsa (Idina Menzel) sound so much alike. The other actors, like Josh Gad do fantastic as well. The film flows very nicely too. The graphics and animation look unbelievably real.My favorite scene is when Elsa (the one with powers) runs away and builds her own ice castle. She is also my favorite character because she tries to protect her sister, but keeps messing up at it. The castle is built very nicely and it shows her true powers of being the "Snow Queen." I wouldn't mind living in a castle like that myself, if you know what I mean. Since the movie is so kind, bright and educational, I recommend it to ages 4-18 and give it 5 out of 5 stars. Reviewed by Gerry O., KIDS FIRST! Film Critic

A poignantly triumphant movie, the storyline of “WADJDA” is just as phenomenal as the story of how the film came to be. In short, “WADJDA” represents quite a number of firsts. It’s the first feature film shot entirely in Saudi Arabia, a country where cinema is prohibited. Writer and director Haifaa Al Mansour is Saudi Arabia’s first female filmmaker. It is also the first submission from Saudi Arabia for the Foreign Language Category for the 2014 Academy Awards.Set in a country known for its repression of women, the movie follows our title character—a 10-year-old spirited girl—in her journey to buy a new bicycle so she can race her best friend, neighbor and crush Abdullah. Even though Wadjda’s mother warns her to stay away from both bikes and boys because of their culture’s strict customs, Wadjda is determined to buy her bike with her own hard-earned money, no matter what the consequences. This, in turn, leads to joining a Koran competition at school. If she wins, she will have more than enough to buy a bike and therefore beat the boy next door.Subtly, the film explores the repercussions from this society in which girls should only be seen, not heard and, in public, only their eyes should be seen, with the rest of their faces covered by black veils. Wadjda tests boundaries in her search for freedom of expression. Although she discovers the contradictions in her world, she’s determined to challenge women’s traditional roles. The movie covers major topics such as polygamy and child-brides, as well as smaller oppressions such as the restriction of driving and rules of women in the presence of men.It’s mind-blowing to me that a movie about the oppression of women was made in the exact environment it depicts. On DVD, the making-of featurette explores in-depth the struggles and challenges that faced director Haifaa Al Mansour. The line, “respectable girls go inside,” is said to Wadjda in the film, and Mansour confronted the same problems. She had to direct her cast out-of-sight using a walkie-talkie to communicate with her cast and a monitor to watch the filming. She could not be seen working with men and often, when religious officials would come to inspect the bustle, production would be halted and moved to another location. It took close to five years to make the movie, but the effort is worth it.First timer Waad Mohammed is perfect as the fun-loving rebel Wadjda. This film is rated PG and I recommend it for ages 10 to 18. The pace may be slow for kids under ten. This is truly a landmark film that the world needs to watch. I give it five out of five stars. Perhaps the most uplifting message is that although the plot is fiction, the remarkable story behind the movie is not, and that shows that revolution is possible. This film played in theaters last year and will be released on February 11 on DVD/Blu-ray.Reviewed by KIDS FIRST! Film Critic Cassandra H.

This is an incredible film based on the book by the same name. It follows the life of a young girl who is abandoned by her mother and placed in foster care with a couple who also take in a young Jewish man who puts the entire family at risk. It give us a glimpse of what life might have been like for children similar to this during the time the Nazi party controlled Germany. At times terrifying, at times humorous, it will surely give you a full range of emotions. The production is simply stunning from the first rate performances to the sets that portray a very realistic image of this small German town. Young Sophie Nelisse plays a very believable character as the young girl, Liesel and Geoffrey Rush and Emily Watson, the adoptive parents, are equally believable.I know that this book is required reading for many middle schoolers and would highly recommend that they watch this film as well. It portrays so well life in 1938 Germany from the Hitler youth groups to the book burning, the anti-Jewish propaganda, and the brainwashing that ordinary people endured.  It certainly opens up for discussion why all of these people bought into the Nazi regime.Youth comments: Out of all the movies I've ever seen, this one is the saddest. "The Book Thief" is a fantastic film that would make everyone who sees it cry, laugh, enjoy and be at the edge of their seats.  This movie has so much to watch - a tiny bit of comedy, sadness, history, suspense, thrilling scenes, intense, a bit of violence and, of course, theft.The story begins when a young girl is on her way with her sick brother to live with a new family. Sadly, the brother dies along the way. The girl is left alone with a new mother, a new father and stuck in Germany during World War II. Her family does a lot of scary things and it's a very sad story as well.The movie has so much history. I am Jewish so I cried quite a lot when I watched it. The facts are very accurate and very well done. The actors are stupendous. They are sad, happy, scared, brave and a lot more. The special affects and the thrilling way this film is done is amazing. This film is one of those films that made me cry. I wanted to go back in time so I could change Hitler's childhood to convince him to be nicer, kinder and not kill people. This movie is definitely big, intense and memorable.My favorite scene is a happy one. The family is hiding a Jew in their basement. The father (Geoffrey Rush) is a bit of a goof so he gets a lot of snow and they start a snow fight in the basement. For once, the mother plays along, and the girl builds a snow man. There they are huddled against each other, listening to the father play an accordion and feeling happy despite what is happening in the outside world. Because the movie is so intense, I recommend it for ages 11 to 18. I give it 5 out of 5 stars and would recommend that everyone watch this film and think about what happened in the past. We all have responsibility to make sure that this history doesn't repeat itself.  Reviewed by KIDS FIRST! Film Critic Gerry O,For more film reviews, go to kidsfirst dot org.

My dog thinks this is good stuff. Eukanuba is a quality brand, so I have no concerns about trying it. I mixed it in with the dog's regular kibble for the first couple of days (to minimize GI distress from changing foods), and she was very excited. I gave her a full bowl of it last night, and she eagerly went to town on it. She doesn't typically get that excited about kibble and sometimes waits an hour or more after I put it down before eating it. This stuff was irresistible, so I gather it's quite palatable. There's not that much else to say about dog food unless you're concerned about the ingredients and/or where it was manufactured - no concerns about either for me. Eukanuba is one of the good ones.

This is a lovely, lyrical journey through a family’s history. I found it to be particularly interesting, because it delved into the many different societal norms and echelons in terms of Jewish assimilation prior to – and during – the worst of the antisemitism movement. Following Bernard and Win Schlesinger’s letters over the years was a privilege. They clearly had an extraordinary marriage that resulted in a loving family, who are introduced in the beginning of the book, so that you know the end result going in.The five decades of letters between Bernard and Win form a rich tapestry documenting courtship and separations due to wars and other divergent paths during an exceedingly turbulent time. Antisemitism did touch their lives deeply, and the author explores the tensions beneath the surface of his family’s societal ascent. He also shares the stories of their generosity in helping to rescue Jewish children in 1930s Germany. This book is a work of art and a pleasure to read.

The photos do not show that there is a little dangler at the bottom with a likeness of Elsa in it (well, they didn't until I pointed that out in this review). If I had known that, I would not have selected it. Fortunately, I can remove it easily enough. (If you want to get this for your daughter, you might want to know that the Elsa is pretty small.) The snowflake is very pretty, and it will look beautiful on my Christmas tree. It's a little on the heavy side, so you will need to put it on a sturdy part of the branch. I'm not sure it's worth the original retail price, but Disney fans may feel otherwise.

These are beautiful decorative towels for your kitchen. I washed them first to soften them up a little bit. I tend to use my dish towels more for drying my hands after washing them, and not so much for drying dishes. With that in mind, these towels work perfectly for me. They are not really absorbent enough to efficiently dry your dishes, but they can be the towel you put under the dishes while air drying them. They are an attractive touch, and they can do light drying duty.

This gadget is comparing itself to the VacuVin Wine Saver ("No longer do you need the complicated rubber stopper with a long plastic pump to suck the air out of the wine bottle..."), but I can't say that it measures up. It's prettier and smaller, but that's about it. This one fits over the top of the wine bottle, and you push down (pump) the top button until it stays down, which is supposed to indicate the wine bottle is vacuum sealed. But when you take the Visol Vacustopper off of the wine bottle, you only hear a very minor "pop" noise, which makes me think there wasn't that much of a vacuum seal. I don't trust that it's protecting my wine for future drinkage. You *do* hear a significant pop with the VacuVin, and I never found the VacuVin to be complicated, so guess what - I'm sticking with the VacuVin.

My initial impression of this spinner is that it's a very pretty and elegant touch for my front garden. It was easy to assemble, but the instructions advise you to bend each of the "wheels" 30 degrees to enable the spinning effect. I dislike the fact that I have to be the one to do this. I think it should come already bent at the proper angle, although I realize that would make shipping a little tricky. Without using a protractor, it's difficult to tell if I got it right. The instructions do provide a drawing of what a  30-degree bend looks like, but it doesn't show the wheels themselves with the bend, so it's not a sufficient reference. I set the spinner in my garden on a breezy day, and I have yet to see it spin on its own. It also appears to be very delicate, so I wonder how long it will last in a strong wind. (I noticed that other reviewers said the spinner flew off in a strong wind.) I also think this is overpriced. It's pretty, but as Forrest Gump's mother would say: "Pretty is as pretty does." So far, it's not doing that much.

This is a nice pair of long johns that make a good base layer in cold weather. I wore these under my hiking pants in 45-degree weather and was warm and toasty all day. They are perfectly comfortable, although not so soft that I would wear them around the house as loungewear. I would like them to have been a tad more snug, as that makes for more efficient heat retention with your base layer, but they're pretty good. They don't add bulk under my jeans or hiking pants, and I can see them working under ski pants (when the weather isn't *too* cold). And the color/pattern is attractive. I'll make good use of them.

"Flood-ravaged" is a bit of an overstatement, but the lower level of my house was recently flooded after a deluge of rain, and the rug was soaked. To make matters worse, I was out of town, so the rug had to just sit there for a few days. Then I dried it out in the sun for a couple of days and brought it back inside to see if it could be salvaged. It stank pretty badly. I tried spraying Febreze on it - the heavy-duty version - two days in a row, but the smell kept coming back. After a web search on rug deodorizers, I came across this product and ran out and bought it. As the directions suggested for stubborn odors, I sprinkled it liberally and left it for 30 minutes before vacuuming it up. The smell this powder puts off is quite strong at first, so I recommend retreating to another room until after vacuuming. After vacuuming, the rug looked and smelled great. It looks as clean as the day I bought it. Two days later, that is still the case. The rug carries a slight hint of the Arm & Hammer's scent, but nothing offensive. I'm very impressed! An added benefit - I don't empty my vacuum canister as often as I should, so *it* tends to smell. After vacuuming up the Arm & Hammer rug deodorizer, the vacuum now smells good, too!

I already have a Flexees "slip" to wear under dresses on fat days. A particular pair of pants had recently shrunk (or maybe I gained a few pounds...), and I wear those pants a lot, so I thought I might try the Flexees thigh slimmer. It's a waist/hips/thigh slimmer, and it really does work to take a few visual pounds off. It's as comfortable as this type of garment can be, and I'm particularly impressed that the lower leg is crafted such that you can't see where the slimmer ends. And this is with off-white pants. I can zip up my pants easily, which is great. I'm a size 8/10 and purchase a medium, which was just right. Recommended!

I like using an epilator, because you only have to do it every couple of weeks. I already have an epilator that I liked (a corded Braun model), but I was intrigued by the features on this Panasonic. It’s rechargeable, so you don’t have to mess with the cord, and you can use it in the shower. When I use my epilator, I find that I need a lot of light AND my eyeglasses so I can tell if I got all the hair. But I thought if this Panasonic worked well enough, I wouldn’t have to worry about that. Well… it doesn’t. It’s okay, but it’s not quite there. On the bright side, the Panasonic epilator came already charged and assembled, so I was able to test it right out of the box. I used it dry first, and it didn’t get all the hair. I switched to my other epilator to make sure I was being fair, and the Braun corded epilator was definitely more effective. I did try the Panasonic with shave gel. I sat on the side of the tub so I could wear my glasses to see how well it was working. I think in the wet conditions with the shave gel, it worked slightly better, but for me, it’s not quite good enough.

After spending a little time tweaking a couple of things, I can say this makes an excellent second TV. I got this as a lightning deal on Prime Day, so it was roughly half-price of what the big box retailers charge. When I first set the TV up, I thought that was probably all it was worth. The picture quality was subpar – some excessively bright spots that seemed to reduce the resolution – and I was very disappointed. Then I played with the settings and discovered that the TV has several presets for picture quality (similar to presets for a stereo equalizer), and I experimented until I found one (“cinema”) that I really liked. Now I have a beautiful, sharp picture on this great little TV that is set up on the wall in my bedroom. This is 720p, which is not the highest resolution available, but it’s more than sufficient for a 32-inch picture. No complaints there.Setup was very easy except for one little glitch. An onscreen menu guided me through the process of connecting to my home wifi, but the onscreen keyboard doesn’t appear until you click the “okay” button on the remote while in the onscreen box you want to fill in. Hard to explain without a visual, but when you click “sign in” on the screen and you see the boxes for username and password, and you click down to the username box, you expect the keyboard to come up automatically. You have to do the extra “okay” click on the remote before that happens. That’s a little odd, and it took me a few tries to figure that out.The Smart apps work very well. I experimented with Netflix and Amazon Instant Video – signed in easily and access my videos right away.I like to fall asleep to TV, so I appreciate the fact that this one has a sleep timer. A minor point for most people, but it’s a big deal for me, especially since my last bedroom TV didn’t have a timer. I also like to be able to continue to watch a program after retiring to the bedroom, and if I’m watching something on a Smart app on the TV in my living room, I can now turn it off and head upstairs and use the Smart apps on this TV to continue where I left off. That’s not unique to this TV – just a really nice reason to have a Smart TV in the boudoir.I mounted this on the wall, and the fact that this TV is lightweight (and paper-thin!) enabled me to do this without assistance. All in all, this makes an excellent second TV – or perhaps a nice first TV for a small apartment. I’m very pleased with it!

I have a collection of various sundry tools from DIY projects over the years, and they are stored in a multitude of drawers and cubbies all over the house, so I usually spend a lot of time hunting down the right tool. So one thing I really like about this tool kit is that it’s a compact (almost) all-in-one set that I can keep/carry altogether and have everything at my fingertips. No running back and forth to get the one tool I forgot. The pieces are solid, and I love that they are both US and metric. This kit is already coming in very handy, and I'm impressed with the quality. Recommended!
I like these a lot. They are thin, which is great for warm weather. They have ample padding in just the right spots. These are very comfortable running socks.

I chose this storage unit because of the size. I wanted something smallish that would hold a couple of chair cushions and a few other small items that I need to keep clean and dry, and this is the perfect size. The unit assembles very easily. It looks a little cheap, but the color keeps it from standing out much on my patio. I don't have any need to sit on it, but it looks sturdy enough to handle an average-sized adult. It doesn't appear to be completely debris-proof. I notice a tiny bit of tree debris in the box, but I can't figure out how it's getting in. It's not bad enough for me to return it. The box basically does its job, and despite a bit of debris, it's keep my cushions dry. It's a good compact size, it's convenient, and I like having it well enough.

I love a shoe that's a little different without being too showy. I saw this shoe with the metal accents and thought it looked like something I would like. You always take a chance when you order shoes online, but these fit perfectly, and they were quite comfortable from the moment I put them on. I wore them all day at work, doing a moderate amount of walking, and I had no discomfort at all.The shoes are beautiful. The metal accents are very stylish but not garish or tacky. The heel height is just right for me - I don't like wearing high heels to work. I'm not a fan of kitten heels, and that's the one thing I would change if I could. I knew the shoes had kitten heels when I ordered them, so that's not a complaint. These days, it's so hard to find stylish (i.e., non-frumpy) shoes without high heels. I'm happy. These look great and don't cause me pain!

As another reviewer's headline stated, these are comfortable and classy, although I would not call them all that stylish. They're a little ordinary-looking, which isn't necessarily a bad thing. I think they are pretty enough. They have what I consider to be the perfect heel for a working woman's pump, and the shoe does feel immediately good on your feet. The patent leather accents add a little extra style. My one complaint is with the buckle on the ankle strap. It's a bit wonky - doesn't seem to lay flat the way I would expect it to, and it's very challenging to adjust. If I were able to slide the rear strap over my heel without unbuckling and rebuckling, this wouldn't be an issue, but unfortunately, it doesn't just slip on. I had a significant amount of trouble with this, and it's going to lead me to return the shoes.

It is true that the best time to moisturize your skin is right after a shower when your skin is already moist. This can either be before or after you have toweled off, because your skin isn't completely dry after toweling off. This moisturizer is to be used before, and it does work well. My skin retains the oil and stays smooth and moist, but unfortunately, so does my towel. This is the downside of many of these types of moisturizers, and I found that after using this one two days in a row, I had to wash my towel. If you're someone who replaces towels frequently anyway, this won't be an inconvenience for you. It will keep me from continuing to use this moisturizer. In addition to the more frequent washing, after I towel off, I wrap my bath towel around my head to keep my hair from dripping, and I don't want that oil on my hair.This product has a nice light fragrance. And while I normally prefer such things to be unscented, I have to admit the fragrance is unnoticeable after a short time, so it's not a problem.Bottom line - it goes on easily and moisturizes well, but there is too much oily residue on the towel, in my opinion.

I have a number of Belkin products and have always been satisfied with them. This one is advertised as a rapid charger, and I'm not sure it's as rapid as some I have used in the past, but it's reasonably fast. It charged my iPad Mini in a few hours. I like the fact that it has a long cord for when I'm in not right next to an outlet. It does not come with the AC adaptor, but I have a few extras, so that doesn't concern me. More than anything, I like having an extra iPad charger. It comes in very handy. This is a good one.

Variety of stroke widths, meaning the width of your mark can be adjusted. I have only used the original-style Sharpies before, and they are great for making permanent marks on mark-resistant surfaces. I mistakenly thought this chisel tip would allow you to make a finer line than the regular Sharpies, but that's not the case. There *are* fine-line Sharpies, but these particular markers allow you to make medium-to-thick lines. The product description also says these markers won't bleed through paper, and I don't find that to be the case. They don't bleed through much, but they do bleed through a bit. I like the variety of colors, and it's nice to have a choice of mark width. Sharpie always makes good-quality markers.

This is an improvement over some of the more basic Keurig brewers. You have multiple choices for the amount of coffee you want to brew – small cup, big cup, small carafe. (The carafe is not included, and I recommend buying one that is insulated so it retains the heat.) It’s a small unit, so it doesn’t take up much space on your counter. You do have to use Keurig K-cups or an “approved brand,” because the machine reads the pod to determine brew strength. There are MANY approved brands, though, so I don’t think it’s the end of the world. It worked with my Eight-O’Clock brand K-cups just fine.This machine is well designed for functionality, versatility, and convenience. The fact that I can brew one BIG cup of coffee is perfect for me. And of course, one of my favorite things about single-cup brewers is that you can give your guests whatever they want – any type of coffee, tea, or even hot chocolate. For that matter, if you only drink one cup of coffee in the morning, that’s all you have to make.The brewer makes a great cup of coffee – any size you like. Highly recommended!

I am new to running, and I'm not exactly young, and I was in old shoes that weren't quite right for me. Shin splints hit me after the 6th run. (Well, to be fair, it's a walk-to-run program, so it's not that much running just yet.) I checked a few Internet tools that help you figure out what kind of shoe you need (neutral stability in my case), and this particular shoe kept coming up. Then I did what everyone who's new to running should do - I went to a specialty running store and got an expert to study my gait and do a good fitting. These were among the shoes he recommended, and they felt the best. He put me in a size 9, which was a surprise, because I wear a 7 1/2 in regular shoes (and that's one big reason you should get a professional fitting if you're new to this). While I was recovering from my shin splints, I walked in these to get them broken in. Once I was ready to try running again, I discovered just how great these shoes feel. The wide toe box gives me plenty of room, the heel fits me just snugly enough, and there's just the right amount of cushion to protect my feet. I'm very happy with them, and I'm looking forward to gradually upping my running game.

These are replacing an old heavy, wood-handled trimmer, so it's hard to imagine that a newer trimmer would *not* be better. However, I have to say this is a LOT better. I love how lightweight it is, and the blades are nice and sharp. All of this makes the trimmer easy to use for careful touchups where you want to be precise. I did test the knob that adjusts blade tension, and I find it to be easy to use and effective in making minor adjustments for different types of shrubs. I'm willing to bet that I will be less likely to put off my hedge trimming work now that I have these.Update October 1: I have noticed that I no longer put off the shrub trimming now that I have a nice set of shears. I see something that needs to be lopped off, and I take care of it right away. Funny how much of a difference it makes to have nicer tools to work with.

This travel mug is an attractive design and seemingly very functional at first glance. I tested it with my morning coffee, which I drink during my long commute to work. I tend to sip slowly, so a mug that maintains heat is desirable. That much - it does. When finishing my last sip an hour later, the coffee was still hot. The vacuum seal is not quite 100%. I snapped the lid seal down and screwed the lid onto the mug tightly, then held the mug upside-down over the sink and shook it a bit. There was a bit of leakage from the side of the top (where you screw it on), but it was pretty minimal - not enough to keep me from using the mug. The top seals shut with a snap. When you snap it open, a little ball that seals the drinking slot recedes. Here's the worst part from my perspective: the drinking slot is small, and the little ball is still close enough to the opening that it interferes just a bit. I found that I could only sip very small amounts of coffee, as opposed to taking a healthy sip. When you're driving, you don't want to be distracted by having to think too hard about how to get a full sip of coffee from your travel mug.This particular mug size is too tall to fit with my K-cup brewer (I would have done better with the smaller size), so that's an inconvenience. I have to brew the coffee in another mug and then pour the coffee into the travel mug. If you're brewing a full pot of coffee and pouring from a carafe, this won't be an issue for you.I also tested the mug's cold retention function by pouring ice water in the mug and letting it sit for three hours. The water was still very cold, although the ice had mostly melted. Good enough. I'm not likely to need to keep anything ice-cold for longer than that. I do like the fact that this mug is dishwasher safe.Overall, I'd have to say I'm not crazy about the functionality of the sipping mechanism, and that will probably keep me from using this mug on a regular basis.

I previously had one of the 3M filters for a company laptop and liked it very much. I didn't realize Dell was making these now, and as it happens, they're not. This would appear to be a 3M filter with a Dell package wrapped around it. Either way, a good product. (In case you're wondering, these are compatible with any laptop - it doesn't have to be a Dell. I have an HP.) This was easy to install. I put the adhesive "slides" on the side of my laptop monitor frame and slid the screen down into place easily. I can leave it in place all the time, which is a nice convenient feature, or I can use it only when I'm concerned about privacy issues. I can see my screen just fine - it's only a shade or two darker than normal, and I *could* increase the brightness if that were a concern. People sitting beside me can't see the screen clearly enough to recognize the content. Depending on the angle from which they're viewing, they might be able to make out some of the image on screen, but most likely wouldn't be able to discern the big picture - especially when smaller type/font is involved. This is great for when you're traveling on a plane and don't want to share your business with everyone around you. I can view or create confidential business materials, I can watch a movie privately, any number of things. People sitting directly behind you can see what you're doing, because they're working from the same angle as you. This filter is designed to block the view of the nosy people sitting beside you, and it works well. I'll use this on a regular basis.

My dog says these are good but not out-of-this-world awesome. When I gave her the first one, she eyed it suspiciously, then took it to her spot where she eats, then she rolled around next to it for awhile as if she needed to think about whether to accept it. To be fair, my dog doesn't always take to new treats immediately. If it's not what she's used to, she takes her time. She did get around to chewing on it, and then she very happily finished it off. It didn't last very long once she got started on it, which means she really liked it. When I gave her another one the next day, she displayed a similar level of non-enthusiasm, which I would *not* expect if she had really loved it the first time around. Same reaction with bone #3, and I noticed that she needs to drink a lot of water afterwards, so something about the taste makes her very thirsty. It's hard to know why a dog does or doesn't like something, but I can't say this is a major hit. The bones don't last very long, which was a bit disappointing. I'm not sure yet whether I'll buy more.

There isn't much else to say about a pen except that it writes and it's comfortable to hold. I have always liked the rollerball gel pens, because they are more reliable than standard ink barrel pens. These fit the bill nicely, and the shape and texture of the lower barrel make them comfortable to hold. The colors are not quite as bright as in the picture, so I don't think they're too effeminate (if that's a concern). I don't really care for the flowery design myself, but it's not ostentatious, and it does help to identify which pen is mine. The fact that there are 48 in the set means I will have plenty of ink for life, I suspect. Good pens.

I have a sloped back yard and an inset exterior stairwell that leads down to the lower level of my house. When we get a lot of rain, water gets in the house. I have spent all kinds of money building an enclosure around the stairwell, regrading the walkway, building a little dam - you name it. While all those things made *some* difference, I still have gotten a little water. I was at my wit's end. A friend saw these and mentioned them to me. I read the reviews and decided to give them a try. Two days after they arrived, we had a flash flood. No water in my house. None. I put my bare foot on top of the Quick Dam that was at the downstairs door, and it was dry. I thought no water had gotten in. A little later, I turned it over to doublecheck, and it was indeed wet. Then I checked the one in the bottom of the stairwell, and it was swollen but not overflowing. My point - these sandbags can take in a LOT of water. They had room for much more. I bought a bag of 6, and I don't know that I'll ever use more than 2 or 3. They dry out pretty quickly in between rain storms. But I have extras on hand if we get recurring deluges. I'm in awe. And I no longer have to panic when the weather forecast calls for 2 inches of rain. This product has made a huge difference.Update January 2015:Five months later, I can still attest to the effectiveness of these sandbags. (And as you probably noticed, I technically don't use them as sandbags - I use them as water absorption bags.) The one issue with them is that you need a warm sunny day to dry them out. You need to be able to put them somewhere where the water will evaporate efficiently. That's a problem in the winter when it's cold and there's less sun to help out. I have bought another box of these to help me with my water issue, and I'm not complaining. If that's all it takes, I'm fine with this minimal cost and effort. It's just something to be aware of.

I've had it with the cheap sprinklers that either break quickly or just don't quite cover as much space as they should. I can't believe how much ground this covers. You can adjust the water flow at the sprinkler so you don't have to run back and forth to the faucet to get it just right. You can adjust how wide the spray goes. This is a really good lawn sprinkler that does a great job covering a lot of territory. Highly recommended.

I mounted this inside a closet door, so it's not something that people see, but I almost wish they did. It's a really nice-looking ironing board holder. I had a couple of false starts and had to take screws out a couple of times to figure out how it all fits together. Now that it's in place, I'm very happy with it.

It matches my own watch (a Wittenauer) in the diamond rim and my wife fell in love with it on first sight.  We've had it exactly one day and the time has been solid (set by time on cable box, checked by time on cable box).The watch has a lovely band that fits snugly but not tightly and looks great on my wife's arm.  Ladies, if you are considering purchase, my wife strongly recommends.  Gentlemen, if you are buying for a lady, good way to score some brownie points!All in, high recommend, great watch!

The new Panasonic Earbuds are just what I've been looking for...good sound, comfortable in ear and able to dampen out noise from outside.  I use them on a long commute every day, so being able to wrap myself into a decent TV show, movie or music is essential.  These do the job very very well and I've been impressed by how well they work!I am not an audio engineer...but I'm a discerning consumer and these pass muster very nicely.  The bass and treble pop well, the volume is solid (I hate ear buds that don't get loud) and voices, both spoken words as well as sung verses were crisp, clear and easily heard. The cord for the earbuds is substantially and I believe will stand up to everyday use and abuse and the body of the earbuds seems well engineered.Last, the earbuds come with three different sizes of rubber heads, and even the smallest worked well on my oversized ears.  All of the heads stayed secure, even as I tested their stability with a finger nail (is there anything more annoying than a lost head on a set of earbuds?).All in all, very happy with my new acquisition and looks forward to many hours enjoying them!

I recently had a chance to review one of Ammex's other nitrile gloves, the medium blues and gave them a good rating. My sole complaint was that they were a little snug (more my fault, not sure my hands are medium in size) and that they felt a little sweaty.  The material seemed solid, but those gloves can be used by others...these are the gloves I'm going to use from now on.Black gloves with a matte finish, these are very comfortable, not at all sweaty and the material feel like its ready for work.  I use gloves when I turn wood, do glue ups, apply finishes (including CA finishes which is messy and leads to a week of picking CA glue off skin and nails everytime) and do yard work.  I need to be able to feel what I'm touching, even to a point of delicacy and be able to depend on the gloves to stay comfortable and tough.These do all of that...the material is strong (I was able to rip it but it took some concentrated effort) and I wore them for around 40 mins when I was doing some work yesterday.  Without latex (there is no latex, so sayeth the box), without powder (which can stain work, there's no powder here), these gloves worked like a charm.Very strong recommend and an excellent add to my woodshop!

I bought these gloves because I do woodturning on a lathe.  Often, I used glues (wood and CA glues) and they get everywhere.  Other times, I used finishes (just put boiled linseed oil on a bowl about 20 mins ago) and oils track onto everything.  Using gloves helps...even if they get pretty sweaty inside after an hour of work.I used to use the white surgical gloves you can buy at drug stores but more often than not, they would rip putting them on or while you were using them (usually when you get to the tough part where you REALLY don't want to stop to put on new gloves).I will point out that I have some pretty big hands and these 'Medium' sized gloves were a touch snug (not unbearable, not even really uncomfortable).  But my cleaning person loves them and I have a strong recommend if you are considering buying them.  Thanks for a great product!

I mounted the new OmniMount Wall up in our living room, adjacent to a 60" wall mounted television.  I found the studs (wasn't hard, just measured off the rack that was already holding the TV) and had it installed in all of 10 minutes.  The mounts it comes with will work with a variety of wall types, and, if you prefer, you can probably substitute heavier duty plasterboard wall mounts to replace the ones here which are supposed to mount up to 60 pounds.Its black, painted underside of the glass shelf unit and pretty much goes with anything.  The channel cover is very functional and did a good job hiding cables out of sight.All in, a simple setup, a pretty looking item that is functional.  The only reason it was not a 5 star was that the compartment is really small (roughly 19"x2") and that's simply not very big. It would have been better to either make it larger or give the option for a second shelf somewhere below the primary one. Right now, I've got remotes stashed in there and a cable or two, but it would be nice to put my cable box in there, or (as someone else suggested) a bluray player. For my cable box (which is really a TIVO in disguise, my bluray, my receiver and amp, they are on the table below the TV and shelf, with cables trailing up the channel.  This works well, but leaves the cabinet they are sitting on looking very cluttered.All in all, a good recommend for what it is...it will be a nice addition to a mounted TV, will hide wire and do so with grace and style.  But it will not likely hold everything you may want to hold.

Product Review: My First Lab Mini Duo Scope  Exec Summary, excellent educational toy!Last week, I had the opportunity to offer a kid-safe microscope to my grandson as a way to jumpstart his imagination toward science. To say it went well would be an understatement, it went extremely well.  He was engaged with the microscope for an entire weekend and I don't think he encountered ANYTHING that didn't go under the lenses (assuming they fit).My experience with microscopes is varied.  I spent a year as a biology major back in college, but those days are long behind me.  Back then, I always had a difficult time discerning just what the heck I was looking at.  That has not changed...and its not the fault of the microscope.The microscope in question is plastic but its pretty hardy.  There will not be parts breaking or falling off anytime soon, even with relatively rough handling.  The unit takes AAA batteries which powers two lights (above and below), a 10x lense up top and up to 40x below.  What comes through is a solid image, by a microscope that maintains its focus (even as I was focusing and handing it to my grandson) and a clear and easily changed stage for the scope.The image was solid, functional and easy to see.  The unit comes with three prepared slides (plastic), a number of empty slides and specimen windows, a couple of specimen bottles and some yeast and brine shrimp (Sea Monkeys!)  We tried preparing the brine shrimp but either they didn't hatch or we didn't wait long enough (waiting 3 days).Separately, I had a set of prepared glass slides from a microscope I bought my son some years ago, and again, this microscope did very well with them.All in all, a strong recommendation.  If you have children who are youngish (marketing suggests 8-15), this is an excellent and inexpensive way to offer the microscopic world to your children.  If a child is looking for a microscope, this is a great way to introduce it, and perhaps consider a more expensive unit at a later time.

You may be familiar with Lonely Planet from their travels guides...I know I was.  Smart, well photographed and researched, the Lonely Planet guides are an excellent value for the traveler.This calendar has some of the most beautiful images ever...with places I would love to travel one day. The detail box that others are complaining about is pretty evident (though not on the back cover where a purchaser might be surprised at what they are getting and how much of the picture is concealed) and the text is informative and interesting.  Overall, I love the calendar, but the images (beautiful!) need to be the primary target for the eye, not the complicated arrangement that is evident in the calendar itself.The quality of the paper is very good, a nice thick stock and the detail of the pictures is amazing.  All in all, a solid four-stars...the calendar is very nice, the presentation a little less so, but not so much as to deter purchase.

I’m going to approach this review in a different manner than I have written reviews in the past.  I suspect many pet owners simply go to their local pet store and grab up whatever food their pets like and maybe whatever is on sale.  I want to review based on the dog food, but also on the experience of ordering dog food online.I would love to say that my dog has a discriminating palette that ensures he eats only the best and most healthful and, then, only disdainfully.  But that’s not my dog (nor, likely, anyone else’s) and when he eats, he does it with his whole face deep in his bowl, as fast as he can take it in, chew it and swallow it. He doesn’t limit himself to traditional food (sneakers, flip flops and the odd paper item he can fetch off a kitchen counter will also suit) nor is he ever not hungry.  In short, he’s a happy little critter that loves eating anything at all times and we have to be careful at home to make sure that anything within reach is reasonably dog-friendly.So it’s up to me to make sure that what he does eat makes sense from a health standpoint. The Nutro dog food is quite healthful, from what research I have been able to crib from the ingredients list (pasted below al9ong with the guaranteed analysis from the Nutro website).  Lamb and brown rice contain many healthy components, like antioxidants for immunity boosting and other elements for joint health. Further, other ingredients are promoting a shine to his fur coat and I’m happy to say that I have seen the results.Changing to this dog food didn’t upset my dog’s stomach at all, which was a worry.  My dog has a sensitive stomach, despite his taste for anything he can swallow.  But not to worry, this Nutro dog food had no effect on his stomach and, in fact, he likes the flavor enough that he kicks his bowl around if there isn’t any more in it. The advertised ability toLast, I’d like to spend a minute talking about ordering dog food online.  This dog food online was cheaper than the dog food I got at my local pet store, even with shipping.  The nice thing about it is that I can order a regular delivery, have it show up every month and always have consistent food in the house.  So, its cheaper, more convenient and that’s a win for me.All in all, I recommend the dog food (so would my dog), believe it to be a good value and that ordering online was a win all the way around.From the Nutro website details on this dog food:Ingredients: Lamb, Lamb Meal (source of Glucosamine and Chondroitin Sulfate), Brewers Rice, Rice Bran, Chickpeas, Whole Brown Rice, Split Peas, Whole Grain Oatmeal, Pea Protein, Chicken Fat (preserved with mixed Tocopherols), Natural Flavor, Sunflower Oil (preserved with mixed Tocopherols), Soybean Oil (preserved with mixed Tocopherols), Potassium Chloride, Salt, Choline Chloride, DL-Methionine, Taurine, Zinc Sulfate, Niacin Supplement, Vitamin E Supplement, Calcium Pantothenate, Riboflavin Supplement (Vitamin B2), Pyridoxine Hydrochloride (Vitamin B6), Vitamin B12 Supplement, Iron Amino Acid Chelate, Copper Amino Acid Chelate, Selenium Yeast, Biotin, Manganese Amino Acid Chelate, Vitamin A Supplement, Thiamine Mononitrate (Vitamin B1), Vitamin D3 Supplement, Potassium Iodide, Folic Acid, Rosemary Extract, Decaffeinated Green Tea Extract, Spearmint Extract.Guaranteed Analysis  Crude Protein (Min.) 21.00%  Crude Fat (Min.) 13.00%  Crude Fiber (Max.) 3.50%  Moisture (Max.) 10.00%  Linoleic Acid (Min.) 3.50%  Zinc (Min.) 250 mg/kg  Selenium (Min.) 0.25 mg/kg  Vitamin E (Min.) 80 IU/kg  Niacin (Min.) 250 mg/kg  Biotin (Min.)* 2.5 mg/kg  Glucosamine (Min.)* 100 mg/kg Chondroitin Sulfate (Min.)* 350 mg/kg  * Not recognized as an essential nutrient by the AAFCO Dog Food Nutrient Profiles

The SUMMARY: The Perfectly Simple Bars are not so simple.  There’s a lot going on in these bars, both from a taste and a consistency basis.  The bars don’t LOOK delicious, there’s a lot of ingredients (see below) with a few almonds and Bing cherries.  The sweetness comes from honey and vanilla (Madagascar vanilla!). When you bite into it, you don’t expect what you get, which is a rich a tasty bar, satisfying and filling. There’s 180 calories in each bar, with 70 of them coming from fat.  That’s not a lot, considering I think the bars can be a complete meal replacement. There’s also 10 g of protein.  For more about the bars, I included a snapshot of its nutritional details with this review.The AD: "These tarty Bing Cherry & Almond Bars are sure to perk up your taste buds. Wholesome ingredients, such as dry-roasted almonds and Bing cherries, are mixed with a little sweetness (courtesy of USDA Grade A light-amber honey and Madagascar vanilla), so each bite explodes with the kind of sweet and savory goodness that makes you wanna do a little happy dance."The INGREDIENTS: Soy Protein Isolate, Dried Bing Cherries, Dry Roasted Almonds, Sugar, High Oleic Safflower Oil, Crystalline Fructose, Brown Rice Syrup, Almond Butter, Light Amber Honey, Cocoa Butter, Raspberry Puree, Tapioca Starch, Palm Kernel Oil, Concentrated Apple Puree; Less than 2% of the following: Concentrated Apple Juice, Corn Syrup, Palm Fat, Natural Flavors, Dutch-Process Cocoa (Processed With Alkali), Nonfat Milk Powder, Whey Powder, Milk Fat, Salt, Madagascar Vanilla, Natural Cinnamon Flavor, Pasteurized Whole Egg Powder, Concentrated Aronia Juice, Maize Starch, Soy Lecithin, Glycerol, Citrus Fiber, Pectin, Citric Acid, Calcium Lactate, Sunflower Lecithin.  NOTE: Contains soy, milk, almonds, and egg ingredients. Manufactured in a facility that processes peanuts, other tree nuts, and wheat.The COMPANY: The company that makes the Perfectly Simple bars is called ZonePerfect and their website proudly proclaims that they have been “nourishing lives since 2003.”  It actually says that, but despite the cheesy hype, the product is pretty good.  As it turns out (and is not easy to find), ZonePerfect seems to be owned by Abbott Nutrition, which is a division of Abbott Labs.  That its owned by Abbott doesn’t bother me…Abbott makes excellent products.  This is one of them. You can find this at Walmart, among other places, or you can, as I did, order from Amazon.The EXPERIENCE: The bar announces itself prominently when you open the wrapper.  It smells delicious, with the cherry right at the olfactory forefront.  The bar comes out of the wrapper and although it looks like a bit of a mess (a lot going on in that bar), it tastes delicious and the consistency is reasonable.  Sometimes with bars like these, they fall apart because the ingredients don’t blend right.  These do not have that problem. The taste is excellent, with a hint of honeyed sweetness but the sweetness is nicely offset by the tartness of the cherry.The FINAL ANALYSIS: All in all, these bars are delicious, reasonably nutritious and taste much better than they look. One bar made for my breakfast this morning and it was filling and satisfying. My recommendation?  If you’re looking for your next good bar, this one is really good and I recommend it!

In reviewing Protein drinks, there’s not a ton to be able to tell about their long term effect. Sodas will eat away stomach lining if you drink enough of them long enough. Juices have acid so they can as well.  What’s the long term effect of drinking a protein-additive drink?  I’m not sure…but this particular drink is tasty, the right amount of sweet and, in addition to protein, contains electrolytes, vitamins and minerals. The slogan is Rehydrate, Restore, Recover. I will add another that the company will appreciate: Reorder.  I liked it and we (my family and I) are going to order more.The COMPANY: The drink is produced by a company called New Whey Nutrition, and according to their website, their first products were made to meet the protein replacement needs of post-surgery bariatric patients. In researching the company, New Whey’s Mission Statement is stated as: “It is the desire of New Whey Nutrition to develop and provide quality products for you, "the customer." In addition, New Whey Nutrition will provide you with the utmost comprehensive and innovative products. All the products sold on this website are to arrive promptly from the time that they are ordered and to arrive in good condition. If any product is unsatisfactory, please return un-used portion and you will promptly be refunded.”  You can find their products at GNC, Walmart or Wegmans among others, or you can, as I did, order them on Amazon.The BEVERAGE: The bottle contains 20 fluid ounces of beverage and that represents a single serving size.  That’s relatively large, but part of the idea is to reduce hunger by filling the stomach with liquid.  There’s 140 calories in the bottle, none of which come from fat. There’s 6 base electrolytes, 110 grams of sodium, 220 grams of potassium, 24 grams of carbs.  Other contents include: Vitamin A, Calcium, Vitamins B, B6 and B12, Riboflavin, Niacin, Biotin and Folic Acid. What’s missing that’s in a lot of other drinks? Fat, Gluten, Lactose, Caffeine, Cholesterol and (my personal fav) high Fructose corn syrup. All in all, this is a reasonably healthy rehydrating cocktail.  If you want more specific ingredients (good luck reading the label. I went out into the sun with 1.25x reading glasses and couldn’t make it out completely) I’m attaching a snapshot of the label to this review.The EXPERIENCE: The consistency of the beverage is a little thick, which I like and probably will lessen hunger.  There's a sweetness to it, but given the lack of High Fructose Syrup, I’m guessing that comes from a little sugar and the fruit blended in.  Even though you get the sweetness, you don’t get the after-taste that comes from so many drinks.  It starts sweet and finishes that way.  The taste pops nicely and, as a blend you can distinguish between the flavors, at least as far as the pomegranate and blueberry go. Not sure what an acai tastes like...but I'm guessing it taste ACAI (ok), yes, that's a pun there.The SUMMARY: I cannot say whether there are long term health benefits from drinking the Nuaquos beverage, but I can say that it is satisfying and I like it a lot.  The ingredients seem to be reasonably healthy and the experience of drinking it is a good one.  If you are considering, I recommend it!

In reviewing this case, all I can tell you is that if you compare it to what else is available for the S6, you will pick this out of the crowd immediately.  The case is clear heavy duty plastic and rubber edges and the phone slips into it simply and easily.  There's no mistaking this for the other cheap plastic cases.  You might mistake it for some kind of military 'Protect at all costs' style of case because its rugged, solid and very functional. It actually does meet military specs for protection (seriously) but this one actually looks like it does. You probably couldn't spike the phone-in-the-case at the ground but the case seems very solid for most accidental drops. Its similar to an Otterbox (which I use for my Ipad) in its durability and styling, but I like this one better.  It looks great.The case is very well thought out for the product.  The buttons and access is simple and you can tell when you're pushing it properly. The headphone cutout is particularly useful being large enough to accommodate my larger-sized jack on my headphones. That's rare...other cases couldn't accommodate my favorite headphones that I use for my ipod.Worth noting is that I didn't get a screen protector as promised, but I already had one so it was not a problem and if you wind up disappointed on this score, its easily removed (unlike my Otterbox) to put on after the fact.If I had to pick a negative (its not for me), the case does add to the bulk of the phone.  I'm not sure how you can protect the phone without adding bulk and truly it is really not a problem for me.  But if you are sensitive to the heft of the unit with the case on, you may wish to consider it. Having said that, a thinner case would probably not be as rugged or as pretty.All in all, strong recommend.

In reviewing this product, I've enlisted the help of my wife who is much more the natural market than am I.  She's also fairly critical when it comes to products and skeptical when it comes to relatively wild claims to do things that then happen only in moderation. The product is produced by Ulta Beauty, a chain of cosmetic superstores out of Bolingbrook, IL.  Their lines include all kinds of cosmetics and some very big names.  They even have two stores (apparently) in my home city of Philadelphia.These gels are placed around the mouth and on the forehead for a period of ten minutes at a go.  Its suggested to use them once a week or more often if you, as consumer, think its necessary.  I'm pretty sure that ‘skyn’ (since when is capitalization a marketing brand?) would love if you used the ‘ICELAND’ product every day.I will suggest that the actual gels are simply weird feeling.  They feel like they’ve been refrigerated (they weren’t), like there’s some kind of moisturize on their surface (there doesn’t seem to be) but they do feel effective.  To call them gels is probably an oversimplification.  These are peptide-packed (infused) transdermal patches, but a far cry from nicotine patches.  These are comfortable, easy to use and relaxing.The gels seem to be some kind of soft cloth with the gel material facing the skin.  They are individually and carefully wrapped and require a little work to get out of their casings whole.  But once applied, they cool wonderfully and feel great against the skin.  After use, twice, my wife is happy to report that she likes the product a lot, wants to buy more and (you're welcome, ‘skyn’) and use them more often than once a week.  She really believes they alleviated wrinkles and I agree with her.Be aware that we are not in a position to offer advice as to the long term effects (or lack of effects) of using the product.  I suspect people’s mileage in this regard will vary based on their own complexions, how often they use them and for how long.  But I know my wife is satisfied and that’s good enough to warrant their continued use.  Having gone through a bunch of products over the years, that she is satisfied makes for a happy surprise.When I say that it feels like there’s moisturizer on the gels, a finger test seems to come up dry.  But there’s actually a lot going on here. The ingredient list (cribbed from the website) includes: Water/Aqua/Eau, Glycerin, Olea Europea (Olive) Fruit Oil, Angelica Archangelica Root Water*, Sodium Hydroxide, Acrylates Copolymer, Agar, Ginkgo Biloba Leaf Extract, Hydrolyzed Elastin, Acetyl Hexapeptide-8, Caprylyl Glycol, Perfluorodecalin, Simmondsia Chinensis (Jojoba) Seed Oil, PEG-75 Shea Butter Glycerides, Glycosphingolipids, Xanthan Gum, Ubiquinone, Thymus Vulgaris (Thyme) Flower/Leaf Extract, Buddleja Davidii Extract, Rubus Chamaemorus (Arctic Cloudberry) Seed Oil, Oxycoccus Palustris (Arctic Cranberry) Seed Oil, Aluminum Glycinate, Butylene Glycol, Polysorbate 60, Phenoxyethanol, Benzoic Acid, Dehydroacetic Acid, Propylene Glycol, Sorbic Acid, 1,2-Hexanediol.The website also points out the gels are: “Free of parabens, petroleum, mineral oil, chemical sulfates and phthalates. 100% vegan and cruelty-free. Dermatologist tested for sensitive skin.”All in all, a really good product that I believe we will be reordering in coming days.  As well recommended as any product we’ve used twice can be.

I'm a person that tends to go through safety glasses pretty rapidly.  Somewhere in my garage-workshop there's about a dozen pairs, all of which are probably hanging out together, laughing as I go looking for a pair readily at hand.  Mostly, I use the cheap $2 ones that will do the job but not much more than that.These safety glasses do more than just the job.  First, they're comfortable as a pair of light glasses can be expected to be.  They do feel like plastic, but there's a foam (I think its open cell so it can breathe) backing that makes them tolerable. That same foam forms a comfortable seal against your face, keeping dust out of your eyes.  That's one thing the cheap ones do not do that's appreciated!  They are comfortable enough that I can likely wear them for extended periods of time before they are not welcome on my face anymore.  I have a large head...they fit me perfectly, your own mileage may vary!Second, the lenses are a bright yellow (what is referred to as 'Amber') which actually seems to brighten up the workshop considerably.Third, they have a strap so if I do take them off, they will be right where I can get at them without much effort.All in all, great glasses, recommend them highly!

I'm a real fan of Werther's candies, and have been for quite a number of years. The company itself isn't named for an individual (according to the website), its named for the European town in which a candy maker named Gustav Nebel first made his caramels.Caramel can come in a variety of textures and hardnesses (assuming that's a word).  In this case, these caramels are wrapped individually and are soft, rich and creamy delicious. A serving of 4 contains about 100 calories, much of which is about the sugar content. Other ingredients are butter and cream.In terms of textures, they are soft and if you have difficulty with hard caramels, have braces or dentures, I believe that these would likely be fine for you.  I hesitate to say so in case someone has a problem, but my son, who has braces and is careful not to eat foods (like caramels) which might damage them) tried one and had no problems. If you are one of the people above, try at your own risk, but I suspect you'll have no problems and a really happy treat.All in, high recommend (applicable to all of Werther's products that I've tried over the years).

In reviewing this 'Child Carrier,' I'd like to point out that it is a remarkable piece of engineering.
