Since there is no 3.5mm audio jack it's tough to get audio out of the Alpha if you plug it into an HDMI monitor instead of a TV.When you get to downloading games from Steam you find another limitation.  It downloads them one at a time and you can't start play until a game is fully downloaded.  I looked around and found a couple of people that said just to cue up a batch of games and leave it running overnight.  Again, if you are planning on playing some of the Window's games from EA or others you have to go to the Windows desktop to install and run EA games like Crysis 3 and Titanfall.  That means you need the keyboard/mouse again.Should you buy it?  Do you want a game console? Then buy one as a Windows box will be anywhere near as easy as an Xbox or PlayStation.  BUT, if you want a gaming PC that fits into the living room better than any gaming PC I have ever seen, this is what you want.  If you do, buy the base model and spend a little extra on a SSD or hybrid hard drive to replace the one that comes standard. Upgrade the RAM yourself. Get a mouse and keyboard.  Happiness will ensue.

Great set of features.  We had it installed at the foot of our stairs where it is really dark at night.  The little LED light is just enough to find it.  The slider for setting the light is a real improvement over the others we have used.  Much easier to find and use. One interesting feature we didn't need is that it supports dimming of incandescent, dimmable CFL and dimmable LED.  We have one from the other "L" switch company that only supports LED and we needed one for a mixed group of lights.  I had to replace all of the CFL lamps with dimmable LED to work with the switch.  If I had known, I would have just replaced the switch instead of buying all new lights.Great product.
Series getting boring.  These books are too expensive to have this big a let down in the writing.
Using it to weatherproof my Fi-Shock EA5M-FS AC Low Impedance Energizer, 5-Mile.  Works perfectly for that purpose.
Great series, character development is outstanding. Can't wait for the next one.
Well written and researched as all of Chris Nuttall books are.  Can't wait for the sequel.
Didn't expect the heavy religion bias.  Well written, but for someone that is not very religious it wouldn't be appropriate.
Worked perfectly in my Laguna Woven Fabric Floating Plant Basket.  Easy to use and fairly dense.  I put Creeping Jenny in the floating basket and it looks healthy and happy.

Absolutely HYSTERICAL!!!!!!!I would love to see this guy's stand-up comedy in person!  He has got early parenthood down!  I can only hope that he continues with these books, a couple of times each decade, for the next 30 years!Wonderfully funny!  If a new parent can't relate to at least 50% of the book -- I suspect a severe case of "Sense of Humor Failure"!Maybe all the items in each list are necessarily appropriate for your maiden aunt -- but this is really funny!Recommended!

. . . and I realize that my opinion is in the minority.I gave the book two stars because it is head-and-shoulders above the pablum that poses for "historical", "1st century Christian" fiction written by other authors.Randy Singer is, in many respects, a good writer.  I have not read any of his legal fiction, but I am willing to give one a try.  He tried to do his historical homework with regard to 1st century Rome, and I appreciated that.  He used the writings of Roman philosophers and historians, and I appreciated that.  His approach to the New Testament was more disappointing -- and his refusal to use any of the 1st and 2nd century Christian material -- which has survived, and is readily available in English-language critical editions -- is, in my opinion, historically dishonest.  A number of points, some of which have been raised by other reviewers.  There may be points presented that could be construed as spoilers -- so I'm giving the alert now.Item:  Singer seems to have a fixation with crucifixion.  The notion that Seneca would subject sons of Roman nobles to fake crucifixions -- and that the noble families would allow it, is absurd on its face.Item:  Singer seems to have a fixation with Vestal Virgins.  The notion of a years-long love affair involving a Vestal Virgin, without discovery, or even reasonable suspicion, is also absurd on its face -- and the penalty for love affairs with Vestal Virgins was severe.Item:  While obviously wanting to stick to an uber-literal interpretation of the Biblical text, Singer makes some gaffes.  For example, Nicodemus came to Jesus by night -- not the other way around.  We don't know if the woman caught in the act of adultery was at the foot of the cross; we don't know what Jesus wrote with His finger in the sand -- Singer uses these as legitimate plot devices -- but if you're going to insist on ultra-literalism, you have to be consistent.Item:  I don't find the notion that Theophilus was Paul's advocate convincing -- but as a plot device, I'm willing to let it stand.Item:  THE BIGGEST AND MOST EGREGIOUS ISSUES ARE HISTORICAL!  If you are willing to use the testimony of Josephus; if you are willing to use the testimony of Roman historians, why in heaven's name don't you do the same with the early Christian texts?*  The entire notion of both Luke's Gospel and the book of Acts being hastily composed during the very earliest time of persecution suggests to me that Singer has never seriously studied the composition of either text.  Luke was a highly educated man who was an eyewitness to some of the events in Acts.  In the Prologue verses for both books, he proposes to his readership exactly what he plans to do, and how he plans to do it.  He then executes his plan exactly as he stated that he would.  This is classical Greek biography; not something dashed off in a short period of time.*  How does Singer's views of the composition of Luke's Gospel explain the personal family details found in the Infancy Narrative?*  Singer presents Luke as using some fragments of an account of the life of Jesus written by some young Christian named John Mark.  Mark was more than just some guy!  He had traveled with Paul, and was the secretary to Peter.*  For that matter, where is Peter?  He's mentioned once.  Doesn't Singer realize that Peter, too, was a victim of Nero's persecution?*  Singer's historical timeline is goofed up.  Acts ends with Paul in Rome, living in a rented house, awaiting trial.  Most scholars (using the testimony in both Acts, and in II Timothy) believe that Paul was released following his first trial, continued to travel, and was re-arrested and martyred during Nero's persecution.*  Singer's theology is goofed up.  When a crowd of believers shows up at the home of Theophilus, a watered-down version of a post-Reformation era communion service is presented -- as almost an afterthought.  Is Singer unaware of Paul's specific instructions in 1st Corinthians regarding the celebration of the Lord's Supper?*  Details about the persecution under Nero abound.  It didn't happen the way Singer presents it.  And no, even Nero, would not have dared to crucify Roman citizens.  Hence, the beheading of Paul (the Roman citizen) and the crucifixion of Peter (not a Roman citizen.)*  Singer does give a few clues to a reviewer who is an historian, that at least some early Christian traditions were researched.  Singer uses the name "Longinus" -- long associated with the Centurion at the foot of the cross.  Singer also writes an epilogue, using the name of an Early Church Father -- Eusebius -- but mis-dating the Council of Nicaea by a decade; and suggesting that Eusebius presented the Emperor Constantine with copies of the Bible.  Only problem here?  The New Testament was still very much in flux during the time of Eusebius -- and Eusebius writes about that very controversy!As I said:  I wanted to like this book.  I liked the premise.  But I can't get past the sloppy Scripture scholarship, and I REALLY can't get past what appears to be a deliberate re-writing of Early Church History.Give this one a miss.

. . . but he is so agenda-driven regarding the issue of anti-semitism (real or imagined) that it really detracts from the storyline.Please don't get me wrong; this is a good novel in many respects.  The theme of post-WWII Italy is one that can -- and should -- be thoroughly explored, both through works of fiction and non-fiction, and in this work of fiction, Carroll uses interesting, well-fleshed out characters to tell several stories (Warburg being one of them).  Without spoilers, I found much of the ending quite satisfying.The problem here is that seemingly every non-Jewish character is presented as all anti-Semitic, all of the time from (predictably) Church leaders to the President of the United States.  In the latter case, he suggests that the historical President Truman deliberately fired his Jewish Cabinet Secretary, because he was afraid that if he, the Vice-President, and the Secretary of State were all killed, someone Jewish would become President.  The only problem with that theory, Mr. Carroll, is that this is not (and was not) how the line of succession works -- and any 9th grade civics textbook could have told you that.  (The Speaker of the House and the President Pro-Tempore of the Senate are ahead of any Cabinet Secretaries.Stick to the historical fiction; stick to creating believable, flawed, yet likable characters; stick to good storytelling -- but try to tone down the agenda.

. . . by a first time author -- and one who was only 10 years old when the book was completed!"The Monster Realm" is a work of teen/YA fantasy and is the first book in a proposed trilogy.  I read the book, as did two of my daughters, ages 13 and 17.  I can't wait for the next two books to be published.Nara's human characters are well-developed and likable; her storytelling is engaging; she shows an enviable knowledge of Greek mythological creatures; and the plot flows nicely, leaving the reader wanting more.  (I know that I did!)I strongly suspect that the author is extremely well-read for her age.  I loved the character who swore in Shakespearean insults!  (And I could not help but be impressed by her reference to "Titus Andronicus"!  I suspect that most college English majors are not familiar with THAT play!)This is a young author to watch.  If this is the quality of work she is capable of now, just think what the next few decades could bring!Well done, Nara!  I'll gladly review anything else you write.

I can hardly wait until the remaining two books in the trilogy are translated into English!I chose to review this novel because it is completely outside my expertise -- and even comfort zone.  From time to time, I feel that it is important to me to do so!Boy, am I glad that I did!I'll freely admit that while I am a professional theologian, my area of expertise is in the West (part of the reason I wanted to review this book).  I am not an expert in either ancient or modern Hinduism -- and don't purport to be.  This book, however, is intelligent and challenging.  The author is essentially re-creating a 4,000 year-old myth, and bringing it down to human terms.Very highly recommended!  I loved this one!I couldn't put this book down!  It is expertly written (and translated) and conveying a very riveting and interesting story.

. . . and they had become somewhat formulaic.  In "The Three Emperors", the author really gets back to the good storytelling one found in the first two "Ethan Gage" novels -- and I appreciated that!  I want to avoid giving away spoilers -- but evil secret societies, battles, temptation, and beautiful women abound.The author has a tendency to make characters (both good and evil) from previous books re-appear -- and "The Three Emperors" is no exception.There was a lot of resolution of tension (sexual and otherwise) that had been building over the last three or four books; and I am eagerly anticipating the next novel.No spoilers -- but a really enjoyable story.

. . . in a previous review, I vowed NEVER to review another Steve Berry "Cotton Malone" novel.I changed my mind.  "The Lincoln Myth" was so superior to the previous book, that I have to be honest and say that I did enjoy it.People who won't enjoy it:  Traditional members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints.  Berry has demonstrated that he is "equal opportunity" in his disdain for religious traditions -- regardless of what they happen to be.Other people who won't enjoy it:  Those readers who insist that if one is going to write a series of novels using the same set of characters, back-stories cannot violently change.  One wonders if the author is capable of keeping up with more than one or two major characters at a time.But the book is a ripping good yarn -- even if not reasonably believable.Not a bad beach novel.

. . . by this purported novel (using the term very loosely).  I am a conservative Catholic by most reasonably accepted standards.  I'm a convert who knew exactly what I was getting into when I was received into the Church.  I am, by profession, an historian and theologian -- and my Scripture studies and interpretation would certainly fall well to the right of center.  I believe in the reality of sin and evil and am sadly aware of the sins committed in the name of God and in the name of the Church.  I am strongly opposed to the heresy of Modernism -- but I am equally opposed to that (hopefully) small group of very traditionalist Catholics who throw around the term "Modernism" to attack anyone who dares to disagree with them.  I see that as a mark of intellectual laziness.This work of "faction" is a hashed together diatribe about anything the author doesn't like about the Church, held thinly together by a bizarre plot that would make most conspiracy theorists blush.I was given my copy by a very devout, very pious, woman in my parish who is quite possibly more conservative than I am.  She was very frustrated by the author's strident tone and wanted to discuss her concerns with me.  I not only concurred with her concerns, but added a few of my own.  The author may have been more persuasive if his tone had been a bit more irenic -- but that still would not have made up for the structural defects of the novel itself.Without spoilers, let me just suggest that the ending smacks of more than a little "sede-vacante" influence.Don't waste your time.

. . . with "Glad" products.  I am, however, with this one.  I have a large family, and I tend to cook large meals.  These bags are exactly as advertised -- and I suspect that, by the end of summer, my freezer will be full of them!I like the heavy duty plastic, and I really like the strong seal.I would definitely purchase this product.

. . . and think that I'm liable to like the series.I've read all the "Sigma Force" novels, and found the "Tucker Wayne" character to be intriguing.  Apparently, so did others.Yes, this is a somewhat formulaic novel in the "Action Thriller" category -- but I found it better than many in the genre.I liked it -- and liked it well enough to try the next book in the series.Recommended.

. . . and I learned quite a bit.I'll admit it.  Even as a history major, World War I history has not been an area of expertise.  I knew that the assassination of the Archduke was considered to be the spark which ignited the powder keg which erupted into World War I.  I knew that the stupidity, naiveté, and just plain bone-headedness of the leadership of most of the participating nations pretty much guaranteed a second world war.  I knew that American involvement in the war probably helped bring an early end to the war.  Beyond that?  Not much.Boy did I learn!I didn't know what an "Archduke" was and didn't understand the (very) complicated hierarchies of the Austrian royalty and nobility.  I didn't realize that the Archduke Franz Ferdinand was the Heir Apparent.  I didn't realize how devout both he and his wife were, nor how devoted they both were to their family.  I also didn't realize how poorly his children were treated and how his sons suffered during the Nazi regime.This book sets out to re-examine the Archduke; discover who he really was and what he believed; and to attempt to correct some of the historical revisionism that surrounded his family.  In my view, the authors succeeded in their purposes -- and, apparently, at least one surviving member of his House believe so as well.This book; this love story reads like a novel.  I couldn't put it down, and indeed, have re-read a good deal of it.As an interesting side-note, the Archduke's nephew (and heir) who was forced off the throne in 1918, is well on his way to being declared a saint in the Catholic Church.After reading this book, the following remark by Sir Winston Churchill makes a great deal of sense:"This war (World War II) would never have come unless, under American and modernising pressure, we had driven the Habsburgs out of Austria and the Hohenzollerns out of Germany. By making these vacuums we gave the opening for the Hitlerite monster to crawl out of its sewer on to the vacant thrones. No doubt these views are very unfashionable...." Sir Winston Churchill, 8th April 1945.I can't recommend this book highly enough.  5 enthusiastic stars!

. . . with a good deal of value.I have no doubt that this book has infuriated many.  In "JFK, Conservative", Ira Stoll is literally attempting to re-make a legend.  Such an attempt will generate controversy.Stoll makes the point, however, that word usages have changed significantly throughout the years, and words like "liberal" and "conservative" don't necessarily carry the same meanings today that they have in the past.  It is also true that the perspective of the various political parties has also changed over the years.Whether Stoll's usage of "conservative" or "liberal" can be sustained is a reasonable point of discussion.  However . . .. . . as the words are understood today, Kennedy's anti-Communism would certainly be considered "conservative".. . . as the words are understood today, Kennedy's foreign policy would certainly be considered "conservative" (except with the Libertarian movement).. . . as the words are understood today, Kennedy's tax-cutting policies would certainly be considered "conservative".  (Even, it is interesting to note, more conservative than Barry Goldwater's views).. . . as the words are understood today, Kennedy's attempts at fiscal restraint would certainly be considered conservative.Stoll also points out that some of Kennedy's liberal biographers were creative in their editing and selective in their use of quotation to attempt to prove their own points and political philosophies.I would not classify this book as straight history, but by the same token, I would not classify it as agenda-driven either.  Let's say that it is provocative in the questions that it asks.  The readers can draw their own conclusions.Highly recommended.

. . . detailing what Lawrence himself called "a sideshow of a sideshow" -- namely the Middle-Eastern front in World War One.  While the book is titled "Lawrence in Arabia", the book isn't merely about TE Lawrence (though he is the major player).  The book also details the machinations of the German anti-Semite Curt Prufer (who manages to acquire as a lover and recruit as a spy the younger sister of the man who would become the first president of the State of Israel; Aaron Aaronsohn, a scientist and committed Zionist; and the American William Yale, working for the interests of Standard Oil, New York.  All four men play significant roles in this book."Lawrence in Arabia" also serves to de-bunk myths made popular by the classic film "Lawrence of Arabia" -- and also recounts in incredible detail the idiocy of most of the military commanders, especially the British and French; the deceitful diplomatic posturing and posing, again, especially by the British and French; and the complete naiveté of President Wilson as to the historical and political realities in the Middle East.I appreciate the enormous depth of research and work that went into this book.  I also appreciate that the personal editorializing by the author was kept to a minimum (and concentrated at the very end of the book.)  I'm offering 4 stars instead of 5 only because the work is so incredibly in-depth and detailed, that I'm afraid that it may prove too daunting a read for some.I greatly enjoyed this book.  Highly recommended.

. . . as is my brother, and we both have a number of iterations of the game.  This one looks flashy and "hip" (and, I suppose in one sense, it is) but I note a number of detractions.  For one thing, only 2-4 players can play the game rather than 6 (or even more, in some editions.)  For another, at least to my mind, the game has been "dumbed-down".  There is more luck involved than merely two six-sided dice.  And the game seems designed to run more quickly than the standard edition (and yes, I realize that this may NOT be a detraction for all!)  This edition will also need to be updated regularly, as certain "brands" come and go in popularity (though I'll freely admit that Coca-Cola and Pepsi are likely here to stay!)Look, to my mind, it's hard to improve on a classic -- and the original game is a classic.  In my view, Hasbro has seriously damaged the board game market; absorbing Milton Bradley, Parker Brothers, Selchow and Righter and Avalon Hill, but not noticeably improving the product or developing new games.I've been playing the original game since I was five.  I think I'll stick to it.

. . . to a stunning saga of Space Opera.In the opinion of this reviewer, Michael Flynn does "Space Opera" as well as any alive today (and with more depth of character than Doc Smith, and less of the tediousness one sees toward the end of Asimov's "Foundation" series).To the best of my ability, there are no spoilers here.Several reviewers pointed out (rightly, in my estimation) that this novel is not a "stand-alone".  It must be read as the fourth book of a four volume saga.  (I will point out, though, that knocking off stars for not being a stand-alone is not quite fair).  This concludes the saga begun in "The January Dancer" and opens up a universe of worlds which is thousands, if not tens of thousands years in the future; a universe of high technology -- but one in which much has been forgotten.  Amid the fighting; the betrayal; the various factions; backstories galore (which really don't begin to clarify themselves until the third volume) this is, at the end of the day, a love story.  A love story with vibrant, yet deeply flawed characters and well worth the read.As an aside, I love what Flynn has done with his take on the evolution of languages and names.  Very creative -- and believable.Flynn's style is not to everyone's taste -- and requires effort -- but the reward gained is well worth the effort.Very highly recommended.

. . . to be able to read and review this masterful and thorough biography.I grew up with Sesame Street.  My wife grew up on The Muppet Show.  Our kids watched Muppet Babies.  Etc., etc., etc.This is the biography of Jim Henson -- Muppet Man and creative genius extraordinare that Henson fans have been waiting for since his untimely demise in 1990.This extremely thorough and well-written book begins by tracing Henson's ancestors (on both sides of the family) giving important information on some of the things that would influence him throughout his life.  Chapters are devoted to each stage of Henson's career, from his early days at WTOP in Washington, DC, to Sesame Street (which, I argue, would never have been the huge success it has been over the last 40 years without Henson and his Muppet team), to the wildly hysterical (and ground-breaking) The Muppet Show; to Fraggle Rock; to the films -- both the successful Muppet Movies, and the less than successful (but cult classics) "The Dark Crystal" and "Labyrinth" and everything in-between.I learned a lot about Jim Henson.  This biography does an excellent job of presenting who he was as a person.  It is not a hagiography by any stretch of the imagination.  Character flaws are certainly not ignored (and Henson had his share).  But the character qualities also shine through:  his personal generosity, his loyalty, his love of family, just to name a few.I highly recommend this book for anyone who has had any connection with any of Henson's creations.  And for anyone who hasn't!Jim Henson truly was a Storyteller.  May he rest in peace.Five enthusiastic stars!

. . . and didn't stay around for very long!I love dried fruit, and I thought that this would be a good way to try a new product.  The serving size was appropriate for a snack -- and healthy and tasty in equal parts.  "Dried" can sometimes mean "dried-out" -- but not in this case.  The fruit was flavorful and chewy.  There is no sugar or other sweetener added -- and none was needed whatsoever.  The fruit was more than sweet enough on its own.  (I'm guessing that the dehydration process concentrates the naturally occurring fruit sugars. . . ?)Anyway, this is certainly a product I'd eat again, and I'll probably sample some of the other flavors as well.Recommended.

. . . and unique book.I'll admit it.  I didn't know what to expect when I selected this item from Vine.  "Soviet" and "cooking" are not typically two words which appear in the same sentence!  But the second part of the title "A Memoir of Food and Longing" is an exact description of what this book is.The author, born in the former Soviet Union in 1963, emigrated with her mother to the United States in 1974.  This book tells her story -- and the story of her mother and father (who grew up in the Stalin years -- and during the Second World War) -- and the story of her grand-parents, etc., etc., using food to describe the changes in the USSR from the time of the 1917 Revolution through the present.  The stories range from the wildly funny to the depths of pathos -- and food seems to be part of every story that is told.  At the end of the book, the author gives a recipe for each of the decades of the USSR -- except for one (and in the interest of not spoiling the book, I'll leave it at that!)  Some of the recipes I'd love to try -- others, I'd love to avoid, but certainly understand their inclusion.Recommended! Very highly!

. . . I've liked this one the best.  From Alexander the Great to the Greek rulers of Egypt to the tomb of St. Mark (Alexandria? Venice?) to the steppes of Central Asia and into China, this novel will not disappoint.I've mentioned before that I've felt that Berry's character development is certainly one of his strong suits -- and he shows this again in "The Venetian Betrayal".  We see a different side of Cassiopeia Vitt; a charismatic, yet ruthless tyrant in Central Asia; some double-agents (or are they?); and of course Cotton Malone doing his thing.Certainly an enjoyable summer read.

. . . than the previous novel -- but with a similar criticism.  It is obvious that Mr. Berry loves history -- and I applaud him for that.  This being said:  If you're going to delve into Middle-Eastern history (which is primarily religious in nature) you need to have some idea as to what you are talking about; you need to have more than just a superficial grasp of theology.  It is clear to this reviewer that Mr. Berry really does not.What I liked most about this book was the character interplay between Cotton, his ex-wife, and his son.  Some of it was, perhaps, predictable -- but for whatever reasons, I like Mr. Berry's characters.  The quest for the lost "Great Library of Alexandria" is a theme that has been used before -- but that's okay as it is an interesting theme, and one that will most likely to be continued to used.Not high literature -- but not bad for a bit of escapism!

. . . to the chapter of "The Supper of the Lamb" entitled "The Long Session".In Fr. Capon's masterpiece, "The Supper of the Lamb", one of the later chapters is dedicated to the importance of the dinner party.  In "Party Spirit", Fr. Capon takes the concept of the dinner party and carries it forward in a most delightful way.Ten or more years separate "Party Spirit" from "The Supper of the Lamb", and in some respects, Fr. Capon's tastes (and principles) have redacted slightly.  For example, while still abhorring the concept of the cocktail party (and, with apologies to St. Thomas Aquinas, demolishes the concept in a manner which would delight any scholastic theologian) valuable points are given for when the giving of a cocktail party seems inevitable.  In addition, Fr. Capon's views on the ideal number of guests is more broadly characterized than in the earlier work.Fr. Capon opines that the only two types of parties are the planned ones and the impromptu ones -- and spends a good deal of time discussing both.  I particularly enjoyed, however, the umpteen number of both main dishes and desserts created impromptu from a minimum number of ingredients.The theology, while not as pervasive as in "The Supper of the Lamb" is nonetheless present -- and a necessary part of the book.  Of particular interest to me was his discussion of the Parable of the Wedding Feast.Four+ stars.  It's not "The Supper of the Lamb" -- such a Magnum Opus comes along only once a lifetime.  But nevertheless, a worthy read -- both entertaining and thought-provoking.

. . . and I ate it immediately!This was REALLY good!  The mixed nuts were just salty enough; the chocolate was just enough (but not too sweet); and the nutritional benefits were just what I needed for a mid-afternoon pick-me-up.If you're doing Adkins or South Beach, you might not want to expend this many carbs on a snack, but the 4 grams of fiber and 8 grams of protein makes it a good choice for most.I really enjoyed this, and would most likely purchase it again.Recommended.

. . . than a Vatican conspiracy novel?  I know!  A vampire novel!  So the next logical step?  A VATICAN CONSPIRACY VAMPIRE NOVEL!Oh please!  A secret order of "Good" vampires?  Dating back to the raising of Lazarus?  Incorporating the historical tragedy of Masada?  And the bizarre behavior of (an admittedly bizarre) Rasputin some 20 centuries later?Again.  Oh Please!I picked this novel up primarily because I have thoroughly enjoyed James Rollins' "Sigma Force" novels, and also a couple of his "stand-alones".  I figured I'd give him the benefit of the doubt and give this book a try.Historically (ridiculously) unsound (even assuming the fantasy element), this book does no justice to either historical OR supernatural fiction.Not the best choice in reading I've made! Give this one a miss!

. . . I never thought I would use, much less own, a juicer.  But this machine is WAY cool!It was easier to set up and run than I expected; easier to clean than I expected; worked much faster than I expected; AND it makes GREAT juice!First attempt:  Cherry-Limeade.  Works equally well whether you peel the limes or not and handled the cherry pits and stems without any problems at all.  Furthermore, my wife liked the results!Second attempt:  Oranges, limes, chunk pineapple (from a can) and maraschino cherries.  DELICIOUS!  Had the juice for breakfast, then added some sweet Italian sparkling wine for after dinner.I'm gonna have fun with this thing . . .RECOMMENDED!

. . . by a number of elements in this book.  I've reviewed several books in this genre; I have children in the high school and college age range -- and it is certainly a different world than it was when my wife and I were in school.Positive #1 -- "Revised and Updated"  If a book in this genre is NOT "revised and updated" on a regular basis, it rapidly becomes useless.  Laws, regulations, and tax codes change so frequently that updating is needed.Positive #2 -- The recognition that there is a difference between "good" debt and "bad" debt.  This is a point that many people seem to miss.  Not all debt is inherently "evil" and this book helps the reader understand the difference.Positive #3 -- Unlike virtually every book in this genre I've read or reviewed, this book actually discusses school loans; how to use them; and how to get yourself out of trouble if things go wrong.Recommended!

. . . I thought that I'd give the other "Cotton  Malone" novels a try.I'm glad I didn't read this one first.  I may well not have continued.Let me start with the positives:  I truly liked the characters, and that is probably the main reason this book received two stars, instead of one.  I liked the human interest angle.  I liked the action.  I liked the centuries-old castle being restored using only tools available hundreds of years ago.But . . .Mr. Berry may well love history -- but his knowledge of Church history and Early Christianity is sorely lacking.  And I'm not talking about those issues over which scholars have legitimate and reasonable disagreement.  I'm talking basic, fundamental facts about which there really isn't any dispute.  One example should suffice (and I know I'll lose some readers here).  There was a fundamental difference between sub-New Testament writings which, even though never part of Scripture, were widely used in the Church, and writings which the Church rejected outright -- and never used in any capacity.  The author completely conflates these two very distinct types of literature into a single genre.  You just can't do that.I'm continuing to read the series, again, because I like the characters -- and need a bit of escapism from time to time.  But the flaws of this book certainly outweighed the good points.

. . . in the "inner workings" of the Royal Household of Queen Victoria, this book is for you.This book is neither biography, in the strict sense of the word; nor is it history, again in the strict sense of the word -- though there is a good deal of both contained within the pages.  It relates the story of the reign of Queen Victoria from beginning to end -- through the eyes of six different retainers who served her in various (and very different) ways.  All six perspectives are unique -- and anyone even remotely interested in 19th century England should be delighted.  One thing I particularly enjoyed was reading about the quite different relationships that the Queen maintained with her various Prime Ministers -- and how whatever political party was in power would try to place "their people" in the Queen's "Inner Circle".A truly enjoyable read -- and not just for a "history geek" like me!

. . . Steve Berry "Cotton Malone" novel I ever read, so I did not have a great deal of the backstory available to those who have already been fans.  I have to be careful with this type of review, because I don't want to run the risk of "spoilers".I checked this book out of the library because the premise -- a link between the assassinations of Presidents Lincoln, Garfield, McKinley, and Kennedy -- thoroughly interested the "historical geek" in me.  The stories of all four of these presidents has long interested me, so I thought I'd give the book a try.I'm glad that I did.  The premise, admittedly, was a bit far-fetched, but the storyline was well-handled.  Some of the characters interested me enough that I decided to go back and read some of Berry's early "Cotton Malone" novels (which I will review at a later point)."Conspiracy" novels do run the risk of trying to be "too clever by half" or by insulting an historically informed reader with silliness -- but I didn't find that this novel fell into either of these pitfalls.An enjoyable and recommended read.

. . . but this one seemed "manufactured" to me.  Yes, I know what to expect from a formulaic plot -- and there is nothing wrong with a good formula -- but this one was weak.Without any spoilers, the rather dramatic ending of the last Ethan Gage novel resolves itself almost immediately -- in a manner I found to be somewhat staged, if not downright unbelievable.  And, again without spoilers, some of the plot developments are excruciatingly predictable.If you enjoy the series, by all means, continue.  But if this is your first attempt at an "Ethan Gage" novel -- have second thoughts about starting here.  Go back to the beginning!

. . . since I have derived so much pleasure in a novel.  The title fascinated me: a combination of Jewish and Arabian folklore?  In one novel?  Set in turn-of-the 20th century New York?This, I had to try!And boy am I glad that I did.  The author has a way of making characters come alive; the interplay between the various traditions is fascinating and well-written; and the descriptions of the immigrant life in New York City resonated with me.I can only hope that this author follows up with further books!  If so, count me in!Very, very highly recommended!  It's completely outside the "norm" in a truly wonderful way.

. . . of a somewhat overlooked aspect of the "era" of King Henry VIII.Most consideration of the children of King Henry VIII typically deals with the reigns of Edward VI, Mary I, and Elizabeth I.  This book gives deep background on the upbringing and education (both religious and secular) of Henry's children; not only the three that later ruled, but also of his acknowledged illegitimate son, Henry Fitz Roy.  This book deals not so much on "how" they reigned (whether for good or for ill) but also "what made them tick" as human beings, caught as they were in politically perilous times.In my professional life, I've had occasion to lecture on numerous occasions on Henry VIII and the role that he played in the English Reformation -- and I'll confess, upon reading this book, I learned quite a few things I didn't previously know.  I enjoy it when that happens!  I only wish there had been even more detail!  (But perhaps that's the history geek in me coming out . . . )Recommended!

. . . and absolutely fascinating journey through time and history.  (Disclaimer:  I am a historian by education and profession, so this stuff might appeal to me more than to the average reader!)Author Andrew Carroll took several months and traveled literally all over the United States (including to a practically uninhabited island in Hawai'i) to find the "back stories" to episodes in American history that we thought we knew; characters we have never heard of who made larger impacts than we can imagine, sites of long-forgotten battles and massacres, and more -- much more!I can't recommend this book highly enough.  Even if you're not a history geek (like me) not only will the stories amaze and enlighten you, the skill of the storyteller himself is delightful.Very highly recommended!

. . . if not completely exhaustive look at the National Parks in the United States.  I chose to review this book, as I have traveled through and camped in many National Parks all over the country.  This book would be a definite asset were I to make such trips again.  As one might expect from National Geographic, the photography is absolutely stunning.  The information about the parks is complete and up-to-date -- though this is a book that will need to be revised on a regular basis.While not covering every park in equal detail (this is a guidebook -- not an encyclopedia!) many of the parks I have especially enjoyed were highlighted:  Shenandoah, Grand Tetons, Yellowstone, Yosemite, Mesa Verde, Sequoia, etc.Our National Parks are truly a national treasure.  I hope to see this book updated regularly through the years.Recommended.

. . . I've read most of Tom Clancy's novels, and have enjoyed them.  Yes, the plots are a bit formulaic -- but it's an entertaining formula -- and the reader is aware of this going in.I also appreciate that while I was reading this work of fiction -- cyber attacks from China were actually occurring.  Clancy has a knack for current events; his "what might happen" does seem to sometimes happen!I am deducting a star however as there were some significant continuity issues from the previous novel with regard to the "Melanie Kraft" sub-plot.  From this reader's perspective, the entire sub-plot could have been handled much better -- through both novels.But I enjoyed the read and certainly didn't think that I'd wasted my time.A solid four stars.

. . . but nothing particularly worthy of being preserved in Michel Delving or in the Library at Tuckborough, much less in Gondor.With the enormous popularity engendered by the "Lord of the Rings" films, and now, the first installation of "The Hobbit", it was inevitable that all kinds of handbooks, commentaries, essays, opinions, biographies, etc. would be written.  Some are good; some few are excellent.  This one isn't bad; only mediocre.  The reader will get a few laughs; possibly a few insights; but unless the reader is really into amassing a collection of all things "Middle-Earth", this book isn't necessary.Three stars.

. . . better late than never!In short, we really liked this product.  And not just as a mattress "topper"!  In a home with multiple high-school and college students always in and out, something that can be used as an emergency "extra bed" can be very handy!  Honestly, this didn't feel so much like a mattress topper as it did an honest-to-goodness real mattress.  Technology is advancing, and thus the comfort level is as well.  This is not a typical foam pad!Only problem:  this type of foam is considerably more fragile than the old-fashioned kind, and can crack if treated with disrespect!  But that's my only caveat.Recommended!EDITED:  Only 3 stars, after extended use.  See my only problem with the earlier review.  Over time, the cracking got worse, and, honestly, this is difficult to roll and to transport.  Sad. It really is comfortable.
This peeler works great!  It feels good in the hand; slices expertly, and is easy to use.  My children enjoyed using it as much as I did.Not much more to say!Highly recommended!

. . . with the tragedies in Ireland in the 19th century; this book was a devastating reading."The Famine Plot" examines the relationship between England and Ireland during the various waves of famine and blight which swept over Ireland through much of the 19th century.  I'm a reasonably well-read historian -- and even I was shocked by the callousness, disregard, bloated bureaucracy, greed, and downright evil perpetrated by the English political, social, and religious leadership against Ireland.  The book's author is obviously trying to make a case that the behavior of the English government toward the starving Irish rises to the level of genocide (according to the UN definition) and, in the eyes of this reviewer, he makes a pretty darn good case.  (Honestly, there were times when I could only read a few pages without tossing the book aside in disgust at man's inhumanity to his fellow man.)The stereotypical Irish Catholic mistrust of the English Protestant is certainly made clear.  And understandable.I have to note that there were few "good guys" in this narrative.  Both major political parties in England share plenty of blame.  The sympathetic and/or charitable English landlord was the exception, rather than the rule.  And the attempt to tie food for the starving to coerced religious conversion was beyond the pale.An outstanding, yet painful read.Highly recommended.

. . . of an old Jewish folk-tale.  (In the interest of historical accuracy, there was a "Rabbi Judah" who, according to some traditions, did, in fact, create a golem!)In this charming Hanukkah story, Rabbi Judah leaves his home to visit the Emperor.  While he was away, his lazy housekeeper figured that she could use the golem to make latkes -- but she forgot the magic words to make it stop!  This lavishly illustrated children's story made me laugh out loud!Highly recommended -- and not only throughout the Jewish population.  This Catholic Christian enjoyed it thoroughly (as did the entire family!)

There are quite a few tea drinkers in my family -- and we all seem to enjoy different styles and flavors.  The Lipton Herbal Orange Blossom Hibiscus was a huge hit.  Not only was the flavor a delight, Lipton's "Pyramid Tea Bags" do a wonderful job of bringing out the best while steeping.  If you're looking for a non-caffeinated orange tea -- try this one.  You won't regret it.Highly Recommended!

Hook Me Up:How can you not be hooked right way when a book starts off with the barely clothed heroine stuck in a tree with her cat. You know it has just get better from there because soon you add a hunky fireman who comes to her rescue. It's a short read, but you get everything you need to make it a great story. You're not left disappointed.

The thing that grabbed me first about this book is that the hero is a baseball player. That right there will have me reading the book. I saw some reviews about the kink Chase is into. Now I read erotica, D/s themed books, and ones with kink this was very tame compared to those. Yes Chase has a secret kink, but Amanda makes it consensual and enjoys it so as far as that topic goes it's fine with me. Plus Chase treats Amanda like a queen. The atmosphere does change in the book from the beginning until Chase reveals his secret, but it grows as the couple does.  They have their ups and downs, but you see the love they have for one another shine through. I loved the wedding scene so perfect.

I really liked the idea of Coop trying to reunite with  the one who got away. Second thoughts emerge, but Coop is in for a surprise when Julia shows up instead of her twin. Julia wants to turn right around when she's Coop because she knows that her wanted her sister. Can Coop convince Julia to stay an experience the delights he has to offer and she is the one his body craves? Julia sees little glimpse of the true Coop, but how can he possible fall for her. Can these two take advantage of the chance fate has given them? I liked getting to know Coop because every layer revealed makes you fall more in love with him. Julia living in her twin's shadow she deserves what Coop is offering. Can't wait to read the other two books in the series.

Right off the bat I like Jared just for rescuing Elise, but as we get into more of the book you can't help to love him. Elise is a werewolf, but she's never met anyone else like her that changes one fateful night she finally crosses paths with another werewolf. There is a very romantic part to me at least towards the end with Jared surprising Elise. It's sort of a whirlwind romance, but these two have the sparks and chemistry. Sometimes you know you've found your mate.

Loved this book. Being a Lord of the Rings fan loved the reference. Ari is a sexy as sin rockstar who is burning out. He's losing his passion so a vacation is in order. Neveah finds herself with a rockstar for a week living and breathing fantasy come true. As these two get to know each they start to reveal their inner makings. The chemistry and heat level is off the charts steaming hot.

I really enjoyed this one. The elementary school teacher and the fireman. Cole is still battling with losing a squad member. He takes care of everyone, but who takes care of him? Ivy is a parent pleaser, but her one rebellion is her career. I love how animated and passionate she is about her students. Though Cole and Ivy didn't originally want to go along with this plan of staying at the castle they learn it's the best decision they've ever made. Right from the get go this book has you snared with the bratwurst eating contest and the after math. Not everything is sunshine and rainbows especially when Cole's ex shows up. What Cole does at the end just makes you fall in love with him. Plus I have to add the heat level between these two is hot!!

This book has one of my favorite troupes brother's sister/brother's best friend. Elle is going to find the evidence she needs, but unexpected twist Logan shows up. His task keep Elle out of trouble, but who's going to protect her from him? Sparks immediately start flaring between these two. They secretly have crushing on one another, but the whole best friend's sister deal. Danger is lurking. Can Elle get the info she needs before someone gets her? I really liked these two because of the history they have since childhood you can tell they're already great friends, but attraction is there. The action in this one just hooks me even more.

Laney and Gunner haven't had it easy, but things sure get even harder in this one. I really liked that we got Gunner's point of view along with Laney's in this one. We really needed it with everything coming to a head. This book sure keeps you on your toes. The previous books have been leading up to this. Betrayal, back stabbing, and bring you to your knees hurt happen, but there is more than meets the eye. We all know about Luke and Gunner, but Colt another cowboy is added to the mix. Mighty jealous of Laney having three hunky cowboys in her life. Will Gunner finally get the justice he seeks? And will Laney get her HEA? The epilogue is the moment all us Laney and Gunner fans having been waiting for. Jodi delivers in this one and gives her readers the perfect ending who have been on this wild journey.

At the beginning while reading I didn't think I was going to really like this one as much as the previous book in the series, but boy was I proved wrong. I really got caught up in the book. You have Luke and Alexis two damaged souls. They have scars both physical and emotional. To see the magic healing touch these two have for one another is something to read. You can't help, but feel for them. Their inner demons really do a number, but on Alexis' journey of self discovery she gets way more then she ever expected. Luke is set to task of "babysitting" Alexis, but he definitely gets way more then he bargained for. But will it come back to bit him in the butt by keeping it a secret why he just happens to show up everywhere Alexis is?

Wow, what a book. I was hooked right from the beginning with Ryker interacting with his little girls and the whole spider scene. The book just gets better from there. Ryker is definitely going on my favorite book boyfriend list. He has passion, compassion, and protective of those he cares about plus a bonus he is oh so yummy. I liked how the book really got in the process of running a hockey team. It gives a great feel of the game which as a sports lover and romance book lover I feel is so important.  Gray is making history by becoming the first female general manager in hockey. She has an up hill battle, but she has the support of her star goalie. You can feel the instant attraction between them. When they're together it's HOT!! One problem, they have to keep it a secret with what's going on between them. Things get dicey for them, but can they come ahead on top? Loved the ending of the book was just perfect and the epilogue was a great way to wrap up this story. If you want a book the has it all and will suck you in grab this one for sure.

In this one we meet Trent (who is 6 at the time), but he has no memory. He has to rely on wolf shifters to help him to try to figure out where he is from and who he is. We are also introduced to Stella a 6 year old shifter. They are on a journey to seek answers, but once they get there danger is lurking. It does end on a cliffhanger, but it so makes you anticipate the next part.

We continue with Trent's journey. We get to learn a little more about the wolf shifters and the world of magic. Plus Trent gets a some answers that to lead to more questions. I liked that we get to see the other side when Trent and Emma make contact which is very intriguing, but you have to read to find out the significance of the moment. Will Trent gain any memory of who or what he is?  Can he be trusted by the wolf shifters?

This is the second part of a four part series. Evan has gone back home to Paris, but Margie is on her way to Paris for apprenticeship with a bread maker. Ava weaves such a beautiful tale of the magic in bread making. That part in the book is just so magical it gave me chills. Evan is still keeping the secret of his billionaire status from Margie. Margie is slowly, but surely falling for Evan the man she thinks he is. Evan is such a romantic, but what happens when his secret comes out?

This book sucks you in. I love how the main characters and secondary characters have their interesting quirks that make them unique. Very tight close knit group of friends. Trish is very intriguing character. She has a very painful past that she struggles to deal with, but in spite of that she is one remarkable character. Too bad she doesn't see it. She doesn't believe in fairtytales, but Max sure makes her want to. Max has issues of his own, but with Trish be his side he may just be able to find the help. I really loved seeing these two characters bring the best out each other and the support that they give one another. Just that alone is worth reading this book.

How can you not like a book that starts off with the hero stranded naked on the side of the road. You know it's going to be a good one. Pierce has a little gambling problem and he's racked up a lot of debt. Now widowed Duchess Evelyn stumbles upon him and offers him an unlikely proposal to benefit them both. What starts out as a business proposal turns very personal. As Pierce and Evelyn explore untold pleasures Pierce gets to thinking about his life choices. Will Evelyn have the courage to love again or will she lose Pierce?

I will confess I was not a fan of Grayson at beginning his attitude was not the greatest , but like most heroes he redeemed himself. I really enjoyed this one because it gives you the perspective from a romance author's point of view. I laughed a lot while reading this. The passion between Grayson and Jessie is hot!!!! Jessie is a romance writer and the book mostly takes place at a romance convention. I liked seeing it through an author's eyes. Grayson is a workaholic CEO who believes he knows what's best for his publishing company, but could it cost him something greater?

I loved this book. The characters are well written and intriguing. You have Chloe who is a shy introvert that believes she has to take on cosplay roles to be alluring to men. Then you have Grant single dad and dirty talker extraordinaire. When Grant and Chloe come together it's off the charts hot, they have so much chemistry. Chloe hides behind her roles because she is dealing with the tragedy in her family and believes the real her isn't worthy. Good thing Grant has come into her life because he's exactly what she needs. You won't be disappointed in this book. This book has passion, humor, heartbreak, and love.

I really enjoyed this one I could hear the Scottish accent when reading Craig, but the one thing that was a little off for me is how fast Arianna and Craig got together. As I read on of course I get more of a understanding behind it. Arianna is working on her thesis and it's about the legend/myths about Castle Nathair. What she gets is way more then she bargained for. There is something about the blacksmith Craig. More then meets the eye with that one. Get yourself wrapped up in magic, intrigue, and mystery with this book. I loved how this one ended for what Craig and Arianna had endured is was the magic tough this story needed.

I was not a fan of Lucas at the beginning his attitude rubbed me the wrong way, but of course he won me over. Can the love of the One can be what thaws Lucas' cold heart. He's on course to seek revenge against the man that cost him his family with any means necessary. Sydney is stuck between a rock in a hard place. Blackmailed into marrying Lucas or let her father's company go down. Now in the middle of a scandal she marries Lucas. Lines start to get blurred for Lucas when he gets to know the real Sydney behind the socialite facade. The chemistry between these two is HOT! I have to say Sydney is one of my favorite heroines. She is very relatable because of her own struggle with body image. I love the self confidence she finds with a little encouragement from Lucas.

I love these Bayou Heat novels. They just keep getting better and better. Both of these stories were awesome and pulled me right in.In Rage's story he has to look for the Geek who was a little hacker crazy and told move out of the Bayou. Now his mission is get her to help. Lucie always had a thing for Rage and didn't go about it the right way. Now he is stuck like glue while she does what she does best hacking. Being pushed together their animal instincts kick in and will the realize how they feel for one another before it's too late?In Killian's story you have Killian who is human, but unknown to his knowledge was being experimented in a lab now he is anything but normal. Rosalie is dealing with a whole lot of grief after losing her mate to the humans. She is seeking revenge and justice for her mate. a lot of the time her puma takes over, but there is something about Killian that calms here puma. Can Rosalie let go and move on or will she forever be stuck in the past? Soon Killian realizes the extent of what they did to him in the lab. Will he accept what he is now or will he lose the will to live and let Rosalie finish what she started.

The tension between Eros and Chloe is really boiling now. Chloe is going over the hump now on her challenge. Can she succeed on couple number 7? This one grabs you right away. Amber is a Siren who does the one night stand and believes a lasting relationship is not in the cards for her then Andreas walks into the bar. Andreas, a wolf shifter, with the convincing of his friend takes a mini vacation and finds something unexpected his mate. Andreas is in need of change and thinks he may have just stumbled across it. Amber can feel the magnetic pull when Andreas is around. Soon they are burning up the sheets. Definitely very hot between these two. How can they make it work when Andreas lives in the city? His company is there, but how can he stay away from Amber.

A really enjoyable read. You have Nick the unconventional prince who is forced to rule as king. His whole life is about turn upside down. Can he rule his people? Does he have what it takes? Coming home to Callanos he never expected Isabel. Isabel has some secrets of her own and wants to stay clear of the spotlight. Unfortunately for her she has gained the attention of a prince who goes after he wants. Nick won't give up on Isabel and his people, but when Isabel's secret comes out can he stand by her side even if it may cost him the crown? You feel for Nick he has so much to live up from how his father and brother ruled. The pressure is on then throw in Isabel into the mix things sure get interesting. Isabel has so much courage for what she had to do and survive. You just want these two souls find their HEA.

This book keeps you on the edge of your seat. It has action, passion, and humor. Poor Emma when she's running through the woods man I felt for her falling in questionable substances. Her life is threatened and she finds herself in Somewhere. Her day couldn't get any worse or so she thought. She didn't count on werewolf Noah to make his secret known. Now Emma has more on her plate then ever before. Noah is still waiting to find his mate then Emma comes barreling into his life. It's nothing like he thought it would be. With men out for Emma's life plus now add in his family to the equation things are about to get very interesting. Can Noah protect her even from his own family?

A nice fast paced sexy read. You have werewolf Tala who wants to turn her home into a B&B. She's on her own with her brother on his way to college. Is it a coincidence that a stranger another werewolf no less shows up is exactly what Tala is looking for? Has fate worked it's magic? Yas has come back to see the place he is from for answers he didn't expect the instant attraction to Tala. His protective instincts kick in when trouble comes knocking on Tala's doorstep. Will these two wolves who weren't looking for a Nate have actually found theirs?

Every book I read in this series just keeps getting better. I love how different the personalities are for Hope and Brice. They balance each other out, miss merry sunshine and the paranoid cynic. When I say I was on the edge of my seat I really was. You just want to keep on reading to see who is behind it all and how they catch the bad guys. Loved being able to revisit previous characters in the series. You can feel the comrade and banter between the Justice Team. A Supreme Court Chief Justice is accidentally killed or is it murder? Former ATF agent now blogger may just have tip leading to murder. Hope is in charge of defusing the situation with the blogger, but soon she finds herself teaming up with him. Now lives are on the line. Can they figure out who is behind it to serve justice before they're too late?

A lot of history between Tande and Marcus. She won't come back to Somewhere and Marcus won't leave. Tande is back for a wedding and scandal just follows these two. Someone is out to ruin this wedding and Tande enlists Marcus' help. Those undeniable sparks flare to life when these two are together, but they just can't get that hurdle. Marcus is sticking to Tande like glue because someone is threatening her. Intrigue and mystery in this one. When one thing happens and you think you have it all figured out a twist comes. I felt bad for Marcus Tande had put him trough a lot. With the threats and destruction can Marcus keep Tande safe? Will Tande finally push Marcus beyond repair?

What a beautiful story about two people who find healing touch from one another. Cooper is trying to make a come back in his baseball career after an injury and stupid mistake he regrets. Annabelle's modeling career may have just gone up in smoke after her accident. Both are in situations of finding themselves when they believe all is lost. With the magic of Annabelle's twins and the belief in fairy tales anything is possible. Loved Cooper right from the beginning being a baseball player, but they way he steps up to help Annabelle and her little girls won me right over. Yeah he screwed up, but he more than redeems himself through out this book. I really liked Annabelle's journey finding her way to stand on her own two feet after the struggles she has gone through, but also realizing accepting a helping hand every now and then isn't a bad thing. I enjoyed this so much I'm going to check out the previous two books. If you're a fan of baseball who enjoys romance you'll really appreciate this book. Even if you're not a sports nut the magic of romance will win your heart.

A great read. Both Liam and Sybil have preconceived ideas about Scots and Englishmen, but when these two meet they are soon to find out how wrong they are. Soon this English lass starts to develop feelings for the Scot and vice versa. Could they make it work? One bug hurdle in their way Liam's mother is NOT a fan of the English. With Liam's making life a nightmare how could they possibly make it work. I like how Sybil is so unexpected and not the norm. Liam is one yummy hero. Every time I read the word Sassanach I could hear the accent.

This is the last book in the trilogy and I'm so sad to see it end. I loved all three books, but I have to say Avery went out with a bang. This is my favorite of the three. There is no way to explain how much I enjoyed this book! It had me so hooked I hardly could stop reading it. The connection between Olivia and Mateo makes this book work so well. Man the heat in this book is off the charts hot! Right off the bat too. Be forewarned you may need to fan yourself when reading. Mateo is a dirty talker and he does it so well. Olivia is a very likable character. Her life is in the toilet at the moment and she's coming back to Salvation where she won't get the warmest welcome, but she sucks it up and makes a stand. I loved how it ended it's just so the Salvation way. I also liked the little surprise at the very end, it's super sweet.

If you've seen or read Outlander you know any woman would be on a mission to find her own Jamie Fraser. Well that's exactly what Sloane decides to do. Taking a vacation to Scotland to "find" a man to put her friends off their matchmaking. She thinks she has the brilliant plan all sorted out, but she doesn't count on Galen. These two are very opposite, but once they're together sparks fly. A bargain is made, but what happens when pretend starts to feel real? Loved this book. The humor elements just made this one just perfect. I really enjoyed the different characters. Being a fan of Outlander I could appreciate the references. I would definitely recommend reading this one you'll really enjoy it.

Sophia is anxious to meet with the mysterious Dom from Hush, he’s even been texting her. Of course, before she can do that, she must face Peter and break his heart, she just wants to be friends. Desmond is surprised by his attraction to Sophia as well as his desire to see her again. The drama is building as Sophia is working on her expose of Hush. What will happen when she learns her mysterious doms identity? Strap in for a sexy, drama filled ride!

Incredible roller-coaster romance delivering all the feels, many surprised me. Trace is a single Dad and is very protective of his son Ryder, after Kristi left shortly after he was born. He is jaded and unwilling to let another woman into their lives. Ryder is 7 and as school begins, it appears not having a mother around is taking a toll on this little boy. Tori worked at the Funky Monkey while going to school and always enjoyed when Trace came to the bar but now she finds herself across from him as Ryder's school counselor. Trace has always been attracted to Tori, now that Ryder has brought these 2 together in a different capacity, will they acknowledge the sparks between them? Or will Trace push her away to protect the bubble he's created for Ryder? Along the way, Kristi reappears, what does this mean for Ryder? Trace? Tori is faced with some difficult family issues. I was captivated by Tori and Trace's journey and yes, there were tears. Truly a spectacular romance to dive into. I was given a copy for an honest review.

Ok, to me, anytime I can spend with the crew from Jack’em Up is a great day. Loved, loved, loved getting to be part of Rachel and Jesse’s wedding. The road to love for Rachel and Jesse wasn’t easy but now that they have it each other, the beauty of their romance is a joy to experience. This is fun, short step in their journey to experience they love they have as they get married with all their friends and family by their sides.

Wow, Reese finally knows who her father is and she now has a family for the first time in her life with a grandmother and brother but she finds the only family that really matters to her is Mase. Mase loves having Reese live with him on his ranch as they work to build a home. Of course, this wouldn’t be an Abbi Glines story if we didn’t have some drama trying to break apart our couple. Enter Aida, a cousin of Mase’s that has more on her mind than being a cousin. She preys on Reese’s insecurities then Captain appears and he flirts with Reese which pushes Mase’s buttons. It was fun to see the back and forth and watch Reese and Mase figure out what they truly wanted. There were several unexpected twists involving Reese’s family that I never saw coming. Another fabulous installment in the lives of the Rosemary Beach family.

Stepping into Rosemary Beach stories is like visiting old friends. I have truly enjoyed this series and cast of characters that we have met along the way, experiencing all the highs and lows of their lives. This time we meet Reese, the opening prologue gutted me but it sets the tone for the resiliency and fortitude Reese needs to find and build a life for herself in Rosemary Beach. She works as a maid and walks everywhere just living a content life. One of the houses is Nan’s which ends up with her crossing paths with Mase as he comes to town to visit Harlow which sends her life on a new course. Mase can’t believe his eyes when he encounters the sexy cleaning lady singing totally off key yet he’s enchanted. Mase has shied away from commitments based on the history of his parent’s lives so when he finds himself wanting to cross paths with Reese and then helping her, he isn’t sure what to think. He just knows that Reese is important. Jump in for all the fun, drama, romance and sexiness you expect from all of the Rosemary Beach books, you won’t be disappointed.

So unexpected, completely enthralling, loved every minute. The beginning of VIP shocked me as we experience the life Ysabella grew up in but then we watch her persevere through sheer strength and determination to strike out on her own and make her way in the world. She encounters some key people that help her along the way but the Madam is the one that truly sets her on her journey as a high end escort. Sebastian’s journey surprised me. From the day Julie was born, he was connected to her at the hip. They were always best friends and it seemed to be the happy couple one day. Then Julie gets an adopted sister Olivia which rattles Sebastian’s world. He suddenly feels something differently for Olivia than he does for Julie. What do you do when the person you thought you would love forever might not be the one? How do you balance these challenges and not hurt anyone’s feelings? When Ysabella and Sebastian cross paths, they both need something different but don’t know what. Can they help each other find their way? Dive in for a drama filled, passionate and erotic journey of love and redemption.

Surprising journey of love and redemption. Trent has made several mistakes in his life but he is trying to be a better man to provide for his unexpected son, Tomas. Tomas lives in Brazil with his mother Gabriella who is working to find a wealthy husband to make her life easier. She makes some questionable choices and suddenly, Tomas, is without a mother. Alessandra has been the one constant in Tomas’s life as his nanny so when Trent arrives to be his father, she finds herself torn, knowing she will need to walk away from Tomas but being drawn in by Trent’s sexy and charming demeanor. As Trent is faced with the challenges of being allowed to take Tomas out of Brazil, he finds an ally in Alessandra, the nanny and law school student. Alessandra provides Trent with a home on her family farm as he waits the court’s decision. Will these two find something even greater between the two of them? Will Tomas get a mother after all?

Fun, flirty, sexy romance. Gracie has been in love with her brother’s best friend Hudson for as long as she can remember. As kids, Hudson was incredibly sweet and supportive of her while her over achieving older brother and sister garnered most of the attention. Then one day, Hudson stopped paying attention to her which crushed her. Gracie is now grown up and starting her career as an architect but she is still a virgin. When she tells her brother and Hudson that she plans to find a guy on the internet to take her V-card, well, that turns on the cave man in Hudson. Hudson can’t believe Gracie is going to pick some random guy to give her virginity to so he proposes a plan, he will do it and teach her all the techniques she needs to please a man. Needless to say, this is a fun romp for both of them. Will they be able to be truly honest with each other? Can they find the love they both desire during their deal?

Holy mind spin! Noriko makes the ultimate sacrifice by participating in a mail order/arranged bride service in Japan so that she can provide the money needed for her father to get his cancer treated. She ends up in the US married to Drake living in a huge mansion with all of her needs provided for her however she isn't allowed to leave the mansion or grounds and has no contact with the outside world, not even her family. Drake is a successful billionaire having inherited his father's company after he killed himself. Drake has seen his share of hardships through his parents failed relationship so he works very hard to protect what is his. As much as he loves Noriko, he never truly sees her. Noriko finds a kindred spirit in Keir, the gardener, which leads her down a path that a married woman shouldn't pursue. What would you do to escape the prison walls? I really didn't know what to expect from this story. It is definitely not your typical romance yet a romance lies within its pages. The real depth and breadth of the tale focuses on Noriko and the walls Drake places her behind. Does she abandon who she truly is or will she find a way out?Oh my Keir. We know how much he loves Noriko but to truly walk in his steps on this crazy journey was fabulous. He is such a beautiful soul and is truly what Noriko needs at the time she meets him while she helps him reach for his own dreams. Being able to experience this story from his view point was fabulous. I have to admit that Hanna Peach gives us a great twist in the POV at the end which is a beautiful way to wrap up this sad tale.Drake is a mystery and my initial impression was to dislike him so I loved peeking inside his mind to truly understand his motivations. There is so much more going on with him than meets the eye which really adds to the complexity of this intriguing story.

Oh my Keir. We know how much he loves Noriko but to truly walk in his steps on this crazy journey was fabulous. He is such a beautiful soul and is truly what Noriko needs at the time she meets him while she helps him reach for his own dreams. Being able to experience this story from his view point was fabulous. I have to admit that Hanna Peach gives us a great twist in the POV at the end which is a beautiful way to wrap up this sad tale.Drake is a mystery and my initial impression was to dislike him so I loved peeking inside his mind to truly understand his motivations. There is so much more going on with him than meets the eye which really adds to the complexity of this intriguing story.

Erin had a crush on Brad, her best friend's brother for years but then she realizes that he doesn’t do relationships so she pushes all hope of every being with Brad away. When Brad suddenly needs a temporary home, Erin's extra bedroom becomes the best option since Lexie just moved out. Brad has a successful business but seems to be targeted for some type of sabotage which puts Brad in need of a girlfriend to help secure a contract. Erin volunteers to help him out; she has her own drama at work now that her ex-boyfriend has been hired, his wife believing she wants him back. Is there any chance this fake relationship can be real? Will the confirmed bachelor realize that a relationship isn't as scary as he thought? Miranda Charles consistently delivers a fun and flirty romance with just the right mix of drama for a great escape.

Lindsey is one tough cookie. She grew up in Bliss, a town focused on weddings, and she has a gift. She can tell when a couple is a good match but when sharing her knowledge in college turns her friends away, she decides to hide her gift. Though, one spring break she encounters Will, a fabulous guy that sweeps her off her feet until she gets scared and breaks his heart. She boldly becomes a divorce attorney, something no one in Bliss wants to consider. Will shows up in Bliss, he is now a famous singer, having achieved all his dreams. When Will shows up, Lindsey's match meter goes haywire and she still believes they aren't a good match. As Will finds his music, can he crack open Lindsey's heart? A beautiful journey of love, redemption and learning to believe in yourself.

Falyn is one tough woman and when her secrets were revealed coupled with the challenges she has faced, well, my opinion of her grew. She grew up with wealthy parents that focus on appearances so when her life deviates from their desired plan, she has to choose to stay and be someone she isn't deep down or break away and forge her own path. This ends up putting her in Taylor Maddox's path as he works as a Hotshot on the wildfires. Taylor is a love'em and leave'em guy, he's never had a relationship but there is something about Falyn that intrigues him and pushes him to pursue her. She knows his type and isn't looking for a relationship; can they just enjoy a summer together? Of course, there is a great twist when Falyn learns where Taylor is from which is very intriguing as he becomes a way for her to tackle something in her life if he will take her to his hometown. I wasn’t prepared for that secret at all. This is not an easy journey and they both make mistakes (though Taylor is a total dork), can they forgive each other? Can they face their fears and embrace something brighter than either ever expected to find? Totally worth finding out!

Leila and Jacob have had a rocky road to a marriage that is finally clicking on all cylinders then the unthinkable happens … an old nemesis resurfaces, Rachel Laraby, ready to rain whatever chaos she can muster down upon them. It's exciting to continue spending time with Leila and Jacob to experience life after the happily ever after, what happens when the real world interferes? Daily life? We get to experience all the highs and lows as they grow as a couple while experiencing all the amazing sexual chemistry they share in and out of the playroom!

This was so completely unexpected for me. The depth of deception within Georgie and Sloane's worlds is mind boggling. I don’t want to give away any of the amazing twists that I encountered but know that I loved every minute. When we left off at the end of Inferno, Sloane had left Georgie, pregnant even though he loves her. What happens next takes you on a draw dropping ride of deceit where Georgie and Sloane have to find the strength to follow their hearts and combat all the craziness thrown at them to find true happiness. Georgie has to rekindle her inner girl power but it's fabulous when she does. Sloane has to be willing to give up what he loves to find an even greater love. Everything about this story kept me flipping the pages as I tried to unravel the mystery. Excellent job by Kathryn Kelly to take us on such an outstanding journey.

As Vivie moves forward with expanding her business, she finds herself in Paris to research perfumes. Jacob experiences a new form of jealousy so he pursues Vivie. Their relationship gets to blossom during a romantic trip to Paris and the south of France. Jacob finally opens the door to a true submissive relationship; will Vivie be willing to venture into this new domain? Of course, Vivie is constantly challenged by Jacob's hot/cold behavior as he tries to keep the rules and boundaries in place. Will Vivie be able to break down his walls?

David's life is more complex than we could see on the surface. His supposed girlfriend is Natasha, an autistic deaf woman that he promised her parents he would take care of. When we finally meet Natasha, you encounter a young woman striving to fit in and find her place but feels confined by David. She wants to experience life realizing all her friends are online, besides David she only has Rosie who lives with them to take care of her. She pushes David to be honest with Kat. Kat struggles to overcome her humiliation after kissing David and learning he has a girlfriend. Will she give him a chance to explain? What happens if Kat meets Natasha? This story has surprised me several times over. Yes, I'm getting my usual romance that I love with David and Kat dancing around each other but we also have the struggle of a commitment and how that drives your life. David is so afraid of letting down Natasha and her parents that he is struggling to enjoy life for himself. Will he find a balance?

So unexpected. On the surface, Inferno appears to be a rock star romance, which it is, but when you dig in you find so much more to explore and devour.
