I'm going to buy another as a gift because it's perfect for every woman!One star lost because after I tore off the tags and used it, I realized there was a hard bump by the outside pocket (visible on the middle white stripe part). I thought I just had a wrapper or something pointy in the pocket, but it's in fact a bubble/manufacturing error in the material.  Kinda bummed about that...Update: bought the white purse for my friend. Super cute and hers was not defective like mine with the material bump. Nice white classy purse. It's fully white...not cream and not beige.

My dad is obsessed with the life is good men's crusher shirts. The xxl fits him perfectly. However, I tried a different shirt model (not the crusher) from our local marshalls and he said the neck was tight and the xxl was small...so I'm definitely only ordering the crusher kind. Shirt is super comfy and he wears this and his other one ALL the time. Perfect bday or fday gift. I only order the golf ones...ha. get the men's crusher if the man or dad in your life needs true sizing and comfort.

Ordered this as an icebreaker for my speech class and also for "fun Friday's" where we do acting games or now ..catchphrase for the last few minutes of class. My class is addicted to this game. No repeats yet...easy to use... just hate how I have to unscrew the back for the batteries...I'd like to keep my batteries out when not using it, but that's a hassle. Also, recently brought this to a party and everyone plans to order it. I was use to the original catchphrase, but that was $70 on Amazon. I'm NOT disappointed with this version at all and highly recommend it.

I was scared at first because I have an Illinois plate and it didn't fit perfectly in it. I had to squeeze and push down my plate into the frame. However, after screwing it down to my car it stays perfectly and doesn't make sound when I close my trunk. I did read reviews of wear and tear, so I'll update this after it has undergone the Illinois weather more.... Super cute and looks great on my silver Toyota Camry.

Ok. I ordered this Friday before fourth of july and this came Sunday. Super fast shipping when it was suppose to come Monday! I went to Vegas recently and walked the entire strip for ALL three days I was there...bad idea...It tore my feet to shreds. With the heat and sun, my heels were cracked and in pain. My feet were peeling.... I immediately ordered this upon great reviews. I JUST got done using it. I was impatient and used it on my dry feet, which it said you could. OMG, my feet are already back to normal I kid you not. It's exactly like someone else said, a huge cheese grater for feet.... It didn't hurt at all and I rinsed and put on lotion right after. The pedicure people always use a sand scrub that never does anything for me, but this product has allowed me to now take care of my feet on my own. Highly recommend this product.
cheap, didn't really work or come together as pictured... wouldn't re-buy or recommend to others...save your money..

I noticed my dog lays on this... I don't know if it's by choice... I just put it in his crate and he sleeps in there most of the time... I haven't had the opportunity to put it in the fridge because in this crap economy... I live at home with my parents who are clean freaks and won't allow it.I don't think it's a major loss for the price I paid... I truly cannot tell if it makes a difference for him.. I put a t-shirt over it because that was the only way to stop him from digging at the pad.

I only bought the #2 bottle, which is maybe WHY this didn't completely work as I had hoped for.... I scratched my boyfriend's dad's old fashion looking popcorn maker. It's a plastic door that I scratched. This made the scratches less noticeable to the naked eye, but they were still there. My stupid self scratched it with those brillo pad sponge sides, but they weren't deep scratches!!Maybe this would have completely taken the scratches away had I bought bottle 1 and 3 with it... I used it as it stated... but if you look up close, you can still see all the scratches...

I don't know WHAT people are talking about with these reviews! This is the best flea medicine I have come across. I have a 15lb Maltese Shih Tzu mix who lets me apply this every month with no problem.  He doesn't have any reactions to this medicine and I live in the woods with a pond in my backyard filled with frogs, snacks, we also have ticks in our bushes. I have NEVER found a tick on my dog nor a flea. My parents dog lives with us and they do not keep up with their flea medicine on their dog because she has reactions... I keep telling them to try this brand...anyways, she always comes in with ticks on her, but not my dog...One day they will learn... K9 Advantix II is my go to and is worth the money (plus I can always find it on sale whether it be on Amazon, 1800 pet meds, or chewy...etc.)Update: I've been using this product for 3 1/2 years and my dog has never had a tick and I live by the woods and walk him by that area. Just a few days ago, I noticed his first tick on him. However, due to this awesome medicine it was dead already. So glad my little guy is protected. Fyi, ticks detach with vinegar in case you're in a bind.

What a great deal! I have 2 dogs and we go through treats fast. Just a box of these is around $6-7 by me, so to get this many with my Amazon Prime for $10 is amazing. I am so happy I am stocked up and so are my two dogs who already have some of these upon opening. Love Milk-Bone, Love Amazon.

They fit true to size and look exactly as pictured. These are surprisingly warm, so perfect for fall. There is absolutely no foot support. This make it hard to wear all day, but I plan to put foot inserts in.Update on boots. Wore them twice already...My pants don't stay tucked into the boot and they're skinny jeans. They bunch at my ankle..then when I walk you can see my skin and socks. I'd return these, but it's not worth it to me. They'll be my junk fall boots for rain or slush..also found some poor craftsmanship near shoelaces. I used Amazon money so I'm not heartbroken about this purchase, but I would never pay the full price for these. Also, these are hard to get on. I only wear them when I know I'm not in a hurry and won't be taking my shoes off.

I liked this product. I wrapped it around candle holders and put a flameless led candle in the holder to illuminate it. It turned out beautiful and were center pieces for a movie themed bridal shower. My guests were impressed. I had a ton of this leftover. My only reason for four stars is because there is small writing on the film with the company name which shows... minor flaw for my decorations. See my picture on how I used it.

I ordered this to make a tulle runner for my tales for a bridal shower I was throwing. I had to throw most of this roll away!! It had holes everywhere!!! It also had white stitched seams that were thick. I had to cut off most of it and try to salvage what I could since I opened it on short notice. BUYER BEWARE. so upset I wasted my money on this.
Exactly as pictured. Enough said. My future sister in law loved it.

I originally gave this five stars because it's working on my dog, but now I have to change my review because the collar broke. It doesn't charge AT ALL. it's not the remote battery, I've tried several outlets, and even attached the charger to my cell phone charger since it connects with usb, but the collar use to light up red for charging and it doesn't anymore. Let it charge anyways for eight hours and still nothing. I'm mad. I'll be contacting customer service. I have a cheap toaster that lasted longer than this collar.The thing I hate about the collar is the shock component is heavy/bulky and it doesn't snap to the entire collar (you know how there's 2 collar parts to adjust the size) it only snaps to one part of the collar so it hangs down low on my dogs neck. The remote is nice, but it didn't come with instructions so I did contact customer service who reported:4 and 1 are one shock5 and 2 are two shocks6 and 3 are three shocksthe shock is not more powerful than the others, but just longer.

A relentlessly negative portrayal of one of the central political figures of the Civil War era. In William Marvel's estimation, which may be true, Edwin Stanton was a "kiss-up/kick-down" type in a world of extreme political and bureaucratic in-fighting.People close to Stanton, such as Judge Holt and Senator Charles Summner, are heaped with scorn. No one in this story is credited with any disinterested patriotic or public spirited acts. All is done for a desire for personal advancement, lust for political power, money, nepotism, jealousy, stupidity,or hatred. The Radicals were just that; not principled fighters seeking to end the South's brutal system of slavery,While Mr. Marvel makes a strong case that Stanton was not a true and nice man, I can't shake the remembrance that he was in charge of the War Department when the Union defeated the South. And he was sufficiently well thought of to be nominated and confirmed as a U.S. Supreme Court justice as his life came to a close.The most interesting part of this version of history to me are the contrarian views taken on many of the events and incidents familiar to students of the Civil War. Mr. Marvel seems to delight in being a modern day Copperhead historian, more concerned with the temporarily abridged civil liberties of Northern opponents to the Administration and the rights of rebellious states than to the entrenched and crushing reality of Southern slavery.Edwin Stanton remains in need of a balanced, modern appraisal of his significant life and career.

A nice study of the life of a great Civil War era photographer, Alexander Gardner, as intertwined--at several points during that severe war--with Abraham Lincoln.The basics of photography of the times, Antietam, Gettysburg, and coverage of the fate of Booth's cohorts make up the bulk what's here.  Professor Lowry does a good job of explaining the art contained in many of Garner's finest plates, whether of President Lincoln or of the lonely dead left at the scene of grim battle.Note for a future edition: John Hay was educated at Brown, not Princeton (p. 74).For readers interested in this general subject, I highly recommend "Photography and the Civil War" by Jeff L. Rosenheim, a 2013 publication of The Metropolitan Museum of Art.

A nicely written examination of how the American poet Walt Whitman throws instructive light forward onto many of today's social and political dilemmas.This is not a dry academic text, but a highly personal story crafted by a young, sincere, talented college professor, one on the leftward edge of our nation's political spectrum. Read Dr. Marsh's book and you will learn more about a great poet and something about today's society.I am not on the political left and reject a number of the author's thoughts on American's current economic system. But I found this to be an interesting book, one that I enjoyed and recommend highly.Note for the next edition: The expression is "dyed-in-the-wool" not "died" as on page 156.

A sharp and useful study of what Abraham Lincoln thought and did about the thorny political problem posed by the rebel states as the Civil War wound down. How were they to be brought back within the fold?  Were they conquered territories or as states rescued from misguided local leaders? Could the federal government mandate their election laws to force black suffrage? Were the wayward leaders of the Confederacy to  be treated harshly or with leniency?President Lincoln emerges here as a kindly but pragmatic politician focused on reestablishing a strong national union, with slavery banished. Facts on the ground and his judgments of what was socially achievable at that moment were more important than considerations of abstract racial justice.The "last speech" is not to be remembered for literary style, but as a vehicle to better understand President Lincoln's struggle with the complexities of reconstruction.(What a great tragedy for the nation's future it was that Andrew Johnson  came to power after Booth's last act.)

A popular history of George Washington's two terms as president, with a focus on his closest advisers within the first administration under the new U.S. constitution.This book will do as an introduction to some prominent (Adams, Jefferson, and Hamilton) and some not so prominent (Edmund Randolph, Henry Knox, and Tobias Lear) early Americans associated with the great man. However, those with previous reading on this era will find little new in this volume.In terms of style, the two authors often drift into the annoying habit of summing up their paragraphs with an overly cute twist. Such as "But when the enormous man with the huge hands and powder blue eyes walked into her shop, she became an American. She would be an American for the rest of her days. She was why the trips were important."If you only have the time or interest to read one recent book on George Washington, I recommend "The Return of George Washington" by Edward J. Larson.

An uneven book in that the author drifts away at times from his "body" theme to other topics, such as with a lengthy discussion on Dr. Martin Luther King's complicated relationship with the historical Lincoln. While little is here that would be new to the many that form the Lincoln cult, I still found it to be well-written with many interesting insights.Professor Fox is strongest when he is relating the factual history of the various physical representations of Abraham Lincoln over time, since the assassination and lengthy burial ritual to the present day's movie by Steven Spielberg. For example, the materiel on the spirited debate over the proper siting of the memorial in Washington,D. C., and then its eventual racially insensitive dedication is well done.As is not uncommon of late with Lincoln commentary, the undertone of this book is decidedly prone to view our first Republican president as someone who would be in the camp of modern day Democrats.

A view of the events associated with President Lincoln's assassination and its aftermath taken from common people's diaries of the period.Professor Hodes has mined a lode of primary documents, but has produced little new or surprising, at least to one who has read many books on that troublesome era. For example, the idea that people reacted with shock to Lincoln's death, but quickly turned to every day chores and duties would not be too difficult to understand for most adult readers of today. And it is not novel to learn that Northern Copperheads didn't love the martyred president or that Southern freedmen did.My real difficulty is that this book did not flow smoothly for enjoyable reading, because, I think, the author inserts an excess of direct quotes from various diaries in a very repetitive fashion to prove whatever historical point is to be made.I did find an ending essay on sources to be useful and interesting.

I enjoyed this book more for the current political history of the countries where Lord Lyons held diplomatic posts during his long career than for getting to know Lord Lyons. While the author clearly respects his subject, its hard to walk away after closing this book thinking "I wish I had known this fellow." But he did live in interesting times.This competent but not flashy representative of the British Empire was in Washington, D.C., at the time of the Civil War and had other significant tours working with the Sublime Porte and the Quai d' Orsay. He saw the decay of the Ottoman Empire and, from Paris, the rise of Bismark's Germany.Reading this solid effort by Professor Jenkins helps one understand the confused world of today. For example, it is not new for Greece to be broke and troublesome. Or Russia with an urge to thrust South.

This is an essential resource book for art historians, especially those focused on French paintings of the 19th and early 20th centuries.The memoirs of the great art dealer are focused on the difficult years of selling the works of those, such as Manet, Degas, and Renoir, who are so prized today. Unfortunately, Mr. Durand-Ruel was either too absorbed in the history of individual paintings or too discrete: there are few interesting descriptions or insights on the many now famous artists he helped and knew so well. Nor is there much here on the turbulent political times of the era in Paris. What stories he could have told.But what a resource for those tracking individual paintings and their purchasers.

A brave intellectual's interior struggle during the German occupation, a teacher armed only with thought. He valued freedom and the dignity of man while living through an appalling period of French history.An honest and well written book, with what seems to me an excellent English translation by David Ball.

A book that provokes thought, but fails to convince.Professor Kateb  delivers many startling personal opinions. Two examples: "...Lincoln felt driven, during the indispensable war, to destroy the constitution he had revered..." and "We must say that the US Constitution was unworthy of obedience..."I do not think many general readers will enjoy this book, but for those interested in exploring the intellectual path Mr. Lincoln took to saving the Union and ending chattel slavery it is worth the purchase.I do not know Professor Kateb, but he strikes me as an intelligent thinker, albeit one high in the clouds and far removed from the practical world of human affairs and political realities. I do not agree with his often harsh judgments on Abraham Lincoln's thoughts and acts while this great man led our nation through its fiery trial.

An academic's review of the selected tracks of five writers, all of whom who had written from personal experiences arising from the Civil War.There are some nice insights provided here, but too often Professor Cushman's prose simply does not stand a chance against the gifted writers whose work he dissects. And, as I closed his book,I failed to understand the importance many of the points made, such as on the different ways Joshua Chamberlain wrote about his role in the final surrender of Lee's troops.Not a bad book, but not one in the league with the volumes written by such experts as White or Kaplan; experts who have plumbed the depths of President Lincoln's writings.

A useful, but not extraordinary, book for the narrow band of readers interested in William Howard Taft's career between his stint as president and his being appointed chief justice.I did find Professor Gould's remarks on President Taft's intensive work on the League of Nations quite interesting, but seriously doubt, as he seems to suggest, that Taft, the arch Republican, might have thrown his considerable bulk to the side of Cox over Harding in the 1920 presidential election over this one contentious international issue.

A good selection for any reader seeking to learn about changes in multicultural Istanbul in the first half of the last century, without having to navigate a dry as dust narrative.While I have never been to Turkey-- and have no desire to make the trip--I did find Professor King's book both interesting and informative.Am I the only reader who linked this book, with its Pera Palace hotel, with the unrelated movie "The Grand  Budapest Hotel"?

The U.S. Civil War was more than battles, weapons, and generals. It was a symbolic contest that held the attention of many peoples and governments far from our shores. How England, France, Italy, and other states treated the matter was far from ordinary.Professor Doyle does a nice job of describing the diplomacy of both North and South as the two sides fought for the attention and favor of rulers and those ruled, especially in Europe. And for those who are not aware of the importance of political events in Mexico during the period of our Civil War, Professor Doyle supplies quite useful information.This book closes with a valuable reminder that the Statue of Liberty not only welcomes the downtrodden to our shores, but serves to "enlighten theworld" as to the hard-earned value of our once threatened, but continuing democracy.

A nice, slender extended essay on the intertwined art of two friends and masters of painting, Edouard Manet and Claude Monet.The German author provides the reader with many interesting insights into art created at a special place (on the Seine near Paris) and time (1874).

I have arrived at a point in life when I refuse to read on once I have become annoyed.Here, I started reading the book's prologue. In its third sentence is a glaring error. Colonel House's father is said to have died in 1980 instead of, what I assume to be, the correct year of death 1880.Do I read on through the next 500 pages of this book published by Oxford, wondering at each point if I can rely on the text?I know this is not the author's fault, but I have little time and other books to read.

Stalin remains one of the most significant players in world history. To understand the Russia now led by an aggressive Putin, one must have a basic understanding of the Russian Revolution, and the careers of Lenin and Stalin. This book is  a brilliant start toward filling that need.I would only warn a potential reader that this is not a book one flies through. It is sometimes complicated and dense, because the underlying subject matter--such as the feuds among the leading Bolsheviks both before and after Lenin's death--is often murky.This is the first volume of a projected comprehensive biography as written by an extremely knowledgeable and insightful scholar. It will win awards.

A well-written, thoughtful book on the public life of John Quincy Adams. Although a failed president and a difficult man, Adams career, taken in its entirety, places him as one of our country's foremost statesmen.Professor Edel clearly lays out the evolving strategy that drove JQA to protect our country from foreign entanglements, promote domestic improvements, and enhance federal power. And, most importantly, to stay in the fight to the last breath against the Southern slave power.JQA laid the theoretical groundwork upon which, a few decades later, Abraham Lincoln triumphed.This book should win prizes.

George Washington is known to most Americans for his leadership during the Revolutionary War and as our first president. This book looks at his influence and leadership during the half-decade between the conclusion of the war and the start of the federal government under the newly ratified Constitution.Professor Larson provides the reader with an enjoyable and deeply informative book, one that makes clear the central role Washington played in not only fashioning the content of our country's foundational law, but also in the the practical political process necessary for its not-so-certain ratification.Along the way, one is reminded of such things as Washington's vision for western expansion and economic growth, why the electoral college came about, how the Bill of Rights was later tacked on, and the intense fight by many leaders of the day against a strong federal government.It is difficult to fathom where we would now be as a people--even if we would be a people--without the popular, decent, and wise George Washington during the years covered by this most excellent book.

A sharp, insightful, and interesting analysis of the writings and political thinking of George Orwell.While this book follows the arc of Orwell's life, this is not a conventional biography. Little is said about his family or friends. Instead, one is given an intelligent tour of Orwell's development over time, through the means of his published works and the topical political events and social realities he confronted.Professor Colls firmly places Orwell within a specific English context and deftly explains the trouble with any attempt to politically pigeonhole this great writer.Readers may also be interested in a book released in 2013: "George Orwell: A Life in Letters." For any serious student, "The Collected Essays, Journalism and Letters of George Orwell" (1968) is indispensable (and enjoyable).

A collection of short papers by various scholars; work arising from an academic conference. While interesting personalities are introduced, most readers familiar with this historical era will not be surprised at any of the information delivered.George Washington remains the Indispensable Man, but this is not the book to unfreeze his personality or unlock the key to his greatness.I did find it odd that some of the chapters were devoted to people who had hardly any, or no, personal contact with General Washington, such as Captain Kirkwood, while our greatest chief justice, John Marshal, and close associate of Washington is ignored.

Here are interesting extracts from letters written by Eleanor Pray, an American living in the port city of Vladivostok during tumultuous times. Somehow amidst wars, occupations, and revolutions, Mrs. Pray keeps her sanity and also her love for her adopted Far Eastern city.Her life centers around daily household duties and the social swirl of the upper class foreign community planted in this Far Eastern Russian outpost. The evolving political situation eventually undermines her comfortable world, but Mrs. Pray adapts due in no small part for her enduring attachment to the scenic beauty of Vladivostok and its people.I especially liked one letter to her Red Cross superiors in Washington, D.C. wherein she reported on the dismal conditions facing the local population in 1922. It is a model for a field report made during a humanitarian crisis.As editor, Professor Birgitta Ingemanson has performed a scholarly task with great insight and precision. Her work-- based on the almost forgotten letters of Eleanor Pray--deserves readers.

A book for anyone with an interest in the nation's political affairs, especially at  the presidential level, from the 1940s to the early part of this century.Dr. Schlesinger wrote well and often. He was involved in the highest levels of Democratic party politics. He was a friend and defender of the extended Kennedy family. He was a public intellectual with sharp elbows, but also with a strong mooring on the side of political freedom and free speech.A creature of Harvard and later Manhattan, he penned interesting and vibrant letters to the famous of his era.While I am not of the same political faith as Arthur Schlesinger, Jr., I nonetheless admire his dedication to this democracy and the spirit with which he so clearly argued his many and varied views.

A solid book describing the principal events leading to the start of World War I.The author, Margaret MacMillan, does a good job re-telling an often told tale. Weak, headstrong, complacent, ambitious or otherwise flawed leaders of the several major powers failed to avert this bloody war of empires.For those interested in this general period, I recommend a book often cited by Professor MacMillan , "Journey to the Abyss:The Diaries of Count Henry Kessler."A last point. I found it annoying that Professor Macmillan found it necessary to frequently go well beyond the period covered by her book to take gratuitous shots at present day conservatives in the United States. For example:fiscal conservatives p.525;George Bush and Iraq p 553; immigration opponents p.559;and,George Bush again p.563.

An excellent book on the multitude of meanings that have been drawn from President Lincoln's short speech given at the Soldiers' National Cemetery.The uses of the Gettysburg Address made by southern historians (mostly non-use), World War I & II patriots, Cold War warriors, and civil rights advocates are the heart of this fine history by a young academic, Dr. Jared Peatman."...the Gettysburg Address was Lincoln's most profound public statement that a democracy could persist only if equality was at its core." Read this book to understand the evolution of thought over a full century that brought us as a  people to the full realization of this point.This is a volume to be added to your Lincoln bookshelf.

Professor Shelden tries a little to hard to show how everyone just got swimmingly along on Capitol Hill in the 1850s and early 60s, whether Northerner or Southerner, whether of one party or another. She often uses as evidence social correspondence that says nice, flowery things about the recipient. I would discount many of these notes and letters as simple formulations of polite things that are routinely said between people (especially politicians), things that are not necessarily the brutal truth.More seriously to me is that the undertone of the book seems to argue that if everyone (e.g., Mr. Lincoln) would have simply compromised, such as advocated by John Crittenden, war would have been averted. No mention is made of how slavery would ever have been abolished or the federal system preserved.The author is gentle on Senator Jefferson Davis: I would have tied him to a sour apple tree.I did enjoy the detailed descriptions of the varied housing arrangements of the senators, representatives, cabinet officers  that made up the floating population in our capital in the years preceding the Civil War.

A much better book than one would imagine from its dry title. The authors tell the tale of the formation and popularization of the great song of the Civil War and bring its impact forward over the past 150 years.The Battle Hymn has been put to use by various political leaders, social reformers, religious groups, labor organizers, and others through the many decades since the days of Julia Ward Howe. Within this book the song itself provides a vehicle to tell many interesting historical stories, ranging from the rise of Billy Sunday to the days of the Wobblies to Martin Luther King, Jr., and 1960s civil rights movement.As this is an effort by two university professors, not surprisingly almost every use of the Battle Hymn by conservatives is belittled. I thought this overall good book drifted to a weak closing chapter, ending with shots at such people as Newt Gringrich and Rush Limbaugh.

My wish is that every politically interested  person who slavishly watches the nightly policy shout fests either on Fox or MSNBC would turn off the television set and quietly sit down and read this book.Yuval Levin has done a nice, clear job of laying out and contrasting the differing thoughts of Paine and Burke on how best to govern mortal man.I agree with Thomas Paine that kings, queens, princes, and such are not worth the powder to blow them up. But, the great weight of the argument comes down for me in favor of Edmund Burke's thought on the ideal statesman having "a disposition to preserve, and an ability to improve ..."

If you are interested in "The New Yorker" magazine and commercial book publishing this easy to read memoir would be an excellent purchase. Daniel Menaker is a master of the tools used in placing words in correct arrangement and with proper meaning on paper.I especially enjoyed the clear, often humorous, descriptions of the internal work of a great weekly publication;from basic fact checking to the higher realms of editorship.Less interesting to me were pages devoted to Mr. Menaker's later life, such as about his cancer treatments.

A smooth, intelligent, and sympathetic study of an interesting man of the high world of art. To fund his preferred style of  life, Bernard Berenson came to know the wealthy of America and then catered to their insatiable need to acquire great European paintings.Professor Cohen's condensed book is of the type that will ignite the desire for further reading on the multitude of characters that touched on, or were central to, the life of her subject:a poor Jewish boy from Boston who studied at Harvard, then who, after relocating to Italy, became a famed international expert on paintings from the Renaissance and a cultural sage.Above all he was a connoisseur. Over the course of a long life and against a backdrop of worry,he enjoyed beautiful vistas, fine art, friends (many of whom were women and beyond mere friends), intelligent conversations, writing, and libraries.

An interesting book focused on the career of J. Carter Brown, the legendary leader for three decades at the National Gallery of Art. Professor Harris provides the reader with a nicely written look back on an exciting time for culture in our nation's capital. (Having said this, one should not look to this book for much on the theater, music, or dance.)While the main story here is about Mr. Brown and the National Gallery's rise as a force in the rarified world of top-flight fine art museums, there are side trips to the Smithsonian Institution and the many spirited aesthetic disputes involving our capital city's urban development since the 1970s, such as the fight to build the World War II memorial on the Mall and the one to tear down the Rhodes Tavern.At times, it seems to me, the author does rely too heavily on contemporary news articles about the various special art shows that are mentioned in this book.If you are interested in Mr. Brown, the Smithsonian, the funding and management of modern art museums, how "international blockbuster art shows" are pulled off, urban planning, and/or the special diplomatic and cultural life of Washington, D.C., this would be a very good purchase.

A good book for those with an intense interest in knowing more about the several drafts and reported versions of the Gettysburg Address and how they relate to one another. Professor Johnson dispels a number of myths about that famous day and anchors  the actual speech given by President Lincoln to his visit to the battleground of Gettysburg and his political vision for the nation to have a "new birth of freedom."A first time reader about this  subject will likely be overwhelmed with some of the detailed explanations given by a very thorough academic scholar.The footnotes to the text are quite good.

Those who enjoy Mark Twain's writings and who have an interest in the era in which he lived should buy and read this book along with its earlier issued companion volume.While this is a true product of this great author, with many bright flashes of wit, it must be said that a good editor at the time of its original writing would have carved out a number of unnecessary words and pages, such as those spilled copying contemporary news clippings of disasters at sea.I give high praise to the editorial staff at the Mark Twain Project and the University of California Press for their dedicated scholarly efforts and the detailed and interesting explanatory material provided.

Before I knew little about the life of Jonathan Swift, and this book served to help me correct this deficiency.Professor Damrosch gives the modern reader a good, positive one-volume biography, while adding informative asides that help explain some of the more obscure political or social references contained in the numerous poems, pamphlets, and letters cited in the text.If you are interested in the history of Irish/English political relations; the English language; political/social satire; the close female and male friends (for instance, Alexander Pope) of Dean Swift; or just want to know more about the guy who wrote "Gulliver's Travels"-- I commend this book to you.

A fine, scholarly assemblage of the early letters to and from Henry David Thoreau. (Two more volumes are yet to come from the Princeton University Press.) Nice explanatory notes and other supporting informational material are also supplied by the editors.While experts on Thoreau's life and works will probably benefit most from them, these letters also will be appreciated by the non-expert reader. I know that any one with an interest in early American literature, especially that especially strong variant emerging from the area of Concord, will enjoy this book.Thoreau could write a clear sentence and usually had something interesting to say or report. The same is true of many of his correspondents, notably Ralph Waldo Emerson.

A nice selection of the letters of one of the great literary figures of the last century. Peter Davison, the editor of this volume, is a leading authority on George Orwell and has done a superb job of supplying clear explanatory footnotes to the text.The book is enhanced with the provision of a good chronology of Orwell's life and a short list of further suggested reading.Anyone with a special interest in the person who was once Eric A. Blair needs to read this book.

This is a very good and significant history, not in the sense that it is lyrically written, but in the welcomed light it sheds on the enduring work of an almost forgotten politician of the Civil War era.John Bingham wrote some of the most significant words amending the U.S. constitution. Without his dogged efforts in the U.S. House of Representatives it is difficult to imagine the modern interpretational course of our nation's constitutional law.Those interested in the congressional politics of the Civil War and Reconstruction, general race relations in our country, the impeachment of President Andrew Johnson, constitutional legal history, and even Japan's Meiji period will benefit from Professor Magliocca's notable effort.While Mr. Bingham had his faults, his name should now rank high on any list of the best federal office holders who have served our country.

An excellent book on the subtle, but profound, shift of meanings associated with Lee's surrender to Grant at Appomattox Court House.With political and social ramifications that echo to the present day, how the defeat of the South was handled by the both winning and losing sides in the aftermath of Appomattox is superbly analyzed by Professor Varon.In essence, the South invented myths that allowed it to believe that, while it lost militarily to an overwhelming force, its cause was still right and its pre-war social system of white supremacy was still valid.My take from this book? The North won for more reasons than brute strength; Lee was far from an unblemished hero; the cause of effective voting rights for blacks was set back for a century; there is a reason there are no public monuments in Washington, D.C., for President Andrew Johnson; and Grant deserves his honored place in our country's history.

A very good book on the First Amendment and how the great Supreme Court Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes came to put his polished interpreting mark on this fundamental protector of free speech.The author, Professor Thomas Healy, avoids academic jargon and keeps the reader interested not only in the evolving law but of the life story of the elderly jurist and his many younger and liberal friends, including such notable people as Learned Hand, Felix Frankfurter, and Harold Laski.If you want to learn about the 20th century history of free speech protection under the U.S. Constitution and how personal friendships can influence the thinking of a judge, this book is a bright starting point.One quarrel: I do think Professor Healy too often discounts the real threat Soviet communism did pose to the United States for most of the last century. Millions did die under this misguided system. And Alger Hiss, who once clerked for Justice Holmes, while targeted by the FBI's reactionary Hoover was, in deed, a Soviet agent.Also, readers of this book will notice a few references to the "House of Truth." If you want to read a good book on this subject, I recommend obtaining a copy of "On Dupont Circle" by James Srodes (2012).

What a great gift for a mom to be basket I got this for a friends daughter along with a bunch of other mom stuff she swears it's what got her attitude and body back together again. I read the book and have to say she was right it's an excellent process for regaining control of your after baby body but it is more than that.Sisterly advice dispensed in real people talk not medical mumbo jumbo that makes no sense to anybody but a person who took advanced classes. No mom needs that when she has a new born. Author Marianne Ryan is a master of making the reader feel like we are at a lovely cafe enjoying tea and talking about what needs to be done after baby.I love the approach she takes and the encouragement and practicle advice she dispenses along with an exercise regime that is doable and great diet and nutrition tips. Overall I think it is a book that has value to new moms and takes into account the variety of self esteem issues the joy of a new baby bring to the party.

I am a long time fan and devotee of the Holy Ghost Writer I enjoy his or her sense of irony and quite frankly their sometimes pugnacious personality that comes through the writing from time to time, the writing reeks of the irreverence they have for all things traditional and that would include Sherlock Holmes.Personally love the blend of fictional and reality that blends together in these action packed books as someone who still watches the original on you tube I find HGW's style of writing to be the perfect blend. Within the characters there is a certain tone I hear almost of laughter if you will as Author HGW throws a whole new twist of plot out there leaving the reader to briefly pause in reverent silence at his or her brilliance once again.I never tire of seeing just what is in store for me it could be Clark Gable it could be Abe LIncoln the Vampire Slayer but whoever is introduced into the book is going to surprise, delight and give you a few if not a lot laugh out loud funny moments.Now without great writing, editing and formatting it would all be for not so rest assured when you read a HGW book you get the whole package well worth the time to read a delight page after page love this guy or girl.

This review is from: Amish Romance; To Have You (Aubrey's Change of Heart) (Amish Romance; Torn series Book 2) (Kindle Edition)I was in the mood for a change of pace I am usually a die hard Chick Lit reader but variety is the spice of life and Memorial Weekend loomed large and lonely on the home front. So, decided to make it a weekend all about me downloaded a couple of books, grabbed a few bottles of wine, some good cheese, crackers and fruit and locked myself in for the duration.Author Saraah Sowells book was the second of the weekend and quite frankly it went to fast even as I slowed my read down to savor each and every page of this new genre for me Amish Romance. I know a bit of an oxymoron but after you read it you'll agree there is something to be said about the Amish way of doing things. LOL. It was really enjoyable and very well written.I can honestly say nothing inferior in Author Sowell's writing either she had what I call the Holy Grail of character development great pathos, enough subtext to keep it interesting and amazing that's right I said amazing dialogue. Some people can write and some just can't this author is diffinitely on the side of "girl got back in her dialogue.Not only is the dialogue realistic but it also serves a purpose who knew that was possible, it helps to move the story line forward so you don't get bogged down in the minutia of the narrative. Yes overall I would say don't be afraid of the Amish Romance well worth the time to read and this cutting edge writer is going to be heard from mark my words.

This is a well designed product that functions better than average., it should also be noted that I love the holder it is smooth and easy to clean with a bleach wipe. This thermometer fits nicely into the tray I have under the bathroom sink for medical supplies. I actually have two of these one for the pets marked with a bit of red nailpolish and the one I use for my little baby grands who spend a lot of time at Yaya's farm.Because they are all between the ages of 1 and seven fever is a regular event in our world when the kids are here visiting. I can promise you at some point during the visit one of them will not be feeling well and need a little TLC. It is easy to place in the child's mouth and once again very easy to wipe down with a Lysol wipe vs a bleach but the same clean effect.It came packaged nicely and did not require surgical equipment to remove from the wrapping but it is secured enough you feel good about the sanitary handling of the product. Over all a good product that does as described and arrives as promised. It should be noted this actually arrived two days early.I would patronize this seller again.

Great quick read about Aaron Rogers the man, the player and the icon. It was a well rounded piece of work and very focused on the success story of pro sports. There are not to many who have successfully handled all the craziness associated with pro sports. It would appear this is one of those rare exceptions to the rule.I learned a lot about football. the Packers and of course Aaron Rogers so overall it was well worth the read, it was well formatted and edited which made it even more enjoyable. Overall it was worth the time and energy to read. So enjoy and get ready to learn a few things I bet you didn't know.

This is one of the most delightful books I have ever had the pleasure of reading, it was also a very interesting study in people who do the bird watching. Lots of interesting side notes about the birds the process and the religious fervor behind bird watching, But the part I locked into was the personal story of this really fun kooky family.By the end of the book you are if anything like me feeling a little disappointed you were raised with such traditional not fun parents LOL I write this review still giggling over some of the antics of this family when faced with the master plan that somehow didn't turn out quite as expected. Whether it was the accommodations, the surroundings or worse each other.At the end of the day this book is a great read about family and really finding that point of common interest that keeps a relationship healthy, happy and growing. Is this book going to change the world probably not but it will give you an insiders view of the odd bird watching fellows you have always pictured in your mind. After the read I think you will as I did realize that there really is no stereotype birdwatchers like people come in all sizes, shapes and colors.By the way, I loved the cover and the title intrigued me so I googled Painted Bunting and it is a real bird that is difficult at best to track even though it is from Florida to the Carolina's it is an elusive member of the bird clan but once seen never forgotten. Kind of like this book it will stay with me for a good long while.

I was looking for entertainment for my Grands who visit my little country place often on the weekends. I thought music at nap time might just be the ticket. In my search I came across these delightful music tracks geared for kids and perfect for naptime quite frankly. I speak of my fav Alice In Wonderland when I say nap time perfect not to exclude the other adorable numbers attached to this same talented artist.Songster Gina Deeming sings like an angel with wings it is the kind of voice that children are drawn to part Fairy Godmother part Forest  Imp the end result being a delightful blend of lilting soprano with fun camp fire counselor.Most kids will hum along and learn the lyrics very quickly in my estimation this is a wonderful example of the new artist out there allowing us to now listen to our favorite children stories with a lyrical twist. Bravo to Gina Deeming for this important work she is doing in the Arts and Education movement.This music does what children s art's should do inspire, educate and entertain grand slam and I feel like an artist with over forty years in arts and education I'm an authority of sorts on the quality of this work.  Well done Ms Deeming well done!

First let me say I was interested from the beginning in a book that explores the dynamic between father and son not often do you get to see an example of that in books, Probably for several well thought out reasons men are not known to be great emotional communicators ;historically but Author James Bowman breaks all the man rules and writes a story that is deep and meaningful.The plot line is fast paced and original I don't believe in spoilers so feel free to read the authors perspective in the summary but suffice it to say I enjoyed every page. I thought that the building of the characters throughout the story rather than all at once was an interesting and workable twist to what could have been a very one dimensional story.The dialogue not only assist the reader by giving an event time stamp tot he flow of the story it also helps to see the subtext of the characters and eliminates the need for long boring narrative. Overall this is a great effort with excellent editing and formatting which in my opine is always a big plus for me as a reader.

I found this book disturbing in a good way the way books are suppose to disturb your thought processes and make you see things from a different perspective. Written in a first voice narrative allows for the reader to actually get inside the mind of the character and understand the pathos and subtext that the story doesn't tell by design, Rather leaves some things to readers imagination and mind to search out a true answer.Author Emanuel Grigoras has managed to raise the veil on the culture and day to day living of a place I have only heard of but now can see with more clarity and certainly with a new sense of understanding for the thinking and sub culture that prevails. While not all grey and dark it needs to be said that there is also a sense of poetry underlying what at first you might perceive to be random thoughts linked together, but early on in the read you will see the puzzle pieces expertly being lined up.Seven degrees of separation has never had a better defined space to flourish in this is an extraordinary story told with skill and much research or first hand knowledge that allows for not only the words but the sights and sounds around the stories being told, In retrospect it was much more like watching a film than reading a book and I liked it . . . a lot. .

I want to start by saying that I love the geographic/cultural sub story of this very touching and moving book. I came with an empty cup not really sure I wanted to read this but the blurb got me and I succumbed to the visual it left in my head.,The entire book was very visual and for lack of a better word touchy feely in a most positive sense of the word. Because this story is all about subtext and pathos and rebuilding not just a family but a culture as well.Healing and forgiveness are the main message but I also got a great sense of healing and moving forward as a victor by finding a way to make things matter. I enjoyed the differences in the sisters and in their purpose of the relationship.The dialogue was meaningful and not a word is wasted in this complex story that just sucks you in and before I knew it I wasn't sure if I was reading letters from friends or reading fiction. It's that moving and personal of a journey recommend this book highly.

There is so many different faucets of this complex issue that to use a guide to understand and get to know the players is essential, in order to grasp the entirety of the situation.It is detailed and exacting in it's honesty this guide if you will breaks everything down that you might just have missed in the big picture while focusing on the details.This book also deals with the underlying social issues that are forced to be dealt with as a result to the serious issue of sexual assault on campuses specifically this one in Montana. The author defers from making a judgement rather he sticks to just the facts.Which makes this situation clearer but no less disconcerting well written and edited with excellent formatting a worthy read for comprehension of the big picture.

Besides being an enourmously well written book with impeccable editing and formatting this book was an interesting and insightful read to boot. As I read I could relate the issues each family member experienced from their technology DT's.But more than being about technology this book is about defining the modern family it is not the same family it was back in the 60's even the 90's. Modern families have become entrenched in technology at the expense of their personal interactions.There are pro and con in each corner but interestingly enough this book falls in neither camp rather the focus is on the individual relationships that began the year and the changes in them over the year. Of course everyone will read into what they want.But for me Author Sharael Kolberg wrote in such a familiar, friendly tone that I found my self fascinated with the individuals rather than the group project. Either way you fall on the coin this book will give you much food for thought.

I'm a huge fan of the Sidekick when done correctly and this one is done to perfection as this one. I have a list of what I think creates a good kick starter basically add to the reading value of the series.It has to sparks creative thought process to enhance the reading experience. Gives more depth and meaning to the existing characters and plot line.In my opinion the cherry on top was the pick your alternate story ending I thought that was a great way to really finish out in your minds eye the way it could hav, should have or might have ended.

As I read this book I had a craving to listen to some Arlo Guthrie or The Weavers what a great mood Author Eldon Spady set for this wonderful real story. The fact that I was raised on a ranch in Inyo County California allowed me to understand some of  inside humor a little more perhaps then someone who never got up early. That would be while it was still dark to feed hungry animals regardless of how cold the morning.I think he really captured for the teen reader a different time and place that because of the Urban setting most kids are raised in these days will never experience except through the musings of authors like him,The stories were from the heart and had a wonderful folksy feel to them as if you were sitting around that potbelly stove trying to dry out while your mom set the oil cloth red gingham table for dinner. You could almost smellf fresh harvest food and farm raised chicken in the oven being stoked by wood. Browning and sizzling as Arlo sung on the radio and you tried to listen over the static. Yeah it is that kind of book,Just awesome a must read for all kids should be on the reading list of all 8th and 9th grade classes well written, edited and here's a switch great formatting yeah team Spady!So buy it and enjoy and don't forget the Apple Cider.

This is book two of  the series and so I decided to give this new series the critical test of becoming a fan. Book number two the true test of a great series. Author Ann Gimpel did a great job hooking me with her writing style and creative plot in book one. Enough so that I kept my eye out for this book.I'm happy to report I'm officially an Ann Gimpel fan what a great continuation of the story I love the way she synced it right up to the end of book one and kept moving. Rather than bogging me down in a big rehash of what I just read. I think that will come in handy when someone buys the series in a swoop and starts reading.I have to say I did like the way she sneaked in a few rehashes very cleverly by utilizing the characters and the dialogue  to do it with, circumventing the problem that rehashing brings out in my reading enjoyment, This was a great weekend read and allowed me to kind of get away after a rough week.For me what is becoming a real trademark when I read her books is the quality of editing and formatting which to me is as important as the story line as I can't relax and enjoy a book that is not at this level of professionalism,  In otherwords this is a first rate book written by a first rate author who knows what a reader wants and delivers in spades.

Reading this book gave me pause and made me think of a well run commercial when I was a kid that ended with the tag line "it's not nice to fool mother nature." LOL that would be the ultimate understatement for this raw, well developed story line.The characters were very real of course I think that Author Ethan Holmes has a real knack for character development that include characters who are rich in pathos and subtext. He also remembers that even in the most stressful moments humans tend to get by with their sense of humor. ,.It's not a short or a long read it seems to be the right amount of space used up for the story no draggy spots or where did that come from kind of moment, I did like the fact that I could relate to alot of the geographic regions I'm on the left coast.Overall I thought it was a well researched scary kind of possiblity book that was entertaining and had some substance

Okey Dokey totally creeped out and I mean that in the best way whoa what a book of a book. Here is the thing I had nothing to do all last weekend and needed to kick it up a notch so decided this was the genre I needed to read. Had no clue I would find a book that sucked me in and had me screeching out loud. Not to mention leaping from bed to as close to the bathroom door I could get just in case . . . there was something under my bed. LOLIt was that gripping my dog even felt the intensity from me and huddled down closer in bed which for him to get closer well I didn't know it was possible he is now a part of my femur.But seriously besides being terrifyingly fabulous a few notes dialogue absolute perfection and does what it should do explores the pathos and subtext of the character so the reader can better understand him or her. In addition Author Christian Masters has a sense of humor that is ironic and irreverent and of course I'm a girl who loves both.So overall did not miss anything staying at home last weekend except sleep Saturday night but I've missed that before and not had nearly as much fun as I did reading this book. I recommend it highly you will not be disappointed, terrified yes disappointed no.

Author Ann Gimpel shows exactly why she is a future up and comer in the Mystery, Suspense, Horror Genre her characters are spot on and the story line is unique and well researched. Don't want to give spoilers away but suffice it to say the success of a story like this depends on the research of the author just my opine.In the area of believable writing in a complex and scientific choice of plot lines Gimpel hits this one out of the park. In addition the necessary technical information is broken down to sound more like a really cool professor giving you the information in a creative and nail biting style.  Keeping the reader fully engaged regardless of the level of technical information.The dialogue brings the characters into focus and makes them human and susceptible to any number of frailities and weakness built in around a subtle strength of the unique and interesting woman who takes center stage throughout the book Glory is quite a girl to get to know whose sense of spirit stays with her throughout all the transitions for lack of a better word she goes through.This is book one and written with a solid eye on the upcoming series that I personally will be reading as soon as they are out great book incredible writing job and well done on the editing.

This is not your standard fantasy it is off beat, funny whimsical and well written. I am so impressed with Author M.R. Mathias with this fifth installment of his well read series around our house. It really is a group enjoyment both my husband and myself find it to be a great book to discuss on our commute into town or hanging out in the garden.What stands out the most is the flavor and style of the story and of course the characters who break through stereotypes of Fantasy cast members. Because it is such a visually written book for me it was more like watching a film open in front of my eyes.I also like the way the dialogue added to the subtext and pathos of the characters which allowed a closer look at what for some could be SOP in the fantasy genre, I hate plot spoilers so none in this review but suffice it to say there is a plot and it moves quickly and efficiently.At no point, will you scratch your head and wonder how the characters or you got where you are, Mathias is spot on in his editing and the formatting is a piece of art. Overall great read with wonderful intriguing characters and a story line that will delight you page after page.

This book is a confidence builder of your own instincts the principles that Author Sherrie Dillard shares increase your self awareness and confidnece in understanding your own body.It is full of advice and tips to cut down on medical cost by using the skills we have had as humans for years but recently have been told by the medical community we shouldn't trust. Rather we should choose to spend endless funds on unnecessary test. Not to say all testing is not necessairy some of it is and she makes that clear to.This is not a don't seek medical help book this is a balance the help with the self knowledge of your own body and the language it is speaking to you written for the lay person. In language and examples that you can understand and graspe.I think this is a must have in your own medical and health library that most people now turn to for a little self diagnosis before seeking medical advice because sometimes we do know better than a doctor.

Part three made it officially a Grand Slam all three of these books were really good. I enjoyed laughing and crying with the characters. Author Denise O'Hara is true blue all the way through the series to the original which I liked. What she does is let you take it a step or sometimes two in the character development. Really love her stuff good job.

I read Pride and Prejudice for the first time like most because I was forced to the other six times I've read it over the years is because each time I'd grown as a person and got more out of it than the original read. This was a natural extension for me when I found it hidden among the other offerings of the book site.I really enjoyed the back history of the principle characters making you see from another perspective why the characters might have reacted as they did with the original. I was particularly glad Author Denise O'Hara stayed true to the characters and rather than try to build a better mouse trap with them. Took the blueprints and ran with subtext and pathos to not change but introduce growth.The first person style is not for everyone but it didn't bother me I thought there was so much more to the story than that it was enchanting and interesting. Worth the read and looking forward to the rest.

Take me back to the good old days of free love and bra less fashion this is a great little jewel of a book that will keep you smiling throughout the read when you're not crying, or laughing out loud. The whole premise of the story is who is Jodi, and how does he fit into who you are. I remember Jodi being the guy who steals your girl when you are away in VietNam.The characters in this book are ones anyone who lived the late 60's would recognize from their neighborhood they are well defined and full of pathos and subtext. The dialogue is first rate and assist the reader as it moves the storyline forward in a comprehensive way. Rather than a bunch of boring, endless narrative.I liked the way the story unfolded rather than being shoved down your throat giving you time to savor and enjoy like a good wine or weed of the era. LOL. It is on task for creating the mood and the ambiance of that time in history and in capturing the quirky characters who were just learning to express themselves and breakout of society's mold.For those not around then fear not you will enjoy the compelling story line and artful writing of Authors Rob Kop and Dan Doyle, the editing is excellent and the formatting is done to perfection adding to the pleasure of this little jewel. I think everyone will enjoy the book but for those of you who lived it get ready for a great ride.

They should hand out a copy of this book with every member of the military who is getting discharged. What a great contribution for Vets who are ready after serving their country with bravery, valor and commitment want to take advantage of the benefits available. We all know it entitles them to a college education and the funding for Veterans is the easy part, relatively speaking.The tough part is all the other details that go along with that decision, what will they be and how to take advantage of opportunities that are available to them. Kenneth A. Bracewell breaks it down in simple easy to comprehend language. Tips and Tricks might be a more apt title of this little jewel of information.Through his real life struggle he shares his heartbreaks and his victories and at the end of the day is always the one that finishes at the top of the pile through dogged determination, guts and a little finesse.

I really have to admit I'm a romance junkie and there is nothing I love more than finding a new author to put on my list. Lisa Shadow has officially made the list after this read. She has managed in an over full category to stand out from the crowd with this book. Firstly you can tell she spent a lot of time with the plotting and flow of the story line. Not a glitch in the book and I would notice I see all the flaws in films books are no exception flow problems jump up and bite me.The characters are strong and well developed more importantly she does not inundate you mind with all the different faucets of their personality in one paragraph. Rather she introduces and then for lack of a better work unveils their quirks and pathos slowly, like a dance of the vails.  Up until the last page of the book I was learning things I didn't know.I also like the way the dialogue helps to move the story line forward so there is not page after page of narrative that becomes a blur and frankly makes me scan. For me the scan is the kiss of death for any book. I did not scan one sentence it held my attention throughout. Author Shadow also built a lot of tension that ebbed and flowed until the final big bang. No spoilers from this reviewer suffice it to say from page one forward it is a roller coaster of a ride.Overall the editing was good always nice to see and the formatting held together great job on the technical end as nothing ruins a good book like bad formatting. Just happens to be my buggyboo. Overall I would say great pathos, great subtext and marvelous absolutely marvelous characters I will be reading more of Lisa Shadow.

Great story for a weekend read when you want to get away from the madness of reality and spend a little time somewhere else with someone else doing anything but what your nine to five Monday through eternity. That is where I found my self last weekend and after glancing through the look inside I made a decision and hit the button. There was no going back LOL.The characters are quite unique and have an irreverent sense of humor, between each other. The story either works or not based on the two main characters  who while much different have a few key values that are the same. I think the relationship between them works because of the balance Author Lana Axe has achieved with them the ying and yang if you will.I enjoyed the way the characters were revealed not all at once but slowly like a dance of the seven veils with the removal of each veil so to speak a little more came into focus. The dialogue was great and not at all robotic or stilted. The whole story line flowed like melted butter. There is no point that stands out in my mind rather the whole story comes to mind when I think back on the book.This was my first book read by Lana Axe but it won't be my last great job.

For starters just let me say this is a book among books if you are into Sci Fi Fantasy and tough determined may I say ass kicking female heroines. I loved this book. I'm not even sure where to begin this review there is so much I want to share without giving all the good stuff away. So let me just say the characters are well written and detailed. Not boring details to fill up space but incredibly detailed as in lots of food for the imagination.The dialogue is fast paced and helps move the story line forward in a cohesive manner without the reader being bored out of their mind with a bunch of narrative that puts you to sleep. Rather the dialogue punctuates the action and helps define where you are and who you are with in the story line. Besides that it also gives you a glimpse or two of the subtext of the characters and where they are coming from within the story and as they relate to each other.I think author Ann Gimpel is delightfully witty with moments of laugh out loud humor, not the stand up comedy pretentious humor instead a funny  and jaded humor that feels just right for the overall story. She is a bit egocentric with some of the characters and that is not a bad thing. There is no heavy handed irony it all just sort of flows into one very cool read.The characters by the way are full of wonderful pathos and quirks that make reading them a delightful journey not to mention the incredible and concise detail of the alternate universe she creates. Everything about this book from page one to the end is well written and purposeful. No meandering prose or unnecessary violence or drama. It's all perfectly placed in an impeccably edited story. Great formatting adds to the enjoyment of the book. This was my first Ann Gimpel book but it won't be my last.

AB Bradley has really gotten the party started with this first book in a new series. As a series aficionado I search Amazon for just this kind of book. One that the writer has the skill to pull of this big of a projet without annoying me LOL.The female Mara is strong and sure of herself but not at the price of looseing a very good soul that is grounded and certain of what she believe's in, confident in what she knows has to be done to make it happen.The alternate Universe is well written with no gaps in the planning and creation which is a pleasant change. I also like that the main characters are not perfet and have plenty of space to grow into who they are in upcoming sequels.This is the kind of story a girl can wrap her heart and brain around with action, adventure and excitement. The action is well palaced and does not appear to be dropped in at an opportune moment. Rather is there in an organic way that feels natural and right.Would recommend with a five for any and all Series Lovers looking for a little fantasy/action with a whole bunch of adventure.

Author Ava Archer Payne has brought together some well written characters added killer dialogue that both adds to the character developoment as well as assisting her in moving the plot line ahead so that the story does not get bogged down in boring narrative. The characters are ones you can identify with especially if you are a college age or young adult.I will say it is a bit steamy so if you have issues with the New Adult Romance style of the younger hipper authors be forewarned that said there is nothing out of line. The "hot" scenes are not dropped into the middle of a chapter with no rhythm or reason. Each word and deed in this book serve a purpose. It is a very organized well written and structured lay out. The formatting is done nicely as well,The author nailed current day standards and it is a relevant book that will hold the attention of people who are well versed in the genre of Romance/Suspense and those who are taking a walk on the wild side for the first time. You can tell the exuberance of the writer for her craft. The book is at times written in the first person which is a nice break from the standard he said she said style of romance.Over all it was a great story with imperfect and readable characters that you could really sink your teeth into and cheer on. Pathos and subtext are introduced at just the right spot to either show dimension of the character or help define a scene that would be unclear without the little known or used technique in most current books being offered in this genreI'm giving this a five star as it is entertaining, at times a little scary and enjoyable every minute of the read.

I do a lot of reading it is for sure one of my favorite pastimes, I like being sucked into the story with this book trust me, you're dropped smack dab in the middle of it, from soup to nuts. Author Edward V'Kanty has set up the story line so that you become a member of the jury if you will. Sort of like a virtual "You We're There" concept. It adds a new twist to reading a book based on historical data and imagination.I found the journal entries fascinating and began to see just what a changing moment this little known historical event was for the state of origin. Often times living in the shadow of the Salem Witch Hunts that has taken center stage over time. This period in history happening long before anyone heard of the town of Salem.Author V'Kanty writings are professional and well done the dialogue that is not of historical record is well written and serves to move the plot line along with no confusion or boring narrative. Exaiming the patho's, subtext and mood of the period. This is a really scary book by the way just my opinion. The descriptions are visual and realistic.I'm giving this book a five for everything it is and nothing it isn't

In a brief prologue to this novel, an English clergyman named Chrysostom Trueman tells how he found the manuscript we are about to read sealed in a metal box encased in the stone of a meteorite that buried itself in his garden one night. It is the story of a pair of young men, Stephen Howard (the manuscript's author) and Carl Geister, who built a spacecraft and journeyed to the moon. Finding themselves unable to return, they shared their remarkable story by placing the manuscript in a metal case and dropping it into a lunar volcano just as it was about to erupt.Howard describes how he discovered a 17th century manuscript in which a Spanish monk relates an expedition into the uncharted mountains of New Spain. Besieged by hostile natives, the Spaniards dig a moat and erect a barricade in front of the cave where they have taken shelter. Suddenly a portion of their barricade simply flies up into the air and disappears.When Howard tells his friend Geister about the monk's tale, Geister immediately conjectures that the Spaniards have stumbled upon an outcropping of minerals which, when mixed, acquire the property of repelling the force of gravity. Geister eventually locates the minerals near what would now be the southwest corner of New Mexico, and resolves to use this discovery as the means to realize his long held dream of flying to the moon.Anti-gravity material had already been used to propel spacecraft in several previous 19th century novels. What the anonymous author adds to the genre is the means of providing fresh air for the long voyage to the moon and back (realizing that there may be no breathable air on the moon itself). Geister's spaceship, the "Lunaviot," is a huge, self-sustaining biosphere which its builders nickname the "Flying Greenhouse." We are even shown the equations by which Geister computed the amount of soil and vegetation needed to sustain two travelers.In previous science fiction novels the moon (or other previously unexplored world) is the setting for one of two things: a farcical satire or a utopian discourse. The History of a Voyage to the Moon is of the latter category; the author even uses the term "Utopia." But this moon is not so much a model community as a Garden of Eden where the reincarnated souls of those who had suffered tragic lives on earth could have a second chance at happiness. It is a world devoid of disease, hunger, violence and jealousy. The theology behind this lunar paradise is rather vague, but there is no suggestion whatsoever that we could remake our own world after its pattern. It could only be the work of God.Up to the point when our adventurers reach and crash-land on the moon, theirs is an adventure story worthy of the pen of a Jules Verne or Edgar Rice Burroughs, and I couldn't help but wonder why it wasn't more widely known. The problem is that the people of the moon are constitutionally disposed to be perpetually happy just making music and painting landscapes. Good for them. But reading about an unchanging world devoid of conflict, romance or danger is, frankly, dull and pointless. It's a shame that the author wasted such a promising beginning on a story that falls so flat in the end.(Note that the pseudonymous author's first name is spelled "Chrysostom" in the book itself. The ebook "cover" spells it "Crystostom" (deleting the H and adding a T). Amazon's catalog listing adds another O, spelling it "Cryostostom.")

Star is a unique and remarkable work of utopian fiction--the epic history of another world. "Star" is the name of that planet, and while it is awkward in English translation to have a planet named Star, this was not a problem in the original French (where it is "Star" and not "Étoile"). The author, Charles Ischir Defontenay, was a physician and a pioneer of plastic surgery. Star is his only known work of fiction.A prologue describes how the manuscript we are about to read fell to earth in the Himalayas enclosed in a metal box which was encased in a meteorite. After years of deciphering and translation, it proved to be the proud history of the planet Star and its inhabited moons. It is a history presented in several forms. Prose narrative alternates with verse, and there are two complete plays embedded in the work as well as a lengthy prose poem.The Starian solar system is very different from ours in that it has four suns. There is a large central star comparable in size and brightness to our own sun. A much smaller sun orbits it closely, a third shines from beyond the orbit of Star, and a fourth tiny sun circles the planet Star itself. "Four suns of diverse size and coloration, four bowers of celestial light, enamel the sky and sparkle from different points on the horizon." With each sun a different color, rising and setting in complex patterns and combinations of infinite variety, the landscape of Star is an ever-changing kaleidoscope of tints and shadows. Its firmament is also adorned with four large moons, one of which is translucent: "Elier is the diamond in which all the fires of suns, moons and stars play, cross each other and are reflected." The beauty of its sky is echoed in the vegetation and animal life of Star and in the language in which it is all described by Defontenay.The people of Star are human, but there are races which differ fundamental ways. On one moon, for example, the people are all hermaphrodites. On another they are transparent (as is everything else), and on a third moon the inhabitants are immune to aging and disease, but "Death" haunts them in the form of a species of corporeal predators. In this last society the greatest heroes are those who have done battle with the Deaths, killing them by the score before succumbing. Did Defontenay the physician picture himself as one of their number?These human variations and the history of their development are the vehicles the author uses to present his ideas on society. Early in their history the Starians dispense with religion, replacing it with a cult of beauty that venerates the marvels of nature and works of art. They allow no family to own more land than it can cultivate, and thereby control covetousness and eliminate class distinctions. Without the stress of religion and class, they are able to eliminate war and all forms of civic violence.
