They are also elected for life. Under each of these is a hierarchy of elected magistrates with more specialized functions. Hoh, Power, Wisdom and Love are all men, but the lesser magistrates are a mixture of men and women. All residents over age 20, male and female, are eligible to vote and do so in a grand Council meeting where the entire population is assembled around the temple.The City is a communist society where there is no private property, no money, and no family structure. Reproduction is under the control of a magistrate. "He sees that men and women are so joined together, that they bring forth the best offspring. Indeed, they laugh at us who exhibit a studious care for our breed of horses and dogs, but neglect the breeding of human beings." Men and women may share each other's company as they please, but unauthorized sexual intercourse is severely punished. Children are nursed by their mothers for two years, then taken away and raised in classes by tutors. They are sorted into various occupations according to their aptitudes, with the brightest becoming scientists and astrologers, the simplest being sent to work in the farms.Citizens dress in identical garments and are assigned to communal housing by sex. They are moved every two years. Men and women eat together in large dining halls while listening to lectures on scientific topics. Learning is a passion for them, and the city walls are their text books. Children study by walking the circumference of the City and reading the walls, and this helps keep them physically fit as well. The nation is so obsessed with physical fitness that seated pastimes such as chess are forbidden.Though the City has only just been discovered by Europeans, they have been aware of Europe for centuries and have sent explorers to all corners of the globe, learned every human language, and accumulated the wisdom of every culture. They have technologies far in advance of any other nation, including ships that move without oars or sails, and their military is both fierce and a source of great pride to the City.The City of the Sun is a work full of novel and sometimes quirky ideas. One wishes Campanella had filled in more details, especially on the lives of average citizens. He obviously drew upon both Plato's The Republic and Thomas More's Utopia for some aspects of his City, but was more radical than either in his social organization. At the same time, as a lifelong believer in astrology, Campanella added a mystical aspect to his utopia that to a modern reader seems totally out of synch with its scientific accomplishments.

Utopia is simply one of the most important and influential books ever written. Its ideas were then (and for the most part still are) so revolutionary that it can be difficult to believe a man with Thomas More's subsequent history even intended them to be taken seriously.More wrote Utopia in Latin, the language most widely read at the time by educated persons in Europe. It is also a language independent of place and time, which translator Paul Turner says is ample justification for using informal contemporary English in his translation. The result is highly readable and entertaining, but no less thought-provoking.The structure of the novel has More himself recounting a conversation he had with a traveler named Raphael who had spent five years living in Utopia, an island roughly 200 miles in diameter located somewhere in the New World. More has all the opinions and observations come from Raphael's mouth rather than his own, obviously to protect himself from being charged with promoting seditious ideas. But while Utopia does satirize a few of Europe's governments and institutions, it is not an attack on any particular person or country, and this is what has kept it relevant over the centuries.The most radical and most important feature of Utopia is that there is no private property and therefore no need for money. People dress identically and live in identical houses in identical towns. They each work at the trade for which they are best suited, usually the same as their parents. Families are sent in rotation to work on farms, the assumption being that farm work is less pleasant and should be shared by all. Military training is compulsory for both sexes, and the entire town is turned out from time to time for major projects such as roads, bridges, and fortifications. Slavery exists, but only as a form of punishment for serious crimes. All children are born free and equal and raised in identical circumstances.With no need for luxury goods and no idle classes, productivity is so high that Utopians need work only six hours a day. The rest of the time is devoted to self improvement and recreations such as music. Utopians do their work gladly, for the most part, out of community spirit. But those who might otherwise slack off know that "Everyone has his eye on you, so you're practically forced to get on with your job, and make some proper use of your spare time." Goods are taken to markets and storehouses where anyone who needs something just helps himself. Meals are served in communal halls where the elders are served first out of respect.There is freedom of religion in Utopia, at least to a point. Citizens are expected to believe in a creator and an afterlife and to attend religious services, but there is no official dogma, and sects are allowed to follow their own beliefs and practices as long as they don't proselytize in public. Atheists are tolerated, but they are considered contemptible and are barred from positions of public trust. That Thomas More would write something advocating religious toleration has always been puzzling, since he later ordered heretics burned at the stake and gave his own life in defense of the supremacy of the Catholic Church. More also mortified his own flesh by wearing a hair shirt despite having written in Utopia that it was as important to be kind to yourself as it was to be kind to others, and that it was ridiculous to suffer unnecessarily.Women in Utopia are subordinate at all times to their husbands, but may serve in the military and even as priests (provided they are widows). Their role in political life isn't addressed. Considering how revolutionary Utopia is in other respects, it is strangely conventional in sexual matters--probably reflecting More's own prudery. Marriage is for life except in rare circumstances, and any sex before or outside of marriage is severely punished, sometimes by enslavement or death. In a country where there is no private property and therefore no inheritance and no need to worry about legitimacy, where the pursuit of pleasure is considered a laudable goal, and where children are moved from one household to another to learn different trades, such rigid insistence on monogamy seems out of place.There is much more in Utopia on such things as foreign trade, warfare, education, medicine, aging and city planning. But what comes across most forcefully is the evil of the inequitable distribution of resources which is inevitable in a capitalist economy. The Utopians found one way to address this, a communist solution which many have since tried to emulate, at least in part.

In the early 19th century opium was as cheap and widely available as aspirin is today, and used almost as freely. Taken typically in a liquid form called laudanum, it was an effective painkiller for persons of all ages, and a cheap intoxicant. Thomas De Quincey first took opium as a youth for an affliction that sounds like a sinus infection. He so enjoyed its effects that for several years he took a dose as a treat every Saturday night. He found it made him more sociable and enhanced his enjoyment of the opera. It was only when he started taking laudanum daily for a chronic stomach pain that he became physically addicted to it. As he took greater and greater doses, De Quincey experienced vivid, exotic and terrifying dreams, some of which he describes in his writings.De Quincey tells us in no uncertain terms that he is THE expert on opium addiction. He disputes what the medical profession says about the drug. "And therefore, worthy doctors," he proclaims, "stand aside, and allow me to come forward and lecture on this matter." He also lets us know that he was, and is, an unparalleled scholar of the Greek language and as at home in Latin as Cicero. But he seems to have disdained any form of regular employment and spent most of his life in poverty, living off of the charity of a prostitute at one point, and later becoming something of a parasite of the poet William Wordsworth. De Quincey moved frequently to stay ahead of debt collectors, and wrote his Confessions while in hiding in London.The Confessions are largely a self-justification of his predicament, but there is some valuable insight into the effects of opium from a person who has gone through all stages of casual use, dependency, addiction, and withdrawal. As an example of one of his dreams: "I was buried, for a thousand years, in stone coffins, with mummies and sphynxes, in narrow chambers at the heart of eternal pyramids. I was kissed, with cancerous kisses, by crocodiles; and laid, confounded with all unutterable slimy things, amongst reeds and Nilotic mud.""Suspira de Profundis" (A Sigh from the Depths) is a sequel of sorts to the Confessions, but one that mostly goes back to fill in details of De Quincey's childhood. His point apparently is to show the raw material for some of his opium dreams, but he doesn't tell us a lot about the dreams themselves. Instead he, once again, seems chiefly to want to impress us with how exceptionally brilliant and sensitive he was as a child. He writes with such a combination of insufferable arrogance and rambling, purple-prosed Victorian sentimentality that it becomes an unintentional self-parody. De Quincey would have us believe that he was in tears when his housemaid killed a spider, and was only consoled when she explained that it was necessary to save the lives of the fifty flies that the spider would have murdered."The English Mail Coach" begins with a much welcome bit of humor, as De Quincey describes the public express coaches which he rode frequently between Oxford and London. The coaches held four passengers inside, and three on the roof with the driver. "It had been the fixed assumption of the four inside people," he explains, "that they, the illustrious quaternion, constituted a porcelain variety of the human race, whose dignity would have been compromised by exchanging one word of civility with the three delf ware outsides. Even to have kicked an outsider might have been held to attaint the foot concerned in that operation; so that, perhaps, it would have required an act of parliament to restore its purity of blood."In the second half of the essay De Quincey gets serious again and describes in detail an accident in which the massive mail coach in which he is riding at the furious speed of thirteen miles an hour overturns a small gig. The horrified De Quincey sees a young woman go flying, and he assumes she is killed (though the coach apparently never stopped). He then describes five opium dreams from later years, each a bizarre and unique variation of that accident.De Quincey's condescending tone and his rambling, repetitive, but incomplete narrative can be infuriating, but his Confessions do offer valuable insight into the social and psychological aspects of opium use in early 19th century England.

Phantastes is a beautifully-crafted story of a young man's adventures in Faerie Land and the lessons he learns there. Anodos, the narrator, on coming of age is given a key to a cabinet belonging to his late father. When he opens the cabinet a tiny woman appears who tells him he has faerie blood in him, and will be granted his once-expressed wish to enter Faerie Land.Anodos awakens the next morning to find his bedroom slowing changing into a woodland glade, and his wash basin overflowing to become a forest stream. He follows the stream into a world of mystery and magic, peopled by talking flowers, walking trees, ogres, giants, knights and damsels.Inside a cave he encounters a young woman apparently frozen into a block of alabaster. She is more beautiful than anything he has ever seen, and Anodos is sure that she will become his if he can only free her from the stone. He can't reach her to kiss her, but on a sudden inspiration he tries song. Sure enough, his singing gradually melts away the stone, but when she is free the young beauty jumps up and runs away. Anodos spends much of his time pursuing this ideal beauty, but is frustrated at every turn.Anodos's adventures are numerous, bizarre, and sometimes unsettling. There are also several stories within stories, such as one where a young man in Prague attempts to free the woman he loves from an enchanted mirror. Mirrors and reflections figure prominently throughout the novel, with the common question being: "Why are all reflections lovelier than what we call the reality?--not so grand or so strong, it may be, but always lovelier?" And later: "All mirrors are magic mirrors. The commonest room is a room in a poem when I turn to the glass."Anodos learns that the pursuit of the ideal, be it a woman or a reputation, is a sign of false pride. "I learned that it is better, a thousand-fold, for a proud man to fall and be humbled, than to hold up his head in his pride and fancied innocence. I learned that he that will be a hero, will barely be a man; that he that will be nothing but a doer of his work, is sure of his manhood." He also learns that the joy is in loving, not in being loved.Most of the images and events in Phantastes have no obvious meaning or message, and appear to be there just to stimulate the imagination. There are some obviously Christian concepts and values, but no overt theological message or allegory. The purpose of the novel may, perhaps, be revealed in this passage:"But is it not rather that art rescues nature from the weary and sated regards of our senses, and the degrading injustice of our anxious everyday life, and, appealing to the imagination, which dwells apart, reveals Nature in some degree as she really is, and as she represents herself to the eye of the child, whose every-day life, fearless and unambitious, meets the true import of the wonder-teeming world around him, and rejoices therein without questioning?"

Herbert Lottman's biography of Albert Camus is a richly detailed and highly sympathetic examination of the writer's life--too much so in both cases for my taste. The book's strongest point is that it shows how much of Camus's life and work were devoted to areas that are apart from his popular image as novelist and philosopher.Camus was born in Algeria, then a French possession, in 1913. His father was soon to die in the First World War, so Camus was raised by his mother and extended family. As a youth he developed tuberculosis, which chiefly affected his stamina and was partly responsible for directing him toward artistic pursuits. His principal lifetime love was the theater, first as an actor and later as playwright, director and manager. To pay the bills he started work as a journalist, and would continue to do so off and on for most of his life. Camus lived in Algeria, with occasional trips to Europe, until the German invasion in 1940 left him stranded in Paris. Under Nazi occupation he worked openly for a publishing firm while secretly writing for and editing an underground newspaper.Camus's early political allegiance was to the French communist party. But stories of Stalin's atrocities led to a break with the communists who insisted on maintaining their loyalty to the USSR. This was also responsible for Camus's very public break with his friend Jean-Paul Sartre. For the rest of his life, Camus maintained an independent stance that was left of center, but not communist, and resisted France's alignment with either the USSR or the USA. When the Muslim population of Algeria rebelled against the French government, Camus was torn between his belief in self-determination and his desire to protect the lifestyle of his family and other Frenchmen in Algeria. Much to the consternation of his friends, Camus withheld his voice during the Algerian war.Lottman obviously felt that Camus's sex life was off limits. Camus was married twice, and was still living with his second wife Francine when he was killed in an automobile accident in January 1960. But he spent much of his time with other women, particularly actresses, often travelling with them unchaperoned. There is also mention of a "ravishing young woman associated with neither his literary life or the theater" who was Camus's frequent companion for the last two years of his life, but the name of this young woman was apparently withheld out of delicacy.Despite Lottman's enthusiasm for everything he did and said, Camus comes across as less likable than I had expected. He was always sensitive to insult and criticism, and flit from one project to another his whole life. His literary production was rather slim altogether, and even he suspected that the Swedish Academy awarded him the Nobel Prize more for political reasons than for his accomplishments. His best moments appeared to be when he was out of the limelight and not under pressure, when he could be quite unassuming and companionable.I read this particular biography, not because of favorable reviews, but because it came readily to hand. I'm sure there are better and newer ones that make use of sources that were not yet made available to researchers when Lottman was writing. Lottman nonetheless gives us a wealth of detail on Camus's daily life, but I found the author too quick to defend Camus. There is very little insight into the man and his philosophy. Instead we have details such as the names of his friends' dogs, the itinerary of a traveling companion's maid, and the family history of a blacksmith with whom Camus chatted a few times.

Karen Finley is a countercultural performance artist and writer known for her strident denunciations of sexism, racism, homophobia and consumerism. She is a sex-positive feminist whose use of nudity and explicit sexual language in her stage performances has been labeled obscene by critics. Shock Treatment is an early collection of some her performance monologues, essays and poetry.The subjects addressed in this collection are varied and include child abuse, sexual stereotyping, racism, poverty, homelessness, objectification of women's bodies, reproductive freedom and materialism. Writing at a time when some religious leaders were referring to AIDS as a punishment from God, Finley compares the treatment of AIDS victims to the Holocaust and refers to the 700 Club as "America's SS." The general tone of her writing is one of despair that that the liberalism and idealism of the '60s and '70s has been replaced in the '80s by yuppie materialism and religious fundamentalism.Shock Treatment lives up to its name. The text is filled with profanity and contains explicit descriptions of violent and coercive sexual acts including incest, coprophagy, rape and self-mutilation. However, there are also sensitive moments depicting illness, death and grief. As this is just a broad sampling of ideas and opinions, you won't find much depth on any particular topic. Yet there are definitely some thought-provoking comments here, and I don't think any of her pieces has become dated in the 20+ years since they were written.

The Narrative of Arthur Gordon Pym, Poe's only novel, is a nautical adventure with elements of science fiction and horror. It reads like a series of brilliantly told stories somewhat arbitrarily connected and capped by an abrupt and mystifying ending.The story takes place in 1835-36. Pym, a young New Englander, desires to go to sea with a friend, Augustus, whose father captains a whaling brig. Pym's relatives refuse him permission, so Augustus helps him stow away in the hold. Pym's confinement in the dark, unhealthy hold last days longer than he expects, and he fears he will die there, alone and forgotten. Finally Augustus gets word to him that there has been a mutiny, and that Augustus, because of his youth, had been the only non-mutineer allowed to remain alive on board the vessel.There follows a succession of adventures involving a counter-mutiny, a storm, a shipwreck, and a prolonged survival ordeal at sea. Pym eventually finds himself on board another ship which is off to explore the Antarctic in the hope of finding some previously undiscovered land where there are seals to hunt or natives to trade with. His adventures have only begun. Each episode in the novel is told briskly with edge-of-the-seat tension. Poe's descriptions are as vivid and rousing as any nautical adventure I have read.At the time of Poe's writing, a number of European and American expeditions had attempted to determine if there was an Antarctic continent. Most had been turned back by ice. Two or three explorers had only recently come upon dry land within the Antarctic circle, but were unable to determine if these were the shores of a continent or just isolated islands. There had been some reports or rumors that the waters actually grew warmer as one approached the pole, leading to speculations about hidden tropical civilizations. Others believed that the Earth was hollow, and that the poles were the points of entry to a second world inside. Poe recaps much of this in the novel, and Pym and his companions make discoveries that begin to hint that some the wildest theories may be true.The science fiction elements of the novel are found in the "lost world" idea, though this surfaces only in the final chapters. The horror elements are found in the terror of premature burial (a common theme in Poe's short stories) and in the superstitious fear of the reanimated dead. But there is nothing overtly supernatural in the novel.There are two objectionable aspects to the novel. One is the abrupt and unsatisfying ending which has frustrated and mystified readers since its original publication. The other is the strong presence of racial stereotypes. I found myself, while reading the novel, unable to put it down and wondering why it has been so neglected relative to Poe's poems and stories. The puzzling ending is the answer to that question, but it remains a memorable reading experience.

Part history, part homage, London: The Biography tells the story of London from its mythical beginnings to the end of the 20th century. The opening chapters, from prehistory to the middle ages, are conventionally chronological, as are the closing chapters from roughly 1880 to 1999. Everything between is thematically organized, though there is a general chronological drift. There are chapters on food, prisons, mobs, children, plagues, trade, fires, smells, sounds and so forth--over sixty topics in all.Though Ackroyd's history gives the impression of being based on sound research, he writes more from a novelist's perspective about ideas, feelings of identity, and cultural traditions. Most of the quotes he offers come from the fiction or travel writings of literary figures rather than histories and biographies. This is a history that will especially please those with an interest in literature and local heritage; it's likely to disappoint those who want to learn London's place in the larger picture of British or European history.There are several sections of black and white and color plates, as well as a couple of rudimentary maps. One could wish for more, especially when specific paintings or photographs are mentioned in the text but not included in the illustrations. Instead of footnotes and bibliography there is a twelve-page essay on sources. All of the sources appear to be previously published works; the book makes no claim to include original research. There is an index, but it is not comprehensive. When I tried to find the first reference to Whitehall, I discovered that the term is omitted.London: The Biography is highly readable, entertaining and imaginative. It is meant for popular rather than scholarly consumption, and its informal thematic organization may frustrate those who want to learn more about a particular period in London's history. The author's love for his subject is obvious and occasionally carries him away. He is apt to see mystical connections where there is only coincidence, and the notion "only in London" is overused. But Ackroyd makes a convincing case that London is not only a great city, but perhaps the greatest, and one whose history and heritage are certainly worth our attention.

“The silk department was like a huge bedroom dedicated to love, hung with white by the whim of a woman in love who, snowy in her nudity, wished to compete in whiteness. All the milky tones of an adored body were there, from the velvet of the hips to the fine silk of the thighs and the shining satin of the breasts.”In such sexual terms, Émile Zola repeatedly describes the merchandise on display in Paris’s first and greatest department store, “The Ladies’ Paradise,” or simply “The Paradise.”The fabrics and articles of clothing are designed to appeal to all the erotic senses. A pair of leather gloves smells “like an animal in rut which has landed in a girl’s powder box.” Women plunge their hands into bales of silk and piles of lace, their rapture reaching an orgasmic intensity which translates into a frenzy of spending. The shop floor, seen from above, was a “sea of bosoms bursting with life, beating with desire.” And at the end of big sale “the customers, despoiled and violated, were going away in disarray, their desires satisfied, and with the secret shame of having yielded to temptation in the depths of some sleazy hotel.”The setting is Paris in the 1860s during the extravagant, materialistic years of the Second Empire. The owner and manager of The Paradise, Octave Mouret, is one of the two principal characters of the novel. An ambitious young widower of modest origins, he has built The Paradise up from a simple draper’s shop to become the marvel of Paris through his audacity and his merchandising genius.The other principal character, Denise Baudu, appears on the scene as an orphaned teenage girl from the provinces throwing herself and her two brothers unexpectedly upon the charity of her uncle. But the uncle, the owner of a small fabric store across the street from The Paradise, is in the process of being driven out of business by competition from the monster store and can barely feed his own family. Facing starvation, Denise winds up working as a shopgirl in the very store that is ruining her family. Here the pretty teenager soon attracts the eye of the lustful Mouret, a man as accustomed to manipulating women into his bedroom as he is to enticing them onto his sales floor. But Denise, he finds, does not share the casual sexual attitudes of many Parisiennes. Instead he discovers in her a strength and intelligence that both frustrates and inspires him.The Ladies’ Paradise is a novel in Zola’s “Rougon-Macquart” series. The series relates the fortunes and misfortunes of an extended family during the Second Empire period. Many of the titles focus on the influence of heredity and environment on the character of family members, but that is not so much the case here. Octave Mouret, the Rougon-Macquart descendant in this case, is not as much the subject of the novel as the institution he has created. (He actually first acquires The Paradise in Zola’s previous novel, Pot Bouille, translated most recently as Pot Luck.) The Ladies’ Paradise is actually rather short on plot and character development compared to Zola’s other novels.A major theme in the novel is the effect The Paradise has in driving out of business the small, family owned competitors, which can’t complete with The Paradise’s low prices and sex appeal. One constant contrast is between the brilliantly lit interior of The Paradise and the dark, dingy spaces of the other stores where “the dark shadows were falling from the ceiling in great shovelfuls, like black earth into the grave.” The misery into which the small shopkeepers descend is often depicted melodramatically, yet Zola never suggests that the large department store is evil or unfair, but rather that we are witnessing a natural stage in the evolution of commerce.It is fascinating to see in this novel the beginnings of retail practices with which we are now quite familiar. The physical arrangement of departments within a store is done for psychological, rather than logistical purposes. Traffic flow in busy aisles is deliberately impeded to create the illusion of bigger crowds and more excitement. A generous return policy encourages impulse buying. With a staff growing into the thousands, the store becomes a community of its own with dormitories, dining halls, and recreation rooms. Cutthroat employment practices are softened in the interest of employee loyalty, and we see the emergence of employee benefits such as onsite health care, maternity leave, and education programs. On the outside there is a new business/government partnership for further development, and we see the buying power of a large retailer begin to control its suppliers.Octave Mouret explains at one point that he has built his success upon “the exploitation of Woman.” Is the novel demeaning to women by depicting them as so easily exploited--so readily seduced into an orgy of spending? Not necessarily, because what we also see is the increasing power of women in the marketplace as independent consumers. Inside the store Zola shows them growing in power and responsibility as managers, department heads, and buyers (though we still never see a woman supervising a man). Behind the scenes they have additional influence as key investors.The Ladies’ Paradise is a fascinating and enlightening look at the birth of an institution which is still a dominating force in retail. It can be seen as a critique of materialism and greed, but as such is not as forceful as some of the author’s other works. Nor is the novel particularly strong in plot or character. But Zola’s immense powers of description are on full, sensuous display.

As Flies to Whatless Boys is Robert Antoni's imaginative recreation of what he presents as a part of his own family history. In 1845 the William Tucker family of London immigrates to Trinidad with other members of what is called the Tropical Emigration Society. Their leader, a German named Etzler, proposes to set up a utopian socialist community where most of the work will be done by an amazing self-propelled machine of his own invention called the Satellite. A number of poor families, and a few more prosperous idealists, invest their life's savings with Etzler and set sail for Trinidad. Whether Etzler was a fraud or delusional, they never learn, because soon after their arrival they are abandoned on an isolated strip of land that is mostly mud and fever-ridden mangrove swamp.The novel has several parallel narrative threads decades apart. In 1845 William Tucker had a 15-year-old son, also named William but called Willy, who immigrated to Trinidad with him. He is the principal character of the novel. But we first meet him in 1881 when he is preparing to return for the first time to England. He is telling his own son the story of how he and his family came to Trinidad, and the poignant story of his first love.Interspersed with the father/son scene in 1881 and the story Willy is telling about 1845 there are whimsical pieces of correspondence between Robert Antoni himself and a Miss Ramsol, the director of the Trinidad & Tobago National Archives, concerning the research Antoni is doing into the Tucker family, his ancestors. Antoni is making no headway with the obstinate Miss Samsol in his request to use the office photocopier, notwithstanding the fact that the two are carrying on a torrid romance after hours.In 1845 the romance is between 15-year-old Willy and Marguerite, the 18-year-old niece of one of the wealthy emigrants. Marguerite is mute, born without vocal cords, but it is their social difference that stands between the two. Willy's machinations to get to Marguerite before they sail, on the long voyage across the Atlantic, and in their early days in Trinidad are both humorously inventive and romantically touching.At five points in the novel there are notes with links to websites which supplement the text. Not all of these were available yet, as the book has yet to be released to the public, but those that were active brought up beautifully done video clips showing images from Willy's dreams.The title is a Trinidadian version of a quote from King Lear: "As flies to wanton boys are we to the gods / They kill us for their sport." The strange and capricious working of fate would be the principal theme to the novel. I found this a very entertaining novel, unpredictable, often funny, and occasionally moving. I'm not sure that it is necessarily an accurate portrayal of Trinidad in the 1840s or of the experience of utopian settlers in general, especially when the author has his characters using anachronistic terms such as "blitzkrieg" and "seat belt." The use of multiple narrative lines, however, added value to the novel, was never confusing, and helped keep it interesting to the end.

Summery: The L12S Smart Bracelet features an attractive design, and several interesting features ('massage mode', 'pedometer', 'mp3 player'). However, the limited screen size leaves reading text messages tedious. With that being said, consumers on the fence about whether they really need a smartwatch in their lives, could purchase this as a foray into the world of smart wearables. Overall, the price is compelling, and as long as one's expectations are modest, the L12S doesn't really disappoint.Extended Review:*A full video version of my review can be found here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WBgajyiJ5w8Packaging- Other than the watch, instructions, and microUSB cable (fully charging the watch takes +/-2 hours), there's also an included dock. The dock is constructed out of plastic, and allows for the L12S to be elegantly positioned when charging. The instruction manual includes a QR code for an application called 'BTNotification' to be downloaded from the Android Play Store. This app allows the phone/tablet to send notifications to the watch, so don't lose the manual!Hardware- From a design standpoint, the Smart Bracelet looks futuristic, and stands out. For a product that's only $30, we were impressed by the use of metal accents, soft touch rubber, and rugged plastic. The bracelet feels solidly built, even in weight distribution, and comfortable to wear. The front features the power/select button, two capacitive touch buttons (for moving up/down, or long pressing on either to go back), and the OLED display.Performance- To begin, the L12S is designed for Android, and does not work with any iOS products. Connecting the bracelet over Bluetooth was straight-forwards enough, and the wireless connection range was around 30ft. With the L12S powered on, we averaged 12-13 hours of usage. That means owners should expect to charge their smart bracelets every day or two. The OLED screen is on the smaller side of the spectrum, but it's bright enough to be read outdoors and indoors. As aforementioned, the watch relies on two capacitive buttons to control navigation. These buttons were surprisingly response, making the user experience coherent and pretty easy to figure out. Next, we're discuss the various features of the watch:Contacts- Once synced with a phone, the watch can display the contacts stored in your phonebook. Users can then call or look up specific number. Although this feature worked, it's an area where the smaller screen size (roughly 0.5 inches) is a limitation. Plenty of scrolling around is needed.Music- The bracelet acts as a Bluetooth speaker, playing back music from your phone. The speakers on the bracelet are loud, although not especially crisp. Regardless, we found it to be a slight upgrade over the speakers found in most Android smartphones. A limited number of tracks (3-4) can be directly saved onto the watch's memory, via a computer. These tracks will play (mp3 player) even without a connection to the smartphone. Tracks can be show song titles and artist names within the menus.Calling- Users can directly answer incoming calls with the watch (alarm and vibration notification). The built-in microphone is generally good, although it doesn't eliminate background noise. Overall the speakerphone experience is good, but nothing spectacular.Messages- Easily the weakest link of the smart bracelet. Notifications are regularly and accurately pushed to the watch, but the small screen size means you'll be scrolling up and down quite a lot. Unless the messages are exceptionally short, we think using your phone/tablet will be a more comfortable experience.Pedometer- As a fitness tracker, the smart bracelet works pretty well. We're seen more accurate trackers in the past, but general footsteps are recorded without any issues. We would have liked to see a way to store our steps on our phone (with the app), through.Massage- One of the novelty features that turns the vibration sensor on, and promises to 'ease any sore or tired wrists'. It works, although expect the battery life to reduce after use.Anti-Loss alarm- Easily the best feature of the bracelet. If someone steals your phone, and the Bluetooth connection to the watch is severed, an alarm will immediately ring. Similarly, users can 'find' their lost phone/bracelet by using either the watch/phone app.Conclusion- There's certainly room for improvement, mainly with the screen size. However, good call quality, a beautiful design, and the rock-bottom price, provide the L12S with saving grace. For first time smart watch owners, this is a decent option to consider.Rating: 3.6/5 stars, Good(Rounded to 4/5 via Amazon's Rating System)

This app allows the phone/tablet to send notifications to the watch, so don't lose the manual!Hardware- From a design standpoint, the Smart Bracelet looks futuristic, and stands out. For a product that's only $30, we were impressed by the use of metal accents, soft touch rubber, and rugged plastic. The bracelet feels solidly built, even in weight distribution, and comfortable to wear. The front features the power/select button, two capacitive touch buttons (for moving up/down, or long pressing on either to go back), and the OLED display.Performance- To begin, the L12S is designed for Android, and does not work with any iOS products. Connecting the bracelet over Bluetooth was straight-forwards enough, and the wireless connection range was around 30ft. With the L12S powered on, we averaged 12-13 hours of usage. That means owners should expect to charge their smart bracelets every day or two. The OLED screen is on the smaller side of the spectrum, but it's bright enough to be read outdoors and indoors. As aforementioned, the watch relies on two capacitive buttons to control navigation. These buttons were surprisingly response, making the user experience coherent and pretty easy to figure out. Next, we're discuss the various features of the watch:Contacts- Once synced with a phone, the watch can display the contacts stored in your phonebook. Users can then call or look up specific number. Although this feature worked, it's an area where the smaller screen size (roughly 0.5 inches) is a limitation. Plenty of scrolling around is needed.Music- The bracelet acts as a Bluetooth speaker, playing back music from your phone. The speakers on the bracelet are loud, although not especially crisp. Regardless, we found it to be a slight upgrade over the speakers found in most Android smartphones. A limited number of tracks (3-4) can be directly saved onto the watch's memory, via a computer. These tracks will play (mp3 player) even without a connection to the smartphone. Tracks can be show song titles and artist names within the menus.Calling- Users can directly answer incoming calls with the watch (alarm and vibration notification). The built-in microphone is generally good, although it doesn't eliminate background noise. Overall the speakerphone experience is good, but nothing spectacular.Messages- Easily the weakest link of the smart bracelet. Notifications are regularly and accurately pushed to the watch, but the small screen size means you'll be scrolling up and down quite a lot. Unless the messages are exceptionally short, we think using your phone/tablet will be a more comfortable experience.Pedometer- As a fitness tracker, the smart bracelet works pretty well. We're seen more accurate trackers in the past, but general footsteps are recorded without any issues. We would have liked to see a way to store our steps on our phone (with the app), through.Massage- One of the novelty features that turns the vibration sensor on, and promises to 'ease any sore or tired wrists'. It works, although expect the battery life to reduce after use.Anti-Loss alarm- Easily the best feature of the bracelet. If someone steals your phone, and the Bluetooth connection to the watch is severed, an alarm will immediately ring. Similarly, users can 'find' their lost phone/bracelet by using either the watch/phone app.Conclusion- There's certainly room for improvement, mainly with the screen size. However, good call quality, a beautiful design, and the rock-bottom price, provide the L12S with saving grace. For first time smart watch owners, this is a decent option to consider.Rating: 3.6/5 stars, Good(Rounded to 4/5 via Amazon's Rating System)

Unless the messages are exceptionally short, we think using your phone/tablet will be a more comfortable experience.Pedometer- As a fitness tracker, the smart bracelet works pretty well. We're seen more accurate trackers in the past, but general footsteps are recorded without any issues. We would have liked to see a way to store our steps on our phone (with the app), through.Massage- One of the novelty features that turns the vibration sensor on, and promises to 'ease any sore or tired wrists'. It works, although expect the battery life to reduce after use.Anti-Loss alarm- Easily the best feature of the bracelet. If someone steals your phone, and the Bluetooth connection to the watch is severed, an alarm will immediately ring. Similarly, users can 'find' their lost phone/bracelet by using either the watch/phone app.Conclusion- There's certainly room for improvement, mainly with the screen size. However, good call quality, a beautiful design, and the rock-bottom price, provide the L12S with saving grace. For first time smart watch owners, this is a decent option to consider.Rating: 3.6/5 stars, Good(Rounded to 4/5 via Amazon's Rating System)

3:40 Mins SUMMERY:kdLinks's Ultra Slim-Fit case offers an excellent combination of functionality and style. The case itself maintains the slim chassis of the iPhone 6 plus (0.5mm!), while adding a grippy soft-touch coating and sturdy TPU construction. Overall, it's a case that works exactly as advertised.Extended Review:Packaging- The Ultra Slim-Fit case comes in an attractive, transparent box that contains the case, and some details regarding the product.Design & Performance- The main selling point of the Ultra Slim, is how it maintains the sleekness of the original iPhone 6 plus while protecting it from scratches and bumps. All ports are still fully accessible when the case is inserted, from the camera grill to the volume buttons.Construction quality of the case is surprisingly study, considering the slimness of the design. As a hard-shell case, the Ultra-Slim is built from Thermoplastic Polyurethane, which allows for a certain degree of malleability. This means that if you drop the phone/case, the case will absorb some of the shock, protecting the iPhone inside.Otherwise, the texture of the case is described by the manufacture as a 'sandy' texture. I'd say it's closer to being soft-touch, which provides a gripper surface for users to hold their devices. A benefit of this finish, is that it resists fingerprints, and covers-up scratches easily.Lastly, applying the case to the iPhone 6 plus was a simple affair. There are no moving parts, so the phone simply slides in. Removing the phone requires a bit more pressure, but can still be done without harming the device. During our testing, we never had the iPhone slip out from the case- it's a snug fit.Conclusion:Although not the flashiest iPhone case out there, the kdLinks Ultra Slim does a great job in merging form with function.Rating: 4.8/5 (Rounded to 5 on Amazon's system)~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~We were provided this sample to create an honest emulation.

8:04 MinsSUMMERY:THE GOOD: DBPower's 1080P Dashboard Camera offers aluminum construction quality, no-frills video looping, and an excellent wide angle lens.THE CON: Lacks integrated GPS, user manual can be difficult to dissectVERDICT: Despite minor caveats, this dashboard camera still offers incredible value for the money.EXTENDED REVIEW:Packaging- DBPower pairs the camera with a windshield mount, car charger, USB data cable, and user manual. The contents are nicely protected via foam and cardboard. Our review unit arrived within 3 days of ordering.Design- The hardware of the dashboard camera is attractive, with curved edges, and an all-metallic finish. As a small camera, the back is almost entirely dominated by the 2.7" LCD display and navigational controls. The side houses a miniHDMI port that can connect to HDTVs (cable is not included in the box). Note that the wide-angle lens does protrude from the unit quite a bit, so take extra care when handling the camera!DBPower throws in a 2 year warranty with the unit, along with its quite stellar customer support.Functionality- As advertised, when the car engine starts (camera plugged into charger), the dash-cam automatically begins recording looping video. On this particular unit, audio is also recorded, although the microphone is only passable, and there is no speaker built on the camera to play back sound.Speaking of, the video quality itself is quite good. Fine details are easy to interpret (i.e. license place numbers), and colors are vibrant. Low-light performance is considerably weaker, but still acceptable. The 170 degree angle lens does 'stretch' shapes, but this is a common trait among most wide-angle lens. During operation, the camera also remained cool in temperature.Motion sensing is another feature this camera offers. Users can set the camera to automatically begin recording videos when movement is detected (security) in looping intervals of 22 seconds, 1 minute, 3,5 and no loops. One flaw we noticed was that looping sometimes cuts of 1-2 seconds of in-between video (processing). Again, not a deal-breaker, but hopefully an area future models can improve on.Adjustments to contrast, resolution and looping can be found in the menu- which took some acclimation to get used to. The menu layout is clear enough, but the controls didn't always correlate to their intuitive functions. The user manual isn't that much of a help, with the instructions lacking clarity. However, most functions can be figured out by playing around with the product.For memory, users will need to separately purchase a SD card (camera supports up to 64GB). Files are saved in the .mov for video, and standard JPEG for photos.CONCLUSION:Overall, DBPower's dashboard cam is a solid product that does what it's supposed to: capture looping video with enviable resolution. The instructions can admittedly be improved, but this flaw is made up by DBPower's excellent customer support (helping users with the set-up process).Rating: 4.7/5 Stars(Rating rounded to 5/5 on Amazon's System)

5:22 Mins SUMMERY:THE GOOD: Aurin's Mini Bluetooth Headset is inexpensive, attractive in design, and sound quality is excellent. The headset can be used to either listen to music or answer phone calls.THE CON: The 'stereo' label can be misleading because only one earbud is included.VERDICT: As long as your expectations are modest, Aurin's Mini Bluetooth Earbuds are a decent value for the money. Audio quality was better than expected, and the battery life is stronger than the category average.EXTENDED REVIEW:Packaging- Aurin bundles the earphone with a propitiatory USB charging cable (Bluetooth takes 2 hours to fully charge), and an instruction manual. The box is made out of recyclable cardboard.Design- The Mini Bluetooth Headset comes in two color iterations: black or white. Both colors are crafted out of glossy plastic (attractive and sturdy, but attracts fingerprints). A single power/answer button rests on the surface of the unit. This button is easy to press, and resembles an enlarged iPhone 4S home button. Below the surface of this key is an LED that will illuminate when the unit is on.Performance- Aurin's headset can be worn with/without the earhook attached. In testing, we found the Bluetooth headset to be comfortable enough, although there are no adjustable ear pieces included. When jogging around, the Bluetooth headset did not fall out.Pairing up the earbud was easy enough, with a supported range of 10 meters. Once paired, the headset becomes the speaker for the tablet/phone.Audio quality was pleasant (crisp, audible, suitable for general music playback), although the lack of a second earbud makes 3D/true stereo impossible. That means this Earbud won't do the trick for watching immerse films. Call quality was good, with the microphone picking up our voice even in louder environments.Battery life is rated at 3 hours, although we reached 3.5-4 hours in our tests. The standby time is stated at 100 hours.Rating: 4.6/5 Stars(Rating Rounded to 5 via Amazon's Review System)

8:46 Mins DBPower's Mini Bluetooth Speaker is small. Really small. The speaker can actually disappear behind a U.S. 25 cent quarter. In fact, when I first removed the product from the packaging, I couldn't believe what I was seeing. I knew the product would be portable, but a speaker the size of a smartphone charm? This may very well be one of the world's smallest Bluetooth speakers...In terms of design, the speaker is nicely constructed out of durable plastics. A bundled lanyard makes it possible for the speaker to hang from a tablet/smartphone's headphone port, and a power button rests on the very top. The sides also contain the microUSB charging port (cable not included in the box, takes 2 hours to fully charge), and microphone (speakerphone function).Sound quality actually surprised me with the clarity (no static from the Bluetooth) and sheer loudness. No, the speaker won't fill a large room, but it'll more than work for tighter spaces. In the video review, I compare the sound on a Samsung Galaxy S3 with this speaker, and found the latter to be exponentially better. Regardless of genre, music sounded rich and a little bass was even present!However, this wasn't the only thing that startled me... The manufacture decided to record audible 'sounds' to notify users of the unit's different modes. Case in point, when the speaker powers on, a female voice says, "Power On, Ready to Pair!" This is a neat feature, the first time this happened, I nearly jumped out of my skin (was not expecting the speaker to talk to me).The Bluetooth paring went smoothly enough (speaker is called JTL-8). Once paired, the speaker can also take calls, although the built-in microphone was on the fuzzier side of the spectrum. Interestingly, the Bluetooth speaker also acts as an 'anti-loss' alarm. Essentially, once the Bluetooth connection of 30m has been severed between speaker and phone, an alarm will sound on the speaker.One caveat I did find, was with the 'taking photos' (remote) functionality. The feature requires a separate app to work, and is only compatible with Android phones. Sadly, when I tried to install the app (QR code on box), an error message prevented me to go further on a Galaxy S3. Hopefully this software issue will be ironed out down the road!All-in-all, this Mini Bluetooth Speaker is an impressive piece of kit. It's small, relatively powerful, and offers a dense set of useful functions. A job well done!Rating: 4.8/5 stars, Excellent(Rounded to 5/5 on Amazon's System)

7:21 Mins Summery: The A7-T is useful for companies looking for a swift way of checking employee attendance, using the built-in biometric fingerprint reader. When not scanning or recording attendance, the device dubs as a digital clock, with an HTC-inspired look. Otherwise, the device takes some initial set-up to get up and running, but does work as advertised.Extended Review:Packaging- DBPower boxes the A7-T with an AC adapter, wall mount plate, and an instruction manual. The box itself is well cushioned by foam in the interior, and has an attractive exterior.Design- The A7-T is crafted out of plastic and metal components. The part containing the screen and scanner is glossy, whereas the rest of the unit is textually matte. The manufacture adds that the fingerprint scanner surface is durable tempered glass. On the front, users will also find a t-9 keypad (text and number entry). These buttons are large and easy to press, with a tactile response to them. A loudspeaker also sits on the metallic front.Performance-Screen: Under brighter environments, the LCD can become washed out, with extreme viewing angles going against the device's favor. With that being said, this isn't a large concern, with most users opting the use the A7-T indoors. At 3", the screen is also generously sized. During moments of inactivity, the unit can display a custom wallpaper.We do have to note that the user manual doesn't do the device justice. However learning the menu system was still relatively easy to learn by trial/error. As noted by the manufacture, up to 1,000 fingerprints can be stored on the unit.For fingerprint recognition, we found that dry fingers did not work as well as moist ones. With that being said, the scanner does have little preference when it comes to orientation of the finger being scanned, and recognition speed is very fast (2 seconds). After recognition, the user's name will appear on screen for confirmation, and the speaker with announce, "thank you" (can be disabled). The data is then stored on the unit, and can be exported by a USB flash drive, or connecting a computer (no drivers needed- Mac or PC). Attendance will be laid out in an Excel document form.Summery:Overall, this Biometric attendance unit does the job well... as long as you are willing to play around a bit with the menus. This is all-in-all a very interesting piece of technology!Rating: 4.8/5 Stars, Excellent(Rating Rounded to 5/5 on Amazon's Review System)

3:03 Mins Summery: Aurin's Mini All-in-1 Reader stands out for its minuscule dimensions. No larger than a compact flash drive, this USB 3.0 Reader recognizes all SD and microSD formats. Aurin's reader is also plug-and-play, requiring no additional driver to work with Mac and Windows computers.Extended Review:Packaging- Aurin's Eco-conscious packaging consists of the reader, and a quick warranty guide. The box itself is made out of cardboard and fully recyclable. We received our review model within 5 days of ordering the product.Design- The Mini All-in-1 Reader is coated in a layer of soft touch rubber, which resists fingerprints and smudges. The grippy texture also makes the Reader easy to plug/remove from USB ports. On the front is a simple blue LED that will illuminate when the accessory is plugged in.When a SD card is inserted, the card mostly protrudes from the body of the Reader. Although this doesn't impact the unit's functionality, it does mean the card is less securely inserted (increased chance of damage). However, this is a natural trade-off for having a smaller design. As a USB 3.0 device, the Reader is also backwards compatible with USB 2.0/1.1 ports.Functionality- When tested with a range of computers and tablets, we experienced no recognition issues (Windows XP, 7, 8). In most instances, the USB device was recognized within 10 seconds of being plugged in. Because Aurin's Reader is USB 3.0, data transfer speeds were close to reaching nearly 5Gbps. This meant that copying files from a camera's SD card to a computer was fast. Really fast. Case in point, a full 16GB card (filled with QHD video clips), copied onto our computer hard drive in under 55 seconds. Aurin's reader is also compatible with all SD card formats (SD, SDHC, SDXC, MicroSD, TF Cards).One aspect the company could add in a future iteration, is the ability for the USB cap (protection) to be fastened onto the Reader's 2nd end (like marker caps!) when not being used. This would decrease the odds of losing this cap when traveling.Summery:Aurin's All-in-1 Reader functions like a charm, and boasts one of the smallest form factors we've ever seen. This makes Aurin's Reader ideal for road warriors looking to add SD/microSD slots to tablets/ultra-portables.Rating: 4.7/5 Stars, Excellent(Rounded to 5/5 via Amazon's review system)

7:52 Mins Summery: The well-designed Huion P608N graphic tablet is easy on the wallet, but rich in functionality. We were particularly impressed by the pen's 2,048 levels of pressure sensitivity, which felt as natural as drawing with an actual pencil/paper. The tablet's quick access controls are well laid out, and the unit was compatible with all art programs we threw at it.Extended Review:Packaging- Huion's Eco-friendly packaging contains the tablet, pen, instruction manual, four extra pen tips, (1) AA battery (for the pen), and a CD-Rom. The tablet is securely protected by layers of foam and cardboard.Design- The P608N offers an ergonomic look, with curved edges and a matte plastic finish. When placed on a desk, the tablet looks classy, and doesn't slide around (rubber feet on the bottom). We're fans of how the curved ridge on the tablet's top actually holds the stylus when not in use. Along the sides of the 6"x8" touch area are 26 buttons that can be programmed for quick-access functions. For instance, one button can 'cut' artwork, while another 'opens' a blank document.The pen is turned on/off by pressing on the eraser end. The button is spring-assisted, and quite easy to press. Otherwise, the pen is easy to hold, with the thick rubber grip contributing to this trait. However, because the pen lacks any protruding edges (no other buttons or clips), it rolls around quite easily.Functionality:Before the tablet can be used, a software from Huion must first be installed. Unfortunately, the driver that came on the CD-Rom was antiquated, and at least for us, refused to work. An up-to-date version of the driver can be found (free!) on Huion's website. This driver did work, and installed within a matter of seconds on our Windows 8 laptop.During testing, we used both Gimp (free!) and Adobe Photoshop. We found that that the stylus glided smoothly on the tablet's surface, providing little to no resistance. Overall, drawing using the graphic tablet was enjoyable and a no-frills experience... simply press harder to make the drawing/lines darker, and vice versa. The tablet also does a good job being a mouse/cursor for a computer.When compared with a Wacom tablet, there are really only two areas that Huion could improve on. The first is the usage of a battery for the stylus. Although battery life is excellent (rated at 1 year before a replacement is needed), note that some graphic tablets don't require a battery to function (at least not one the user needs to charge/replace). A second area is would be making the eraser tip also pressure sensitive.Summery:All in all, Huion's P608N tablet is a compelling tool that is sleek in design and usability. Huion's close attention to details (quick access keys, stylus holder, grip) are evident in the day-to-day usage of this tablet. For $50, this is a bargain that's difficult to beat...Rating: 4.7/5 Stars, Outstanding(Rounded to 5/5 Stars on Amazon's Review System)

6:30 Mins Full Review:The 1byone iPhone 6 Battery case is unique because it offers a high capacity 3100mAh external battery, a wealth of color options, and customizable bumpers. 1byone did a great job retaining the slimness of the iPhone. Compared to other battery cases, this one is compact, easy to slide into pockets, and does not add too much bulk. The case contains enough juice to charge the iPhone 6 1.5 times.As aforementioned, the bumpers can be swapped out. This provides an excellent amount of customization (transparent and black colored bumpers are included in the packaging, others colors available for separate purchase). The iPhone is also easily inserted, with a two-piece (snap on) design. The back of the case features LED indicators that show the amount of juice remaining in the battery case. The case is charged via a microUSB cable, a process that takes roughly two hours to complete. When inserted, the iPhone can also be externally charged/synced using the standard microUSB. A really cool feature!Since the bottom of the case is recessed (lightning pin connects to the battery case), 1byone includes an extension cable for the 3.5mm headphone jack. This means that users will still have access to all features of the iPhone 6 when placed in the case. However, the extension cord does subtract from the sleekness of the smartphone.With the case, charging the iPhone 6's battery took 2.5 hours to finish, and extended the use time for videos, calls, and web browsing. This makes this case perfect for longer road-trips, or emergency situations. As a MFI certified case, the battery (li-polymer) prevents overcharging, and 1byone states the case won't interfere with cellular reception. During testing in Seattle, we found the reception claim to be accurate (iPhone retained 3-4 bars in connectivity).Overall, the 1byone iPhone 6 battery case comes heavily recommended for its customizable design, slim portfolio, and high-performing built-in battery. The case itself is also solidly built, and protects the iPhone against scruffs. It does exactly what it claims to to, and offers some style to boost!

3:55 Mins Aurin's 4-Port USB Hub features one major advantage over competitors: its size. With its slim portfolio, lightweight design, and bendable cord, Aurin's USB Hub is perfect for road warriors. The entire Hub easily tucks away into pockets, and is a fraction the size of most modern-day smartphones.  What's more impressive, is that the Hub draws power from a standard USB port. That means it doesn't require an AC Adapter/Brick. But don't be fooled by its small size. This is a truly capable computer accessory.For starters, Aurin's USB 3.0 Hub has a smart circuit preventing back-flow/short circuiting. The USB Hub is also plug-and-play, with no additional software needed for Mac/Windows/Android usage. Other USB 3.0 advantages also exist here, such as backwards compatibility with USB 2.0/1.1 products, and file transfer speeds up to a blazing 5Gbps. An Eco-friendly, fully-recyclable packaging is also thrown in.With all this being said, there are a few caveats. For example, in order to make the HUB so small, the USB ports are more closely spaced than I'd like. Users with wider USB products (i.e. Patriot Snowman Thumb Drive), may find it difficult to fit 4 devices into the Hub's ports simultaneously. A second point of weakness is the short cord length. This could inconvenience desktop users looking for a permanent USB Hub.During testing, we were impressed at the functionality of the Hub. When tested with several tablets, laptops, and desktops (Windows 7/8), we encountered no recognition problems. Aurin's Hub also worked fine for Hard Drives and wireless mouses we threw at it. The Hub also charged most smartphones (in addition to data syncing, of course), although it's by no means a rapid charger. For example, an iPhone took 4 hours to reach 100% capacity. A blue LED indicates when the Hub is being plugged in.In conclusion, Aurin's 4-Port USB 3.0 Hub is a compelling buy for its size and ease-of-use. In particular, we'd recommend this product to owners of ultra-portables, tablets, and laptops looking to extend the number of USB ports on their computer.Rating: 4.8/5 Stars, Outstanding(Rounded to 5/5 Stars on Amazon's Review System)

6:30 Mins The MobilePal iPhone 6 Battery case is unique because it offers a high capacity 3100mAh external battery, a wealth of color options, and customizable `bumper frames'. MobilePal did a great job retaining the slimness of the iPhone. Compared to other battery cases, this one is compact, easy to slide into pockets, and does not add too much bulk. The case contains enough juice to charge the iPhone 6 roughly 1.5 times.As aforementioned, the bumpers can be swapped out to change the scheme of the case. This provides an excellent amount of customization (transparent and black colored bumpers are included in the packaging). The iPhone is also easily inserted, with a two-piece (snap on) design. The back of the case features LED indicators that show the amount of juice remaining in the battery case, like on laptops. The case is charged via a microUSB cable, a process that takes roughly two hours to complete.Since the bottom of the case is recessed (lightning pin connects to the battery case), MobilePal includes an extension cable for the 3.5mm headphone jack. This means that users will still have access to all features of the iPhone 6 when placed in the case. However, the extension cord does subtract from the sleekness of the smartphone.With the case, charging the iPhone 6's battery took 2.5 hours to finish, and extended the use time for videos, calls, and web browsing. This makes this case perfect for longer road-trips, or emergency situations. As a MFI certified case, the battery (li-polymer) prevents overcharging, and MobilePal states the case won't interfere with cellular reception. During testing in Seattle, we found the reception claim to be accurate (iPhone retained 3-4 bars in connectivity).Overall, the MobilePal iPhone 6 battery case comes heavily recommended for its customizable design, slim portfolio, and high-performing built-in battery. The case itself is also solidly built, and protects the iPhone against scruffs. It does exactly what it claims to to, and offers some style to boost!
We use this for making home-made dishwasher detergent. The product is exactly as described and works perfectly for our needs.

We have a fair number of Lodge products, and were excited to add this to our collection. It's fantastic for roasting a chicken with root vegetables, or making a nice beef roast. Cast iron does take longer to heat up, but the flavor it adds to the food is unmatched by other cooking materials. We love this and use it regularly!

This book lays out a simple (but not necessarily easy) plan for improving your health and well-being. After just two weeks on this plan, I was sleeping better, feeling fantastic, and noticing clearer skin, looser clothes, and a happier outlook on life. Just be aware that it will take work and commitment to stick to the plan. If you aren't ready to put the time into meal planning and meal prep, then this book is not for you. But if you go into this with the attitude that changing your life is going to take some work, then this might just be the book for you.
If you like to make hummus, this tahini is wonderful - very smooth and creamy. You can also find some wonderful healthy "fudge" recipes that use tahini instead of cream.

I bought two of these for our grandsons, and then two more for grandchildren in another household. For children, these are just fine. For adults (anyone over 100lbs or so), they would probably be a bit too thin. But our grandkids all love them!

We were first introduced to this coffee by a friend who was a distributor for their multi-level marketing plan. I was extremely skeptical that an instant coffee could ever taste good. My husband and I were shocked that the flavor was EXCELLENT - absolutely no bitterness, and way easier on our digestive systems, which was the main reason I had quit drinking coffee some years ago. If you use one packet per cup, the brew is pretty dark; we split one packet between two cups, which is fine since it lowers our monthly coffee bill.
This has a slightly sweet, carmel-y flavor that works well in coffee or in smoothies. I'm not sure about all the health claims, but the taste is great!

This book was so touching. For anyone whose life has been touched by adoption, this is a must-read. For those who don't know anything about adoption, the story will definitely make you think or re-think how it affects those involved.

We use this in a 2-person office that doesn't do a ton of printing, scanning, or copying. So we didn't want a big loud monster of a machine - just something to get the job done quietly and efficiently when we do need it. This fits the bill exactly. I've owned a few Canon MF machines over the years, and this model is a good example of why I am so loyal to the brand.

I paid almost $30 for a similar item at the brand-name phone store, so I was a little skeptical that this discount version would work. It's actually lasted way longer than the expensive one, and it's must nicer than the cheap plastic screen protectors that I used to buy. We will be ordering more of these to keep around as backups when the original ones finally break down.

This is perfect for my husband who has Parkinson's Disease. He can roll this over to his recliner, put his book on it, and read for hours without having to hold the book in his shaking hands. He also puts his phone on a little standing device that sits on the right side of this computer stand, and then uses his headphones to talk to people on the phone. Again, this saves him so much frustration over the previous method of trying to hold the phone in shaking hands.
We have ordered these almonds several times from this seller, and they have always been fresh and tasty. We keep them in the freezer to make almond milk.

We bought a reboxed item, which is always a little concerning until it arrives. Sure enough, the outside box was damaged, and the instruction book was missing. However, the unit and remote work perfectly. For the amount of savings we got, I'm happy to look up directions on the Internet if needed, but so far, everything was so simple to operate that we haven't missed the instruction book at all. We are very happy with this purchase!

We needed an inexpensive but nice-looking reception desk for a small office. We chose this one because it can be set up as a right or left return, and you can also choose where to put the drawer pedestal. Please be aware that it will be delivered on a pallet to your driveway, and it is 400 pounds!! Ask your driver if he will put it inside the garage at least; ours did, for which we are so thankful, because it was raining when he delivered it.The desk arrived quickly and in good shape.Once the box was opened, my husband and son carried the pieces individually into the room where it would be set up. It took the two of them, who are both mechanically inclined, about 2 hours total to get it together. It would be hard for one person to do this, although not impossible.The finished product is exactly what we wanted, and works perfectly in the front office. This is as nice or nicer than most of the other products in this price range, and is WAY nicer than the lower-priced reception desks that we considered. Overall, we are very happy with this desk!

This arrived quickly and in good shape. For those of you who wondered about the color (since it is not listed), it is such a dark brown that it is almost black. Thankfully, that works for my particular need. I was surprised at how big this cover was. I had to do a LOT of tucking, which means that constant tucking would be required if I sat in this chair a lot. Fortunately, that won't be the case for this chair, so it's not a big deal for me, but those of you with smaller wing-back chairs who would be sitting in them often might find that annoying. Overall, I do love SureFit products and this one will work just fine for me.

I like the comfort of these shoes, but was hoping for greater arch support. For those of us with plantar fasciitis who need significant arch support, the arches in these sandals really aren't quite enough. They are about half of what you get from Orthoheel/Vionic sandals. This is too bad, since I have found that quality and durability the Orthoheel/Vionic products has really declined, and I was hoping that these would be a more reasonably-priced alternative. I still wear them, but I'm careful not to do so for long periods, as I work very hard to avoid PF flare-ups.
This salt is wonderful for making brine for home made pickles.

This type of salt was recommended in several recipes. I do appreciate that the flat flakes are better for adhering to certain baked goods (cookies, for instance). However, I don't find the taste any better than that of regular sea salt.
This was a gift for family members, and they tell me that they love being able to buy salt and peppercorns in bulk, and then grind it over their food as needed.
The information is very basic and similar to what you can find online for free.
The flavor is good, but the jerky itself is hard as a rock. I'm not kidding - you could break a tooth on this stuff!!

Kay Smith obviously has a deep and abiding walk with the Lord, and desires to share that with everyone else. All of the books I've read by her are thought-provoking, convicting, and most importantly, draw me into the presence of the Lord for sweet communion with Him.  And unlike most other books, I return to hers time and again to read a chapter here or there, and she never fails to encourage me.

First, I like the mold a lot - works well for making homemade gummy treats with grass-fed gelatin, juice, and fruit - no nasty food dyes, HFCS, etc.However, I was surprised that only one mold was in the package. Two are shown in the picture, so I assumed that two were coming in the package. Also, the price for this single mold was the same as buying a dino mold with a robot mold from another seller. I went back through the description and it's not specific that only one mold is included for this price. So while the product itself is worth 5 stars, it receives only 4 stars for the lack of clarity in the ad. Hopefully the seller will clarify this so future buyers are aware.

This fits well and is comfortable. I very much appreciate how the greater width of the back gives a smoother look (i.e., no back boobs).  I would give it five stars if the cups had some lining that would provide a little more modesty under T-shirts. This is especially needed for most larger-busted women. Also, as is common with back support bras, the straps tend to sit closer to the neck, meaning that you can't wear certain shirts without showing your bra strap on the inside of the collar. Oh well - there are trade-offs, and so far, this back support bra is the best that I've found for me.

What a great way to expand the usefulness of your mason jars into storage containers for celery sticks, homemade chicken broth, soups, stews, etc. They are way more convenient than the two-piece metal lids (plus then those can be reserved for actual canning purposes). I actually use my mason jars a lot more often now because these lids are so handy.
Like almost everything else from Bob's Red Mill, these are high quality oats - perfect for making home-made granola, oatmeal cookies, or plain ol' oatmeal for breakfast.

I home-brew both water kefir and kombucha, and I like to second-ferment it in  the GT's Kombucha bottles that I buy when I'm away from my home-brew. I bring those bottles home, take the labels off, and then frequently find myself searching for the caps (which get lost or broken pretty regularly). These replacement caps are the perfect fit for those bottles and have a much better seal than the original plastic ones.

These work very well for me. I put all of them in the dryer and just leave them there since it's just easier that way. As noted by other reviewers, they do make a bit of a banging noise when the load first starts, and more so if it's a small load. It doesn't bother me at all, but thought I'd mention it for those of you who live near a fussy apartment neighbor or landlord.As also noted by other reviewers, synthetic fabrics seem to create a lot of static when dried with these balls. I took one star off for that. However, there is zero static with a 100% cotton load, and only minor static on the synthetic items if most of the load is cotton with a few synthetic items included.I always use the auto-dry sensor setting on my dryer, not the timer, so it's pretty obvious that drying time with these balls is definitely shortened by about 10 minutes for a full load. Given that I do 5-7 loads per week, that eliminates almost an hour of drying time per week. That saves me ~4.2 hours on my monthly utility bill of the most expensive electricity use in the house besides the fridge. Thank you very much!BTW, why do most people use the timer on their dryer, instead of the auto-dry sensor setting? That makes no sense to me, as the timer either stops too soon, or else it keeps going long after the clothes are dry. In contrast, the sensor setting makes sure that you don't inadvertently leave a load of partially damp clothes in the dryer, or that you don't over-roast them and thereby shorten the useful life of your favorite threads. Plus, the sensor setting saves utility costs and lessens your time and effort to keep checking on the load. Yet I know of few people who take advantage of this energy-and-time-saving option on their dryers.Do yourself, your clothes, and your utility bill a big favor: buy some of these dryer balls, throw ALL of them in the dryer, and use the sensor setting on your dryer.

These simple, direct prayers are a great way to connect with the Lord and seek His will for your life, which includes freedom from bondage to overeating. I like that the author encourages the reader to take personal responsibility for her choices, but also acknowledges that without the power of God, we are unable to remedy the problem.I do have to admit that I read the entire book at one sitting (it's meant as a 30-day devotional). But now I enjoy pulling out this book to read a couple of prayers when I need encouragement. It never fails to help me connect and communicate with the Lord, which in the end, is what we all need.

I admit, I was pretty skeptical, but my daughter recommended these to me. Sure enough, about 20 minutes after taking them, they eliminated symptoms of seasonal allergies such as watery eyes, coughing, sneezing, and congestion. The effects weren't as dramatic as prescription meds, but we had no noticeable side effects, and the relief lasted 3-4 hours before another dose was needed.For us, those kind of results beat the heck out of prescription nose sprays and antihistamines, all of which have horrible side effects for me. Also, my husband can't take any of those things because of potentially fatal interaction with his other meds. So we were very glad to find this stuff! We also ordered some nettle leaf (one of the ingredients of this product) and hope to try that as a tea, since supposedly it works well, too. Haven't tried that yet, but will post a review on it once we have.

I was a little nervous about purchasing this since other reviewers had trouble. Also, I had one of these long ago, and it didn't work well at all. But after reading the directions online, I realized I had never used it properly, and I decided to order another one and try again.
