Sure enough, by following the directions EXACTLY, this product works perfectly for me.  Here's what I did:1. Don't overfill the container. As stated in the directions, only fill it half full, so that there is room for the air build-up that is necessary to achieve a fine spray.2. Tighten the cap that holds the spray nozzle VERY tightly. Of course, you don't want to crack the plastic, but do your best to crank the cap down very tightly. Otherwise, the pressure won't build up and you won't get a good spray.  This is where I blew it before as I didn't realize that was such an important issue.3. Pump vigorously for as many times as it takes to feel the pressure build up. For me, this is 15-20 fast pumps.4. After you spray, loosen the cap that has the sprayer nozzle so as to release all the pressure.By following these instructions, you should get a nice mist for coating that egg pan in the morning, or for the top of your bread loaves before they go into the oven. Enjoy!

I bought this knowing that the bedskirt pins wouldn't work that well on our Sleep Number bed (which has a hard plastic decking instead of box springs). So that's not really my issue. The shipping speed was fine, and the package and product were in good shape.The color does match what is shown on the screen, but in my mind, that is not taupe - it's more the color of dark brown sugar. I  would have preferred a less satiny fabric finish, although again, I knew from other reviews that this was the case.What I didn't know and couldn't see from the picture was that the bottom edges of each piece have several pleats running horizontally, from the front of the bed to the back, and across the foot piece, as well. The picture shows one straight piece of fabric, which is the clean look I was hoping to achieve. Oh well - I'm keeping it for now but thought I'd share this info in case others are considering a purchase.

I wanted to like this, as I really want to incorporate wheat juice into my diet without having to grow my own. I already have a greenhouse and garden, plus kefir water and kombucha  and a husband - I don't need one more living thing to take care of, haha!! Anyway, I thought I'd give the powder a try. The taste isn't great, but also not horrible. I do feel a good burst of energy after consuming it. What I don't like is how it doesn't mix well into anything - not warm water, not cold water, not juice. Unless I put this into a smoothie that is already whirling around in my VitaMix, the powder ends up clumping and sticking to the sides of the container. Given the price, I can't stand all that wasted powder that I can't get off the container and into my body. So, I'll finish this batch and then probably see if I can find another one that is easier to mix.

I ordered this to replace a copy that I lost while traveling. This is an incredible, Christian alternative to yoga that works the whole body and refreshes your spirit, too! For Christians who want to be above reproach and avoid the spiritual connotations of yoga that do not line up with Scripture, you can't go wrong with this workout. Even if you aren't a Christian, the work out is great, and I don't think you will find the Scripture cues offensive. I also have the Basic, Intermediate, and SloFlow workouts and love them all.If you are new to this type of body work, please give yourself time to learn the moves. Modify as needed to make the postures work for you, and go at your own pace. When I first started with the Basic DVD, I could NOT get through the whole thing, and honestly felt very discouraged. But if you keep at it, your body will learn the moves, and you WILL see results. My stance is taller, my stomach is flatter, my thighs are more toned, and my arms are definitely MUCH stronger. I really can't recommend this highly enough!

If you have trouble sleeping, give this stuff a try! Along with tart cherry juice concentrate (see my other review on that), this product has virtually eliminated my sleepless nights. My sleep trouble began when menopause hit; I'd be tired all day, and then lie awake all night just desperate to sleep but unable to turn off my racing thoughts. Ack!! Anyway, use the tart cherry juice concentrate every night, and add in a cup of the Natural Calm a couple of times per week. My sleep is most sound when I use both products, but honestly, I'm just too lazy many evenings to heat up the water for the cup of Calm, especially since I do sleep pretty well most of the time with just a good dose of the cherry juice. That being said, I must admit that my sleep IS better when I use the Natural Calm along with it.I've told a few friends about this, and some like the Natural Calm better, and others like the tart cherry juice concentrate better. So if you have trouble sleeping, I'd try both products, separately and together, to see what works best for you.

Fortunately, I bought this book for the meal planning ideas, which are helpful. However, I could never make her recipes in our house because we generally don't eat processed food. Every recipe calls for a multitude of processed ingredients, so if you prefer whole foods, that part of this book will not be helpful to you.
This book has helpful forms and ideas. It is a little repetitive at times, but great for a starting place for new meal planners.

This book would have gotten more stars bc the recipes are tasty. However, the author is either naive or careless regarding the ingredient choices. For instance, almost all fish sauce has gluten in it, and many have msg. It's a highly processed food and completely inconsistent with an "unprocessed" diet. Same goes for bacon and Italian sausage - many if not most brands contain msg, nitrates, and yes, gluten-containing ingredients. A true Paleo diet would not include these foods unless they were expressly known to come from grass-fed animals that had been processed without all those toxic ingredients.

If the title led you to believe that this book includes quickly prepared  recipes because they technically are not "cooked," you will be sorely disappointed. Almost all of them require significant time in the dehydrator, as well as lots of expensive ingredients. Plus, most of the recipes have similar free versions available everywhere on Paleo blogs. If you can get this book for free, that's fine, but I wouldn't spend money on it.

This was either translated by  translation software, or written by a non-English speaking author. The typos and transliterations are outrageous  to the point of hilarity, but thus diminish the trust in the information being shared. To the author: please have a good editor proof-read this, as it is not appropriate to use the word "incendiary" to refer to a sunburn (my best guess as to your intended meaning and only one example of consistent misuse of the English language).
Nothing in here that you can't find online, or free through a local credit counseling service. I don't think I paid for this book, but if I did, it was money down the drain.

I just wrote a very long review about how I make Kombucha in my New Wave Enviro Porcelain Water Dispenser, Black.  These bottles are an essential part of that process, and I'm so glad I finally got them! I got so tired of making a nice, bubbly batch of booch, only to have it go flat and vinegary within days after decanting.I decanting my brew into these bottles, and then do a second ferment with some juice for a few days on the counter. Now my kombucha tastes as good and is just as fizzy as store-bought stuff, without all the packing, processing, shipping, and landfill waste that accompanies store-bought products.The only thing I would change is that I would try to find 12oz bottles, since 16oz is more than I usually drink at one sitting. Yes, I can recap and put back in fridge, but like any carbonated product, it's best when first opened.

I read other reviews about broken crocks and leaking spigots, and almost didn't buy this product. Amazon had one that was used for a good discount, so I decided to give it a try. It arrived in perfect shape and on time. Per the instructions, I tightened the inside of the spigot, and then filled it with hot water to help seal the gasket. No leaks!After putting in my first batch of kombucha, I used the plastic top ring as a weight to hold down the two handkerchiefs that I use for a top filter. From the first batch of booch until now, this has worked perfectly for me! It sits in an out-of-the way corner of my kitchen counter until I need to fill it or decant it. Because it is opaque ceramic, I don't need to worry about excess light ruining the brew.Decanting is so easy with the spigot on this crock! I insert the end of funnel into one of my flip-top bottles. Turn on the spigot and fill the bottle to desired level. Repeat until there is just enough tea to keep the SCOBY floating above the spigot. That leaves enough starter tea for the next batch. If desired, use a mesh bag over your funnel to strain out the "mother" that will come through the spigot, especially as you get towards the end of your decanting process. You can also strain/decant quickly into a larger container, such as a one-gallon jar, and then decant a second time into bottles without the need for straining. Do whatever works for you and what you have around as far as materials.To make a new batch of tea, boil six cups of water. Stir in two cups of sugar until dissolved. You can also leave it on for 5-10 minutes to make a sugar syrup (I do this because I think it makes a better-tasting booch, but that's up to you). Turn off the heat and steep about five tea bags, or 2-3 T of loose-leaf organic tea in a mesh bag, for about 30 minutes. This is way less tea and a longer steep time than often recommended, but I find it a good way to economize on that expensive organic tea.When everything has cooled down to room temp, pour it into the crock. The tea level should not go past the narrow neck of the crock, since the SCOBY needs room to breath. Put on your cheesecloth or other cloth cover (I use two handkerchiefs), weight down with the plastic top ring that came with the crock, and wait for your booch to brew itself. Begin tasting after 4-5 days to make sure it doesn't go all vinegary on you.I also like to do a second decant on the counter. This requires filling the flip-top bottles just to where the neck begins to narrow. Add some pure fruit juice (POM is amazing) until there is just 1.5" of headspace left in the bottle. Put on the cap, and let bottle sit out on the counter for two days or so. The mixture will build up carbonation and get a bit sweeter, too. You may need do suction out (or pour and strain) some large blobby "mothers" that aren't bad for you but may give you the creeps if you have texture issues and accidentally ingest them (ask me how I know, haha).Best wishes for a successful batch of booch!

This SCOBY arrived on time and in great shape. It sat in the fridge for a few days (oops) until I had time to brew my kombucha tea.  I made a one-gallon batch, put it in a large crock, and added the SCOBY. Ten days later, I had some good kombucha!Since then, this SCOBY grows like crazy; it usually covers the entire top of the liquid in my 2-gallon crock. I have to trim it down at least once a month or it starts to grow out of the top of the crock! Due to the size and strength of the SCOBY, and the fact that I keep the crock next to the fridge (which generates some warmth), my brew is normally done in 5-6 days now. I make 6 quarts at a time. When combined with the two pints or so of starter tea that I leave in the crock each time, the end results are just perfect for filling 12-14 flip-top bottles.I'm really happy with this SCOBY and recommend it to anyone who wants to get started making kombucha. Also, the Amazon price for this SCOBY, along with a 2-gallon crock and some flip-top bottles, was WAAAAYYY less than those kombucha starter kits that are advertised on some websites. Do yourself a favor: make your own "kit" from Amazon and save yourself some $$$.

Unfortunately, the mesh isn't fine enough to keep the tea from floating out into the water. Since I bought this primarily to use loose-leaf organic tea leaves for making kombucha, it doesn't really work for my intended purposes. However, I have been able to repurpose it for putting bay leaves in soup or stew. I wouldn't have purchased it solely for that reason, but now that I have it, I do appreciate not having to fish around for the bay leaves and hope I got them all out.Back to tea - I ended up buying a nylon mesh nut-milk bag and use that instead for steeping the tea leaves in my kombucha tea. The bag is way larger than needed, but I use the extra to tie around the pot handle so it's easy to take the bag out when I'm done. Works very well and keeps all the leaves out of my tea.

Most of this information is available for free on the Internet. That being said, it's always nice to have books on hand so one doesn't need to be on the computer 24/7.I found that sometimes instructions were a little less than clear; a few more steps or clarifications would help. However, one really nice thing about this author is that she responds to emailed questions very quickly, and seems to be very generous with her time and knowledge.
Easy to use, easy to wash. I really like the hooks for hanging it on the edge of container so I don't have to hold it with one hand while pouring with the other.

My husband and I checked this out of our local library and stayed up past our bedtimes to see the end AND all the trailers, both of us tearing up more than once. Even if you aren't horse-crazy, this is a good movie because it is just as much about the hearts of people. We checked the movie out again when family was visiting, and they loved it, too. We rarely watch movies more than once, and we own less than ten movies altogether, so the fact that we decided to purchase this one says a lot.

Their product is always fresh when delivered, and the price is usually competitive, too. I like the smaller bags so the oats don't get stale like they tend to do while I'm working my way through the large cardboard cylinders or bags used by Quaker.

I've bought SunMaid organic raisins for years, but recently lost access to the reasonably-priced ones that I used to purchase. Because I love all of Bob's Red Mill flour products, I was sure I would love these raisins as well.Sadly, I found the taste to be far less sweet and... not quite bitter, but something I can't quite describe. I find myself eating them way less because I don't really like them. Maybe it's a matter of personal preference, and maybe others would like these, especially people who prefer things to be less sweet. However, if you are accustomed to (and like) the taste of SunMaid, you probably won't like these.

awful nutra-sweet, equal aftertaste that completely ruins the other ingredients. why is there stevia in this? I could swear every other tea company is just out to poison us. aren't we all grown up enough to decide if we want our own tea sweetened, and what with? smh..

this is an adorable mask--exactly what you see pictured. the latex is very thin and folds a little at the neck, but the face holds its shape pretty well, considering the thinness. it feels very comfortable on. the features are nicely detailed and painted, and that soft, blowy tuft of hair is just beautiful. : ) the latex smell is mild, almost like a balloon smell. also, though the mask is not as suffocating as comparable masks, you will still have some slight issues with breathing and seeing. the inside of the nose is punched and the mouth is slightly open, but that is it. you will want to at least cut the inner corners of the eyes out, so you will have windows into the world. I highly recommend this mask, and FAMI. great service and good folks, all around.

the mask shipped looks similar to the one in the photo, but it is not exactly the same. the mask shipped does not have small upper teeth. it has no teeth. the mask is a floppy, rather than stiff, latex material. the mouth buckles and the inside palate flops down over the top of the mouth and hangs down and shows, rather than staying up and holding its shape inside the mouth, and this also obstructs breathing. it is impossible to see out of, and it smells very strongly of sharply toxic chemicals (not just latex). as nice as the photo is, I do not recommend this mask.

the sweater is unusually wide and quite on the boxy side--not at all slim and long in the waist, as it looks on the model. the cut makes me think it is not designed for wear by slim or normal to long waisted gals, but rather for squat and boxy gals. the sleeves are also super long, which is very unusual, considering the length of the body (think short waist and super long arms). I may try ordering a size down and see if the  body fits closer to normal, but gauging by the cut of the sweater itself, I think it may very well be shorter, with a shorter zip, but still too wide and still oddly fitting. the knit design is very nice. I love that it is %100 cotton and I love the colors, so I may try ordering a size down. the price is about right at 9 bucks and change, but not if it is nowhere in the neighborhood of fitting a normal body, with regular length arms and a normal length waist.

we did not purchase this soup here, so no, our purchase will not be "verified." I do think that fellow shoppers would appreciate the feedback, though (as I would), so I will share that this was the most awful soup that anyone in my family had ever tried. we enjoy bean soups and veggie soups, are big fans of chickpeas and LOVE Moroccan food, so we expected to enjoy this soup. the flavor has nothing to do with Moroccan flavors, though, as it is not reminiscent of chermoula, tagine, harissa (which is what we thought it might taste like) or any other Moroccan flavors. instead, it is a tart and sour soup with no other discernible flavors. worst, it has a very thick, slimy, translucent quality to it, as it has been made with a ton of cornstarch--similar in texture to chinese egg drop soups (but without the egg). I really cannot say anything positive about this soup. the picture looks appetizing and the name makes it sound like something exotic and tasty, but it is nothing more than deceptive marketing. those who made it must know how foul it is, and that it does not resemble Moroccan cooking in any way. I thought of dumping the two containers' worth of it into a big tupperware bowl and putting it out for the stray cats (as it was not at all spicy, even), but was dissuaded by my family, who said the cats wouldn't even touch it. no, I do not recommend it.

I bought a can of the regular, a can of the vanilla, and two cans of the mocha elsewhere, but I know someone here would appreciate my feedback. the coffee is extremely, unreasonably sweet, and I had to split each can between two people and top it off with what amounted to more milk than coffee, in order for both of us to find it drinkable. I love Rohan's Marley Coffees (and I really wanted to love this product and to share it with Bob-loving friends), but I really cannot recommend it. someone at the manufacturing plant needs to actually taste the final product, or have their blood sugar tested and then have a sit-down with their Dr.

I bought one for myself and one for my mother, who was delighted with her gift (she literally can't stop looking at her mug). : ) what a pretty mug. aside from the aesthetics, I love how light and ergonomic these mugs are. there is something about the weight and shape, feel, size, and the way the fingers wrap around the handle that feels more comfortable than most mugs. the dot design along the top of the pattern makes me think of a headscarf that an old polish gypsy woman might wear, with little beads dangling from it. I now have three different designs by this company, and they all make my tea--or hot cocoa, or coffee--seem that much more special. at first I thought the mugs were slightly smaller than the mugs I was used to, but then I realized that my tea tastes so much better now (which means I have been diluting it by filling my larger, 14 oz mugs to the brim, just because I could). these mugs are so very beautiful, pleasant to hold, and have the perfect balance and light, airy weight. they are great quality stoneware with a lovely natural, unpainted ceramic on the inside, and the designs are even more beautiful in person. it might sound silly to say this, but when I first put my fingers through the handle and felt the weight of the mug, even when full of hot tea, it felt obvious to me that every other mug I have owned had been forcing me to contort my fingers in some uncomfortable and probably unnatural way--and that I just hadn't realized it before. drinking from this mug does not leave a welt on my fingers either, which I have always gotten from mugs (maybe they have all been too heavy, and the handles too narrow and placed in a weird way?). this mug is the perfect large size (meaning not TOO large) and somehow feather-light. it just seems like the stoneware is both lighter than commercially produced (and also easily breakable) ceramic mugs, and that it was specifically designed for a human hand (make sense? if not, just buy yourself one, and you'll see..). I am already shopping for the next patterns to add to my collection. : ) I highly recommend them.

we've only just started using this for our bone and joint issues (arthritis, scoliosis, bulging disks, chronic pain from sprained ankle, torn cartilage, torn meniscus, post- knee replacement, etc) and my mom and I both feel (unless it is a coincidence) that it might be helping to ease the pain and aches in the general areas we are applying it to. there is much to say about "mind over matter," though, specially for folks like us who will tend to favor traditional and natural remedies over drugs, so (scientifically speaking), we are not exactly an unbiased group conducting product experiments on ourselves. we are already better at handling pain than folks who tend to grab for pills to make it all go away. we're letting our brains and bodies do what they are supposed to do, and a big part of that is pain management and healing. that said, though, we are open minded people, and we do have a great respect for healing modalities that have a longer and much more reliable history of human use than recent modern drugs--specially drugs with santa lists full of side effects. we are going to continue using this product on our shoulders, knees, ankles, spines, necks, and wrists, and I will continue putting a dab on my cheek, where I was recently left with a bit of scarring from a runaway bug bite that developed staph (treated externally with external, alternating applications of an apple cider vinegar and baking soda paste and dabs of oregano oil, and treated internally with oregano tea made with a bulk jar of just regular, dried oregano from the spice aisle). feeling positive and keeping my fingers crossed..

I ordered this "rustic log cabin themed" oven mitt and potholder set, selecting the print with the pretty brown/tan plaid pattern checkered with wildlife scenes (a bear w a pine tree, a canoe on the water..) and I instead received a gaudy black and white set with an entirely different structure, fabric and a giant, tacky moose on both pieces--no alternating scenes, no plaid. oddly, the design I received is not even pictured as an option in this listing. the fabric was not at all linen. it was a nondescript fabric and there was some kind of wide, black pocket on the pot holder, which is not at in the product pictured. I do not recommend this product at all.

these are a freeze dried, disk-shaped snack that is the texture of dry, delicate merengues or astronaut ice cream and is a bit tart, like yogurt. we ordered one each of the banana mango and strawberry varieties, and loved the banana mango, which was milkier, less tart, and also less sweet than the strawberry (they were both good). we then reordered two packs of just the banana mango, and all of the bags were full of tiny, broken pieces and a whole lot of powdered product, which ended up in our eyes and brows. amazon credited and said it was ok to dispose of them, so we ate some of the product in the end, and found it to be extremely sour, much more so than in our previous, initial order, tasting more like lemons than like banana and mango (we ended up emptying the rest into our banana smoothies, for an interesting texture--no sense in throwing out a probiotic product because it is crushed and powdered, when there are plenty of folks paying for powdered probiotics!). from the ingredients list, it seems this batch might've received a doubled up portion of the ascorbic acid, which makes me wonder if that might have affected the integrity of the final product's texture as well. the small handful of whole pieces that could be found in each of the bags were much more flattened and delicate than in our previous batch. overall, I think this is a good product with good potential, but there does seem to be some issue with manufacturing or ingredient consistency. for your information, the product never did look like the product pictured on the bags. the image shows tiny, merengue-shaped (or hershey's kiss-shaped) morsels, but the snack has always been a flat, disk-shaped freeze dried snack, with a consistency like dry merengues or astronaut ice cream. maybe our first pack also had an issue, but it seemed ok to us as it was, as the pieces were mostly whole. we enjoyed them. we were initially surprised, though, that the snack in the bags did not look like its picture, which was definitely odd. just sharing.

serendipitously much larger than we are lead to believe, as they are sold as "toddler" hats, which they are not, really. I initially purchased one to give away and now add one or two now and then to complete my orders to qualify for free shipping, as I have found them to fit even my own large, adult woman head, which made them all the more perfect to keep a couple for our use at home and also to give away (in fact, I would dare to call them "one size fits all" hats rather than "toddler kids" hats). the fabric is cheap, which makes the 2.99 price just right, but the assembly is not bad. these are good looking disposable (or at least mourning-free, when you eventually lose them) hats for kicking around in, and I especially like them for giving away, as they are both warm & comfortable and also happy looking (and who doesn't like peace signs?). they are knit on the outside, fleece inside, and very soft and toasty. for a cold house with no heating system, they make great night caps that you can pull over your ears for added coziness. I used to carry a couple of extra clean, warm accessories that no one was using anymore in my backpack for giving away to folks when I was working in the city, specially in the wintertime. these would have been perfect. I love the beige one that I kept for myself, and my mother loves her black one (the grey one is very nice too). I've bought one of each color just to give away when I spot someone who needs a hat somewhere.

I purchased these elsewhere, but am surprised to see what they are selling for here. these mushy, stringy clams are not what I would call "prized." fresh littlenecks, which are available from our own seas and without need to purchase imported or from out of cans, are tastier, cleaner, and both sweeter and brinier tasting, with a much more delicate texture--all without the mushiness. the razor clams from this brand are better than this "prized" variety, and worth the try. they have a pleasant flavor and a very nice texture once cooked that reminds me of squid (and they are very nice out of the can as well). I do not recommend spending money on these "prized" clams, though--let alone for what they are going for. if these clams are so rare as to justify their precious price, then they would be better off left alone, I think.

inferior cereal. it used to be wonderful a couple of years ago and had a lovely crunch and a very authentic cacao taste (very different from the synthetic, chocolate candy taste of cocoa crispies) and was just a joy. we used to purchase it regularly. the quality has since dropped dramatically, while the pricing has skyrocketted to almost twice the retail price from a couple of years ago. I am not sure what these prices are based on. one box was always just over 4 bucks at WF stores, and two boxes could be purchased for 5 or 6 bucks when on sale. I have no idea what is going on with the manufacturing of this cereal that could have made it both an inferior product now and also somehow justify the added expense. I have written to erewhon twice in the past couple of years with questions about recent changes to ingredients, the different taste and texture, and also the cost of production but have received no responses. I do not recommend.

this is a wonderful tea that I simmer (1/2 tsp in a small pot) for 15-20 mins with a couple of broken up star anise for the most soothing drink for an irritated or dry throat, stomach issues, or even the occasional upset at the other end (I have gluten allergies--it happens). it is mildly, mildly sweet and has a soothing texture (not slimy, just slippery) that is such a comfort when you most need it, anywhere you might be having issue with your alimentary canal (in or out--enough said). slippery elm is the main ingredient in thayers throat lozenges, which are traditionally used by singers. I have removed a couple of stars from my review of this superb product and brand only to catch your attention--this product is consistently grossly overpriced here by amazon. you can find it elsewhere for $9 or less, and I recommend that you check out the current selling price at iHerb ; ) (in fact in Whole Foods, where it is exorbitantly overpriced, it has consistently sold for 11.99--still cheaper than through amazon). I recommend this tea highly, but not amazon as its source, unless it ever drops its price to $9 or less.

no longer fresh tasting, but leaves a slightly off, slightly rancid taste at the end. there is no change listed, but there is definitely something different about how it is being prepared, as there was with its competitors (my previous favorite being vita coco). I do not recommend.

folks, this is not a sipping tea. it is not a tea time drink for sharing or anything that you are meant to drink simply for pleasure. you really do need to use your computers to educate yourselves on what things are for--specially when it comes to food and health supplements. slippery elm is slippery--that is why it is called slippery elm. it is right on the box--it is not just an ingredient in a tea blend. you are buying a box of the powdered inner bark from a tree. before purchasing this product, you really should already be familiar with what it is and be looking to treat a specific ailment. slippery elm bark, when simmered in water, releases a mucilaginous substance that is typically used to lubricate your entire digestive tract, in and out. it is traditionally used for soothing sore throats (are you familiar with thayers throat lozenges?), digestive discomfort, and even for calming hemorrhoids. it does not have any kind of taste at all. if you want to feel like you are drinking tea, you can add something to the water you are going to simmer it in, or you can drop a tea bag in when it is done simmering, turn off the heat, cover the pot, and let it steep. personally, I simmer my slippery elm for 15 mins with a couple of broken up star anise, as the spice has benefits that I am also in need of. it makes a pretty pink brew that tastes great too. you can drink your slippery elm any way you like (in fact, you can also simmer it with a half tsp of cloves instead of the star anise for a sore throat, as cloves have a very numbing effect), if you do not like it plain. it is a great carrier for additional herbal or spice remedies. it is not slimy. it simply produces a slightly thickened water that is extremely soothing to your entire tract, on contact (if and when you need it). it is the main ingredient in a wonderful lozenge that has been around for a very long time and is used by singers for its soothing effect on the throat: Thayers Slippery Elm Lozenges, Cherry, 150 Count. if any of this sounds like what you are in need of, I highly recommend this tea to you. if not, and if you are one of those folks who confused this herbal remedy for a box of sipping tea and then came to review it as if it were a box of sipping tea, you really need to be more aware. this brand sells herbs that are meant for medicinal, therapeutic purposes and can be prepared as teas--that is all. small children are known for picking random things up and drinking them, so we need to be mindful of them. we are adults, though, and should really know to be mindful of these things for ourselves. we are none of us above errors in judgment, but I think returning to review a product unfairly even after our error has become apparent is a bit unfair, both to the brand and to other shoppers. this is a wonderful product with benefits that will be very well-received by anyone in need of them. fyi, though, a box will typically be found in-store for 11.99 or less (ie, at WF).

I purchased these sardines, as well as the regular king oscar double layer which are similar, because of the positive references to these "tiny tots" on different reviews for sardines of all kinds here, and cannot help but share that I was disappointed. I was able to try one can due to an issue with my 3 pack order but, even within the realm of us folks who enjoy canned fish, sardines in particular, it is all an acquired taste, and tastes do differ. some folks like their sardines big, some small. I tend to enjoy all varieties of a favorite thing for their own merits, but I cannot join the club in favor of these tiny tots. they are not just tiny--they are soft, mushy and flavorless. I am a fan of bela portuguese sardines, which are huge (maybe 4 sardines per can), plump, and very, very meaty. they are firm sardines that can stand up to a fork without a problem, and feel like a substantial fish meal. I like that. they also taste and smell incredible. but that is my personal preference. I gave these tiny guys a chance and I know I would have liked them just fine, had I not found them to be mushy and flavorless. I sprinkled some paprika on them and ate them anyway. they were not at all unpalatable, just not my cup of fish tea. they were tail-on and headless, and they were clean enough and packed nicely. I have no complaints. but I will not be trading in my belas for these or any other tiny sardines any time in the future. if these are the sardines you grew up with and you have some nostalgic associations with them, then these will likely always hold a special place in your heart. but if you do have an opportunity to try bela, I highly recommend you do so, specially the plain olive oil variety: Bela-Olhao Lightly Smoked Sardines in Olive Oil, 4.25 Ounce -- 12 per case you may discover something you've been missing out on, and may enjoy switching it up from time to time (hey, I gave your tiny tots a shot) ; ) two other brands that I highly recommend are sclafani: Skinless and Boneless Portuguese Sardines in Pure Olive Oil Eight Packs of 3.75 Oz Net Weight and angelo parodi: ( http://www.amazon.com/Angelo-Parodi-Portuguese-Mackerel-Fillets/dp/B001UFZETQ/ref=sr_1_3?s=grocery&ie=UTF8&qid=1429639685&sr=1-3&keywords=angelo+parodi+sardines). they are both equally delicious, and are also both bit smaller than the bela (both are 3.99 at your local italian grocer, btw). I think you will enjoy them. cheers.

I did not ultimately enjoy these kippers. : ( I had once relished TJ's smoked kippers (my favorites in texture, flavor, and smell), until I realized that they had been swimming in canola oil all along and I had not noticed. I had not found any kippers to substitute my favorites that I really felt good about until I came across these Harbor Bay kippers, which are also naturally smoked (not smoke flavored), and I liked that they are simply packed in a tiny bit of water. however, the filets are so very limp, mushy, slimy, and gritty, with chunks of...salt? to be found and crunched through randomly. the filets are also skin on and have bits of fin still on them. they are very pungently fishy, reminding me of a scandinavian delicacy that consists of fish left to ferment for months in a pail (no, I have never tried it--but the smell and flavor of these kippers certainly reminds me of what I imagined that fermented fish to taste like through my tv screen). I ate two tins with a lovely mustard from TJ's that much improved them: Trader Joes Mustard Miscellany Gift Set: Provencal; Blackcurrant; Chablis; Basil upon opening the third tin, though, these kippers began to go downhill, and I began finding stringier and slimier bits in the tins, found them to be mushier and mushier, and also found I no longer found the smell in the slightest bit novel. I gave these a chance and was very positive at first, but they did not grow on me, but rather...shrunk on me?. if you are a fan of anything I am describing, I recommend having them with a nice mustard, particular the TJ's assortment I shared, if you can find any past the holidays (it is lovely with sardines or made into salad dressings). in my opinion, though, these kippers may be up there with the best quality, most natural, and healthiest, but they do not win any prizes in taste, smell or texture. I truly wanted to love these and apologize to bar harbor for my negative review, but these are just not what I was expecting at all. : (

we have been missing our traditional sorini brand marrons glacee and marzipan panettone every holiday since williams sonoma switched bakeries a handful of years ago for an inferior product. we have tried several different brands since, and this panettone is the first one that we have been impressed with. we purchased a fiasconaro panettone with candied pineapple and pistachios for a friend, and it smelled so good through the wrapping that we returned to purchase this pear and chocolate panettone for ourselves. it was soft and moist (though neither as much as our old favorite), and the aroma was very nice, as it is flavored and scented with pear william liquor. it is dotted with raisins throughout, glazed with white chocolate and sprinkled with chocolate "b-b's," and had (and this is our only complaint) only a few tiny pieces of candied pear at the very bottom of the cake, as if they had dropped to the very bottom of the batter in the pan and stayed there. we would have loved it with more candied pear, but I still could not rate it 5 stars, after having known and loved sorini. compared to every other available brand out there, though, including williams sonoma's current holiday offering in a collector's tin (priced at twice the price of our fiasconaros), fiasconaro is the clear winner so far, and our recommendation. I cannot leave this, though, without sharing that we have purchased both our fiasconaro panettones for $25 at our local italian grocer, and have seen them offered for less from seller taylor's market (an amazon seller who we highly recommend), direct. ; )

we really enjoyed this mackerel, and found it to be the best we have had on all counts (we had previously enjoyed the conservas de cambados brand of mackerel, but have found the brand to be entirely inconsistent, and with recent batches of fish appearing rubbery, grey and tasteless). we had tried several different brands of fancy smoked and in-olive oil mackerel in between, and angelo parodi was a pleasant surprise, and exactly what we had been hoping for. the mackerel is skinless, boneless, and completely clean of any internal organs or vessels, as all other brands of mackerel have also been. angelo parodi's mackerel in particular is firm and meaty, not mushy or flaky, and the taste is something between the cleanest and highest-end tuna and chicken, of all things. it is also very juicy. the taste of the oil in the can is also like a very low-sodium chicken broth, which we enjoyed (no, there is no actual chicken flavor in the fish or its oil--they are just so entirely absent that typical fishy flavor or smell one would expect, that I can think of nothing better to compare them to). this brand is new to us, and we really appreciate that they are not heavy handed in their use of salt--there is the merest whisper of salt in the can, enough to accent but also respect the naturally clean flavor of the fish. we did not purchase these from amazon, as our local italian grocer sells the same product for $4 a can (same size), and so will only purchase here when the price is right, either as an add-on or in bulk. aside from the current pricing, I recommend this product very highly, and without reservation.

I paid 14.92 (with Free Shipping) for a pack of 4 of these cereals back in December, and ever since about January, immediately afterwards, the price was raised by more than 150% for those same 4 boxes. considered purchasing the 6 pack if the price was comarable to what I originally paid, per box, but the price has been hiked for this pack as well. How does anyone justify charging these kinds of prices for a small box of cereal, specially when it is much lower in stores? organic or no, gluten-free or no, this pricing is unusually abusive and delusional. purchase your Erewhon cereals at Whole Foods or any other natural foods market--specially during flyer specials. there is no need to encourage this kind of price hike, specially on Amazon.

I just received my order of this gorgeous wintry mug, along with Polish Pottery Mug 12 Oz. From Zaklady Ceramiczne Boleslawiec #1105-217a Classic Pattern, Capacity: 12 Oz. and am just delighted with both of them. at first I thought the mugs were slightly smaller than the mugs I was replacing, but then I realized that my tea tastes better now (which means I have been diluting it by filling my larger mugs to the brim, just because I could). these mugs are so very beautiful, pleasant to hold, and have the perfect balance and light, airy weight. they are great quality stoneware with a lovely natural, unpainted ceramic on the inside, and the designs are even more beautiful in person. it might sound silly to say this, but when I first put my fingers through the handle and felt the weight of the mug, even when full of hot tea, it felt obvious to me that every other mug I have owned had been forcing me to contort my fingers in some uncomfortable and probably unnatural way--and that I just hadn't realized it before. drinking from this mug does not leave a welt on my fingers either, which I have always gotten from mugs (maybe they have all been too heavy, and the handles too narrow and placed in a weird way?). this mug is the perfect large size (meaning not TOO large) and somehow feather-light. it just seems like the stoneware is both lighter than commercially produced (and also easily breakable) ceramic mugs, and that it was specifically designed for a human hand (make sense? if not, just buy yourself one, and you'll see..). I am already shopping for the next patterns to add to my collection. : ) I highly recommend them.

I just received my order of this mug, along with Polish Pottery Mug 12 Oz. From Zaklady Ceramiczne Boleslawiec #1105-243a Classic Pattern, Capacity: 12 Oz. and am just delighted with both of them (this particular one, with its lovely geometric pattern, reminds me of a favorite sweater, and somehow makes my tea--or hot cocoa, or coffee--seem that much more special). at first I thought the mugs were slightly smaller than the mugs I was replacing, but then I realized that my tea tastes better now (which means I have been diluting it by filling my larger mugs to the brim, just because I could). these mugs are so very beautiful, pleasant to hold, and have the perfect balance and light, airy weight. they are great quality stoneware with a lovely natural, unpainted ceramic on the inside, and the designs are even more beautiful in person. it might sound silly to say this, but when I first put my fingers through the handle and felt the weight of the mug, even when full of hot tea, it felt obvious to me that every other mug I have owned had been forcing me to contort my fingers in some uncomfortable and probably unnatural way--and that I just hadn't realized it before. drinking from this mug does not leave a welt on my fingers either, which I have always gotten from mugs (maybe they have all been too heavy, and the handles too narrow and placed in a weird way?). this mug is the perfect large size (meaning not TOO large) and somehow feather-light. it just seems like the stoneware is both lighter than commercially produced (and also easily breakable) ceramic mugs, and that it was specifically designed for a human hand (make sense? if not, just buy yourself one, and you'll see..). I am already shopping for the next patterns to add to my collection. : ) I highly recommend them.

I LOVE toasted hemp seeds, and I LOVE chocolate, but I did not enjoy this product. I tend to be unable to set chocolate aside for more than a minute. this bag arrived several days ago, I had about a teaspoon's worth of it and put it in the fridge (it arrived fine), and I have yet to feel the urge to have any more. I just did not find the hemp and the chocolate to be compatible textures or flavors, and the chocolate glaze being subpar does not improve on the idea at all (it is that very kind that you have to chew and swirl around your mouth for too long a time before you realize that it is waxy and not at all dissolving, like real chocolate would). the chocolate is also very sweet. the hemp seeds as well are not ideal, and I found them not to have the crunch that toasted hemp seeds alone usually have (to be fair, I am not implying that they were not fresh--coating them with this waxy chocolate glaze probably imparted some unwanted moisture to them). food products that are at first unexpected to me will always grow on me if they have redeeming qualities. I just am not finding this to be the case with this product. I recommend trying the chocolate coated, cacao dusted goji berries from the same brand, and also some toasted hemseeds from Hempzels or any low-salt brand. but I cannot recommend these chocolate coated hemp seeds.

I received one of these flashlights today, turned it on, saw the different light configurations, and loved it. I tried to show it off to someone a bit later on, and the light would not stay on once I removed my finger from the ON button. a while later, while waiting to connect to a Help Chat rep, I turned it on and it stayed on, I clicked through the three light settings to turn it OFF, then clicked one last time to turn it back on and the light would not stay on, but would flash on and immediately off. This looks like a good light and feels light and comfortable to hold, but apparently there are some defects. catching Amazon Customer Service on a bad or off night was not a positive ending to a bad experience either, regardless of my eventual refund, which I am expecting to see in the next couple of days. Amazon really needs to supervise its reps, specially those that work during the Help Chat night shifts, because there is a lot of insensitivity towards customers and occasional mocking and disrespectful behavior like putting a customer on hold and not ever returning, so a customer might wait 20 minutes before realizing they were being had, or having fun at a customer's expense by hearing them ask for help regarding one item or issue and replying regarding a completely different item or order, over and over, while the customer is correcting them, just for fun. I do not know if Amazon does not take care of its employees and they sometimes retaliate against their customers, but something is amiss at Customer Service.

the nuts were all stale. the expiration date on the bottom of the bag was well off, which makes me think that either the manufacturer sourced some already stale nuts for its mix, or Amazon might not have its act together as far as temperature and storage for its raw and organic food products. either way, I am going to give it a bit of time and then re-order, as the mix itself is, I think, the best I have had. perfect combination of fruits and nuts, and the flavor combination was delightful, aside from the stale nuts. it is currently on sale and I thought of purchasing a couple more bags, but now that I think about it, Amazon might indeed be refreshing its stock, so I think I will wait until the price goes back up again and cross my fingers that I receive a new batch. by the time you read this, I think you should be fine, and I highly recommend this product. just give Amazon some honest feedback on those nuts if they seem off (or, better yet, the manufacturer?). cheers.

I am a huge fan of Living Intentions Superfood Cereals, and so is my family. We love the Hemp & Greens as a morning cereal with bananas and milk, and also as a dry treat, straight out of the bag. As a really special treat, we also enjoy the Cacao Crunch and Acai Blueberry (though these two are more difficult to stop snacking on). We were really looking forward to trying Chia Ginger, being lovers of both ginger and chia seeds. We were shocked at how awful this variety was, though, finding that it tasted as if some kind of soap or cleaner had gotten into the mix. I looked at every ingredient on that bag and nothing would explain the flavor. Chemical or botanical-based, there is a very strong soapy flavor in this bag. It may have just been the one batch, but I would not repeat and definitely not recommend Chia Ginger. If you are thinking of trying this cereal, I highly recommend Hemp & Greens, Cacao Crunch, and Acai Blueberry, without reservations.

"Natural Honey Flavor, Natural Lavender Flavor, Natural Vanilla Flavor.." that is a whole lot of "flavors"--what are the actual ingredients? Petrol-based flavorings are often snuck in as "natural flavors" under warped FDA loopholes designed to support the industry. Not to mention that many things that you or I would not put in our mouths, however "natural" they might truly be, are often used in place of costlier, authentic ingredients, with the FDA's full blessing. And even when a legitimately natural and truly food-based ingredient with a similar flavor profile is used as a substitute (as in the case of lemon myrtle for lemon), folks have a right to know what is in their food regardless of a manufacturer's proprietary concerns. Along with Yogi's unhealthy choice in tea bags and its sudden obsession with adding stevia to most of the teas in its line (aside from the manufacturing process of powdered, white stevia being about as bad as any of those commercial artificial sweeteners, doesn't Yogi think its customers have a right to decide whether to sweeten their teas or not, and what with?), now we see "flavors" on all of their teas, as opposed to a genuine ingredients list. I don't know what changes have been made at Yogi at a corporate level, but it is just not the same company any more, with anywhere near the same ethics. Some of their teas are better than others, but this is not one of them. Always take a look at that ingredients panel if it is pictured here. If it is not, then purchase from a store where you can pick it up and look at it. I definitely do not recommend this one tea. All my ingredient concerns aside, it isn't just aromatic--it actually tastes like body lotion or soap and leaves an itchy feeling behind in the throat (and, for reference, I enjoy lavender honey, violet "mints," rose tea and preserves, and all of these floral flavors and scents in marshmallows).

what starts out as a possible disaster movie with a very relatable setting and characters (ie, what might transpire if a disaster--natural or man-made--were to suddenly occur in the middle of your work day) suddenly begins to show seams of otherworldly "happenings," along the lines of the interwoven stories in "Lost." coincidences begin to take on a very designed feeling, and shadows and objects begin to catch your eye...this is one bizarre and creepy show with symbolism that points more to the occult than to anything else. if Lost's mythology can be said to have been handled with a bit of suspense and subtlety, in contrast I think The After is slated to take a very dark and punishing approach to its eventual destination. to those who like their stories creepy and ominous, this series will likely fulfill that dark cup of tea. beware, though, it may also fuel the fires of certain kinds of cultural fearmongering and their subsequently diminished, fundamentalist mentalities. watch with an educated mind, though, and be entertained.

it kind of defeats the purpose to stock up on tuna because you are on a budget if your taste also leans towards the pricey kind, but this tuna is definitely worth it. I enjoy it as is, from the can and into a bowl, oil and all, with some Le Pain des Fleurs Crispbread, Quinoa, 4.4 Ounce or Orgran Toasted Buckwheat Crispibread Gluten Free -- 4.4 oz. when feeling in the mood for a tuna sandwich, though, I will lightly soak two slices of a nice rustic bread in olive oil and put them in the toaster while I fix my tuna with a big handful of chopped parsley and red onions, and then add a bit of a favorite spice blend, like Teeny Tiny Spice Co. of Vermont Organic British Curry, Flavor of the Empire, Medium, 2.8 Oz. when my bread has achieved the perfect crunchy toast, I assemble the best tuna sandwich, with or without some baby greens and tomatoes, that you will find anywhere. for comfort food that will blow the lid off of any fancy restaurant or hotel sandwich, this tuna is very difficult to beat. a pack of 12 is gone in my house in no time. I highly recommend this product and would happily give it more than 5 stars if I could. order some with confidence, specially from seller Taylor's Market--good, honest folks there, and great customer service.

this caramel was a very nice treat. it has a lovely, liquidy texture (I assume because it is made with goat milk rather than cream) and has an amazingly rich, creamy, buttery caramel taste. it is not at all gamey or "goaty," and is just perfect for folks with lactose issues and who cannot enjoy conventional dairy products. it is a little sweeter than I would have liked, and I think that maybe Fat Toad Farm overcompensated a bit much for the natural saltiness of the goat milk with the extra sugar (and I actually think the slight saltiness of the goat milk, if allowed to shine through, would have been a very nice and special touch, something like gourmet caramels topped with fleur de sel). I have to say, though, that I really did not make the mental connection I should have, for how tiny this little jar would be (that picture above is fiSHEye mAGNIFied, my friend). this jar is literally the same jar used by manufacturers of eye cream (yes--it is that small), and two fairies could have flown away with this itty bitty jar between the two of them without straining a single teeny tiny fairy muscle. I tend to go for the smaller size of a thing, specially when that smaller size is on offer here, until I know I love it enough to order a larger portion or even a bulk order. In this case, though, I am kicking myself for not holding out for a friendlier price (or at least Free Shipping) for the very largest--but actually just closer to normal sized--jar. I will not make that mistake in my next order. I am keeping an eye out for Amazon Free Shipping offers of one or even two full-sized jars together--hopefully a variety pack of this same Original plus one of their more exotic flavors (like Bourbon, which sounds like something a lover of vanilla would enjoy). : ) If you ever spot that, grab it without hesitation.

I am really enjoying this tea, which I have purchased from Amazon many times now. I can see why it is called "honeybush," as the taste and aroma truly do resemble honey. It has a mellow, natural sweetness to it that really does not need sweetening, and a very mild, easy taste that reminds me of chamomile tea, in that it has a soft, understated character with no bitter note or aftertaste, and a bit of a woodsy note. I have never added milk to this tea, but I may try it and see what it does. I love it straight, and have even enjoyed the random mug I have accidentally allowed to cool down too much. I have been able to have it either in the early morning, midday, with meals, between meals, on an empty stomach, or very late at night--all with no issues. The taste is honey-like and light, with the tiniest hint of mesquite when freshly poured. If it sits for a considerable amount of time, it develops an additional note that reminds me of fig leaves. This is a completely caffeine free tea that is even given to tiny children and to people taking meds, as it does not interact adversely with anything or have any known adverse effects to the health. I have heard it is great for the skin, and perhaps it is all true, from what I have noticed. I would call this a nourishing tea. If it has any calming effects, they are probably all cerebral, and it may just be due to how pleasant and easy it is to drink, and how relaxing pleasant things usually are. If you are looking for a mellow and pleasant cup of tea that is smooth and easy without being harsh on the stomach or nerves or, alternately, putting you to sleep, I recommend giving this honeybush tea a try.

These chocolates have a very thin dark chocolate shell and inner milk chocolate shell surrounding a ball of both almond and pistachio marzipan with a tiny hazelnut chocolate center which has a touch of liquor in it. They are pretty sweet but good, and the chocolate is high quality. I did not realize, though, there was more than one company out there making Mozart Kugel chocolates. I enjoyed them, but they were not the chocolates I remember having and which I thought I was ordering, of the same Mozart theme. The ones I remember had a decadent, thicker, deeply dark chocolate and thinner milk chocolate shell. I remember being floored by the flavor and aroma of the almond and pistachio marzipan layers, which I somehow also remember being a little bit warm and heady, as if there might have been a touch of stronger brandy or some other liquor in them (or maybe it was in the hazelnut center?). Also, I think the chocolate hazelnut center was a larger part of the center. My memory is a bit hazy because it has been a while since I last indulged in these chocolates, but I do remember them being a little bit warmer (though not overly boozy) and with a more pronounced, almost amaretto-like marzipan taste and richer dark chocolate. Maybe my taste buds have aged and lost their tolerance for sweet notes, but, although these chocolates were not at all bad, I did find them to have a sweeter and maybe slightly commercial flavor to them (does that make any sense?), and I also found them less aromatic, overall. I did enjoy them and do recommend them, but am basically sharing my more detailed input in case another shopper out there can maybe help jar my memory to the right direction, and maybe the right Mozart kugels.

Like spicy, warm, exotically fruity molasses, leaning more towards a honeylike base flavor than a fruit preserve fruitiness. Not tart, but rather rootsy, botanical and warming. I had tried one other organic chyawanprash, from Organic India, and had reviewed that one as having a tougher texture but also a higher quantity of medicinal roots, fruits, herbs, and botanicals, and also had originally found it less sweet, and so had preferred it. I purchased about a dozen jars direct from Organic India after first ordering here, but as I worked my way through the first couple of jars, I found the texture in each progressive jar becoming tougher and tougher to work out (apparently, they dry rather quickly), until I finally unsealed a fresh jar to find a solid mass my spoon could not push or break through. I recently placed another order with Banyan Botanicals and included a few jars of their chyavanprash, and was very pleased, again, to find its consistency so spreadable and easy. I just finished one jar of this chyavanprash and will have to get back to my Organic India stock and do my best with those jars, but I wanted to come back and share my reconsidered review. These are still my two favorite chyawanprashes (sp?), but I now feel that Banyan is probably the better of the two. It does contain fewer botanicals, but that may even be by design (how many of those things can possibly be compatible all at once to our human system? after all, these ingredients are all potent!). I also had originally thought it was much sweeter than the Organic India chyawanprash, but, on second thought, I may have had that other chyawanprash after eating a piece of fruit or something, because I find them almost equal in sweetness now. If you are interested in trying both, please do. If you get a fresh jar of Organic India chyawanprash, it will be a nice treat too. If you are only looking for one, though, maybe Banyan Botanicals would be your best bet. The product is more consistent and smooth in texture, there is nothing grainy or gritty in it, it is delicious, and it is easy to spoon out from the jar. After one jar, I am sure you will return for more. Please contact your seller and request care in shipping, though, as these jars are glass and fragile, and can break in transit (it happened to me once). Enjoy!

I received two of this product in error, as I had ordered one bag of these "Nougat" twists, and one bag of the "Classic," pistachio marzipan and hazelnut nougat twists (one from a seller, and the other from Amazon stock). I enjoy marzipan, and so was looking forward to the one bag I did not receive, and ultimately did not enjoy this other chocolate very much at all. I found the chocolate itself cloyingly sweet, with the sugar level overpowering any flavors in the filling, which was a disappointment, specially since I now had two bags of the product. They were also very tiny, oval chocolate eggs, the kind you see around Easter (but tinier), which is not what I expected, from looking at the picture (the chocolates in the photo reminded me of those Toffifay caramel cups, and so I thought these chocolates would be either cups or maybe actual chocolate balls and that the picture was intended as an inside view of the filling). I gave both bags as a treat to a senior center and then regretted it, realizing there are probably a few diabetic folks over there. They are teeny tiny chocolates, though, so I am sure they were fine despite my lapse in judgement. Also, I heard everyone enjoyed them.

think you're about to eat healthy? think again. these veggie chips are saturated in canola and palm oil. you are better off dehydrating your own chips, or just looking around. there are veggie chips out there with just a touch of light olive or sunflower oil. The next time I shop for these, I will tell you what brands to look for. take care of your health.

These Chocolate Ghost Chile Salted Caramels are made with corn syrup. Theo should know better. Honey would have been the smarter choice, or agave. Even straight sugar would have been better for consumers' health than corn syrup. Caramels are traditional made with three ingredients: sugar, butter, and cream. Not sure why Theo thought corn syrup would be an improvement. Very disappointed.

We LOVE these chocolates at home, and so does everyone who we have ever shared them with (and they are often described back to us years later by folks wanting to know where they might find them). The chocolate is high content, high quality, deep, dark chocolate (the kind that actually melts in your body-temp fingertips) that is rounded in character and not bitter, the marzipan has a very recognizable almond taste and aroma and a great, naturally chewy texture, the plum marmalade is delightful, and the madeira is incredibly warm and heady. This is the perfect chocolate for mature palates that enjoy their chocolate deeply dark and not overly sweet (they are still sweet, mind you, but short of becoming cloying), and who enjoy a touch of liquor in their desserts, but not anything overly boozy. I have tried the apricots in brandy as well and they are very good, but these plums in madeira are the very best of the Anthon Berg fruits in liquor, I think. I would love Amazon to offer mixed boxes at the same price (a box of plum and a box of apricot, for example, or all four, including cherry and grape, which I have not yet tried), as I have been wanting to share around the other flavors as well. These being our favorites, though, I have not been able to bring myself to ordering two whole boxes at a time of any other variety except plum (and this offer of two boxes for 24.99 is the reason I opted to purchase these here, through Amazon. If you look very hard, it is possible to find them elsewhere for less, but they have always been hard to find, like any good thing). They come in generously sized, individually wrapped, single-serving pieces, and are so very easy to share with a special friend or loved one. If you have not tried these chocolates yet and are reading our reviews, you should dive in and order the two boxes of this plum in madeira variety. You may find it difficult to give that second box away once you try one. They are truly exquisite.

I purchased the three varieties of Iceland seaweed available here: Kelp, Dulse, and Wakame. I have yet to try the Kelp (I purchased it for use in beans and for dashi broth) and found the Dulse extremely salty (compared to the Maine Coast Dulse that I also purchased, and which was more minerally-sweet than salty), but I really enjoyed the Wakame. I have yet to cook with this Wakame like a serious adult. I did, however, pan toast a few strips in a bit of olive oil (gnawing on a raw piece was very difficult, as it felt more like a chew toy than like something that would eventually biodegrade). This made a fantastic snack that was incredibly crunchy and flavorful, with no need for salting. I have not tried soaking this Wakame yet (or the Dulse, for that matter). Until I figure out how else to best use this Wakame (salads? soups? beans?), I highly recommend it for toasting, as a snack (specially when the price bounces back down to $7.00 or lower for this 1.76 ounce bag) ; )

$45.33 plus shipping for an item that doesn't cost much more than $15.00 anywhere else, and there is a second listing for $86.99 plus shipping for the same single unit item? Prices like these always make me wonder if folks are moving around a little more than what their product pages reflect, right here on Amazon. This product is only worth its normal $15.00 (plus or minus a buck or two) price. This product may benefit your bones, hair, nails, and connective tissue, but overpricing it benefits no one.

This is an interesting addition to your Gardena watering system, but one that I'm not sure you really need if you already own something like their multifunction sprayer. The thing is, unless you want to use a nozzle instead of a spray gun, there really isn't much difference between using the multifunction sprayer on the fine spray setting. Just like the spray gun, you can vary the intensity/throughput (rotate the orange part of this nozzle, vs. the knob at the back of the spray guns), but there is no changing the pattern.Additionally, and this I am not too thrilled with, when you first open the sprayer, that's when you get the most intense spray. You have to then dial it down from there. It works similar to their "classic" nozzle in this regard. Takes some getting used to, for sure. Another drawback vs. the spray gun is that while you have an on/off on the gun without changing intensity settings, there is no means to do that here. As with the "classic nozzle", to stop the flow of water, you need to close off the valve and completely shut it off. That can be a bummer if you're going between nearby plantings, since you'll spend a lot more time re-opening and adjusting the spray intensity downward each time you need to re-start the flow of water.Does it work? Yes. Does it do anything special or particularly better than the spray gun? Not really, quite the opposite actually. On the other hand, if you want the control mechanism of a nozzle, but with the fine spray output instead of a stream, this will do the job. The question is why you would choose to use this over a spray gun in any circumstance? If you don't have a spray gun with this type of pattern, this is a better option than spending the money for another sprayer, but most people have a spray gun that has this pattern (or something close to it) already.So there you have it. If you don't already have a watering implement that covers this type of pattern, this would be a good addition to fill the gap, but I don't think it's necessarily worth adding if you already have a multifunction sprayer. There may be instances where the form factor is more suited, or issues of personal preference, but on balance, it's a niche watering tool that most people already have covered with their multifunction sprayers.

Top quality, made-in-Germany adapter for your garden hoses, to be used with the Gardena system. Typical set up is to screw one of these on the female end of your garden hose and then slap a model 39004-G onto the hose bib and couple the two together. This is nice, except that if you want to connect two hoses together, you then need a double sided male adapter, which is not sold (to my knowledge) in a metal configuration (and I wouldn't trust a plastic one). If you need one, you can make one by combining this 39004-G with a 39022-G to get a double-sided metal version, but that's an expensive setup.In my case, I prefer to use a 39018 screwed onto the (male) hose bib connection, a 39022-G screwed into the female end of the hose and another 39018 on the other (male) end of the hose. In either setup, you invest in 3 pieces of the Gardena system in order to be able to quick-disconnect your hoses at both ends, but if you go with the latter, you can connect two hoses in series without ever needing an adapter. Furthermore, if you remove your hose from the hose bib to store it, you won't leave your 39004-G out in the open with its rubber seal rotting in the elements. The only downside is that if you have a 39018 on the hose bib, the water-stop features means you can't use the hose bib without a hose or other connector inserted into it. For dedicated outside gardening/watering hose bibs, I don't know the last time I wanted to use it without a hose connector, so this is a non-issue for me, but your measurements might vary.An alternative to mitigate the water-stop on the hose bib side, albeit more expensive, would be to get a double sided female adapter and connect this 39017 directly to your hose bib with that, rather than using a 39018. This way you get the benefit of not needing an adapter to connect hoses in series, AND you can flow water out of the spigot/hose bib freely when you disconnect the hose (via the 39022-G).All that said, I did purchase one of these 39017's just in case I needed it or wanted to change configurations, or if I needed to build an adapter of some kind. These are top quality, German-made components and miles beyond the Melnor, Gilmour and other imported China junk you can find at the stores these days. I'd been a Luddite for years, avoiding a quick disconnect system, because of quality issues with the components. Gardena has been a welcome change and I'll gladly pay the premium for their authentic, German parts.

Top quality, made-in-Germany adapter for your hose bib (or garden hose) to be used with the Gardena system. Typical set up is to screw one of these on tot he hose bib instead of the hose, and then slap a model 39017 quick disconnect onto the female end of your garden hose and couple the two together. This is nice, except that if you want to connect two hoses together, you then need a double sided version of this tool, which is not sold (to my knowledge) in a metal configuration. If you need one, you can make one by combining this 39004-G with a 39022-G to get a double-sided metal version, but that's an expensive setup.In my case, I prefer to use a 39018 screwed onto the (male) hose bib connection, a 39022-G screwed into the female end of the hose and another 39018 on the other (male) end of the hose. In either setup, you invest in 3 pieces of the Gardena system in order to be able to quick-disconnect your hoses at both ends, but if you go with the latter, you can connect two hoses in series without ever needing an adapter. Furthermore, if you remove your hose from the hose bib to store it, you won't leave your 39004-G out in the open with its rubber seal rotting in the elements. The only downside is that if you have a 39018 on the hose bib, the water-stop features means you can't use the hose bib without a hose or other connector inserted into it. For dedicated outside gardening/watering hose bibs, I don't know the last time I wanted to use it without a hose connector, so this is a non-issue for me, but your measurements might vary.All that said, I did purchase one of these 39004-G just in case I needed it or wanted to change configurations, or if I needed to build an adapter. These are top quality, German-made components and miles beyond the Melnor, Gilmour and other imported China junk you can find at the stores these days. I'd been a Luddite for years, avoiding a quick disconnect system, because of quality issues with the components. Gardena has been a welcome change and I'll gladly pay the premium for their authentic, German parts.

I've become an avid fan of the Gardena system since trying out one of their spray guns and some of the quick disconnects. I don't usually use a spray nozzle like this model, but for some tasks, it really is better than anything else, so I decided to pick this up and give it a try. Why not have one more quick-disconnect accessory to play around with, after all?I was pleasantly surprised to find that this actually does the job extremely well, in fact better than some of the brass nozzles I have used in the past. You get a lot of power on the jet/pinpoint stream setting, in fact more power and narrower stream than you can achieve with, say, their trigger-style, 3-in-1 sprayer on the same stream setting. This makes it excellent for things like cleaning/pressure washing. The wider fan settings are also good, giving you an easy way to handle most watering tasks if you don't have a spray gun around. You also get pretty easy one-handed operation, unless you have unusually large/small hands. I saw reviewers state that it was an issue to adjust without using both hands, but I did not encounter that problem at all. And, in case anyone is wondering, yes, you can shut the sprayer completely off/closed by turning it all the way. Works perfectly and no leaks.As others have noted, the mechanism in this nozzle has one peculiarity, in that if you shut off the water and turn it back on, you get the jet/pinpoint stream setting again, regardless of where the nozzle is set (say a wide, fan setting). I was not able reproduce this by simple snagging the hose, as some suggested, but if you completely cut off the flow, it can happen. What you need to do is then turn/twist the sprayer completely off, then re-open / twist back to your desired setting. It's a little annoying, yes, but honestly I don't know how much of an issue it really is. Are you going to snag the hose in the middle of watering something? Probably not. Are you going to have the sprayer running while walking around and when the hose might actually have a chance of getting snagged? Probably not. Even if you snag the hose, will it be bad enough to completely cut the pressure off and cause this hiccup issue? Probably not, especially with pressure in the hose.Bottom line, I watered my whole backyard with this thing today, including moving around, purposely snagging the hose, purposely trying to bend it and cause this issue, and I wasn't able to do it. The only thing that worked was shutting it off at the hose bib/spigot and turning it back on. My humble opinion, but the few reviews that harp on this seem to be making a mountain out of a mole hill, and downplaying the really good features of this nozzle. It's well made (in Germany!), has a very nice grip, is easy to operate with one hand and gives you all the patterns you could possibly want for in a nozzle of this type. Output is very narrow and powerful on the stream setting and works superbly for cleaning and blasting away dirt on pavement/sidewalks/etc.A nozzle like this has its place and if you use the Gardena system of quick disconnects, you really shouldn't be without one of these. Well made and well functioning, I'd highly recommend it to anyone. Much preferred over any brass model I've used before and any of the plastic import junk at the stores.

Another nice pair of underwear from the "gigolo" line, this time in an aqua color. As with the orange mesh underwear they released last fall, this pair is a bit more concealing than, say, the white or black see-through kind. No, nothing is left to the imagination, but details are still obscured for some minimal amount of modesty, I suppose.Fit and finish wise, these are as good as any other AC offering. The waistband is nice, comfortable and a step up from the regular style (about twice as tell, if not more). Piping on the leg openings is nice and adds some contrast, while also snugging everything up. Plenty of room in the pouch on these as well, so everything sits right where it should.If you're into the "gigolo" line, these are definitely another nice pair to have. As I have said before, in this line, you really do feel 'almost naked' while wearing them, in addition to looking as such. Recommended.

If you already have the Gardena 7-in-1 spray gun of the same style, you can definitely benefit from adding this particular 3-in-1, fully adjustable model to your lineup. The description on Amazon is misleading (although the item name and model # are correct), so I'll elaborate a bit on how this one differs from the 7-in-1 model.First, while you can somewhat replicate 2 out of the 3 modes this 3-in-1 model gives you with the other 7-in-1 sprayer, you have to realize that those are the 3 specific points along an infinitely variable spectrum, hence the "fully adjustable" part of this item's name. To put it another way, if you adjust the nozzle end of this 3-in-1 sprayer all the way to the left, you get a fine mist. This is not doable with the 7-in-1 spray gun. As you adjust from left to right, at the mid point, there is a mark with a wide spray pattern. This is approximately the same as one of the modes available on the 7-in-1 spray gun. If you turn/adjust furthest to the right, you get a narrow jet stream, again demarcated on the tip and another pattern you can get with the 7-in-1 gun.Where's the difference then, you ask? All the in-between for those 3 specific patterns! You can adjust this spray gun much like the familiar brass spray nozzles, it just so happens that along that spectrum, you can approximate some of the fixed patterns on the 7-in-1 sprayer. In a nutshell, this gives you the flexibility of a brass spray nozzle, but in the venerable Gardena trigger-operated sprayer form factor. You can control the flow at the back, you get on/off flexibility and auto-locking on/off as well.
