The advantage here is that, unlike a brass nozzle, if you have a setting you like, you can leave it there and still cut off the water flow, whereas on a brass nozzle you'd have to either shut it off at the hose bib or turn the nozzle all the way off, losing the spray pattern.Definitely a nice addition to your Gardena arsenal and something I highly recommend if you like their 7-in-1 sprayer of the same style. Both have their places and there's very little redundancy to having the pair as opposed to only one or the other. A bit pricey, but it includes a two year warranty and has German engineered, German built quality behind it. No leaks, no fuss, no muss and better features and ergonomics than anything else I've used. I won't go back to a brass nozzle.

Took a chance on one of these from another retailer, before it became available on Amazon, but I felt compelled to write a review on here and share my enthusiasm for this pencil. I've used a lot of nice, higher end mechanical pencils, such as the Kuru Toga high grade lines and some of the Platinum OLEenu stuff, all of which have their own innovations to either hold the lead, rotate the lead, absorb shock, and so forth, and this pencil is right up there with them.What makes this one special, however, is that you get a couple features in one. First, there are two sets of stabilizing springs, separate from the standard spring when you advance the lead. One spring absorbs direct up/down shock, another is there to buffer the side to side load on the load by way of the floating tip. It's definitely cool to see the multiple springs there, and watch them in action, and they do work beautifully. It's no panacea for habitual lead breakers, but it does definitely cut down on it for most users. With other pencils, you probably break lead despite your best efforts, now and then, but with this one, you will notice readily that it happens very rarely.The other nice thing is that the entire pencil is very well made (in Japan) and looks stunning. The lead advancement has a very short throw, so you don't have to click it too far. Some people take issue with this, but for me, it kind of feels more finessed and easier to control, so I don't mind it at all. Also sounds more muted when you click it to advance the lead, not loud like some other mechanical pencils. Again, this gets to what I said about finessed and refined. All around, this thing oozes good design blended with eye-catching style.For anyone that's interested in high quality mechanical pencils with some advanced features, this is definitely a keeper. I purchased two, just to have a spare on hand, and have not been able to use anything else since I got it. It seems like in this market, there's always something new and exciting coming out, so who knows what's next, but as of this review, it is my favorite and my go-to pencil. Highly recommended!

This is a nice product, a good quality wing weeder that works as advertised. The metal is 12-gauge, not 7-gauge, as some have asked. Apparently Amazon has the right description in the detail section, but the title is incorrect. Still, fairly heavy duty for its intended purpose and it does work well. It's not a sharpened tool, so you might have to do that yourself, but depending on the medium you use it in, that probably won't be necessary. In my case, I have small 1/2" to 1" rock that I need to get into and weed between, and this tool will take the abuse that my hula hoe wouldn't be able to.If I have one gripe, it would probably be the angle of the head. Perhaps personal preference, but I would like it a bit wider than it is. As it stands, I feel like you have to bend over way too much to get the angle you need on the weeding head, especially when using a pulling motion, or edging along a line. The handle would be better if it were angled up more, so you don't have to stoop quite so much to get behind it and push/pull. Still, it's not a huge issue, but one I'll deduct a star for.Otherwise, build quality is excellent. You get the standard, albeit heavy duty fiberglass handle that Bully is known for, as well as pretty decent length and a very stout connection to the weeding head itself. Weld quality is very good, much better than the crap in the big box stores. I don't see how a human being could ever break this thing, so it will probably last a lifetime and the head will surely outlast the handle.Overall a nice addition to your weeding arsenal. Not the end all / be all, of course, but for situations where you want to weed in rough terrain or do close cuts against a border/wall/etc., I think this would be a superb choice.

Awesome adapter for use with the Gardena system, superb quality and built like a tank. These things are weighty, properly coated to resist rust and have a very nice set of flutes cut into them to make it easy to tighten by hand, even when wet/slippery (or wearing gardening gloves). They are also fully interchangeable with their plastic counterparts, so you can mix and match without having to replace an entire system at once.As I pointed out in another review for the 39018 connector, I purchased one of these and two of the 39018 connectors, and was able to rig up a complete system for my backyard needs. Slap the 39022-G (this item) on the female end of your hose, then one 39018 on the male and a econd 39018 to your hose bib and voila! You can now quick disconnect your watering implements (e.g. sprayers, sprinklers, etc.) from the end of the hose AND you can quick disconnect the entire hose from the hose bib at will. For those that might want to store their hose indoors or be able to quickly remove it to make it easier to untangle or coil up, this will save you tons of time. Being able to swivel it on both ends will also make it easier to deal with snags/kinks. Because the connection the hose bib is entirely metal parts, you don't have to worry about stress from pulling on the hose either, since these connectors and adapters are considerably overbuilt and heavy duty.I could not be happier, and I am re-ordering another set to do the same setup with the hose in my front yard. Absolutely fantastic product, light years ahead of the import junk and other garbage out there. Highly recommended.

I've wanted to switch to some kind of quick disconnect system over the years, having seen a plot of professional/commercial applications in nurseries and the like (and tiring of the battle to spin accessories on/off hoses over the years), but up until now, nothing had been satisfactory. The few I tried, whether metal or plastic, were always just absolute junk and turned me off to the whole concept.Enter the Gardena products and, in particular, this adapter. I bought it to swap out for the plastic one that came with my 7-in-1 Gardena sprayer, because you can't snug the plastic ones down without fear of breaking it and I wanted something that would endure better in the desert sun. There are still plastic parts on this adapter, of course, but not the critical connection to the hose where you want to snug it up and prevent any leaks. And, for those curious, unlike the grey vs. orange (Euro vs. North American) thread issue, I encountered absolutely no leaks when using these on my good old USA-made hoses. Whether it's because you can tighten them more or because they fit North American hose, I cannot say, but they don't leak a drop and that's the bottom line.In terms of fit and finish, these bad boys are miles ahead of the junk at the home improvement and big box retail outlets. They are heavy/weighty in the hand and that heft almost always correlates with quality. No cheap parts, no cheap metal, just loads of German engineered and German-made, uncompromising quality. The connections are quick, simple and rock solid, especially when coupled with metal adapters, although these will work with either metal or plastic versions, as they are fully interchangeable.In my case, I snagged two of these and one of the 39022-G premium metal adapters, and was able to rig up a complete system for my backyard needs. Slap the 39022-G on one end of your hose, the 39018 on the other and then a second 39018 to your hose bib and voila. You can now quick disconnect your watering implements (e.g. sprayers, sprinklers, etc.) from the end of the hose AND you can disconnect the hose from the hose bib at will. For those that might want to store their hose or be able to quickly remove it to make it easier to untangle or coil up, this will save you tons of time. Being able to swivel it on both ends will also make it easier to deal with snags/kinks.I could not be happier, and I am re-ordering another set to do the same setup with the hose in my front yard. Absolutely fantastic product, light years ahead of the import junk and other garbage out there. Highly recommended.

I have lots of mousse and hair gel, but I'm always on the look out for new products to try.  This Tresemme Expert Selection Root Lifting Cream did an OK job at making the hair on the top of my hair look fuller and thicker, but nothing extraordinary.  The one thing that bothered me was the scent, the fragrance is too strong for me as I prefer lightly scented products. I think that if I liked perfumed products, I wouldn't notice this but if you don't, I would skip this one.

Once you plug the device in, it starts filling the room with the smell of menthol, which really helps clear stuffed noses, especially children's, as their noses are so much more sensitive.  The smell is very pleasant and soothing, and the night light adds to this effect.  My only caveat is that, unlike a humidifier you can use and reuse, the device requires refills, which if bought regularly will no doubt end up costing more than the product itself (which is not that cheap either).  Also, you can't use it continuously in a sick room, as the device can only be used once every 8 hours.  For this reason, I've been using in the evening, just before I go to bed, so that I remember to unplug it first thing when I wake up.Overall it's good but it has limited usage unless you continue to buy refills. This is a shame, since it works quite well.

Combo shampoo and conditioners are great because they save time, not only in the morning when you're rushing to work, but at the gym, where you don't want to spend more time than necessary in the shower.  I poured some of this into a travel size bottle and used it after my last workout. It lathers well and has a slight woodsy scent that dissipates after your hair dries. Though it's aimed at men, I don't see why women can't use it as well.  It left my hair feeling fresh and clean, though I didn't feel it made my hair particularly soft or shiny.  For the price, however, (especially if you're a Prime member), it's a good buy.

This product adds a nice shine and softens your hair as long as you're careful and don't use too much of it. The first time I used it, I think I sprayed too much and after blow drying, my hair felt limp and slightly oily.  I have very fine, thin hair and the product seems more geared to people with very thick, frizzy hair.  The second time I used it sparingly and the results were much better - it's meant to keep your hair moist after blow drying and preserve the moisture your hair loses thanks to heat.  If you blow dry a lot, it's quite useful, but if you're like me (I alternate between blow drying and letting my hair dry naturally), you may find it's an OK product but not great.

I'm giving this four stars because it seems to work better for men than for women, and for short hair than long.  I have fine hair with some curls, and when I used this it made it feel stiff and crunchy, like when you use too much hairspray. When hubby used this, however, it worked as good as his hair gel and made the waves in his hair look more molded and defined. Perhaps it's because he used only a little bit of the product, while I used too much. That said, I think it works best on freshly washed, towel dried short hair, and even so only when you use a small amount. Otherwise, I don't think I'll be using this product.

I thought this mask would help me with an acne problem caused by age and hormonal changes.  While it reduced the redness beneath my eyes and made the rough skin left by a flattened pimple feel smoother, the mask itself felt gritty and too drying.  I think this product is best for teenagers and young adults who have problems with oily skin and acne.  My skin doesn't have as much oiliness anymore, so it felt irritated.  Overall, it works but it feels too strong for my sensitive skin.

I was a little wary about using this muffin mix after the oat cookie mix by the same company turned out to be disappointingly bland.As a result, I went all out, adding the less healthy stuff that would make vegans shudder:  a cup of dried cranberries that's been boiled for a few minutes in orange juice, 2 eggs, and a spoonful of blueberry jam.  After I poured the batter into my cupcake tray, I sprinkled some sugar on top of each one.  In addition, I followed the Bona Dea advice to add a tablespoon of white distilled vinegar to prevent dryness. It worked.My cranberry/orange muffins turned out pretty tasty, though the texture still wasn't the same as regular muffins.  If I had tried to stick to only healthy alternatives, however, I'm pretty sure these muffins would have turned out bland.  However, the fact that I had to add so much of the unhealthy stuff to make these more edible kind of discourage me from buying more in the future.  I mean, it's nice that it's organic, gluten-free, etc., but if I have to load it down with more fat just to get more flavor, I might well as well settle with getting a regular mix and add less sugar.It's too bad, since it has healthy, non-GMO ingredients and is perfect for those with a gluten allergy.

A friend of mine recently bought a "fixer-upper" house for cheap that he intends to renovate and flip for a higher price.  This set is not too expensive compared to other tools on the market out there.  The Lotos 2-in-1 comes with a staple gun, a small supply of oil to grease the gun, a rubber mallet, and a case.  It says goggles are included, but for some reason, mine didn't come with any.  It doesn't include staples or cleats, but they're easy enough to obtain from a hardware store.The tools are solidly made and heavy duty, which is good because installing a wood floor is not an easy project to do. You want something that is totally reliable for a tough job like this.Overall this is a great set for the money and I look forward to using this on our next project.

The foam is very light and has a strong woodsy/after shave lotion cologne smell, like all the other AXE body care products. My husband didn't think it really "cleanses" your hair as the label claims.  It feels more like a dry shampoo or leave-in conditioner to disguise the fact you haven't had a real wash yet.  He used it right after a run and said it makes your hair feel less gross when you don't have time to shower, but unlike gel, it doesn't provide much hold.  He thinks the foam is mainly good for disguising the smell of sweat but it wasn't a product he'd feel compelled to use all the time.So overall this product might work well for others, but it didn't for him.

This is a lovely set of three portable atomizers - each one has a nice glossy surface, which makes it easy to confuse it with a tube of fancy lipstick. When I got this set, I had no idea how to open it up so that I could fill it with my favorite cologne. As it turns out, it needs to be poked from the bottom, which is not easy and led to me spilling some perfume.I would have liked this design so much more if you could simply screw it open from the middle and pour in your oils or perfume. As it is, I wish the seller would include a clear diagram and instructions with each set they sold, as I had to go on the internet and research it in order to learn how to use it.Otherwise, it's a nice set to take with you while traveling (as long as it doesn't leak over time). You could use it not only for perfume, but for whatever body mist you'd like to take with you.I received this product in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

I've never used Nexxus products before but I'm familiar with their brand -I often see their products in the salon windows of those I frequent.  Now that I've tried their Shampoo, I really like it.My hair has lost some of its natural softness and smoothness thanks to years of highlighting and dyeing.  I deliberately did not use conditioner to see how well this shampoo would work on its own. I'm happy to report that, even without conditioner, it does make my hair feel softer and silkier to the touch  (so much so that conditioner hardly seems necessary).  I now understand why so many salons sell this product and look forward to buying more. My only caveat is that it did not seem to add enough volume.

Though this multivitamin oddly lacks iron, it's an overall excellent multivitamin, containing energy-boosting B12 vitamins, zinc and a blend of other vitamins and nutrients aimed at bone health (osteoporosis), heart and skin health.My only complaint is that it's in a tablet form and doesn't taste very good. I prefer gummy vitamins usually because they're fun to take, so I remember to take them. This is more like medicine.Other than that, I find that have more energy when I'm taking this.

After using this for 15 days and trying to eliminate the crows-nest wrinkles around my eyes, here's my review:PROS:• Easy to use, if a little uncomfortable (the laser makes your skin feel tingly and sensitive)• Short length of treatment: one minute, just before bedtime (recommended)•The light on the device tells you when to stop treatment – goes from green to purple then stops• Wrinkles are less noticeable but still visible, but overall it seems to be working.  I will update this review after the recommended 8 weeks and let you know.CONS:• You have to be very careful using it around your eyes.  The instruction warn that the laser can cause problems with vision if held too close, like to the eyes or eyelids. Yikes!• Don’t use if pregnant – which is ok, since the device seems made for older, postmenopausal women• It's not meant for people who have darker skin - according to the instructions, the laser can cause redness on dark skin.• I can't use this if I've just had a botox treatment or any other “professional cosmetic treatments", like skin peels, etc).  Unfortunately, the instructions are unclear about how long you should wait – I assume after the effects wear off?!• Effects are meant to be TEMPORARY.  The instructions say you can only use it for 8 weeks straight (7 days a week), but it doesn't say anything about how long you can wait between treatments, or if the device is even reusable after 8 weeks.  If not, you're basically paying over $200 for a device that you can only use ONCE.• The instructions are confusing.  The study they mention say that results were best after 8 weeks, with a slight decrease after 12 weeks, even though the device is not meant to be used after 8 weeks straight.  I assume it means the treatment keeps working even when you're stopped the nightly routine of using the laser, but it's unclear.•The Instructions recommend purchasing more Tria products, like tria priming cleanser and nourishing rye removal cream, to supplement this product.  I'm not surprised by this, but I used my own cleanser and cream, and it worked just as fine.Overall, it seems to be working, but I'm disappointed that, despite the high price tag, it's apparently a disposable device - after 8 weeks, you're not supposed to be able to use it anymore.

We hold a monthly “Game Night” at our house and felt this was the perfect opportunity to introduce the Pathfinder Card game to our friends.  Unfortunately, it took at least two hours to explain the rules of the game and our crowd is mostly people over 40, so keeping track of each character’s journey, remembering what powers they do or do not have, and explaining strategy was somewhat difficult, especially as everyone was a first time player.  I think this game is best suited to a younger crowd (under 40) but it’s still fun for those who really stick with it.A few of us played Dungeons & Dragons years ago, so this playing this felt very familiar.  Every player is given the opportunity to "customize" their game play, in that they can choose to be a particular character. The characters are individually possessed of different powers, spells, weapons, and capabilities. You choose a specific character and a “scenerio” (a.k.a storyline) and draw cards that determine the path of your journey.  Your objective is to maximize your advantage, using the cards and dice to advance or retreat.  The objective, of course, is to win the game by overcoming monsters and capturing the bad guys for points. It’s like a video game in that they are different levels and you can move on to different stages. The game shifts scenes as you advance, so it feels like a continual maze. The game can technically go on forever as the company encourages you to buy “expansion sets” that give you additional cards and new adventures to go on.Two people in our group are big science fiction and fantasy buffs, and they absolutely loved it.  For the rest of us, it was challenging, and after playing this for two hours, a little tedious, since it requires so much thinking.  This is not a game to be played when you’ve had a few cocktails!  But for devoted game geeks, I can see this being a big hit.

These washcloths feel rough and not worth the $10 they're currently selling for.  Not soft enough for a baby's delicate skin and are really not different in type from ones you'd use to dry dishes with.  I'm very disappointed.

Honestly, this is the most economical option to see a movie in NYC - less than $9 and the popcorn and soda cost about the same as if you were living in a small town in the Midwest or upstate; in other words, insanely cheap, which makes me wonder how on earth this place can stay in business, given NYC rent prices.It's in a very cool location as well - not a dingy, look-over-your-shoulder dangerous neighborhood but on trendy Metropolitan Ave (take the bus that runs along it and you'll end up in Williamsburg in 20 minutes!).  It's near one of the few Michelin-starred restaurants in NYC - Danny Brown's Wine Bar - and a bunch of very classy eateries.  There's no shortage of good places to eat after you've seen a movie, plus there's the famous Eddie's Sweet Shop for a delicious ice cream soda.Support this little theater that could - no, it won't have reclining seats or gourmet treats, but it does have that old-fashioned NYC feel to it - if you grew up in NYC, you will love this very retro place.

I wasn't aware that Purina has now entered the field of "gourmet" and more "natural" cat food, but it's good to hear.  My Russian Blue Cat lapped this up as soon as I gave her a sample of this food, so she gives this a big "paws up"!  I usually feed her Purina Cat Chow, but I know that type has less natural ingredients than this does, so I plan on switching now that I know she has a hearty appetite for this type of food.While it's more pricey than Purina Cat Chow, I'd rather pay more for quality ingredients, which results in fewer vet visits for my beloved kitty.

This mobile is rather cheaply made, so simple in design that I could have possibly rigged it up myself. It's a very modern, minimalist design, as if you were training your baby to be an abstract painter someday.  Basically it consists of a hard plastic rod, a cord, and several discs on which various geometric designs have been imprinted on it.  It reminds me of a wind chime, only the pieces are far away enough for the baby to see each one clearly and the discs are sensitive to the motion of the air (they're very thin).  The discs are interchangeable and customizable and the cord can be adjusted.The designs are nice, but that's it.  It will keep your baby entertained, but it feels cheap, flimsy, and overpriced at $30.

I recently had the privilege to try out several AXE products and have been very pleased with the scent and the eye-catching packaging, which screams "masculine" and no-nonsense.  This fits in my hubby's ethos, so when I gave him this deodorant to try he was very pleased.  He runs twice a week and works up a good sweat (he does a six mile run no matter what the weather), so he found this works well for him.  It has a nice woodsy pine scent, very manly, and not too strong (he hates strong fragrance, being a natural, outdoorsy type of person).Best of all it's NOT an antiperspirant - sweat is human and normal and to keep your body from producing it is not good for you, so we prefer using deodorant sticks wherever possible.  Like other AXE products, this stick looks like frozen gel but glides on smoothly and doesn't leave the bathroom swimming in powdery flakes like other ones he's tried.Overall he's very pleased - his only complaint is that Axe products, despite the stated size, tend to get used up fairly quickly in our house - perhaps the packaging is thicker than the amount of allotted product.

So far, so good. My Russian Blue isn't a very picky eater, so the fact that she ate this without hesitation doesn't necessary mean this food will be right for every cat, but she apparently likes it. However, as someone who tries to eat organic and avoid subpar quality food as much as possible, I pay attention to the ingredients and this Nutro product lists a number of natural ingredients, including whole brown rice (!) which I didn't know cats could eat or like.  In fact, the list contains such a good number of natural food that I wouldn't mind seeing a similar list of ingredients on the food I'd eat myself (though of course I don't mean to say I'd eat cat food :)Since my cat Maggie is already fairly healthy, I didn't notice any significant change in her behavior or appearance since she started trying Nutro, but then no news is good news.  I think the real test will be when I switch this brand with another, and see if she reacts negatively.  If so, Her Royal Highness will get more Nutro, since what makes her happy makes us happy.

These pads won't prevent severe incontinence, but it does a good job of preventing minor accidents. The pad is noticeably thicker toward the middle and appears most absorbent there.  Unlike maxi pads, it has a cloth backing with a little bit of elastic on the sides.  This makes the pad bunch up a little, like a diaper, but actually makes it more likely to stick to an undergarment, as the pad's shape tends to curve instead of lying flat, to prevent leakage.  For this reason, it works well and I'd echo the views of other reviewers who mention that women who have moderately heavy periods can also use this as well.  My only caveat is that the price per package (about $4 each) is higher than that of conventional maxi pads.

It looks like a hockey puck but this is a solidly made grinder. The way it works is to unscrew to cover, put your chunky spices into the teeth and twist it back and forth, as if you were tightening a lid.  The spices or herbs go through a built-in sieve and a small compartment at the bottom catches all the spices you've ground.Compared to other grinders, this design is very space-saving and, since everything you need is within the levels of the grinder, compact and great if you're traveling (I can see a chef being happy to have this). It even comes with a tiny brush that helps you clean it.  I plan to use this for peppercorns, cloves, and perhaps even lemongrass. Very convenient and useful.I received this product for free in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

My lashes are thin and short. This mascara did a good job at making them seem longer, but it didn't make them thicker. The applicator was easy to use but the mascara felt thin and I had to reapply it several times to make it feel fuller.Over the course of the day, it smudged a little, though not as badly as other mascaras I've used. Overall, a mixed rating. I like it, especially the packaging, but didn't feel I would go out of my way to buy this again.

My elderly father has prostrate problems. Since he doesn't like pumpkin or eat pumpkin seeds outside of a Halloween or maybe Thanksgiving celebration, this bottle of Pumpkin Seed Oil vitamins seems like a good and easy way to get the benefits of this vegetable into his daily diet. I've bought Nature's bounty before and while I'm not sure this product is organic, I think this is a reputable brand.Since Dad starting taking this two weeks ago, he has noticed a decrease in his need to go to the bathroom.  He is very happy this product exists.

The design will please "Hello Kitty" fans but it's overpriced and I wouldn't call it a "Trapper Keeper".  It's really more like your standard three-ring binder with two interior pockets and a snap clasp.  When I think of a "trapper keeper", I think of a sturdy binder that's been laminated with a plastic cover, clearly defined tabs, and a Velcro snap.Also, it's big - wider than your typical binder and will take up more space in a backpack.  The flap feels flimsy though it does a good job of keeping papers in place.  The problem is how it will hold up over time - it feels like it could tear at some point.If I didn't know it was an official licensed product of "Hello Kitty," I would have sworn it was a knock-off.  It's OK if you have low expectations, but it shouldn't have been called "trapper keeper" and the price is too high.

This tea infuser looks like my husband when he's drinking beer, so I knew I had to have it.  I was a little wary of dunking plastic into hot water (I try to avoid doing this, as we don't know how much plastic can leach into water) so I was relieved to hear that it's made of BFA-free plastic.  Still, I prefer to pour the hot water and let it cool down for a bit before dunking him in.As an infuser, it's amusing to look at but I found that the tea tastes best when he's fully immersed and you're basically drowning him for a few minutes.  Putting him in a position with his arms hanging off the sides of the cup, looking really chill, should be done just to make others laugh as this position doesn't give your tea enough flavor.This set came with not one, but four little Mister Tea infusers, which is a little unusual - that's great for the money (and would make ideal stocking stuffers!) but I hope that doesn't mean each one isn't intended to last that long.I received this product at a free or discounted price for my honest and unbiased review

This is a very colorful set of collapsible cups made of silicone - I don't go camping as much but these are great to throw into your bag for when you're on the go. I have found them especially useful when I'm on a plane or airport and need to brush my teeth. They're also great when you need to take a pill and need a cup to hold the water.  It doesn't take up much space in your luggage and the silicone is lightweight.My only quibble is that the cup could be a little smaller, but that's a minor thing.I received this product at a free or discounted price for my honest and unbiased review

I love eating Naan in Indian restaurants (for the uninitiated, it's that aromatic flatbread that either comes with your meal or could be ordered as a side dish). I've always wanted to make some of my own and found a great recipe using Chakki Atta.  I added milk, yogurt and yeast and the bread turned out great - moist and flavorful.  I'm glad I didn't use Pillsbury or some other mass produced product - it definitely tastes more authentic.I always make a point of buying organic products, so I was happy to see that this is available on Amazon.  Though it's more expensive than what I've found in an Asian grocery (Jackson Heights in NYC has tons of those!), the fact that's healthier for you is worth the additional cost.I received this product in exchange for an honest review.

This is probably the second "hipster" movie I've seen.  What exactly is a hipster movie?  Well, it has certain elements in common.  First, there's the preoccupation with "how things look" over an intelligent plot or good dialogue.  Every shot in this movie calls attention to itself, whether it's necessary or not - dunk Tilda Swinton in a sea of tomatoes, show her staring wordlessly into the camera, focus on a fan blowing the edge of a poster, show a bunch of broken eggs in an egg carton, capture the "look" of raindrops reflecting traffic lights.Do any of these shots reveal anything about the characters, give us any real insight to a character's mind?  No.  It's just a young director showing off, a presumably privileged youngster who lacks experience in the "real world" and is trying desperately to prove that, despite his MFA-buffeted life, he has "suffered" and can convey that "suffering."The other sign of a hipster movie is the deliberate use of relentlessly cheery, vintage music to underscore a few serious scenes in an "ironic" manner.  It's a device that's so obvious and self-important I kept cringing.If you're looking for a meaningful movie about what motivates kids and parents and explores the complexities of a dysfunctional family, skip this.  The "edgy" plot is just an excuse for the director to play with his camera.  The real test of a good movie is to walk out for ten minutes, come back, and see if you missed anything important. I walked away for 30 minutes, came back, and didn't miss anything.

I really wanted to like this product, but the taste is not that great. I was expecting a smoothie-like taste, but since this drink is overwhelmingly flavored by veggies and not fruit, there is more of tartness than a sweetness.It's certainly healthy for you - it's got spinach, a combo of cucumber, celery, green bell pepper, even romaine lettuce(!), 2 apples, yellow carrots (never had these, only the orange kind), and "hint" of pineapple. One 8 oz glass is deemed equivalent to one serving of vegetables.  Health-wise, this is the perfect beverage for the type of person who lives off coffee and cigarettes or eats lot of junk food, but since I eat relatively healthy (I try to have a side meal of veggies for dinner every night), the benefits seem a little lost on me, especially since I find sauteed spinach and onions, grilled peppers or roasted broccoli are far more tastier than this drink.My other quibble is that this product doesn't seem to be organic - spinach, apples, and green bell peppers are members of the "dirty dozen" that are better bought that way, especially if you're juicing them.  V8 should seriously consider this, especially for a drink purported to be healthy.On the plus side, you do get a huge bottle for the price.

Reading the other reviews, I was worried this would be too big for me (I ordered a Medium).  Fortunately it was fine - it fit true to size and felt very comfortable.I tested this shirt under ideal conditions - I went out at noon on a day when the humidity was near 70% and the temp was in the upper 90s.  Though my face still felt hot, the shirt kept my upper body feeling reasonably cool and not sticky or too sweaty.  It was great being able to gallivant in the hot weather without feeling my shirt stick to my skin, for once!The color is great, the electric violet is very attractive. Though the material has a stretchy material often used in workout clothing (and a small logo at the hem of the shirt makes it feel like a sports shirt), I was able to wear this to work without anyone noticing that the shirt was specially made for active wear.  This makes it very versatile.  Recommended.

This is a surprisingly inexpensive set of cycling sunglasses that comes with five interchangeable lenses. This review is for the one with the yellow and red frame.It comes in a zippered hard case with five layers of foam inserts that protect each individual lens - very compact and great for travel. The set includes a blue, yellow, clear, reflective, and black polarized lens.  I don't feel the need to change my lenses during a bike ride, so it's clearly intended for times when you know how light or dark a place will be and adjust accordingly - I prefer using the polarized during times of brightest sunlight, whereas the clear ones will come in handy for a nighttime ride.  I also like the fact the set includes a plastic glass frame with no lenses - the inner spectacles are for prescription lenses that you can wear behind your sunglasses. Since I wear contacts, I doubt I'll use this, but it's a nice option to have (though I wonder if it will work for someone with thick prescription glasses, since the frame feels kind of flimsy).It wasn't hard for me to pop the lenses in and out - just make sure the edges of each lense fit into the groove and fit it over the nosepiece. The hard rubber nose piece felt comfortable for the first hour or so, but it started to make my nose itch a little afterwards.On the inside of the frame you will see "Italy Design" written on it - not grammatically correct (it should say "Designed in Italy" or "Italian Design"), which tips me off this product is likely made in China and is paying a "homage" to Italian-style sunglasses. That's a shame, because the glasses, despite made of inexpensive plastic, are very well made (I've seen more expensive sunglasses that are flimsier than these) and a great buy for the money.Disclaimer: I received this set in exchange for an honest review.

Since I'm no longer a spring chicken, this gel is just what I needed for my hair, which is on the dry side and graying.  As it provides more softness than volume, I prefer to use it on my dry hair.  My hair has become dry and dull after years of dyeing it, and pumping a few squirts on my hair did make it feel more silky and smooth.  It has a pleasant, fruity smell to it that's not too strong, which is good. The only downside is the pump, which tends to clog and I have to press it a few more times.  Since it's really a gel, I would have preferred a tube rather than something that resembles a spray.Other than that, I find the product works well for my hair.

This gel pomade looks like petroleum jelly and has a slightly chemical scent when you first uncap it but thankfully it goes away once you use it.  A little gel goes a long way, so unless you want to look like the Fonz or John Travolta in "Grease," it's really not necessary to use a lot of it. I took a dab of it and ran it through my hair after washing it.  It kept all my flyaways in place, didn't leave my hair feeling too stiff and added a nice shine to it.I like Jack Black products - it's a brand I was first introduced to via Birchbox Man and most of their products are pricey but good.

This review is for the Tomato Soup.I love the fact that this is made of 100% organic ingredients. I also like the fact that the soup comes in a box rather than a metal can - it's lightweight and I can take boxes of it to work. It resembles one of those cardboard juice boxes, and when it first arrived I was tempted to look for a hole to poke my straw through, then I remembered it was soup. Best of all, such packaging is recyclable - it's clear Campbell's is making a serious effort to join the upscale soup market, where those soups (like Nature's Promise, etc.) package their soups in boxes.The size is just enough for one person, though the servings say it's enough for 2.  It's a little pricey, but then most organic foodstuffs are.I remembered to shake it before pouring. It's creamy with some tiny chunks of tomato in it but I couldn't taste the basil at all.  It was a little sweet, but I prefer my tomato soup that way. I added some croutons and bits of shredded cheddar cheese and it was delicious. I think this soup makes a great base for you to add your ingredients - by itself it's OK, but not great.The downside is that it's fattening (40% of calories from fat) and very high in salt (650 mg of sodium for 1 cup of soup!!) so if you're on a diet where you have to avoid salt and fat (to paraphrase Seinfeld's Soup Nazi), no soup for you!

These are very pretty earrings with an eye-catching array of delicate stone in different shades of blue. I bought these at a party thrown by a friend of mine a year ago, when she was still a Lia Sophia consultant (as you know, they went out of business as of Dec 2014).  Although I read some negative reviews about their jewelry (stones will fall out and tarnish), so far I've been very lucky with these earrings - I still wear them frequently and they've never lost their tarnish and all the stones are still there!  My only regret is that they're selling so cheaply now and I paid so much more for them (as is the case if you buy from a hostess).

I feel this conditioner was "made" for me - it's aimed at aging hair, and now that I'm several years shy of 50 I sorely need products like this.  This conditioner has a pleasant, subtle scent and leaves my hair feeling softer and fuller.  Since I shed a lot of hair, I find that whatever remains often looks limp and flat when dry. This conditioner helped give it some much needed volume so that I didn't have to apply an additional product. In addition to working well with my hair, the price is right!  Very pleased.

I received a set of three to review: #10 (Rosy), #40 (Bronzed) and #50 (Luminous). All are very light and subtle in color, and best for those with light to medium skin tones. Fortunately it works for me, but I doubt these would work well with those with olive or darker skin complexions.While I found the "Rosy" too light to use alone, I found it easy enough to add some of the darker "Bronzed" color to give my cheeks a more textured color. Of the three, #50 didn't do it for me - it's too close to the color of "nude" or light beige foundation to have any impact, and I had to mix it with a darker coral Benefit blush that I had to make it stand out more.All three blushes contain Vitamin C and botanical conditioners. Neutrogena products have always worked well for my skin, and each blush went on smoothly with a soft, lightly powdery consistency. While I think the colors could be a little more textured, this is a good set for those who want to wear makeup but prefer the "natural look" as opposed to the louder, more defined makeup that some women wear.

This heart-shaped necklace has a lightweight and delicate quality despite having a silver frame that gives it some depth.  Like most jewelry from Amazon's Curated Collection, it came beautifully packaged in a gift box that makes any jewelry piece feel special.I was a little disappointed, however, in two things:  the color and the thickness of the chain.  The photo shows a deeper purple color but the amethyst is actually on the light side, so if you wear it in bright light, it looks almost like clear crystal.  Also the chain feels dainty and easily breakable, more so than the pendant. Its lightness makes it almost invisible when worn.Overall, however, this is a pretty necklace, and since it is silver and uses a real gemstone, the under $20 price tag makes it a decent buy.

This highly entertaining novel by the author of “Five Men Who Broke My Heart” starts off with an opening reminiscent of Stefan Zweig‘s “Letter From an Unknown Woman” – what if you were a young, impressionable poet who had a life-changing love affair with a much older Pulitzer-Prize poet who, years later at a book signing, fails to remember who you are?Such is the opening of Susan Shapiro’s “What’s Never Said,” an endearing and funny novel that manages to combine an eventful plot with characters so immersed in the competitive literary world that they ironically fail to see and understand the unspoken boundaries and vacillations endemic of personal relationships.  In depicting what could have been a stereotypical older professor-younger woman/student love affair, Shapiro successfully upends expectations and captures how relationships begin, progress and then fall apart in a way that never feels contrived, judgmental or moralistic.In addition, by switching skillfully between two points of view, Ms. Shapiro manages a feat that few writers have managed to do – create a convincing portrait of an older man who has an affair with a student for reasons that aren’t lamentable or pathetic, but realistic; and the same for the young blonde poet who falls for the older professor with a passion that can’t be categorized as Lolita-like or entirely naïve.If you’re looking for a fast-moving, entertaining and emotional summer (and winter) read, you can’t really do much better than "What's Never Said.”

These tea light candles are great to have on hand. I used around 10 candles so far while lighting my carved Halloween pumpkins for several evenings. I found that these tealight candles lit up easily and stayed lit for at least 2 hours. I find that a pack of 100 is perfect, since I use these kind of candles regularly. They fit candle holders great. I also found them easy to light up. The wicks stay put and light up without a problem. I do admit with another reviewer that the packaging can use a bit of improvement. A few of the candles were slightly squashed during the shipping. I tend to use these types of candles inside candle holders, so this mild imperfection wasn't a big deal. I received these tea light candles at a discounted rate for review purposes in exchange for my honest and unbiased opinion.

I am very pleased with the feel and quality of this down alternative comforter. I like to use comforters that can fit duvet covers. I find it more sanitary and easier to wash a duvet cover, rather than an entire comforter. I use to use down comforters, but have since been diagnosed with an allergy to dust mites. My doctor explained that down comforters are notorious for breeding dust mights and that my allergies are exacerbated by them. I have since switched to this down alternative comforter and my allergies and breathing has really improved. I also no longer wake up with a sore throat. This comforter is hypoallergenic. I purchased the king size, and it has a great fluffy feel to it. I plan to order another comforter to have on hand for guests that visit. Overall great price and quality. I received this down alternative comforter at a discounted rate for review purposes in exchange for my honest and unbiased opinion.

This is a nice infinity nursing scarf. It is a cotton jersey material. I got the grey color, so it will match many different outfits. The nursing scarf can be warn in a variety of ways. I tend to put it around my neck like a giant oval and hide the baby under it. It is a nice amount of material without being too heavy or much. Also, when not using it to nurse, it can be double wrapped around the neck as a scarf. Overall this would make a great baby shower gift. I have a 5 month old and am regularly nursing on the go, This scarf if great for a bit more privacy. I will say that when folded up it will take a bit of space in the diaper bag. This is definitely one of the things I grab when walking out the door with my baby. I received this nursing scarf at a discounted rate in exchange for my honest and unbiased opinion.

I received this yoga mat in the light blue. It rolls up pretty easy and secures using the velcro straps. However, I do feel this mat is too thin for my daily needs and may not hold up the way I need. This mat does not have the same skid bottom technology that firmly holds it in place. Instead, it can slide around on a smooth floor and the corners want to curl back up. Additionally, the mat is shorter than other mats on the market and may be more suitable for children and home use. I am not sure I would feel so comfortable taking this mat to the gym.I do plan to use it occasionally around the house.  I received this mat at a discounted rate in exchange for my honest and unbiased feedback.

I am very impressed with the quality of this baby wrap. It is in the same category as the Boba and the Moby wrap at a better cost and quality. The wrap is a lengthy piece of jersey stretch cotton material (95% cotton). What makes the wrap better than the Boba that I already own is that it is a thinner cotton, yet just as durable and secure. I prefer the thinner fabric which I found to be less hot and more comfortable. I received the wrap in the navy blue color, which is perfect. I have used it with my 4 month old in the toddler and front carry position and will post some pictures when I get a chance. Additionally, because the fabric is a bit thinner than other similar wraps, it fits better into the carry bag and is more compact. What also sets this wrap apart, is the packaging, the lifetime guarantee and the pamphlet that comes with it. I loved that it came with detailed picture diagrams to show how to correctly wear the wrap. I never even knew I could use to to do a front carry and was so excited when I saw that!  Overall, I would highly recommend this wrap to others and feel it can compete with the other leading names on the market today that sell similar types of baby wraps. Thank you so much baby wrap for offering me this wrap at a discounted rate in exchange for my honest and unbiased feedback.

finally a prenatal that doesn't have the awful fish smell! This prenatal comes in a white capsule. I found it easy to swallow and it didn't leave my mouth with any fowl aftertaste. Additionally, my hands smelled like before. I have tried other prenatals that just made me want to gag based on the smell. This has a sufficient amount of folic acid and most other vitamins I look for. Overall, I am happy with these. I am currently a nursing mother and do notice an improvement with my nails and hair while taking this vitamin. I received this multivitamin at a discount in order to try the product and provide my honest feedback.

This is a very attractively designed makeup mirror. It is very compact and stands nicely on the table without tipping over. It has two sides. One side is a regular mirror and the other side is magnifying mirror. This is exactly what I have been looking for to do my makeup. The best part is that it has a built in light that illuminates and helps see any flaws or imperfections and rather than needing to replace batteries, this light is rechargeable using a regular USB cable that it comes with. My only comment is that I originally thought the mirror was a bit larger. I will still be using this mirror, but would of liked it to be just a little bit bigger. I received this mirror at a discounted rate in exchange for my honest and unbiased feedback.

This outdoor picnic blanket is just what I needed for my 5 month old, who isn't crawling or walking yet. This blanket is a great size for my needs. I like how compact it folds up and how easy it is to open. Also the material is thick and appears easy to wipe clean. It is a pretty heavy duty material. This is particularly useful if the ground is a bit damp and will not soak through the fabric. Also the bright colors are very attractive, and my baby loved it! I plan to use this picnic blanket regularly to do some outdoor tummy time and have a safe and clean area for my little one to play. The mat also comes with convenient pins that can be used to better anchor it to the ground in case of wind. I have attached a couple of pictures showing the size of it once opened and my little one on it and also a picture of how compact it gets when closed. I am thrilled to have received this picnic blanket at a discounted rate for review and inspection purposes in exchange for my honest and unbiased feedback.

This is a great set of silicone spatulas and brushes. I like that the set provides spatulas in a variety of sizes. I received these magnetic tiles at a slightly discounted rate for review purposes in exchange for my honest and unbiased feedback.Review Edit**** I originally mistakenly wrote that I owned magna tiles and that the Tinsky were interchangeable. I meant to say I owned Magformers. These tiles work with Magformers. Additionally, as a previous reviewer noted, after 2 months of play, one of our tiles split apart and the magnets came out.

I am a stay at home mom with a toddler and 2 month old. I am regularly cooking homemade food for my family. These scissors are definitely a novelty piece for me. I have never owned a pair of herb scissors before and really liked the idea of them. I traditionally need to chop up my herbs with a knife. This is a terrific piece of gear!  The blades are sharp and work well, and the device is very easy to adjust. The veggie tray works very well and is easy to use.  It doesn't hold a lot (you'll have to empty if frequently if you're doing a lot of work).  It could also be a bit wider, but of course I knew the size when I ordered it and they make a wider one.  This really is a classic and nearly every kitchen I've worked in has had one of these stashed somewhere.I use mine in a restaurant kitchen and it works very well.  If you're doing a very high volume you're probably going to be better off getting a Bron but this will certainly do a great job if you aren't banging out twenty pounds of vegetables per day.  If you're a home cook it's a total no-brainer!  This is likely all you'd ever need at home, provided it does what you want it to do (basically slices, juliennes and batonettes).

This is a case where I should have dug into the reviews before I purchased them.  Since I've used the same case but in Orange I ass/u/me'd these where the same. Wrong!  Every other brand these are sold under has a sheet of striker material rolled up and placed in a baggie inside the tube.  Not these ones, though.  It's not easy to find the striker material in sheets as a stand-alone item.  Just as an FYI the old school strike-anywhere match have the red phosphorus on the head of the match; that's why friction will light them.  Safety (ie strike on box) matches rely on a striker impregnated with phosphorus for them to work.  The "striker" on the bottom of the case isn't a striker at all- it's a ferrocerium rod (aka fire steel). This is made to create a shower of sparks when scraped briskly with a metal edge, not light matches.I can't fault the basic case itself, especially for a buck and a half.  It's sturdy for what it is and well sealed against dust and water.  But you're left having to cut the striker off the box of whatever matches you choose to fill this container.  Since you can get the Orange version of this case at Wal-Mart, branded by Coleman and filled full of matches, for $1 this isn't really a bargain.  I ordered ten of these because I think the Safety Yellow is maybe a bit more visible than the Orange ones but I wouldn't have got them had I known there were no strikers.I still recommend them if you want to use them for something besides matches or if you don't care about the strikers.

I picked this us to use as a tablet bag to carry my Galaxy Tab Pro 8.4 with a few accessories.  It's great for that!  The Tab 8.4 in it's cover fits in this pack like it was made for it.  The pack is a little smaller than I expected from the listing but it's plenty big for the intended purpose.  The material is pretty lightweight but it feels well made. The stitching is neat with no loose ends or runs.  Internal organization is minimal; there's one big main section with a thin divider that makes a shallow pocket about 2/3 the size of the back.  The outer zippered section has a similar pocket but split into two and about 4/5 of the height of the pocket.  These are sized about right for a large tactical flashlight such as a Surefire 6P, or of course a wound up USB cable, etc.  Right about the body of the pack at the base of the strap there's a small mesh pocket with an elastic shock cord.  This is really nice touch as it puts whatever you store in it right where you can easily reach it on your shoulder.  It's almost exactly the size of that 6P flashlight I referenced above.  I should also mention that this bag has really nice zipper pulls!  They're sturdy and ergonomic, and the bright plastic dip stands out from the body of the pack.  You can remove them if  you don't like them, too.  Lastly there's a strap that connects the front and the back; this strap would keep the pack closed even if both zippers failed.  You don't normally see that on a pack this small and it's probably not necessary but it's a nice touch.The only minor downsides are the small size and the fact that there's minimal padding.  The padding on the shoulder strap isn't too bad as long as you don't try to carry a lot of weight.  Again, in a pack this tiny it's not likely to be an issue.  Also, the strap is permanently attached to the bottom right side (if looking from the back).  This means it's not quite as ambidextrous as it would be if the strap attache in the middle or better still, clipped to a D-ring on either side.This is a borderline five-star pack, especially considering the low price (I think I paid $12 or so).  It could use a little bit more internal organization but if you're looking for a small bag for a tablet it's great so long as you stick to probably an 8" model (I'm not sure anything bigger would fit).  This could be a good bag for day hikes if you only plan to carry minimal gear.

This is my third Elzetta light, and tt's an extraordinary device that's just short of perfection.  Like all Elzettas there's nothing to fault in the construction.  The parts all screw together as smoothly as silk, and when assembled it's bank-vault solid.  The anodizing is rich, velvety perfection.  Just looking at the body, tailcap and bezel this light is flawless.  Only the tint/color temperature leaves a bit to be desired.  The Malkoff engine is powerful but it's biased a little cooler (to my eye) than the newer Alpha light engine.  Subjectively the beam is as nice and artifact free as the spot lens of my Alpha, it's just a smidge cooler/bluer than I'd like.  It's certainly not bad by any means, it's just a little short of the flawless performance I was expecting.  I also have to say that as fantastic as Elzetta lights are none of them that I have seen can match the color of the Malkoff M61N that I dropped into my Elzetta Bravo.  I have an AVS head coming, and perhaps this will be superior to the M60S unit in this light.I only purchases this older/legacy version because Amazon had it on markdown for $133. That's basically less than the body, tailcap and bezel normally costs, and the light engine was essentially free.  So this was still a great deal.  And by any objective measure this is an awesome light.  I do feel that a three cell light could be a bit brighter.  Of course, that's why sell the AVS head (900 lumens) and run time with three cells should be outstanding.To someone that likes a cooler colored beam this is probably about as good as you can get for a tactical/hard use light.  I fully expect it to last at least the rest of my life!  Great light, but if like me you prefer a warmer/more neutral color temperature you'd be better off getting just the body, bezel and tail cap switch of your choice then adding a Malkoff M61N or M61W.Lastly, I should point out that this isn't built for "lumen drag racing".  It's not as bright as those piercingly blue Chinese wonder lights.  Elzettas are designed for absolute, never-say-die reliability. They don't push the emitters too hard, they don't drive them with crappy drivers, and they don't set them up to blaze at turbo level for two minutes and then drop off.  It isn't hard to find a brighter light in stated lumens but it's hard to find a better practical illumination tool than an Elzetta.Highly recommended.

There is no doubt that the Elzetta Alpha is in a league of its own.  I've got a lot of very good flashlights including several from Streamlight, Surefire, Inforce and JETBeam but they can't match the build quality of an Elzetta.  Everything about it screams quality.  First off the anodizing is simply fantastic.  The level of precision in construction is unmatched by any other light I've seen. The machining is very precise; when you screw it apart and back together it's incredibly smooth.  The entire light is like a tank.  All the electronics are fully potted.  This means that after assembly of the electronics they're filled with an epoxy resin.  This makes them incredibly durable and tough and nearly immune to shock.The power of this little one CR123A is also exceptional.  There are other small lights with this lumen level but the beam quality is extraordinary due to the use of optical lenses instead of the reflectors other lights use.  I will note that the lens is replaceable, too, with a flood option being available for ten bucks.  Just as impressive is the color temp- this one is much much more neutral than almost everything else out there.  Compared to the Alpha most of my other lights are annoyingly, shockingly blue tinted. Well, except for my Surefires.  They're annoyingly green compared to the Elzetta.  To date the only LED I've seen with better color is the Malkoff M61N module (which I dropped into my Elzetta Bravo body).Another great feature of the Elzetta line is modularity.  You can swap out lenses and change switch modes easily.  I added a crenelated bezel ring to mine and got a flood lens, and both installed in about 30 seconds.  The Bravo and Charlie lights from Elzetta are even more modular with many parts you can "Lego" into the same body.  The Alpha has only one option for light engines but the bigger ones can accept any P60-type module.  Luckily the emitter of the Alpha is terrific.This light is very close to being perfect, but it does have a few minor flaws. First it comes with no pocket clip.  You can buy one for $15 but it's kind of a kluge; it's a two piece ring design that uses a friction ring to lock the clip ring in place.  It's difficult to install, bulky and the clip itself is inferior to something like the one on my Surefire E1b. With the clip on the body it's about midway up the light, meaning if you clip it to the body it rides about halfway in and halfway out of the pocket, a bit too high.  The clip can be mounted on the tail for deeper carry but this interferes in a minor way with operation the twisting switch.That switch is mostly outstanding, with one minor issue.  If you toggle rapidly between high and low it usually gets stuck in low. If this happens it can't be switched back to high until you turn it off for a second.  This is a known issue reported by a couple of other owners of the light over at CPF.  Elzetta is apparently aware of the issue and doesn't think it's important enough to worry about.  I actually agree with them. In actual use it's not a big deal at all in a $150 flashlight anything short of flawless is worth noting.But forget those very minor nits- this is an stunningly great light!  I used to think Surefire made the best lights in the world but Elzetta is simply on a whole other level.  It's hard to imaging that humans could build a more bombproof light with present technology.Two thumbs way up!  I highly recommend this this light along with the Bravo.  IMO there is no better light on the planet at any price (that I am aware of).  No single product will the best choice for every user but if reliability and bullet-proof build quality are you top priorities then search no more.  Elzetta makes the best tactical lights in the world.

Overall I like the Speed Clip but it's not perfect.  First off it is pretty hard to install.  According to a pro review site I frequent it's a lot easier after you've done it a few times, and I can see how that's probably true.  Second, as another reviewer here pointed out it's pretty easy to knock it loose compared to how difficult it is to seat it.However, I like the actual clip pretty well.  I also like the fact that it allows the clip to be positioned anywhere, and removed if necessary.  And in actual practice I can't imagine that the clip would be dislodged in normal use.I'd rate this as not quite as nice as most Surefire clips but much better than the ones provided by JETBeam.

Despite the very low price I'm really surprised at how awesome this case it!  It fits perfectly as it very well made.  It covers the tablet and protects well while offering good access to the ports.  The magnets do a great job of keeping it closed and allow it to fold into a stand.  And as a stand it works exceptionally well!  It's a little too straight up and down to read for long periods but I balance it on the stand while tipping it back and that works great. The texture of the case is also awesome- it's grippy but not sticky and very easy to hold onto.Highly recommended!

Overall this is a decent pack for light duty use.  It's a little smaller than I thought it would be, though.  It's fairly well made but very lightly constructed.  The nylon is a very light denier and there's very little padding, either on the back of the pack or the strap.  I was a bit disappointed that there's no belt tab/slot to affix it to a belt to help distribute the load but then it's a tiny pack so I suppose that's not a critical omission.  The stitching seems fine and it should hold up pretty well.I kind of hoped to use this as a day bag for hikes but it's too small for that. It's really more like a purse.  It would be fine for a small tablet or e-reader (probably an 8" tablet, tops) with maybe a few things like a charger, keys, wallet, etc.  Not a lot space but there's a ton of internal organization, though.If you're looking for a book bag or day pack it's going to disappoint you- it's simply too small.  As a case for a tablet or as  purse/murse it's not too bad.  It could be a four star pack for you if you don't need a lot of room.EDIT:  I've used this pack a bit more and I'm revising my opinion upwards.  It is small but my Galaxy TAB PRO 8.4 fits perfectly.  The internal organization is minimal but effective for a basic pack.  It has held up really well and I've begun to appreciate the little details that make it easier and more convenient (like the really nice zipper pulls).If you're in the market for a really small bag to use as a purse/murse of for an e-reader or tablet this is a nice little pack.

This is a really superb WML for an M4-type rifle.  I think that momentary-only is the way to go on a defensive rifle; for predator control maybe a constant on would be useful but most trainers advocate short bursts of light combined with movement for CQB.  I've been alternating between this light and my Surefire X300 Ultra on my AR and it's hard to decide which I like more.  The Inforce is smaller and lighter and has a better switch.  The Surefire is brighter.  For outdoor use, and again maybe for varmints, the extra light would be useful.  Indoors though it's overkill.  Overall I think the Inforce is better for the role I envision for this particular rifle.The construction is great and it mounts securely to the rail, yet it's easy to remove, too. The set screw is an ingenious way to ensure it won't fly off when you need it.The only minor downside is probably going to be battery life.  I expect that like my 1-cell Inforce APL it won't have the run time of the 2-cell Surefire of JETBeam lights I run on my other long guns.  That and of max brightness- if you're looking for a blowtorch this isn't your light.  But the angled push button switch is very intuitive and run at 12:00 on my carbine it's perfectly ambidextrous.Highly recommended for an AR!

I got this Seahorse SE920FPL for $100 with Prime shipping!  It's just slightly more than that now and still a bargain.  I use mine for a range bag/case for my handguns.  The case itself is extremely well made.  The latches are solid and secure.  The wheels work well and the extendable handle is smooth and solid when extended.  The pluck foam takes a bit of practice to work with but does the job well once you get it scienced out.  I created slots for four sidearms with a compartment for ammo, one for ear pro, one for eye pro and a few for misc stuff and mags.  Eventually I might get a spare set of foam for it; my first layout works okay but could be improved with another attempt.Pelican makes great cases too but one this size would cost twice as much- and not be much better, much less twice as good.  In this class I feel Seahorse makes cases that offer better value.I'm adding a few pictures of case as I have it set up.Apologies in advance for the crap in the background, I took this in my basement shop which is kind of cluttered with junk right now.
The colors overall are nice!  A tad bit subdued but appropriate to the picture.  The banner is well made and attractive.  I would buy it again, especially at the price.

This isn't a bad holster but it's not great for CCW.  It's pretty tight on an LCR, and as I guess you can see in the picture it doesn't really "shade" the grip very much.  When inserted into a jeans pocket it's pretty clear you're carrying.  I was hoping for a bit more breakup of the outline of the gun.  However, it's fine for a larger pocket like a coat or jacket.  I recommend for the latter application but if you plan to carry in your pants pocket you'll probably be disappointed.

This adapter works very well.  It does require a bit of fiddling to get it adjusted properly, but once adjusted you don't need to mess with it when you swap bottles.  Not much else to say.  Screw it to a 12oz paintball tank and put it in the Sodastream.  Works just like a stock bottle, although occasionally you have to tighten it.  For some reason it works itself loose from the machine early on.  Once you use it awhile it seems to quite doing it, not sure why.My local bike shop fills a 12oz container for $3.80 with tax.  Compare that to a $30 bottle plus tax.  It's a no brainer.  The taste is exactly the same.  Only very minor issue is that a SodaStream bottle is 13 or 14 oz, slightly bigger, so it lasts slightly longer.  Not a big deal considering the cost is ten times as high!

Overall this rack from Sanus is really amazing, especially for the price.  It's rock solid and very attractive, and the design is superb.  The center post is far enough back from the front that it's not visually intrusive but it adds strength to the rack.  There's plenty of space for a small to medium AV system; my Denon receiver fit's nicely on one shelf with my universal player and BRD on the other, leaving space for maybe four more components.  The feet can be adjusted individually to level the rack- a very nice touch.  The finish is a very attractive matte on the shelves with a durable powder coat on the tubing.  Lastly there are six clips you can add to the back with velcro ties to manage the cables.  Nice!The most remarkable thing about this rack is how easy it is to assemble!  Generally I loath putting furniture together.  Many times I have opted not to buy something simply because I don't want to got through the hassle of assembly.  Man, this rack was a nice surprise!  All the parts are very well made, something I don't see much nowadays.  Everything fits well and the parts are well finished.  Another nice surprise is that the instructions are clear, simple and accurate!  Once I had it unboxed I think it took only 15 minutes to assemble.The only thing I can ding about this deal is the seller (3 Kings).  They shipped the rack in just the manufacturer's box and it was trashed when it arrived.  An item this heavy simply can't be shipped without some kind of overbox to protect it.  One of the panels was dented and chipped and the bottom tube that holds the feet was also dented.  The box was so beat up that I even took pics of it in case I needed to make a claim.  Honestly I didn't want to mess with putting it back in (what was left of) the box to return it but it's a bummer to spend $200 and get a dinged up bit of kit.  Still, that doesn't detract from the superb design of the Sanus rack.Absolutely awesome rack, and highly recommended!

I've carried my little E01 for about a year and a half now and it's among my favorite small lights.  It's compact and light and very reliable; the twist switch is pretty robust and very simple.  There's not much to go wrong.  The light is waterproof, a necessity for an EDC light in my opinion.  Brightness is good but not mind blowing- it's a very small light.  The manufacturer claims 9 lumens for it.  While this isn't a powerhouse it's plenty for most tasks you might use it for like illumination a lock at night.  And it's actually bright enough to change a tire by.  It's always a trade off, output vs run time, and the E01 seems to nail it.  Lastly, the throw is good.  Enough spot to have decent range but lots of flood to light up close-up tasks.It won't tail stand (if you care about such things) but that's fine with me because it does something more important to me:  It attaches to a keyring via a lanyard hole.  This is really crucial for my EDC setup as it allows me to keep it with my keys and knife so it won't get lost.  Not much good if I can't find it when I need it.This is very nearly a five star light.  The only minor quibbles that detract from it:- The finish isn't very durable.  The color came off pretty fast when carried daily.  Not a big deal by any means.- Output could be better.  Again, it's a trade off- more lumens would mean less time.  But I wouldn't mind a slightly more potent light.  I wouldn't mind changing the batteries more often to get more output.Again, very minor issues.  So far I haven't found anything that's likely to oust my Fenix E01 from it's position on my EDC keyring.

Okay, not grammatically correct, but the CS Kudu might be the bestest cheapest knife out there.  I purchased mine here at Amazon for $6.09 shipped; at that price there is nothing, literally nothing, else that you could buy new that would be comparable to this one.  The edge is serviceable out of the box, the lockup is rock solid (supposedly will withstand 60 lbs of force) and the knife is very sturdy.  The Krup steel isn't high end but it's a good steel.  It's hardened to a point where it holds an edge adequately without being excessively brittle.The Kudu is a copy of a popular African knife called an Okapi.  The CS version is probably better than the original.  It's awkward to close but that's due to the close copy of the design and not really a flaw.  It's pretty ingenious actually.  It's a solid blend of maximum strength with minimum cost.Some reviews point out the flaws of this knife and mention things that could be improved.  While that's perhaps true it completely misses the point of this knife.  CS designed it to copy a traditional design while improving on it, but making it even cheaper.  In that sense it must be said to do exactly what it was intended to do.I think the Cold Steel Kudu would be a great knife to store in a survival kit, tackle box or glove compartment.  It's not a knife I'd want to use daily (awkward mechanics & ergos) but it would be great to have for emergencies or occasional use.  You can stash a few of them in places where you know they will be used infrequently without tying up a lot of cash.Even at full retail the Kudu is supposed to sell for $8 or so.  At six bucks there's no reasonable knife you could select instead.  An Opinel, a Mora, or even the CS's own superb Pendleton Lite Hunter will still cost $10-$15, nearly twice the cost of the Kudu.  This might be the best value in a sporting knife that I've ever seen.

The InForce APL is a superior product in almost every way; the best WML I have found for use on a sidearm.  It's very light, considerably lighter than the Surefire X300 Ultra.  It's also more compact.  This is especially nice since the dust cover & rail section on modern polymer handguns is very short compared to older designs like the 1911.  This means that the end of most WMLs extends out past the muzzle resulting in a lot of soot and carbon being deposited on the glass/plastic lens and bezel.The APL isn't as bright as the newest uber-lights from Surefire and Streamlight.  But after using it for awhile I realize that this is actually a positive, not a negative, at least if you anticipate deploying your sidearm inside.  The 500 lumen X300 Ultra (and likely the new HL steamlight) will blind you when reflecting off the walls and ceiling of your home, totally ruining your night adapted vision.  The APL is still plenty bright enough to blind any potential opponent but not so bright as to blind you as well.  And the ratio of hotspot to spill is actually a bit better than that of the Surefire.But the slam dunk for me is the switching system- it's here that the InForce leaves Surefire and Streamlight in the dust.  The ambi paddle switches of the APL is vastly superior to the odd toggle switches of the competition.  Tap it on either side and it activates; press and hold for momentary.  Unlike the competing lights it's easy to reach the switch without changing your grip on the sidearm.There's only one minor drawback to the paddle switch- the easy of activation also makes it easy to inadvertently turn on while being stored or carried.  Turning the bezel about 1/5 of a turn will lock out the switch; a good option for storage but not ideal for CCW.While my Surefire X300 Ultra is much brighter than the APL I find that the APL is superior in every other way.  In my opinion the APL is the best general purpose handgun WML on the market today.  Highly recommended!

These shears work great!  I bought some kevlar cloth for a project I was working on not thinking about the fact that the stuff is very hard to cut.  I ordered these shears just to cut the stuff and they work great!  The micro serrations really grip the fabric instead of pushing it out like regular scissors, and they'll even push cut kevlar cloth!  That really surprised me.  So far I've made several hundred cuts with no noticeable loss of sharpness.

I think this saw is for arborists but it's really amazing for camping.  I've taken down and sectioned 5" diameter standing dead oak trees in minutes with this saw.  It really does zip through wood, and is way better for most people than an axe.  It's hard to believe how fast this saw cuts until you actually use it.  Even my substantially smaller Pocketboy is efficient at cutting wrist size chunks of wood.This saw only cuts on the draw, and you do have to watch your technique to avoid kinking/bending it.  I'm not sure how long it will stay sharp; I've cut with mine on ten trips throughout the last year and it's still sharp.  Replacement blades are moderately expensive but so far I'm still using the first one.I can't recommend this saw highly enough.  It's a lot faster than the (admittedly smaller) Bahco Laplander.  To do work much faster you'd need a chainsaw.

I've been carrying this little Fenix E01 on my keychain as my EDC for almost a year now so I thought I'd post a short review.  It's been a great light.  On the plus side it's very small and light.  I can't stand having a bunch of crap in my pockets but I always need to have my smart phone, wallet, keys, knife and light on me.  The first three are what they are, no practical way to change the amount of room they require.  So with the knife and light I need to compromise a bit.  My knife is a Spyderco Ladybug in ZDP.  If I went with a little larger knife I'd have to go with a bit smaller knife and vice versa.  The E01 is a great blend of size and power.  It's not super bright but plenty for the intended uses (eg unlocking my vehicle and house locks, changing a tire, checking the oil).  If my eyes are night adapted then the little guy is bright enough for general outdoors use.  It casts a beam with enough flood to be broadly useful.
